ETF investors saw rosy visions postelection of dilapidated roadways getting repaired and insufficient waterways getting built out. A change in the political guard raised hopes for infrastructure spending and economic growth.So exchange traded funds investing in metals with industrial and commercial uses were red-hot in November, while gold sold off as the stock market rallied to new heights.However, one precious metal sizzled last month as its peers fizzled. ETFS Physical Palladium (PALL) swung 24% higher in November, setting a new 52-week high on the last day of the month.Why did it buck the trend?"Palladium moves more in line with industrial metals such as copper, steel and zinc," said Maxwell Gold, director of investment strategy at ETF Securities, which runs a suite of precious metal funds including PALL. "It's a metal that sees strong auto catalyst demand."In fact, 66% to 76% of palladium's demand stems from the automotive sector and another 21% to 25% from industrial and technological uses, while only 3% to 8% is tied to jewelry, according to ETF Securities.Its No. 1 use is in catalytic converters to reduce air pollution from gasoline-powered automobiles. Besides the U.S., a key market for car sales is China. There, in Gold's view, a growing population and more stringent environmental controls bode well for demand for both cars and catalytic converters.Palladium also is attractive from a supply-side perspective, he said.Named after the Greek goddess of wisdom Pallas Athena, palladium is one of the rarest metals on Earth and is 15 times more scarce than platinum. The vast majority of output comes from South Africa and Russia, and any unrest in either country can dent supplies.The palladium market has been in a huge supply deficit for the past five years, with another big one in the works for 2017, according to Gold. A drawdown in aboveground stocks, combined with expectations of a rebound in global economies, contributes to palladium's strong fundamentals, he added.PALL holds $189.6 million in assets and trades on average 32,500 shares a day. Its underlying liquidity is solid and trading spreads are tight, according to Gold.It vaulted 17.5% in the month ended Dec. 6 and is up 30.2% year to date.By comparison, SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), the bellwether commodity ETF, plunged 10.4% in the past month and is now only up 9.8% in 2016 so far.And iShares Silver Trust (SLV) gave up 9.2% and rose 20.2% over those respective time periods.The palladium ETF is modestly more costly than those gold and silver peers, at a 0.60% expense ratio. However, investors get easy and reasonably priced exposure to this extremely scarce metal.The fund is physically backed with palladium bars held in a secure London vault.Investing in commodities can help to diversify investment portfolios and reduce equity risk. While palladium offers tactical opportunity, an alternative such as ETFS Physical PM Basket (GLTR) offers stronger diversification benefits.GLTR invests in gold, silver, platinum and palladium. Its core holding is gold, but the other precious metal holdings offer further potential upside when gold lags, Gold said.This diversified fund stumbled 8.4% in the past month but is still up 13.5% year to date.In terms of flow of money, GLTR has seen $83.2 million in net inflow in 2016 through Nov. 30. Its palladium sibling ETF saw $40.2 million in net outflow over the same period.One risk tied to palladium is significantly higher volatility than other precious metals, Gold said. He also thinks PALL could be challenged if the run-up in industrial metals proves to be a speculative rally.It may, in that case, see a short-term correction despite its constructive fundamentals, he added.PALL was falling on the stock market today in early trade and sits 5% below its recent high.RELATED:Why Some Strategists Still Like Gold Despite Its Recent Weakness

The major indexes are back in rally mode even after heady gains in recent weeks. As of 2:45 PM New York time on Tuesday, the Nasdaq composite, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrials all rallied with gains of 0.1% to 0.4%.Meanwhile, Dow 30 components Verizon Communications (VZ) and Apple (AAPL) helped lead the market's upside with gains of 1.4% and 0.6%, respectively. Also up within the Dow: financial plays Goldman Sachs (GS) (up the biggest amount points wise among the 30, rising 2.59 or 1.1%) and American Express (AXP) (up 0.4%).Small cap names lagged a little bit, with the Russell 2000 up 0.3%.The NYSE Composite led the way with a 0.5% boost higher. Diversified operations, auto retailing, staffing, air conditioning and heating, movide and airline stocks paced the upside, all up 1.8% or more. The market also saw strength in fabless semiconductor, homebuilding, auto parts and life insurance plays.Apple, gaining some steam following news that CEO Tim Cook defended the strength of Apple Watch sales during the holiday shopping season, is still a laggard among most large- and mega-cap names. With a weak 51 RS Rating and a poor Accumulation/Distribution Rating of D+, the former huge winner from 2004 to 2015 needs to prove it has the institutional support to finish a new base and stage a new breakout.The current action is encouraging in the sense that Apple has held above its 200-day moving average, but it's still below its 50-day moving average.One key IBD rule is to avoid stocks that "live" below the 10-week moving average (see a weekly chart) for nine weeks or more. Such behavior indicates flagging demand among mutual funds, hedge funds, pensions, insurers, banks and large investment advisors.Verizon, a big winner in the first half of 2016, is up 1.4% to 50.47. The stock recently rebounded back above its 50-day moving average. Watch to see if it can climb back above its 200-day line, which flattened out last month. Q4 profit is expected to be flat at 89 cents a share.Verizon's integrated telecom services group is now a laggard, ranked in the bottom half of IBD's daily ranking of 197 industry groups. Group peer AT&T (T) is also in base-building mode, up nearly 2% to 39.36 and just shy of possibly retaking its own 200-day moving average. The broadband and telecom giant had rallied 25% after breaking out past a 35.09 saucer with handle buy point before beginning its current correction.Elsewhere in the stock market today, large-cap and mega-cap names showing more strength include Broadcom (AVGO), part of IBD Leaderboard; Lockheed Martin (LMT), a defense play and hovering near a 267.03 cup entry; and JPMorgan Chase (JPM), which has moved past a tight, narrow consolidation at 80.54 and gave advanced traders an aggressive entry point to add a small amount of shares to a winning position.JPMorgan, covered frequently in the Stock Market Today column in the summer to early fall, has rallied sharply since clearing a 65.08 narrow cup with handle entry within a long bottoming base pattern.In economic news, unit labor costs for the third quarter jumped a revised 0.7%, up from a 0.3% gain. The new data points to added evidence of wage inflation, which may further cement a decision by the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates during a Dec. 13-14 meeting.RELATED:Why Apple May Be Creating A New BaseWhen Did Apple Initially Break Out?The Case For A Trump Era New Secular Bull RunApple iPhone Business Outlook Set To Improve Next Year, But China Still A Worry

The indexes rallied in the stock market today following Sunday's constitutional referendum in Italy. Voters rejected Prime Minster Matteo Renzi's proposals, and the PM announced he was stepping down following the defeat.The Nasdaq jumped 1%, the S&P 500 moved up 0.7%, and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.5%. The blue chip index reached a record high today.Along with financials, Nike (NKE) and McDonald's (MCD) led the way on the Dow Jones industrial average after upgrades propelled the stocks higher. Analysts at HSBC raised Nike from hold to buy. Meanwhile, Nomura raised McDonald's from neutral to buy. Shares were up 3.4% and 0.9%, respectively.Among leading growth stocks, regional banks were the best performers of the day. Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK) and SVB Financial (SIVB) were up 3% and 2%.HSBC Holdings (HSBC), the investment bank, initiated research coverage on two financial heavyweights: Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS). Goldman was initiated with a buy rating with a 250 per share price target, while Morgan Stanley started with a hold rating. Goldman shares rose 2%, while Morgan Stanley tacked on 1.5% in early trading. Financials have enjoyed a solid run since the U.S. election as rising interest rates and potential deregulation generated substantial fund managers' interest. Goldman shares are up 28% since early November.Arista Networks (ANET) was cut to equal-weight from overweight by Morgan Stanley. The cloud networking provider edged up 0.1% and is up about 5% from its 87.72 flat base entry. The company has two quarters of accelerating quarterly earnings growth and a 98 EPS Rating.Goldman Sachs downgraded Marvell Technology (MRVL) to sell from neutral. Goldman believes the company's growth catalysts are already priced-in to the stock price. Their price target has been trimmed to 12 from 14 per share. The stock has now retraced the bulk of its upside reaction from last month's quarterly earnings release. Shares briefly turned positive after being down as much as 3%.Oil prices reached a new 52-week high today and were up 0.7% extending the winning streak to four days. The U.S. dollar traded lower after initially surging following Italy's referendum results.The Markit Purchasing Managers' Index came in at 54.6, just shy of the prior 54.8 reading.The Institute for Supply Management reported its November services purchasing managers index at 57.2, topping expectations for 55.5 and also exceeding every estimate in the range.RELATED:Goldman Sachs A Buy, Miners Upgraded, Quantenna A Top PickRenzo Quits As Italy Referendum Defeat Deepens Europe's Turmoil

Wasn't one vapid pretty boy named Justin from Canada enough?At least Justin Bieber is eye candy without the heartburn. Justin Trudeau, on the other hand, is the twinkly-eyed boy toy who makes informed adults wanna hurl.For more than a year, the liberal Canadian prime minister enjoyed drool-stained global press coverage as the "hot hipster" and "dreamy sex symbol" with great hair and a tribal Haida tattoo. He basked in Ryan Gosling-esque memes about his commitment to feminism and touched off "Trudeau-mania" with a series of shirtless selfies and photobombs.But this weekend, the sane world saw the baby-faced Commie apologist for the naked twit he truly is.Mourning the death of repressive dictator Fidel Castro, Trudeau hailed his longtime family friend as a "larger than life leader" who "served his people for almost half a century." Actually, El Comandante ruled with an iron fist and firing squads — serving himself to all of the island's land, private businesses and media, along with his own private yacht, private island, 20 homes, fleet of Mercedes limos and bevy of mistresses.Trudeau's ridiculous mash note to the "legendary revolutionary and orator" caused the social media backlash of the year. The hashtag #TrudeauEulogies erupted to mock Trudeau's soft-soaping of tyranny."As we mourn Emperor Caligula, let us always remember his steadfast devotion to Senate reform," one Twitter user jibed in Trudeau-speak."Although flawed Hitler was a vegetarian who loved animals, was a contributor to the arts & proud advocate for Germany," another joked."Kim Jong Il will always be remembered fondly for his leadership and contributions on climate change," another chimed in.Stung, the Canadian tundra hunk's office announced Monday that he will not attend services for his beloved Uncle Fidel, who had served as a pallbearer at his former Canadian PM father's funeral. But if Trudeau thinks the damage to his celebrity brand is temporary, he has another think coming.Our neighbors to the north are now discovering what disillusioned Barack Obama worshipers realized too late: Beneath the shiny packaging of supermodel progressivism lies the same old decrepit culture of corruption.Political watchdogs have been buzzing about Trudeau's shady fundraising ties to Chinese communist moguls. Like Obama, Trudeau promised unprecedented transparency in government — "sunny ways" that would shed open light on how the Liberal Party was conducting the people's business. Dudley Do-Right's party declared there would be "no preferential access, or appearance of preferential access" in exchange for campaign cash and purported to ban favor-seekers with direct business before the government from attending political fundraisers.Behind closed doors, however, Trudeau was selling out to wealthy Chinese-Canadians and Chinese nationals seeking government green lights for their business deals. According to his conservative critics, Trudeau and the Liberal Party have held 80 such cash-for-access fundraisers crawling with lobbyists and access traders over the past year.The Globe and Mail newspaper revealed last week that Trudeau and his Liberal Party fundraisers had secretly organized one tony $1,500-per-head private residential gala in May attended by Chinese billionaires and bankers gunning for federal approval of projects. Echoing the operations of the Clinton Foundation pay-for-play money machine, the nonprofit Trudeau Foundation and the University of Montreal raked in $1 million from a wealthy Chinese businessman a few weeks after the fundraiser. The donation includes funding for a statue of Pierre Trudeau, who once wrote a book hailing Chairman Mao.The self-aggrandizing Commie fanboy apple doesn't fall far from his cultural Marxist tree.

Stocks were mixed Tuesday morning after upbeat economic data and a rally in oil prices.The Nasdaq gained 0.6%, while the S&P 500 added 0.3%. The Dow Jones industrial average dipped 0.2% as Financials and Home Depot's (HD) earnings weighed on the blue chip index. The market-leading Russell 2000 fell 0.4%. The small-cap index has been on a seven-day winning streak.Volume was tracking modestly lower in the stock market today on both the NYSE and Nasdaq.Home Depot reported its fiscal third quarter earnings this morning of $1.60 per share, surpassing the consensus estimate of $1.58. On the revenue side, Home Depot recorded $23.15 billion. Same-store sales rose 5.5%, which also beat Wall Street's 4.4% estimate. The stock was down 2% after trading higher in the premarket following the earnings beat.Home Depot has been in a downtrend since early August and may be in the process of building the right side of a base. The stock has a great earnings track record and an EPS Rating of 94. However, the RS Rating is a weak 36. Ideally, the RS Rating will improve over the next few weeks if the company's earnings report can prove to be a positive catalyst for the stock.NetEase (NTES) jumped 4% after management authorized up to 1$ billion repurchase of its American depositary receipts. The 13th ranked IBD 50 member dived below its 50 day moving average line last week after reporting Q3 earnings; the first time it has been below this support level since breaking out of its cup with handle base in June 2016.Financials took a breather on Tuesday. Goldman Sachs (GS) fell 1.5% and JPMorgan (JPM) declined 2%. The money center banks industry group has been up almost 10% over the past six straight days as investors place their bets on higher interest rates.Large-cap technology rallied early this morning after several rough days. Facebook (FB), Google (GOOGL) and Amazon (AMZN) all gained at least 2.5%.There was positive economic data out Tuesday morning before the market open. October Retail Sales were 0.8% versus an expected 0.6%. The Empire State Manufacturing Survey came in at 1.5 ahead of the -2.5 estimate. Lastly, US import prices rose 0.5% in October vs. 0.4% estimate, and export prices were up 0.2% vs. 0.1% estimate.The Boston Federal Reserve Bank President Eric Rosengren seemed to reinforce the notion that rising interest rates are imminent in December. "Absent significant negative economic news over the next month, the market's assessment of the likelihood of tightening in December seems plausible," Rosengren said. According to the CME Group's FedWatch Tool, there is an 85% change of a quarter-point rate hike next month. The forecaster uses 30-Day Fed Fund futures prices to forecast the likelihood of changes in U.S. monetary policy.Other Fed Speakers due up today are Robert Kaplan of the Dallas Federal Reserve and Fed Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer at 1:30 pm ET.Oil surged 4% to $45 a barrel on expectations that an OPEC meeting later this month will result in a production cut. Oil prices have bounced off the 200-day moving average in recent sessions after declining as low as $42.20 on Monday.

Investors are dumping Coca-Cola (KO), ConAgra Brands (CAG), Procter & Gamble (PG) and other defensive stocks Thursday, shifting funds toward infrastructure and banking sectors.The Dow Jones Industrial Average opened at a record high Thursday after rallying strongly Wednesday following the presidential election. But food and consumer product makers were down.Coke shares fell 3.15% to close at 40.94 in the stock market today. On Wednesday, Coca-Cola fell 1.4% to just below its 50-day line. PepsiCo (PEP) lost 3.7% to 103.25, falling below its 50-day moving average and dropping below its 200-day for the first time in nine months.Shares of ConAgra, the packaged-foods maker, tumbled 7.9% to 34.30, continuing their fall below a buy point of 37.08. The stock crashed through its 50- and 200-day lines.The company completed the spinoff of  its Lamb Weston commercial-foods business Thursday."The decision to separate into two pure-play companies reflects our ongoing commitment to implementing bold changes in order to deliver sustainable growth and enhanced shareholder value," said CEO Sean Connolly in a press release.The company's name change to ConAgra Brands from ConAgra Foods was also effective Thursday.Shampoo and toothpaste maker Procter and Gamble shares dropped 3.9% to 82.60, falling below its 200-day line for the first time since January. Procter & Gamble lost 1.75% Wednesday.Shares of cigarette producer Altria Group (MO) finished down 3.6% to 61.72, tumbling below their 50-day and 200-day lines. On Tuesday voters in California passed a measure that raised taxes on tobacco products. Altria sells Phillip Morris products in the U.S. Phillip Morris International (PM) lost 4.1% to the lowest since Feb. 17, after falling 3.6% on Wednesday.IBD'S TAKE: A Trump presidency raises the odds for less regulation, higher inflation and a Federal Reserve rate hike next year, so investors are rotating assets to JPM Morgan, Bank of America and other big banks. RELATED: Caterpillar Stock Soars On Trump Win On Hope For Coal; GE, Boeing UpApple, FANG Stocks Aren't Joining Trump Rally

Total dividends in the S&P 500 reached a near record in the second quarter, although the pace of dividend growth continues to slow.Aggregate dividends in the S&P 500 totaled $105.8 billion in Q2, a figure that was topped only by the total of this year's first quarter. The second quarter also was the 10th straight quarter that the trailing 12-month composite per-share dividend for the S&P 500 hit a new high, according to a study by FactSet.Breaking it down by sector, information technology and consumer staples led in rewarding shareholders. The IT sector ended Q2 with dividend payments of $16.4 billion and $64.7 billion on a trailing 12-month basis. In consumer staples, $14.3 billion was paid out in dividends and $56 billion in the trailing 12 months.Procter & Gamble (PG), Philip Morris (PM) and Wal-Mart (WMT) -- companies with a reputation for dependable dividends -- were the top payers in the sector. Philip Morris is in IBD's Dividend Leaders screen, as the stock forms a new base with a 104.30 buy point. Its annualized dividend yield exceeds 4%.But while dividends continue to expand, FactSet also found they increased 6.1% in Q2. That's well below the 10.8% average of the past three years. Also, Q2 dividend growth was at a single-digit pace for the third consecutive quarter.Future gains are likely to slow further. Analysts expect the S&P's dividends to rise only 4.7% over the next 12 months. (Three months ago, the estimate was for a 4.9% increase.)"This slowing growth has been an ongoing trend in the S&P 500 for over a year," the FactSet report said, but it didn't elaborate on the reasons.The trailing 12-month dividend yield of the S&P 500 was 2.07% at the end of Q2, and that also showed a decline, from 2.5% a year ago.There's a softening trend also in yield-rich stocks. FactSet notes that in the first six months of 2016, the ProShares S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrats ETF (NOBL) had risen more than 10%. The S&P 500 utilities and telecom sectors were each up more than 21%. Over the same time period, the S&P 500 index climbed less than 3%. But since the end of June, the Dividend Aristocrats ETF has lagged the S&P 500 by about 3 percentage points. The utilities and telecom sectors have underperformed the S&P by even larger margins.Apple (AAPL), Microsoft (MSFT) and General Electric (GE) came out on top when combining dividend payments and share buybacks over the trailing 12 months. Apple dividends totaled $3.19 billion. Combined with $10.9 billion in buybacks, Apple's contribution to shareholders was more than $14 billion, FactSet says.Microsoft's combined dividend and buyback spending was $6.4 billion and GE's $9.8 billionRELATED:Don't Give Up On These Utility Leaders Just YetHow Apple, Amazon, Alibaba Could Disrupt Google's Mobile Ad Business

Smart investors are dusting off their ETF investing playbooks. While the November election may or may not prove to be an inflection point for stocks, it is sure to mark a turn of the page, revealing new investing scenarios.Still, as the Nov. 8 vote approaches, many investors in exchange traded funds are uncertain of exactly what to expect. Volatility in the near term surely, but then what?"It appears the least unsettling outcome for stocks would be a Clinton win, with both houses of Congress remaining in Republican control," Liz Ann Sonders, the chief investment strategist at Charles Schwab, said recently.Indeed, which party controls Congress may matter more for U.S. stocks than whether Hillary Clinton or Donald Trump wins. And the stock market's direction over the longer term will be far more influenced by the global economy and the Federal Reserve's actions than by any individual player.It's something to keep in mind as you hunt for ideas on how to make money investing in stocks within a shifting landscape.Click Here For A List Of The Best-Performing ETFs Of 2016With low-cost and broad-based ETFs in your toolbox, you can prepare your portfolio for any election result or stock market outcome, whether good or bad.So say strategists at top firms that help investors profit with ETFs and manage portfolio risk. Maxwell Gold of ETF Securities makes a case for investing in gold in an election year where both presidential candidates have taken populist stances.Simeon Hyman of ProShares sees tactical opportunity in specific sectors including infrastructure, with both Clinton and Trump talking up federal expenditure. And Sylvia Jablonski of Direxion discusses how some investors are using inverse and leveraged trades to make bullish or bearish bets on industry groups that are in the political spotlight.Here they are in their own words:Maxwell Gold is director of investment strategy at ETF Securities in New York City. The firm has roughly $22 billion in global assets and its innovations include developing the world's first gold ETF (in Australia) in 2003, and ETFS Physical PM Basket (GLTR), the first physically backed precious metals basket ETF in the U.S., in 2010.Against a backdrop of uncertainty this year, many investors have sought defensive and safe-haven assets like precious metals. With the U.S. presidential race heating up, investors are trying to gauge the election's potential outcome and its impact on precious metals, in particular gold.Looking at historical election results is not a perfect measure, but it may yield some helpful insights. On average, gold's performance was 5.9% in the 12 months following a U.S. presidential vote since 1972.Gold's return was more than double when Democratic candidates have won (over 8% on average) vs. their Republican counterparts (4% on average).Additionally, gold has historically seen higher performance when there is an administration change in the White House. When the incumbent party remained in office, gold rose approximately 2.0% in the subsequent 12 months.Following a change in political administration, however, gold has risen over 10% on average. Therefore, investors looking to hedge against equity volatility and political uncertainty may benefit from including gold as part of their portfolio allocations.Rising uncertainty has been a consistent theme this year, both globally and in the U.S., partly driven by increased populist sentiment. Regardless of the success of populism at elections, populist momentum can be a powerful catalyst for reform among incumbent parties.In this year's U.S. election, both presidential candidates agree on the need to increase fiscal spending on America's deteriorating infrastructure, while low interest rates combined with cheap commodity prices have reduced expected project costs. Populism and pricing together bode well for increased infrastructure spending, which could boost U.S. manufacturing, industrials, transportation and energy sectors, as well as U.S. commodity demand.While infrastructure investment creates economic growth, social initiatives are likely to lead to an increase in consumer spending with the end result being a likely rise in inflation.Rising inflation in the U.S. from these populism-driven factors, along with supply-side destruction in commodities, could potentially add further to inflationary pressures.Additionally, populist policies in the U.S. -- which are likely to include tax cuts, prompting a widening of the budget deficit — could weaken the U.S. dollar in the coming years. Investors can help protect investment portfolios by gaining exposure to assets that perform well in an inflationary environment, including precious metals.For gold investment, physically backed ETFs, like ETFS Physical Swiss Gold Shares (SGOL), are favored over gold mining equity ETFs.Unlike gold, gold miners historically have served as ineffective hedges against large equity market drawdowns over the past three decades.During these market periods, the gold price has posted an average return of 7% during market drawdowns of more than 10% in the S&P 500 since 1987. The gold mining equity index, on average, has posted a total return of -7%, offering limited downside protection against an average 21% drop in U.S. equities.Moreover, during these large drawdowns, gold has posted positive returns nearly 80% of the time vs. only 30% for gold miners.Not all precious metals behave the same, however, and there may be benefits to holding a diversified precious metals basket ETF, like ETFS Physical Precious Metals Basket Trust (GLTR), as opposed to just one metal.Exposure to a precious metals basket may offer diversification benefits across a full economic cycle. Silver, for example, is much more sensitive to the global industrial production cycle than gold, with half of its annual demand stemming from industrial applications.Both platinum and palladium demand, on the other hand, emanates from global auto and jewelry sales, both cyclical factors tied to the global consumer. Each precious metal has diverse fundamentals that occur at different stages of a full cycle, while still providing a low correlation to equities and other financial assets.While investors vary by risk tolerance and investment objectives, the optimal portfolio allocation to precious metals is never zero.Precious metals are a core risk management tool. They provide a hedge against market turmoil and volatility, help preserve purchasing power over long periods of time, and offer a unique source of diversification that can help improve portfolio efficiency.Simeon Hyman is head of investment strategy of ProShares in Bethesda, Md. The $31 billion firm offers one of the largest suites of alternative ETFs in the U.S., including geared (leveraged and inverse) exchange traded products. Launched in 2006, ProShares ETFs help investors go beyond the limitations of conventional investing strategies by reducing volatility, managing risk and enhancing returns. Election season tends to create anxiety for many investors. Financial market forecasts are difficult enough without this additional wild card. Investors looking to position their portfolios may feel forced to come up with a scenario that includes a forecast on the election. That's a daunting challenge.For ETF investors looking at the stock market, a focus on investing strategies that have exhibited effective downside mitigation might make sense.ProShares S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrats (NOBL) is one such ETF strategy. Stocks that have a long track record of dividend growth have outperformed historically through a wide variety of economic cycles, according to research conducted by Ned Davis Research, and a chunk of that outperformance has come from downside mitigation.The long-term outperformance and downside mitigation of dividend growers could be just the sort of strategy that might serve buy-and-hold investors across a range of market environments. ProShares offers an entire suite of dividend growth ETFs across the equity spectrum, both domestic and international.About the only thing Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump agree on in this election is the need for the federal government to spend more on infrastructure.This year has seen an uptick in the performance of infrastructure stocks, and for those who see a bipartisan commitment to infrastructure spending as a sign this momentum will continue, we offer the only "pure play" infrastructure ETF.ProShares DJ Brookfield Global Infrastructure (TOLZ) follows a strategy that focuses exclusively on companies that own and operate infrastructure across the transportation, communications, energy and water sectors. With a requirement that every stock in TOLZ derive more than 70% of cash flows from infrastructure lines of business, TOLZ may be an effective way to position for this long-awaited policy shift.What about bonds? There is indeed some evidence that the Fed has historically been reluctant to raise rates right before an election. But does this mean that bonds are safe for now? Far from it.The Fed only controls the federal funds rate, not the rest of the yield curve. Historically, the yield on 10-Year Treasuries tends to run about 2.5% above inflation. So even if inflation is running at 1.5%, rather than the Fed's target of 2%, a "normal" 10-year yield should be around 4%.That could happen without any change in the fed funds rate and, if it did, bond prices would take a big hit.We offer two exchange traded funds that combine portfolios of bonds with built-in hedges against the effects of rising rates. Both ProShares Investment Grade — Interest Rate Hedged (IGHG) and ProShares High Yield — Interest Rate Hedged (HYHG) target a duration of zero and have almost no sensitivity to interest rates.While the current U.S. election cycle is unlike anything we have ever seen, investors should keep in mind that resources and strategies are available to help them better manage their portfolios, regardless of the election outcome.[Editor's note: The small asset size and trading volume of IGHG, HYHG and TOLZ may merit a closer look.]Sylvia Jablonski is managing director of capital markets and institutional ETF strategist at Direxion in New York City. The $11 billion firm provides nontraditional investments to accommodate various market cycles, including ETFs that position portfolios opportunistically, deliver broader diversification, dampen volatility and generate income or excess returns.The stock market is forward-looking and hates uncertainty. With the presidential race still too close to call, traders are preparing to protect against the unknown.If you're a buy-and-hold investor, there's probably little to concern yourself with. But no matter which party ends up in the White House in November, tactical managers will look for a way to find opportunity over the next few months.Looking beyond the U.S. election cycle, we anticipate a trader's environment in the short and medium term. The landscape may change, but we see a few areas that are attracting interest and volume.Both Clinton and Trump have made it known they want to keep drug prices low, which will likely boost some managed health care companies but may have a negative effect on pharmaceutical and biotech companies.The biotech space has become popular for traders. We've seen an uptick in trading for both the Direxion Daily S&P Biotech Bull 3x (LABU) and Biotech Bear 3x (LABD). For those interested in an inverse trade without a multiplier, we have the Direxion Daily S&P Biotech Bear 1x Shares (LABS).The energy and financial sectors also are in the cross hairs of political discourse. Depending on their outlook for these sectors, investors may benefit from opportunistic trades in the Daily Financial Bull 3x Shares (FAS), Daily Financial Bear 3x Shares (FAZ), Daily Energy Bull 3x Shares (ERX) and the Daily Energy Bear 3x Shares (ERY).Leveraged ETFs aren't for all types of investors. In leveraged ETF trading, the impact of seeking daily objectives has to be understood. Having said that, our leveraged ETFs are tools for hands-on traders looking to take advantage of short-term trends in both up and down markets. In many cases, we have bull and bear funds for both sides of the trade, so they allow you to stay agile.The real power is in the idea and expertise of the trader. The opportunity is only won if you get the direction right.Using leveraged ETFs (with "2x" or "3x" in their names) may allow a manager to gain equity asset class exposure, while letting half or a third of the capital do the work. This allows the balance of capital to be redeployed for other investment and risk-management purposes, such as exposure to yield-enhancing fixed income asset classes.Inverse or "bear" ETFs may be used to hedge the market. As their name reveals, inverse ETFs go up when the market goes down, and they go down when the market goes up. These funds will lose value so long as the market keeps going up, but the potential rewards can be attractive. Used appropriately, even a small allocation of your capital could help make up for any losses you sustain in a market crash.No matter which party ends up in the White House in November, these funds and others like them hopefully will allow managers to find opportunity in the uncertainty.RELATED:Which Of The Best ETF Investment Strategies Is Right For Your Portfolio?

Year to date, gold mining stocks still look shiny. But in recent weeks, they're showing a bit of tarnish.IBD's Mining-Gold/Silver/Gems industry group sat atop the table of 197 industry groups for months. But it's fallen off that vaunted perch and slipped to 26th in terms of six-month relative price performance, as of Monday's market close.The group slid 1.6% on Tuesday for its fourth-straight drop, even as the Nasdaq composite rose 0.9%; the S&P 500 still punched up 0.6% despite the broad decline in commodity-related equities.While there may be plenty of explanations for why gold stocks took a back seat in Tuesday's growth-stock rally, two reasons are indisputable.One, gold prices have cooled off. Mining companies' fortunes depend heavily on the day-to-day price of the commodities they sell.London PM Fixing gold prices have shot up 30% from a December 2015 low near $1,049 an ounce to as high as $1,366 on July 6. Since that peak, prices have gone sideways for more than two months, losing no more than 4%. However, both the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq composite have gone on to notch all-time highs.Why have gold prices slumped lately? While the forces of supply and demand are ultimately the reason, some market observers are quick to note factors such as the increased prospect of higher interest rates in the U.S., which would reflect increased confidence in the economy. Higher interest rates would also likely boost the U.S. dollar and hence make gold more expensive to buy.Here's another viable reason: Gold bugs simply need a break.Consider Newmont Mining (NEM), one of the industry's giants ($20 billion market cap, $7.7 billion in sales last year). The big cap rumbled out of a 10-month bottoming-style cup-with-handle base in the week ended April 8. That week, the Greenwood Village, Colo., firm not only rallied 9%, but it also jumped past a 28.49 buy point (10 cents above the handle's intraday high of 28.39). Even with commodity plays, the cup with handle can serve as a useful timing tool to generate profits in equities quickly.Indeed, the gains came quickly.Newmont surged for four weeks in a row, then went sideways for four weeks while touching its 10-week moving average. That action offered a follow-on entry point near 25.29. By August, Newmont cruised to a 52-week high of 46.09, up 62% from the original 28.49 pivot.Few stocks in IBD's entire database can match that kind of advance so far in 2016. So, today's action in Newmont is perfectly normal. An 18% slide over three weeks is perfectly normal as the stock works on a new cuplike base.A good cup with handle can feature a decline of as much as 33%. Any more than that, though, and the risk of a failed breakout goes up fast.Spy the charts of Yamana Gold (AUY), AngloGold Ashanti (AU) and Randgold Resources (GOLD), all of which fall within the small-to-midcap range, and you see larger corrections in the works. The three have fallen 33%, 35% and 26% from their 52-week highs, respectively. Meanwhile, the S&P SmallCap 600 is less than 2% below its 765.55 peak.Remember that when the economy is buzzing, gold loses its luster as a hedge. While the shares of high-growth companies reflect the opportunity to receive dividends or strong increases in earnings per share, gold bullion lacks these qualities. On Tuesday, the Conference Board's Consumer Confidence Index rose sharply in September to 104.1, crushing the Econoday consensus forecast of 98.8 and well above the 101.1 August reading.RELATED:What Does A Great Cup-With-Handle Base Look Like?Some Cup Bases Are Flawed: How Can You Spot Them?

Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Apple (AAPL) led all S&P 500 companies in stock dividends paid in the second quarter, says a new report from FactSet Research.Exxon Mobil paid $3.13 billion in dividends in Q2, barely edging Apple at $3.12 billion. But Apple dominated the field in dividends and share buybacks in Q2 combined, totaling $14 billion, followed by General Electric (GE), then Microsoft (MSFT), says FactSet.FactSet said aggregate quarterly dividends for the S&P 500 amounted to $105.8 billion in Q2, an increase of 0.8% from Q2 2015. It was the second-largest dividend total in at least 10 years, following Q1 2016. Firms in the S&P 500 also spent $125.1 billion on share buybacks during Q2, the smallest quarterly total since Q3 2013.IBD'S TAKE: A dividend is a payment made by a company to its shareholders, usually as a distribution of profit, in order to return wealth. Dividends put cash in shareholders' hands, while stock buybacks are also a popular way to return capital to shareholders, tending to boost a stock and per-share earnings. Current and annual earnings are keys to IBD's CAN SLIM.At the sector level, companies in information technology led all 10 S&P industry groups in terms of aggregate dividends paid during Q2, at $16.4 billion. Over the trailing 12-month period, the IT sector paid out dividends totaling $64.7 billion, led by Apple, Microsoft and IBM (IBM). The consumer staples sector was second, with $56 billion in dividend distribution over the 12-month period, led by Procter & Gamble (PG), Philip Morris International (PM) and Wal-Mart Stores (WMT).The total dividend payout for the 12 months ending in Q2 amounted to $427.5 billion, up 7.1% year over year and the largest total in at least 10 years. It also marked the 10th consecutive quarter that the trailing 12-month dividend payout for the S&P 500 index hit a new high.Apple stock rose nearly 1% in the stock market today, to 114.62. Exxon Mobil stock rose a fraction, to 83.54.

Traders are the best salespeople in the world.  Why is this?  A trader, once in a position, can deceive himself or herself into believing half-truths faster than a house cat pouncing on a freshly escaped hamster.When faced with a loss, Joe Trader will look at a chart and tell whomever is within spitting distance, "The market is acting as if a reversal is about to happen."  Net result: He does not exit the position.When faced with a profit, Joanne Trader hesitates to pull the trigger, telling her goldfish, "The market is acting great.  It would be premature to sell at these levels."  Net result: She does not exit the trade.The mistake these traders are making is a common, yet fatal, affliction found in most beginning traders.  The net result is a trader who "eats like a sparrow, and defecates like an elephant." This is a situation that no account can withstand.  Worse, this cycle of emotional slavery will never end until it's met head on.  By stepping back and examining this process in more detail, the trader can learn to use their own emotional reactions as indicators.  Properly tuned, these emotional indicators, instead of leading to mistakes, can create great triggers to enter and exit a market.The problem is simple.  Many traders feel they can rely on their judgment while in a trade.  On paper, this makes a lot of sense.  After all, before a trade is placed, a trader is at his most objective.  However, once the trade is on, the degree of objectivity diminishes immediately and in direct proportion to the number of shares or contracts being traded relative to the account size.This perpetuates a vicious cycle. Instead of following a game plan about when to exit a position, the trader in this situation will close a position for one of two reasons.  First, the pain of holding becomes so great he cannot "take it" any longer.  Once he reaches this "uncle" point, he starts frantically banging his keyboard to sell (or cover) "at the market" in order to relieve the pain.  Second, a broker exits the position for the trader.  Not because he is a nice guy, but because the account has run out of margin.  This trade is also placed "at the market."This act of capitulation - traders exiting a position because they have to, not because they want to - is emotions-based trading at its finest. And these acts are responsible for the major moves in all markets, on all time frames, whether it is a sustained multi-month move to the downside due to continuous capitulation selling, or a quick 10-minute rally due to shorts being forced to cover. In the end, markets don't move because they want to.  They move because they have to.This imbalance of market orders causes rip-like movements that result in even worse fills.  Disgusted with themselves and red in the face, the victims of these trades stalk off to contemplate the insanity of the universe.  Meanwhile, another group of traders took the opposite side of this "capitulation trade" and made great profits.  How does a trader get on the winning side of these trades?  The key is for the trader to use his or her own emotions as triggers to take advantage of these "get me the hell out of this position" panic runs.  To fully understand how to do this, we must first step back and understand why traders continually and instinctively sabotage themselves in the first place.The problem is that the tactics an individual uses to achieve his or her goals in everyday life do not work in trading, and, in fact, are one of the main reasons for failure.  While "good judgment" is critical to an individual who wants to climb the corporate ladder or start a business, we have already seen why it doesn't work in the middle of a trade.  In addition, stubbornness and determination are prerequisites for success in many aspects of life, yet in trading these qualities will get you killed.In addition, traders who "play the markets" with a mental framework oriented towards how external society rewards and punishes "good" and "bad" behavior are set up to lose from day one.  For example, "cutting losses short" is difficult when there is the possibility of the market coming back to the breakeven point.  At breakeven, the trader is not a "loser."  Thus, according to the benchmarks of society, if the trader can exit a position with a gain, they are "successful". This leads to the removal of stops "once in a while" in the hopes of getting out at breakeven . . . in order to be a winner in the eyes of society (sigh).  This can work ten times in a row, but it is the one time it doesn't work that knocks a trader flat on his backSo now we have a basic understanding of why and how traders get themselves into trouble.  Let's shift our focus and see how to take advantage of these unfortunate souls.  (It sounds cruel when stated that way, but it's the truth.  Any money that a trader loses is sitting comfortably ensconced in the account of a better trader).1. Four Seasons: When I am in a trade that is going my way, and I start to feel overly excited and feel the urge to add to my position, I instead use this as my trigger to set up a "double stop order."  As an example, let's say I'm long 10 E-mini S&P contracts.  The market is screaming higher.  I find myself thinking of how many nights I could live at the Four Seasons on Maui with the day's profits.  I take the "Four Seasons Trigger" and place a trailing 2 point stop for 20 contracts; double the size of my current position. I will stay in the trade as long as it is moving higher, but once the market turns, not only am I out of my position for a nice profit, I simultaneously get short 10 contracts.  This process takes advantage of the market dynamics of human emotion in a very clean fashion.  The sell-off that occurs will be from other traders who succumbed to their emotions to buy at the top, due to fear of missing a move or the euphoria of having a current winning position.  Once the market does reverse, it will be these traders that provide the fuel for the move down, as they start dumping their positions once they can't take the pain of losing any longer.2. Thank You Sir May I Have Another: When in a trade, I visualize what a newer trader would be doing – or what I would have been doing years ago.  "If I entered here, where would be my pain point?"  I've found on the S&Ps a move of 6 points without any meaningful retracements is the maximum "uncle point" for most traders.  When I see this, I picture myself with a newbie entry, and try to imagine the pain they are feeling.  After about 6 points, I know they won't be able to take the pain any longer, and I step in and take the opposite side of this move.3. When I Tick You Tick We Tick: A more technical way to measure emotion is to watch the ticks.  Whenever I see readings of over +1000 or -1000 Ticks, I start fading the move.  If we get a +1000 tick reading and I am already long, I start exiting the move and initiating a short position.  The reverse is also true.  In these instances, I am using a 4 ½ point stop and a 3 point target on the E-mini S&Ps.  If neither my stop or target is not hit after 25 minutes, I exit the trade at the current price.4. Dive, Captain, Dive: My trading partners and I run a trading room, and one of the things we all like to do is watch how the newer traders react to the market action.  There are "noises" that the people in the room can use.  One of the classics is when the market is falling, and one of the newer traders initiates the "submarine dive, dive, dive" noise.  Immediately upon hearing this, I know it is time to cover my shorts and go long.  The experienced traders in the room also know this, and of course we then share this information with the newbie trader.  Once he catches on, we just have to wait for the next free trial to show up.5. High Five, Baby: Whenever traders I work with start slapping each other on the back as the result of a trade (or if I do it for that matter), I immediately close out my position.  This is the result of extreme emotion, and extreme emotion is not sustainable.  I call this the "high five sell signal."The financial markets naturally take advantage of and prey upon human nature, especially when it comes to greed, hope, and fear.  The key to remember is that the biggest movements in the markets do not occur when traders in general "feel like buying."  They occur because groups of traders are all getting skewered at the same time, and are forced out of a position.  In reality, traders are not trading stocks, futures or options.  They are trading other traders.  The profitable trader learns to be aware of the psychology and emotions behind the person who is taking the opposite side of their trade.  In addition, they go a step further and learn to recognize their own feelings and emotions, letting them run amok, generating buy and sell signals worth their weight in gold.And if you want to learn more about how we look to take advantage of emotions, as well as some indispensable technical tools, you can join me for a free webinar. On Tuesday, September 6 at 7 PM Central, we will be Hunting for Tops and Bottoms. We will discuss low risk option strategies for catching high probability reversal trades. And, of course, we will cover how to avoid getting suckered into those costly traps that our unruly emotions can lead us into. You can sign up for the free class at https://www.simplertrading.com/hunting.

Philip Morris International (PM) stock fell early Tuesday, pulling the sector down, after the tobacco giant reported lower-than-expected second-quarter earnings and revenue amid shrinking cigarette shipments.Earnings per share minus one time items for the maker of Marlboro, Lark and other cigarette brands slid 5% to $1.15 on a 3.1% drop in revenue to $6.65 billion. Wall Street was looking for $1.20 EPS and $6.77 billion revenue. Cigarette shipment volume of 209.3 billion units was down by 4.8% vs. the same quarter a year ago.Excluding unfavorable currency translation of 8 cents a share, EPS would be up 2 cents to $1.21, the company said. It was the second earnings miss in a row for Philip Morris. But the company revised its full-year 2016 earnings outlook upward to $4.45-$4.55.New York City-based Philip Morris International, spun off from Altria (MO) in 2008, earns all its revenue outside the U.S. Philip Morris USA is the U.S. division of Altria.Philip Morris shares ended trading down 3% to 99.89, undercutting a recent 102.65 buy point and its 50-day line. Its stock formed a first-stage flat base from late May to early July and rose above that entry point on July 5.IBD's TAKE: Tobacco stocks often are top dividend payers. Read about Philip Morris, Altria and Reynolds American payouts in this Income Investor column.Among other leading tobacco companies, Altria inched up a nickel to 69.22, while Reynolds American (RAI), maker of Camel and Kool brands, lost that much to end at 52.57. Kent maker British American Tobacco (BTI) sank 0.9% to 126.12.

Some pockets of the stock market invariably do well when investor optimism is wobbling. Several consumer staples ETFs are making new highs or trading near highs as heightened uncertainty raises the sector's appeal.It's easy to see why it does. Consumers are going to need their soft drinks, bleach, cereal and flour no matter how the economy goes.The consumer staples sector generally outperforms during recessionary periods and, to a lesser extent, late in a market cycle, writes Morningstar analyst Robert Goldsborough. It tends to underperform in the early innings."As such, investors interested in this fund should hold a strong belief that the economy is at least headed toward a recessionary environment," Goldsborough noted. Unless, of course, it's part of a diversified portfolio where its role is to help limit portfolio volatility.Investors have hardly been dashing for the stock market exits in recent sessions, but Europe is a niggling worry. The fear is that the U.K's vote to leave the European Union could stoke a regional recession and even perhaps a broader economic slowdown.Against that backdrop, Guggenheim S&P 500 Equal Weight Consumer Staples (RHS) climbed on the stock market today to its best level in more than two years. This exchange traded fund holds 36 large-cap stocks in the consumer staples sector.As its name implies, the ETF veers away from the traditional weighting of stocks by market capitalization (or, the total value of all a company's shares of stock). Instead, each stock gets an identical weight in the portfolio.Procter & Gamble (PG) accounts for roughly 3% of portfolio assets. So does Whole Foods Market (WFM).By contrast, Consumer Staples Select Sector SPDR (XLP), a cap-weighted rival holding the same stocks, gives a 12% weight to Procter & Gamble, its largest stock holding. It has 0.6% weight in Whole Foods Market, its smallest holding.The top 10 holdings in XLP account for 62% of its portfolio assets vs. 29% in RHS.The equal-weighting method followed by the latter prevents a small handful of stocks from having an unduly large impact on performance.That may sometimes work in an investor's favor. But an investor can be sure they'll always get less of a bias toward large companies and a shot at outperforming traditional, cap-weighted rivals with lower volatility.RHS has delivered on that promise both year to date and over the longer run. It's up 11.7% in 2016 through July 1 -- far outpacing the S&P 500 -- and produced an average annual 17.5% gain over the past five years.By comparison, larger peers XLP and Vanguard Consumer Staples (VDC) gained roughly 10% and an average annual 14.8% over those same periods.VDC holds 101 cap-weighted stocks, including Coca-Cola (KO), tobacco giant Philip Morris (PM) and Monster Beverage (MNST), a top-rated IBD Leaderboard stock.Both XLP and VDC also made new multiyear highs on the stock market today.A potentially stronger dollar post-Brexit could act as a headwind for multinational firms such as Procter & Gamble, whose earnings rely on overseas sales. At the same time, investors are discounting the odds of a near-term rate hike. That should boost this dividend-paying sector."Consumer staples stocks tend to be sensitive to interest-rate hikes because most experience less earnings growth during economic expansions to offset the negative impact of rising interest rates," Goldsborough writes.Guggenheim recently launched the 15th in its equal-weighted ETF suite. Guggenheim S&P 100 Equal Weight (OEW) invests in 100 of the largest and most stable companies in the S&P 500, giving each stock an equal portfolio weight. The cap-weighted S&P 100 Index (OEX) is widely used for derivatives and underlies OEX options.The oldest ETF in this innovative suite, S&P 500 Equal Weight (RSP), has, since its 2003 inception, outperformed the cap-weighted S&P 500 in 100% of 10-year monthly rolling periods, 86% of five-year monthly rolling periods, and 81% of three-year monthly rolling periods, according to Guggenheim.Guggenheim's equal-weighted strategies are helped by a disciplined quarterly rebalancing to target weights, which helps them buy stocks low and sell high.

Just days after one of the worst two-day stock market selloffs in years, stocks of some highly rated companies were breaking out Wednesday, including Chinese online gaming company NetEase (NTES) and tobacco products giant Reynolds American (RAI).Meanwhile, novel drug developer Medivation (MDVN), lighting products maker Acuity Brands (AYI) and Broadcom (AVGO), an Apple (AAPL) chip supplier, were all retaking or trying to retake their key 50-day line.NetEase, which boasts a best-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed at least 99% of all stocks on key metrics including sales and profit growth in recent quarters, shot up 4.9% to 181.48 in heavy volume  in the stock market today. It rose above the 179.20 entry point of a four-month-long cup-with-handle base in heavy volume.M Science analyst Henry Guo said NetEase is likely to deliver revenue above current consensus estimates for the second quarter.The IBD 50 list stock has climbed an amazing 375% from a 38.75 low on Dec. 14, 2014, amid robust sales and earnings growth.For annotated charts of NetEase and other top-rated stocks that are at or near buy range, take a free trial of IBD LeaderboardReynolds American has been working on a flat base for about two-and-a-half months and topped its 52.64 buy point in above average volume, closing up 1.2% at 52.89.The maker of Camel, Winston, Kool and other brands of cigarettes, along with snuff and vapor release devices, was on track for its fourth straight higher close after investors fled to "safe" stocks, including shelf stable food makers, utilities and cigarette companies last week.Consumers need food and electricity and tend to keep buying commodities like cigarettes even during market dips. Stocks of its rivals, Altria (MO), British American Tobacco (BTI) and Philip Morris International (PM) have also done well in recent days.Broadcom gapped up 3.5% to 155. The wireless chipmaker continues to grow rapidly despite declining sales of the Apple iPhone. Singapore-based Avago bought the former San Diego-based Broadcom in a deal valued at $37 billion last year and took that company's name. Broadcom hit a record 166 on June 3, after its latest quarterly earnings.Apple rose 0.9% to 94.40.Medivation, which has been forming a flat base for a little more than a month, climbed 5.5% to 60.95, rebounding over the 50-day line after tumbling below that support area in the post-Brexit sell-off. Wednesday's gain may be partly in sync with the 108% jump in share price for Tesaro (TSRO) to a record high. Tesaro said its experimental ovarian cancer drug niaraparib met the main goal of increasing survival rates for patients in a late-stage trial.Medivation has resisted an unsolicited bid from French drugmaker Sanofi (SNY).Acuity Brands, a lighting fixtures maker that has been expanding into adjacent markets including digital lighting products, on Wednesday reported a 50% earnings surge to $2.06 for its  third quarter on a 25% revenue increase to $851.50 million, both beating analyst estimates. Acuity Brands rose 0.8% to 246.61, failing to close above its 50-day line after crossing that support area intraday.
