Wake Up....Global mkts under pressure. Gold up, Oil down as recent comments by the Saudi's raise doubts over the ability of anyone to agree to freeze output......Earnings season is upon us and concern continues to mount....Overnight Christine Lagarde - IMF (International Monetary Fund) Managing Director sounding alarm bells about the state of the global economy..........trying to balance her statement to sound somewhat positive - she says that'while we have growth and are not in crisis mode - the recovery remains far too slow and too fragile and RISKS are INCREASING'........so many people 'are not feeling it...'Couple that with Boston's Fed Pres - Eric Rosengren - who said"If, as I expect the economy data continue to show a moderate recovery, it will likely be appropriate to resume the path of gradual tightening sooner than is implied by financial-market futures,"And that Wall St is 'mistaken' about the timing and direction of rates ( here we go again with the inmates running the asylum...)..... Back up one min, won't you.....'economic data continuing to show moderate recovery'? ....OK? And we have the perfect recipe for RISK OFF.....US futures are getting smashed...down 19 pts in early pre-mkt trading...sending the S&P future down and thru 2040......(must be all that good news......)Yesterday the gov't reported that Factory orders for manufactured goods in February FELL 1.7%, marking the third time in the last four months that they have been down. Total factory orders are down 1.7% year-over-year while orders, excluding transportation, are down 3.4%. (Eric - those are negative numbers...not positive numbers....just sayin...). This supports Friday's NFP report that showed nearly 30,000 lost jobs in manufacturing (another negative number) ....Never mind that Producer prices in Europe continued to fall, resuming their downward deflationary path falling at -4.2% y/y! (grossly negative number...)Overnight - The Nikkei plummeted by 2.4%, the Yen rallies (bad for exporters) - How are those negative rates working? How much more can the Yen rally before we enter 'intervention territory'? Will PM Shinzo Abe announce another stimulus plan? Kathy Lien - Managing Director at FX Strategy at BK Asset Management had this to say:"With the high level of long yen/short dollar positions, this is the prime time for the BoJ to intervene....however Japanese policy makers have not confirmed any intervention thus far...."Hong Kong and Australia both lower by 1.5% - China bucking the trend rallies by 1.3% .This morning European mkts also getting slammed.....Euro zone macro data supporting the recent Lagarde statements as they show little signs of improvement. Euro zone composite PMI - both output and services coming in below the earlier flash estimates.....Now Chris Williams - Chief Economist at Markit - tried to stop the bleed by saying:"This Euro zone data is by no means a disaster....it's just disappointing growth......"He tried to accentuate the positive by saying that there are 'pockets of growth' in both Spain and Ireland.....well that's all well and good - but when you take Germany, France, and Italy out of the equation - it sends a very clear message....and so investors are voting with their feet and heading for the exits today.....FTSE - 1.4%, CAC 40 - 2.2%, DAX -2.3%, EUROSTOXX - 2.25%, SPAIN -2.1% and ITALY -2.2%This morning's WSJ headlines with another round of gov't REGULATION that will serve to further CHOKE the economy.....Jack Lew - another Harvard Educated rocket scientist - announces"New Rules on Tax Inversions Threaten Pfizer/Allergen Deal....In a move , which is far more aggressive than anticipated, sent Allergen's shares tumbling..."Now yes, these new rules - 'the 3rd wave of administrative action against inversions will make it harder for companies' and will curb corporate inversions - but here is the issue.Instead of addressing the 'structural issues' that cause inversions (corp tax structure) - the gov't decides to 'castrate big business" with more regulation . And so this seems to be the Obama Administrations (and by default the Democrats) way to the future.....Castrate capitalism!And in another attempt to become a listed exchange - BATS has launched a new road show - marketing itself to investors 4 yrs after that massive humiliating failed attempt the first time around...... The offering is expected to generate about $212 mil - and allow the private investors an opportunity to 'get out'..... Price talk is in the $17/$19 range. Once again - they are choosing to list their shares on their exchange....let's hope that they fixed that 'software glitch'......Eco data today includes: Markit US Services PMI - exp of 51.2, ISM Non Manf Composite of 54.2 and the JOLTS job openings - Not a major data point at all - unless of course they can use it to sell their story.I suspect that if the mkt remains weak into the opening and we break 2050 on the S&P cash - then a test lower to the 200 dma at 2015 - is not out of the question...as it now appears that all of the excitement at month end has turned into caution ahead of today's slew of mixed to negative news - at the moment there is no reason for mkts to rally....buyers will be patient as they watch sellers squirm....Take Good Care

Tobacco stocks have been smoking in recent weeks, fueled by a move to defensive stocks and by vague rumors about mergers. Even though the broad market has rebounded sharply, money managers have not let go of stocks they believe can weather a market downturn. Tobacco, foods, household staples and utilities -- all dividend-paying stocks -- historically fill the bill. Tobacco…

And as expected - stocks did very little yesterday...in yesterday's note - I suggested that we would remain in the 2055/2065 range with no reason at all to do much else....in fact yesterday's range was 2057/2063 - and there were no fireworks, no end of month or end of qtr surprises at all as investors were just happy to see the end of the qtr come (and go)! In the end the Dow end the qtr with a 1.5% gain and the S&P had a 0.8% gain.Now you could credit yesterday's lack of activity to both exhaustion and reluctance by anyone to do anything ahead of today's NFP report and the host of other macro data points that will bombard us today......... Remember today is April 1st - otherwise known as April Fool's Day around the world....now while its origin is unknown - it is a day defined by tricks, tomfoolery and hoaxes - all designed to make someone look like an April Fool..... So the question today is:Will today's NFP report just be an April Fool's joke? Mkt expectations are calling for an increase of 205k jobs created in March - now remember last month the call was for +195k and the gov't came out and told us that we really created 242k jobs! (Now THAT is a joke.....).....on Wednesday - the ADP reported a slightly higher number of jobs created + 200k (vs. the expected 195k), and they raised the prior month from 205k to 214k......this now suggests that we will get a stronger NFP report.... and to that I say - "April Fools!!!"Other eco data due out today includes:
The Unemployment rate - exp of 4.9%,
Avg Hourly Earnings of +0.2%,
Avg Hours Worked - exp of 34.5
Labor Participation Rate exp of 62.9%
Market US Manf PMI of 51.5
ISM Manf of 51
Construction Spending of +0.1%

Ward's Domestic Vehicle Sales of 13.8 mil and Total Vehicle Sales of 17.5 milSo as you can see - it will be a day of data points...and the mkt appears to be taking a breather. US futures are down 9 pts in early pre-mkt trading.....Now remember - it is a NEW qtr...the slate has been wiped clean and the odometer has been reset to zero.....The dollar continues to come under pressure, oil appears to be de-coupling from the broader mkt - the recent rally in oil driven more by the dollar action vs. any real change in fundamentals.....Gold - which has seen a dramatic 16% gain over the past 3 months is now coming under a bit of pressure as investors decipher the tea leaves over the future of US and global economics. If the data begins strengthen then logic tells us that Gold should weaken (think other more dynamic opportunities) but if the global economies continue to stall or weaken then watch Gold spike higher yet again (think the safe haven play)....Earnings are now clearly in the bulls eye as investors prepare themselves for the onslaught of coming earnings over the next 3 weeks.The WSJ runs with a headline article this morning detailing the state of the IPO (Initial Public Offering) mkt."Lackluster IPO Market Flashes Warning - Pace for initial public offerings is slowest first qtr since 2009, and analysts warn that second period may not bring much relief"In this article the writer tries to connect the dots between the lack of new product and investor appetite for risk...... I am not sure that is the connection...investor appetite will be fed by interesting and dynamic product as well as realistic valuations for these untested products.....it is the purest form of mkt dynamics that rewards proper risk taking......Investment by PE firms, Venture Capital Firm and large asset management firms have push valuations to extremes and maybe investors are finally waking up the idea that these extreme valuations reward nobody but the investment banks and the insiders looking to unload these 'over valued' shares.Yesterday we learned that many of the big asset managers (Fidelity, Blackrock, TRowe Price etc....) - the same ones that have invested in private start ups (PRE-IPO) have pushed valuations to 'extreme' levels and are now taking - 'hair cuts' ( I think it was described as an AX) to valuation estimates for these privately held (difficult to value) companies. I would argue that it was THESE asset managers themselves that are responsible for the crazy valuations creating ' Unicorns' that they now are the focus of investor angst.[A Unicorn is usually a startup company that does NOT have any established performance metrics but have a supposed stock mkt valuation of more than $1 billion dollars]So now that all of these asset managers are having a 'V-8' moment and becoming more realistic - we are beginning to see a change in psychology.....Should these companies really have such ridiculous valuations? Apparently not! And these very markdowns have sucked the life out of the momentum - making it harder for investment banks to 'sell this story' at the ridiculous valuations that they have tried to convince us all of....So now you get untested, overvalued private companies that think they are going to cash out at 'X' and are now told that "maybe that is not the case"......they may have to settle for something more realistic like 'Y'....and they don't want that - so they don't come to the mkt....It's like the guy that says my house is worth $1 mil while everything around him is trading at $400k......HELLO??? Does this remind anyone of the late 90's DOT.COM bubble?????Global mkts begin the new qtr all in the RED - (no one should be surprised at all).

As noted - US futures a pointing lower - now down 9 pts at 2044 - in pre-mkt trading as we prepare for the US jobs report. If we don't find support on the future right here at 2040 - then a move into the low 2030's would be expected.Global mkts also started the new qtr in the RED - In Asia - all mkts ended the day lower.....In Japan the March Manufacturing PMI dropped to 49.1 while the important Tankan Survey also missed estimates coming in at 4 vs. the exp of 6 - and this only causes more angst over the Japanese economy. Next door in China - we did see China Manf PMI rise (surprise) to a 9 month high of 50.2 vs. the est of 49.4. All of this just noise as all eyes are focused on the US - after all the drama of the past couple of weeks. Japan - 3.5%, Hong Kong -1.34%, China +0.12% and ASX -1.64%.In Europe - PMI"s were than the flash estimates, but the weakness in Japan ended up stealing the show....Volumes remain subdued as European investors count the minutes until the US jobs report. FTSE - 1.2%, CAC 40 - 2.09%, DAX -2%, EUROSTOXX -2.06%, SPAIN -1% and ITALY -1.85%

Today we get Cleveland's own Loretta Mester - who will be speaking at 1 pm....she tends to be more hawkish than dovish - but let's see what she has to say today. Remember - it is April Fool's Day -so beware of anything that sounds 'too good to be true'.Take Good Care
KP

Ok...so what happened last night? All that hype about the China macro data kept everyone on edge over the weekend...what would they report? Would it be a disaster? What would that say about the health of the Chinese economy and then by default the global economy? In the end - it was NOT a blockbuster, in fact it was rather boring really....

At 10:00 pm est - China released a bunch of data - and it was mixed.....no disasters but no upside surprises either.........3rd Qtr GDP came in above expectations at 6.9% (exp was for 6.8%), Industrial Production did rise 5.7%, but that was below the exp of 6%. Fixed Asset Investments (FAI) - a key reading - came in at 10.3% - below the expectation of 10.8% and Retail Sales - that beat at 10.9% vs. the exp of 10.8%... So what does it all mean? Well - to start with - the data implies that the world is not ending and that the Chinese economy appears to be stabilizing - which in the end is a positive.
Angus Nicholson - Market Analyst at IG sums it up like this:

"It's hard to be overly optimistic about the headline number, especially given the range of other data released today. Nonetheless, markets have clearly been buoyed by the better than expected headline number, and it shows that China's economy has not deteriorated as much as some had thought"
James Laurenceson - Deputy Director of the Australia-China Relations Institute added that:

"The data show a rebalancing away from growth driven by investment and secondary sector production towards consumption and the services sector. It's time we accept that Chinese growth isn't solely at the mercy of industrial production and fixed asset investment"

So maybe, just maybe this is the 'new normal' for China. Maybe the world will see a China growing at a 6 handle and that's ok. Analysts are already looking out to the 4th qtr and suspect that by year end China will achieve annual growth of 6.8% -7% on continued fiscal and monetary support.

Global markets are not panicking with on these reports. In fact - there appears to be a little bit of 'risk on' as the investors/traders are relieved that the data was NOT as bad as analysts had prepared us for. Asian markets essentially ended flat. Japan - the worst performer - ended the day -0.88%, Hong Kong + 0.04%, China + 0.14% and ASX +0.03%.
European markets are also higher - discounting the China data and refocusing on earnings. FTSE flat, CAC 40 +0.32%, DAX + 0.86%, EUROSTOXX + 0.53%, SPAIN flat, and ITALY + 0.61%.

France's Danone Group up 2.5% beat estimates, Germany's Deutsche Bank +3.1%, announces a big management shakeup and restructuring plan - heads to roll and that is helping to send other financials higher. German retailer Metro - announces a rise in sales and is talking all bullish about the coming Christmas season sending this stock up by 3.7%. Air France- KLM announces job CUTS in 2016 and investors love it - sending that stock higher.... and not to be left in the dark - Italian carmaker Ferrari is getting ready to price its IPO tomorrow and will start trading on the NYSE on Thursday.

This morning US futures are off 1 pt.....Now prior to the China report - US futures were pointing lower on the expectation that we were gonna get hit hard....and when that did not happen - Futures moved to the plus side and are now flat. I suspect that the market will test resistance at 2040 and then back off trying to find support in the 2025 range - if not, then definitely the 1980 range.

As much as there is plenty of US macro data this week - the focus will now return to US corp earnings. This week and next week will see hundreds of reports for investors to chew on. Earnings to include: HAS, MS, HAL, GPC, IBM, ZION, AXP, BA, KO, MCD, MSFT, and PG to name just a few.
NOTE: Fed's Lacker is due to speak today at 12 pm.

Up til now - earnings have been, well, not so good. Not horrible, but not great. 70% are beating the estimates while only 48% of those are beating on top line revenue growth. Despite the economic weakness and a bunch of downgrades - stocks have not done so badly.....with the DOW, S&P and Nasdaq all closing close to 2 month highs.... All of these indexes have now pierced their down trending 50 dma's and are now challenging their intermediate term resistance - or 100 dma's. Now here we may hit some trouble - but I think that is just a matter of time....unless earnings completely implode - then I suspect that we will test resistance one or two more times before 'breaking out' and challenging the longer term resistance levels defined by their 200 dma's. And as is usual - as we move thru the 4th qtr - FOMO (fear of missing out) will help to lift stocks going into year end.

Now on the other hand - small caps are lagging...... The most recent lows for small caps came early October and it was much lower than the August 24th sell-off lows. The most recent highs were just two weeks ago and those highs were lower than the highs set in mid-September. - suggesting that a bearish downtrend (lower lows and lower highs) remains intact from a small cap perspective. And why would this be so?

Well - it is earnings season, and it is more common for the large cap/mid cap companies to be able to borrow money to buy back shares which will serve to 'doll up" their earnings per share. (Small cap companies are not nearly as active buying back stock to create the illusion of better earnings and so you have the disconnect.) Or it could be that small caps are more risky and at a time of global nervousness - investors may want the security of large cap, liquid, dividend paying names....It's just a thought.....

The fact that small caps continue to lag might suggest that the selling pressure is not over yet....but until we get thru earnings season the divergence will continue. Then it will be Thanksgiving, and the debt debacle in DC, and then the FED December decision.... so there is plenty ahead to keep investors on their toes the question is: Does the market have enough strength to support another "Santa Clause" rally into the end of the year?
Take good care
Kp
You can get better. It Starts Here
"Words of War" - A special evening in support of comprehensive mental healthcare for Iraq and Afghanistan Veterans will take place tonight - Monday, October 19th, 2015 - Freedom Tower - NYC.

The Headstrong Project - a veterans charitable organization begun by a returning Iraqi War Veteran - A US Marine - that not only saw but understood the impact that this war was going to have on a nation of Americans, will hold their 3rd Annual Fundraiser to help 'heal the hidden wounds of war'. In partnership with Weill Cornell Medical College - One of this nation's leading mental health care centers - The Headstrong Project has developed the first of its kind, comprehensive treatment program for veterans in need.

I am proud to be on the host committee and I am proud to participate as the evening's Live Auctioneer as we raise money to support the very men and women who answered the call. I am looking to break the record and raise $1 mil this evening and I could use your help. Please visit
Getheadstrong.org/words-of-war/
Getheadstrong.org/donate-support/
as we honor the men and women who fight valiantly for our freedom.

Maybe the world will see a China growing at a 6 handle and that's ok. Analysts are already looking out to the 4th qtr and suspect that by year end China will achieve annual growth of 6.8% -7% on continued fiscal and monetary support.Global markets are not panicking with on these reports. In fact - there appears to be a little bit of 'risk on' as the investors/traders are relieved that the data was NOT as bad as analysts had prepared us for. Asian markets essentially ended flat. Japan - the worst performer - ended the day -0.88%, Hong Kong + 0.04%, China + 0.14% and ASX +0.03%.European markets are also higher - discounting the China data and refocusing on earnings. FTSE flat, CAC 40 +0.32%, DAX + 0.86%, EUROSTOXX + 0.53%, SPAIN flat, and ITALY + 0.61%.France's Danone Group up 2.5% beat estimates, Germany's Deutsche Bank +3.1%, announces a big management shakeup and restructuring plan - heads to roll and that is helping to send other financials higher. German retailer Metro - announces a rise in sales and is talking all bullish about the coming Christmas season sending this stock up by 3.7%. Air France- KLM announces job CUTS in 2016 and investors love it - sending that stock higher.... and not to be left in the dark - Italian carmaker Ferrari is getting ready to price its IPO tomorrow and will start trading on the NYSE on Thursday.This morning US futures are off 1 pt.....Now prior to the China report - US futures were pointing lower on the expectation that we were gonna get hit hard....and when that did not happen - Futures moved to the plus side and are now flat. I suspect that the market will test resistance at 2040 and then back off trying to find support in the 2025 range - if not, then definitely the 1980 range.As much as there is plenty of US macro data this week - the focus will now return to US corp earnings. This week and next week will see hundreds of reports for investors to chew on. Earnings to include: HAS, MS, HAL, GPC, IBM, ZION, AXP, BA, KO, MCD, MSFT, and PG to name just a few.NOTE: Fed's Lacker is due to speak today at 12 pm.Up til now - earnings have been, well, not so good. Not horrible, but not great. 70% are beating the estimates while only 48% of those are beating on top line revenue growth. Despite the economic weakness and a bunch of downgrades - stocks have not done so badly.....with the DOW, S&P and Nasdaq all closing close to 2 month highs.... All of these indexes have now pierced their down trending 50 dma's and are now challenging their intermediate term resistance - or 100 dma's. Now here we may hit some trouble - but I think that is just a matter of time....unless earnings completely implode - then I suspect that we will test resistance one or two more times before 'breaking out' and challenging the longer term resistance levels defined by their 200 dma's. And as is usual - as we move thru the 4th qtr - FOMO (fear of missing out) will help to lift stocks going into year end.Now on the other hand - small caps are lagging...... The most recent lows for small caps came early October and it was much lower than the August 24th sell-off lows. The most recent highs were just two weeks ago and those highs were lower than the highs set in mid-September. - suggesting that a bearish downtrend (lower lows and lower highs) remains intact from a small cap perspective. And why would this be so?Well - it is earnings season, and it is more common for the large cap/mid cap companies to be able to borrow money to buy back shares which will serve to 'doll up" their earnings per share. (Small cap companies are not nearly as active buying back stock to create the illusion of better earnings and so you have the disconnect.) Or it could be that small caps are more risky and at a time of global nervousness - investors may want the security of large cap, liquid, dividend paying names....It's just a thought.....The fact that small caps continue to lag might suggest that the selling pressure is not over yet....but until we get thru earnings season the divergence will continue. Then it will be Thanksgiving, and the debt debacle in DC, and then the FED December decision.... so there is plenty ahead to keep investors on their toes the question is: Does the market have enough strength to support another "Santa Clause" rally into the end of the year?Take good careKpYou can get better. I am looking to break the record and raise $1 mil this evening and I could use your help. In 1976 - Earth Wind and Fire released their new R&B double live album - Gratitude.....This album featured such hits as 'Reasons', "Shining Star', 'Celebrate' and 'Sing A Song' - and yesterday it appeared that that is what investors were doing.... "When you feel down and out, Sing a song, It'll make your day, yeah, yeah....Here's time to shout, Sing…

Stock futures remained positive en route to Thursday's open, but pared gains sharply after a weak reading on New York region manufacturing. Dow futures were 50.3 points above fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures held a 15.9-point gain, down from 22 points an hour earlier. S&P 500 futures rose 7.7 points.

Early economic news on the stock market today included September consumer prices, which the Labor Department reported slipped 0.2%, more than August's 0.1% dip but in line with expectations and flat with year-ago levels. Core prices, minus food and energy, rose 0.2% — more than the forecast 0.1% gain.

Jobless claims dipped 3% in the week ended Oct. 10, to 255,000, much better than the 270,000 claims projected by economist consensus. The four-week moving average fell to 265,000, a fifth straight decline.

September's sharp slowdown in New York region manufacturing eased only slightly in October, with the New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Survey improving to minus 11.4 from a minus 14.7 tally for September. Economists had projected the slowdown would improve to a minus 7 reading.
At 10 a.m. the Philadelphia Federal Reserve releases its regional manufacturing survey for October.
Stock action was all over the map before the bell.
Garmin (GRMN) and Seagate Technology (STX) were down nearly 12% each in premarket trade after lowering expectations for their upcoming quarterly reports.

Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX) dropped 10% late Wednesday and held the loss ahead of Thursday's open. The company reported after Wednesday's close it had received subpoenas from federal prosecutors in Massachusetts and New York related to drug pricing. A company statement said most of the material requested related to how the company helped patients pay for drugs.
Valeant shares rose 84% for the year through early August, then backed down sharply — including a 23% slide in September.

Netflix (NFLX) traded down 3% ahead of the open after falling as much as 15% in extended trade Wednesday. The streaming online entertainment provider reported third-quarter earnings just below consensus estimates and mixed progress in subscriber growth. Shares trimmed losses aggressively during the company's conference call with analysts. The stock ended Wednesday in a test of 10-week support, below a possible 115.93 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Shares of Dexcom (DXCM), maker of wireless glucose monitoring devices for patients with diabetes, thumped out a 15% premarket gain. The San Diego-based company reported preliminary third-quarter results showing revenue up 52% year over year to $105 million, vs. consensus expectations of $96.7 million.

Another San Diego stock, Bofi (BOFI), rebounded 12% ahead of the open. Shares of the Internet-based collapsed 30% on Wednesday after news reports said the bank was being sued by one of its former internal auditors. BofI shares had climbed 85% from Dec. 31 through an Oct. 12 peak.

Other banks and financial issues were in mixed motion on earnings news, with Citigroup (C) a fraction higher, Goldman Sachs (GS) down more than 1% and BB&T (BBT), Home BancShares (HOMB) and Cohen & Steers (CNS) holding steady.

Beyond banks, Unilever (UN) powered up after a solid Q3 report. Phillip Morris International (PM) lit up 2%, and UnitedHealth (UNH) gained 1%. Chipmaker Xilinx (XLNX) rolled ahead 4% after its fiscal Q2 sales and earnings slipped less than expected.

Heavy crane maker Manitowoc (MTW) tumbled 14%. The Wisconsin company late Wednesday guided its Q3 revenue to well below consensus expectations. The stock has been unraveling and fighting a losing battle to retake support since July 2014.

Overseas, China's markets posted a hot session, with the Shanghai Composite and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index adding more than 2%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 took a 1.2% gain. In Europe, stocks climbed broadly higher, with the leading indexes in Paris, Frankfurt and London more than 1% higher near midday.

In other markets, the dollar was mixed, up against the euro, down vs. the yen. Bonds edged lower. Oil backed off, with West Texas Intermediate down more than 1% to just above $46 a barrel.Stock futures remained positive en route to Thursday's open, but pared gains sharply after a weak reading on New York region manufacturing. Who remembers the old Batman TV show? Remember when Batman and Robin were taking on the Joker, The Penguin, Mr. Freeze, Mad Hatter, The Riddler or even King Tut - do you remember how they showed the fights? Words like POW, BOOM & SMACK appeared in bubbles on the TV screen -.....the fight was left to the viewers imagination.....and so ladies and gentlemen - that is what it appears to be today with the markets.......

It's all about your imagination as words like GLOBAL WEAKNESS, CHINA, INTEREST RATES, QE, STIMULUS flash across computer screens causing stocks to jump yesterday sending the S&P, the DOW and the Nasdaq higher for the 5th straight day....

Ok, look - The last week was another example of a manipulated market......traders feel forced to buy stocks to cover short bets as the media and the industry celebrates the weaker macro data and new evidence of economic weakness.....Celebrate? Why yes - because that means that the FED (and the ECB, BoJ and PBoC) will all come to the rescue (again) in one way or another. Stocks rallied yesterday on the rumor or chatter that the FED has to delay raising interest rates even as they tell us how appropriate it is to raise rates in October or December, but the most recent readings on the U.S. economy and global economy appear now to force the Fed to wait until 1Qtr of 2016.

(Just to add another notch in the belt - Yesterday we learned that the ISM Service sector report missed analysts' expectations - although to be fair - it IS still in expansionary mode - but so many took the opportunity to accentuate the negative which then translates into a positive for risk assets....)

And did you see that the treasury sold a 'new gov't security' with a 3-month yield of ZERO for the first time in history? Ok...so just so we understand - investors gave the gov't a 3-month FREE loan......no interest, Here! - just take it. See the Money and Investing Section of today's WSJ -
"Yield of 0%, a First at 3 -Month T-Bill Sale"
As the article points out:
"The result reflects diminishing expectations in financial markets that the Federal Reserve would raise short-term rates before year end after Friday's disappointing jobs report...."
And so - the prospect of loading up the punch bowl with more 'Kool Aid' creates demand for 'riskier assets' and this sent both stocks and commodities higher......

Technically speaking we can expect more volatility in the weeks ahead as we enter earnings season.... We have seen how analysts have slashed estimates and repositioned themselves ahead of what is likely to be a volatile couple of weeks.

Last night we learned that Ellen Kullman - CEO at DuPont (DD) is the first casualty of this 'hurricane season'. News out last night that she is 'retiring' (convenient) just as her company slashed its profit forecast - (dollar strength, global weakness...blah, blah, blah) and the activist investor, Trian, boosted its stake in the company - citing Kullman's failure to meet her targets..... Remember that Trian - owned by Ed Garden and Nelson Peltz - wants to break up the company saying that the parts are worth more than the sum of its whole. The stock is trading UP $2 or 4% in pre-market trading.....

This morning Pepsico (PEP) announces a surprise earnings report : $1.35 vs. exp of $1.26....which is contra to what the expectation was.... Revenues of $16.3 bil vs exp of $16.1 bil and they are on track to deliver $5 bil of productivity savings thru 2019 and return $9 bil to shareholders this year.....the stock is trading UP 3 pts (3%) at $98.57/sh.
Later today we will hear from YUM Brands (YUM) - and on tomorrow afternoon - we will hear from AlcoaAA.

On a side note Uncle Benny (Bernanke) took to the media circuit yesterday - announcing the publication of his new book - "The Courage to Act" . In this book - Benny discusses what went wrong and what went right during the GFC of 2007/2015 and counting......He points his finger at corporate executives saying that:
"It would have been my preference to have more investigation of individual action, since obviously everything that went wrong or was illegal was done by some individual and not by an abstract firm."

He also acknowledges that so many were slow to realize just how serious the crisis would become and he 'faults himself for not doing more to explain to Americans why it was in their interest to rescue the financial firms that had helped cause it'.

And finally he calls out a defective congress that 'failed to do its part' in helping to navigate the turmoil that engulfed this country - turmoil that caused untold hardships and crisis on so many Americans - The book is available today on Amazon and is a must read for anyone interested in how close the country was to financial Armageddon.

Overnight Asian markets were mostly higher due to the news that the TPP (Trans Pacific Partnership) agreement seems to be finished. This trade deal among the US and 11 Pacific Rim countries has been called 'the biggest of its kind in a generation' and is supposed to yield global benefits of $300 bil. by the year 2025. This deal though - still needs final approval from Congress....HSBC analysts had this to say about the deal:

"An accord among countries representing a large swath of the global economy sends a positive signal worldwide.....increased market openness via trade policy reform on this scale can promote growth in a manner that compounds".
We can only hope....Japan +1%, Hong Kong -0.1% and ASX +0.3%.

In Europe - markets are now higher after being lower all morning. German Factory Orders fall 'unexpectedly' raising the risk that Europe's largest economy is vulnerable to a weakening China.....The rebound that we have seen of late has been on the back of the idea of more stimulus....vs. on an improving economic outlook. So - is the move really sustainable? I guess we are about to see.....as earnings season is about to begin in Europe as well....so the devil is in the details...FTSE -0.04%, CAC 40 + 0.72%, DAX + 0.81%, EUROSTOXX +0.65%, SPAIN +0.73% AND ITALY + 0.31%

US Futures are off 4 pts.....that is after they were 10- pts lower earlier....this should not surprise anyone - after yesterday's rally to resistance at 1990ish. Expect the news to be about DD, PEP and YUM today as more of the details emerge over leadership and results. Banks begin next week and those will surely set the overall tone for the broader market. No eco reports to speak of, but there are two FED speakers that will hit the circuit today. Kansas Fed Ester George at 9:15 am and San Fran's John Williams at 3:30 pm.

I suspect that the market will trade tight as it digests yesterday's move and dissects the DD, PEP and YUM news.....as it looks for the next catalyst to determine market direction. Look for resistance at the 50 dma at 2000 and support at 1950.
Take good care
Kp

In what many thought was going to be another bold attempt at a strong rally on the back of Janet's dovish commentary – well they were disappointed….- Why? The S&P ended the day UP 8 pts....yes they did... led by tech stocks as the Nasdaq has now joined its counterparts and pierced to the upside its 200 dma - but that is a bit deceiving….You see – stocks gapped up - as the sellers also expected the buyers to remain aggressive.....but after the open - the buyers retreated, not so anxious to just buy 'em.......so then the sellers came back and put pressure on stocks for the rest of the day....With the advances of late – many investment managers are not finding those 'bargains' that existed just weeks ago…..momo (momentum) buyers have driven stocks higher yes, but those buyers do not fit the classic 'buy and hold' long term investor profile. So the classic long term investor - is NOT chasing this latest rally as many expect the seasonal weakness that we see every April.It seems that all the jawboning about how rates are not going anywhere anytime soon has helped prices rebound…..but – 'caveat emptor' (buyer beware) yesterday's selling into the opening gap up only suggests caution ahead. And with the start of the second qtr on Friday – the process begins anew as we await the all important NFP report. (Non Farm Payrolls). What will it tell us?Now this time around – this report which is due out at 8:30 am April 1st – will be even more closely watched. Why? Well – after what happened on Tuesday – when Janet made it crystal clear that she remains concerned and that there will be no rate hike in April – analysts/strategists stand ready to pull this report apart looking for any signs of strength - (to somehow discredit her) - because if they find it – then they will surely talk about how she is 'out of touch' and revisit the talk of an April hike* (still not happening) but more likely a June hike…..And if they don't find it then – the conversation about then next hike gets put off until the second half of the year……which means what really? A late November/December time frame. Look, if they don't do it by June – then I think her hands are really tied behind her back as the country enters the final turn in the presidential election cycle….So now – we must ask – will she get 'railroaded' into a June hike (like she did in December) – to get it out of the way – or will she remain dovish?[*Yesterday while doing my weekly SkyAustralia mkt update from the floor of the NYSE - Leanne - the anchor asked me : "If the jobs report was stronger than expected - should the mkts expect that Janet could put April back on the table"?Are you kidding me! Hello!!! After her spiel on Tuesday and on March 16th where she expressed concern and took April off the table - any suggestion that April is back on the table is like standing up and screaming that "I have no clue what is happening!" She might as well pack her bags and fade into the sunset - she will have done nothing but destroy any credibility that the FED has left.........April is NOT happening - no matter what tomorrow's NFP report says.....]Yes – the latest commentary emphasizes – lower for longer and is forcing the 'risk on' trade that we have seen in the past 2 weeks.... – but that does not mean there is no concern. The latest move in stocks leaves many wondering whether it is really based on fundamentals or is it just money looking for a home that has forced prices higher. Remember - the continued accommodative policy is pushing the dollar lower – fueling the latest global currency war – which is helping to ignite the 'risk on' story …..commodities and stocks enjoying the limelight.The other part to this story is end of qtr 'window dressing' – remember – back in January/February – it looked like the bottom was falling out….stocks got clobbered as the S&P gave up 13% and many mkts around the world entered 'bear mkt' territory (We did not – came close, but no cigar) so the rally off of the February lows has rescued so many people. Both the Dow and S&P are setting up for a 1% gain this qtr – vs. the 13% losses registered in February – so yes – many are breathing a sigh of relief as the marking period comes to a close at 4 pm today. As a result - I would expect that the mkt will hold in tight - no reason for it to sell off hard, but nor is there any reason for it to rally and challenge 2075 again. I suspect today's trading range to look like 2055/2065.From a global perspective the US is the best horse in the race.....Asian mkts closed out the qtr all in the red....Japan - 12.9%, Hong Kong -5.1%, China - 13.7% and ASX -4%. European mkts - while still trading are on track also to end the qtr in solidly negative territory. FTSE - 1%, CAC 40 - 5%, DAX - 7%, EUROSTOXX -7.7%, SPAIN -8% and ITALY -15%Now it was a fairly busy night of eco data in Europe.....but the most watched is their CPI report - known as the HICP (Harmonized Index of Consumer Prices) - and it is their list of final costs paid by consumers for a basket of common goods. Each member state produces their own report and then they 'harmonize' it to help guide the ECB.... Last night the HICP came in at +1% - better than exp of +0.9%...this causing the Euro to rally while putting more pressure on the $. (Which should help to support stocks and commodities - wink, wink!)Today we get 2 more FED speakers.....Chicago's Charlie Evans (again) at 9:30 and NY's William Dudley at 5 pm. But it is the last day of the qtr so I do not expect them to say so much.Tomorrow is a big day.....the start of a new qtr & the NFP report. Next week begins earnings.... mkt action always sees weakness as we move thru April - why should this year be any different at all?Take Good Care

Reynolds American (RAI) may be a takeover target for British American Tobacco (BTI) as the tobacco industry continues to consolidate amid shrinking cigarette sales.British American, which makes Dunhill and other branded cigarettes, in January acquired a $5 billion stake in Reynolds. An unconfirmed report by the Telegraph over the weekend said the British company is working with bankers on a deal to acquire the rest of Reynolds.No. 2 U.S. tobacco company Reynolds American makes Newport, Camel and Pall Mall cigarette brands. Last year, it was part of a three-way deal in which it bought Lorillard for $25 billion.Reynolds and Lorillard agreed to sell a combined $7.1 billion in cigarette brands and other assets to U.K. based Imperial Tobacco Group, now called Imperial Brands, to win Federal Trade Commission Approval. The FTC gave its blessing to the merger in late May 2015.Tobacco companies have seen sales of cigarettes shrink in recent years amid health concerns. According to Statistica, the number of cigarettes sold globally fell to 5.8 trillion in 2014, the latest year for which figures were available, from 5.88 trillion the year before.But tobacco companies have diversified to other products, including food, beverages and smokeless electronic vapor devices, which are benefiting from the rising popularity of vaping. As a result, the tobacco group is a strong No. 13 on IBD's list of 197 industry groups.Shares of Reynolds American, an IBD Leaderboard stock, closed up less than 0.1% Monday. The Winston-Salem, N.C.-based company has a best-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed at least 99% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth in recent quarters.British American Tobacco has recorded spotty revenue and earnings growth the last couple of years. It reported a 1% rise in 2015 earnings per share, and last year EPS shrank by 9% year over year. Consensus is for the company to just break even this year. British American was closed down 0.7%.Among other major tobacco companies, Philip Morris (PM) -- the sector's revenue leader, with about $74 billion annual sales -- fell 0.6%. Like Reynolds, it's outperformed the market, and its stock is trading near an all-time intraday high of 96.73 set in May 2013.Altria Group (MO), which sells Marlboro, Parliament, Virginia Slims and other cigarette brands, fell 1.9%.

Dividend mutual funds as a group lagged the S&P 500 stock index over the 10 years that ended going into Monday.The reasons for the underperformance are worth keeping in mind whenever you make buy or sell decisions in your portfolio, particularly the diversified portion -- your mutual funds and ETFs. They could boost the octane in your funds' fuel tank.Dividend funds lagged despite having outperformed as a group over the first half of the decade. But as the post-financial-crisis bull market picked up steam, the S&P 500 began to top dividend funds in total return.Many dividend funds are value-oriented, and many are willing to give up more in potential price appreciation for a shot at higher dividend yield.The average dividend funds tracked by Morningstar Inc. rose an average annual 5.24% in the past 40 quarters plus this current quarter to date.In that same span, the S&P 500 rose an average annual 6.75%.If you had invested $10,000 on Dec. 31, 2005, in funds with "dividend" in their name, your money would have grown into $17,753 by March 4.Invested in the S&P 500, the same $10,000 would have ballooned into $19,892.So putting money into a fund tracking the big-cap benchmark would have helped your overall portfolio more -- and your retirement planning in particular.One silver lining: dividend funds average a current 12-month yield of 2.22%. That's slightly higher than the 2.17% 12-month yield of the SPDR S&P 500 ETF (SPY).Also, the top-performing dividend funds have skated past the S&P 500 in 10-year performance, though only three of the top 13 have higher yields.In the past 10 years, the top-performing dividend fund with more than $100 million in assets is $10.2 billion SunAmerica Focused Dividend Strategy Portfolio (FDSAX). The fund averaged a yearly gain of 9.52%. It also yields 2.47%.The fund had 99.63% of its money on U.S. stocks as of Dec. 31. It had 67% of assets at work in giant- and large-cap stocks. Another 28% was in midcaps. The balance of the portfolio was in small caps.The fund's biggest sector bet was consumer cyclical, with a 26% weighting.Industrials were its next biggest sector, with a 20% weighting. Energy was its third-largest sector, with a 16%.Energy was followed by consumer defensive, with a 14% weighting. In contrast, technology was only the fund's seventh-largest sector, with a modest 6.63% weighting.Recent top holdings include Verizon Communications (VZ), which is up 12% this year.The telecom giant has a Composite Rating of 99 from IBD. The Composite Rating combines IBD’s five stock-performance ratings, including EPS and RS Ratings, with 99 being the highest.Verizon pays a 4.4% dividend yield. Earnings per share grew 14%, 17% and 25% the past three quarters.Procter & Gamble (PG), another top holding, is up 5% this year.The cosmetics and personal-care products titan has a strong 87 Comp Rating and a 3.2% dividend yield.The stock has rewarded shareholders by raising its dividend 59 years in a row.EPS grew 9% in the fiscal second quarter. They fell 1% in the prior stanza.Philip Morris International (PM), yet another top holding, is up 7% this year. It has an 83 Comp Rating and pays a 4.3% dividend yield.Q4 EPS fell 4%, reflecting currency translation losses.

So yesterday Janet came out swinging - admitting that the world is on the edge or a recession saying:"Given the risks to the outlook, I consider it appropriate for the committee to proceed cautiously in adjusting policy.....the key is that the global economic and financial backdrop looms more threateningly now than before.........and even though officials expect the US economy to weather any further rough patches, the dangers can't be ignored"Let me be clear - she did NOT give any details on timing whatsoever and now the feeling is that if we get any rate rise at all - it will just ONE and it may not be in June....So we can forget all the chatter about 'multiple increases'.... and should the economy take a turn for the worse - she assured the invitees that the FED could still take steps to resuscitate the economy - think 'forward guidance' (which is just another word for Jawboning - which is what she did yesterday as she 'guided' expectations), the other trick up her sleeve would be the launch of an ECB style bazooka..... but either way - she put the idea of any increase to bed and she essentially told the 5 non-compliant FED mouthpieces to 'assume the position' and prepare to get spanked for insinuating last week that rates are due to rise in April -.......And the mkt roared! Investors and traders immediately hit the BUY button on their computers sending the S&P up 17 pts or 0.8% and the Dow up 97 pts or 0.6%.....Remember - last week - CNBC.com ran with a headline article about how "Fed Chair Yellen has a mini revolt on her hands" as 5 FED presidents took to the airwaves to suggest that the FED was falling behind the curve and that the mkt (and investors) should expect rates to rise in April. Now it appears that Janet was not happy about that development - And whether or not there is a bit of dissension in the ranks - as the French proverb goes: "Il faut laver son linge sale en famille" ......or "Never wash your dirty laundry in public".... and that is what they were doing.......washing their 'dirty laundry' for all to see in the name of 'transparency'. And what does that transparency show - it shows a complete mess within the ranks as no one really knows what to do....so staying the course appears to be the best answer for now.....Oh boy.....this story gets more interesting as the hours tick by.....I am beginning to re-think this whole transparency issue - Is it in fact the best thing for the mkts? Does it create more angst and instability for investors and traders? Would Paul Volker ever run the FED like this? (A: NO) Does the FED secretly want more instability to keep everyone guessing? As far as I am concerned - they can do what they want 'behind closed doors' but once they open those doors and the FED chair speaks then that should be it. Period the end. Whatever happened to loyalty? This business of then letting everyone in the FED run hog wild over any network that will have them is getting a bit exhausting. Because in the end - what does it really accomplish besides mass confusion and mkt instability? It is not helpful for investors nor businesses that are trying to plan for the future - it also does not help the individual as he/she plans for the future. The constant sense of angst concerning (global) monetary policy is unnecessary - and quite honestly has created a global monster...Just look around the world and tell me what you see....I think the worst part of all this is what are we really talking about? 25 bps?

Moving rates from an absurdly low level to another absurdly low level? I mean we are talking about going from 0.05% to 0.75%....not from 4% to 5%. And still this tiny move is creating all of this drama.....For those of you too young to remember 1982 - let me remind you....rates were 21% , the Dow was trading at 792 - and then on Tuesday Aug 17th - Chair Volker cut rates by 10% or a full 2%age points when he decided to take the bull by the horns and do something dramatic.....He took rates down to 19% - and the world celebrated, the mkt surged by 4.5% on that day......volumes exploded and the greatest bull mkt of our lifetime was born....... THAT WAS DRAMATIC! (But that was a different time......Ronald Reagan was president and America was on the verge of an incredible resurgence...)Once again - let's point out how legislators have done zero to assist the FED by being creative and pro-active with fiscal policy....But that's another story - one that we see unfolding right in front of us via the Presidential election......People are disgusted and rightly so.....Does anyone in DC understand that?Overnight - stocks rallied - (duh), credit mkts rallied, commodities (think oil) rallied and the dollar continued to slide lower - extending its worst month in 5 yrs. The VIX also moved lower - sliding 9% taking it to its lowest level of the year.....what does this mean? It means that there is a fair amount of complacency in the mkt - no real sense of fear...of course not - Janet has once again tucked it tightly in bed - kissing it on the head, saying 'Mommy loves you... now go to sleep'..... and this is right in front of what is expected to be a weak earnings season.... so the plot thickens.Stocks in Asia and Europe shot higher on the news....with the exception of Japan that got hit with a huge drop in Industrial Production - sending the Nikkei down 1.5%. Hong Kong +2.15%, China + 2.77% and the ASX +0.1%.European mkts following in lock step with Asia and the US....FTSE +1.7%, CAC 40 + 1.9%, DAX + 1.7%, EUROSTOXX +1.6%, SPAIN +1.5% and ITALY + 1.45%US Futures are up another 11 pts in pre-mkt trading......taking the futures index up to 2060.....which will send the cash index up to 2067 if this holds.....I suspect that 2075 should be another level of resistance - but anything is possible now.... Eco data today includes Mort Apps which fell by 1%, and the ADP employment report which is due to show an increase of something approaching +195k jobs.....We will be entertained by one FED speaker today.....Chicago's own Charlie Evans.....(an admitted DOVE). He will be on CNBC Squawk box at 8:30 just after the ADP release, he will also be speaking at the Forecasters Club of NY at 1 pm.Remember that this is end of month and qtr...so a rally would do so many people so much good - especially ahead of April 15th....(Tax day)..... Either way -Take Good Care

Stocks chopped as neither the bulls nor the bears made a stand, volume was the lowest so far for 2016, and many global mkts had remained closed for what is known as the Easter Monday Holiday......leaving very little for traders or investors to chomp on......and so the S&P did nothing really other than bounce around moving both north and south of the unchanged line some 20 times - and at the final bell was up 1 pt to close at 2037.The lack of action is more reflective of the uncertainty over the near term direction the 1Q earnings season and the uncertainty over FED policy.....Recall that last week - we saw a revolt within the central bank......on the 16th - Janet assured the world that rates were fine right where they were for now (all the while leaving June as the next launch date).....concern over global macro issues and mkt turmoil had given rise to continued caution in terms of US monetary policy...the mkts loved it and rallied hard exploding thru what should have been more significant resistance at the 200 dma....but on the back of the renewed ECB commitment to stimulus and Janet's commitment to 'lower for longer' - investors/traders went on a buying binge - some to 'get more long' while others scrambled to cover 'short positions' (or those bearish bets) on the future direction of stocks.That took us up and thru resistance only to fail at the 2050 level when the revolt began....5 different members of the FED came out and challenged her publicly....defying the data, ignoring the protocol.....each one suggesting that not only should rates rise - they should do so in April....smack in the middle of what is expected to be a weak earnings season.... the mkts stumbled, unable to advance as confusion set in..... but they did not collapse either - or not yet anyway.....Were these bozo's just testing the water? Were they trying to gauge investor sentiment? Was this all a ploy to divert the conversation away from the broader geo-political issues - ISIS, Brussels, Oil, a weakening Europe, Obama's visit to Cuba and his Tango in Argentina and even the comedic stupidity of the Presidential election as two of the GOP contenders running for the highest office in the country succumb to middle school antics?OK...so today - all mkts are back online and the focus is returning to what should be the drivers of mkt action. Investors and traders returned to their desks after the long weekend and now are focusing on the end of the month action, coming macro data and what Janet will say today when she speaks at the Economic Club of NY at 12:20 pm (est)....Overnight - San Fran's Fed President Williams is the latest to opine on monetary policy this morning.... You see - he is in Singapore - and gave 'prepared remarks' to an audience at the National University there about US monetary policy - because that is important.........and in it he appeared to join in with his fellow bankers while never really committing to any hard and fast date - as he said -"Others' economic fate do now spell our own.....My view is essentially, let's just stay on track. Let's not get sidelined by the noise and distraction commentary can sometimes cause. We're not quite where I'd like us to be, but recent developments have been encouraging and add to my confidence that we're on course to reach our (inflation) goal. Overall the US economy keeps chugging ahead."And so there is another vote for a rate increase - at some point - leaving him squarely 'on the fence' but suggesting that the next move should be UP and not DOWN- as he tried to assuage investor/trader angst.Now eco data this week includes a fair amount of information.....today we get lots of Case Shiller Home Price data......(nothing to get excited about), tomorrow brings us the ADP employment report and expectations are for +195k jobs.....Thursday includes ISM Milwaukee and the Chicago Purchasing Managers report.....on Friday - we get the monthly Non Farm Payroll report - and this time the gov't is promising us an increase of 210k jobs, (How many of those are minimum wage?), they expect unemployment to remain at 4.9% and are looking for average hourly wages to increase by 0.2%. Look for ISM Manf, Construction Spending, Labor Force Participation rates, ISM Prices Paid and ISM New orders. All of this macro data will set the stage for more trader speculation on the next FED move. What do FED Fund Futures say about an April increase?US futures are down 4 pts at 2024.....right now....there is no reason for the mkts to really rally hard at the moment.....but remember it is end of month and end of qtr..so the next couple of days could see increased volumes as portfolio managers 'clean up' ahead of the marking period. I continue to believe that we remain range bound within the 2020/2050 trading bands.The next move will come from the FED and if Janet surprises us and tells us that so much has changed in the last two weeks - and SHE puts April squarely on the table.... then watch for the mkt to test lower.....breaching the 2020 support to test the 1996 support level.I don't expect that she is going to divine the tea leaves for anybody today. It will be more of the same - where she plays the Dove and then releases the boys to contradict her to gauge investor and mkt sentiment. After that - then the mkts will settle in for month/qtr end and then prepare for the coming earnings season....which kicks off the week of April 4th.In Asia - stocks traded with a downside bias on some soft economic data. In Japan - the Unemployment Rate and Retail Sales both missed. Japan -0.18%, Hong Kong +0.1%, China -1.28%, ASX -1.57%,In Europe - stocks are edging higher ahead of Yellen’s speech. The Europeans are not convinced that rates are due to rise in April.....Michael Hewson - Chief Mkt analyst at CMC markets sums it up last week's chatter this way:"What was all the more puzzling was that last week's chatter was completely at odds with the recent dovish narrative of the most recent FOMC meeting"So - sit back and enjoy the show.....remember the mkt is now flat on the year and that is a WIN for many asset managers as we close out the qtr.....I suspect the mkt will hold tight thru Thursday....but then Friday is April 1st and the beginning of a new qtr.....Take Good Care

And the mkts have come roaring back…even the trains, planes and automobiles are joining in on the fun as the Dow Transports (Trannies) are now back in 'official' Bull mkt mode having rallied 22% off of the January lows…..Now Dow Theory tells us that the mkt is in an uptrend when ONE of its averages (the industrials or the trannies) advances above a previous important high….it should then be followed by the other Dow index…Now while the Trannies have not pierced their November highs of 8286 - they have rocketed higher over the past 8 weeks – (as noted up 22%), they have pierced the down trending 200 dma at 7856 and look like they are 'breaking out'..... and appear to be on their way to challenge the November high -Now this is important really – because the Trannies represent the transportation sector of the US economy and its companies are tied to the shipping, rail, and trucking sectors – sectors that 'move stuff around' and send signals about the health of the economy…..now recall – this index got 'clocked' in the early part of the year……after concerns about global growth and a coming US recession caused investors to shift out of this important 'barometer group' - Because slowing global growth and a US recession would negatively impact these companies. And there were some real serious concerns – as investors took some 22% out of the index since late November - but remember simple math works in strange ways....if the index (or a stock or any asset) goes down in value by 22% and then rallies back by 22% - you are still short - you have NOT gone back to 0 - in fact the index needs to rally back 30% just to stay even. So it still has work to do.......The latest move now tells us that investors have changed their minds…..Global Growth Concerns? US Recession? – Bah Humbug……Apparently investors are convinced that the worst is over and they have gone out on a buying spree – scooping up some names for a fraction of their current value. Now the Trannies are trading at about 13 times trailing earnings – or a 32% discount to their 3 yr avg of 19.2 times. So there IS value there IF the supposed improving global macro data is true. A look at some of the participants reveals where investors are placing their bets....UPS (UPS) & FedEx (FDX) - have rocketed higher, piercing their 200 dma's....while , Kansas City Southern (KSU), CSX Corp. (CSX), Kirby Corp. (KEX) are all teasing these key trend lines....Now overnight - global mkts began the week a bit mixed.....There is not a lot of macro data due out this week - so we can expect the mkts to churn and digest the latest moves in this holiday shortened week.......Japan was closed for a holiday and China surged by 2% as investors there focused on loosening margin lending requirements.....Australia came under a bit of pressure as losses in commodities weighed on that mkt.In Europe - those mkts are flat to slightly higher after a weaker opening....There was no material news out to drive the mkts either way - so they churn. FTSE -0.09%, CAC 40 -0.2%, DAX +0.4% , EUROSTOXX +0.12%, SPAIN +0.19% and ITALY +0.83%.Oil once again under pressure as the dollar stabilizes and moves a bit higher....remember - much of the oil action has been dollar driven and more unprecedented global monetary easing has created a currency war but has helped to wipe out the losses suffered since January. Now while it makes everyone feel good - the weak dynamics of the global economy still exist....and with earnings season only 2 weeks away - it will be about the fundamentals once again.....And while the central banks have all created the fire - the latest move is sure to come under some pressure if the fundamentals disappoint..... If the fundamentals do not disappoint - then the conversation returns to FED policy and interest rates. I continue to believe that June will see a small hike of 25 bps - but then nothing more.US futures are flat, the dollar is flat and oil is now down 1% as the day begins.....We only have one data point and this is Existing Home Sales - expectations are for a drop of 2.9% m/m. Atlanta FED's Dennis Lockhart is due to speak today at 12:30 pm - I would not expect him to say anything so significant - as he tends to be Dove and is on the side of the latest FED move. - So if anything - look for him to remain cautious on the outlook.....Now the S&P at 2048 is well above the 200 dma which stands at 2017. In this holiday shortened week - with little eco data to digest - it would not be surprising to see the S&P test what is now support for the mkts. After the most recent rally - the mkt is a bit ahead of itself and some back testing is in order.Take Good Care

There's something for everyone in the vast universe of sector funds, from consumer staples to health care to technology.When a sector is in favor, those funds can rack up big returns. But they can also be prone to bigger declines, since they're more concentrated in specific areas than a diversified fund.IBD ran a screen of actively managed funds with at least $100 million in assets that have beaten their benchmarks in each of the past one, three, five and 10 years. Two sectors were the clear winner: The five best sector funds ranked by 10-year performance all focus on biotech or health sciences. (See our full list of best sector mutual funds.)To highlight the best mutual funds in the top-performing sectors, the "best of the best" list of IBD Best Mutual Funds 2016 Award winners includes the top fund in each of six sectors.Click Here To View A Table Of Top Performing Mutual Funds By CategoryFidelity Select Biotechnology Portfolio (FBIOX) came out on top with a 10-year average annual return of 16.9%, well ahead of the S&P 500's 7.31%. The fund held $9.7 billion in net assets as of Feb. 29. Its expense ratio is 0.74%. Rajiv Kaul has managed the fund since October 2005.Like most sectors, biotech has seen its fair share of volatility. But that's not necessarily a negative."In the next five to 10 years, there's going to be a renaissance for the industry in terms of the golden age of innovation," Kaul told IBD. "It's not going to be in a straight line. Biotech is volatile for investors. That's the amazing opportunity that happens."As of Jan. 31, biotech stocks made up 86% of the portfolio and pharmaceuticals 13%. Fidelity Select Biotech held 277 stocks in all. Top holdings at the end of Q4 included Alexion Pharmaceuticals (ALXN), Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN), Vertex Pharmaceuticals (VRTX), Gilead Sciences (GILD) and Celgene (CELG).All five stocks belong to IBD's biotech industry group, which surged more than 800% from a November 2008 low to its July 2015 peak. Turnover in the fund tends to run fairly low, at about 29%.There are high barriers to entry in the biotech field, including expertise, capital and regulatory hurdles, Kaul points out. "But when you do get a major breakthrough in a medication, you really improve people's lives and help save costs for the health care system."How does Kaul pick stocks for the fund?"You have to understand the management and what is the track record of success," he said. "We have that kind of historical understanding and depth of understanding of the industry and the individual players. Equally important is the ability of these companies to access capital at a low cost. I want my companies to be self-reliant."The five top biotech funds all owned big-cap biotech and Soliris maker Alexion in their recently reported quarters. Four of the five funds also held biotechs Celgene and Gilead, which focus on cancer and hepatitis C, respectively. Generic drug makers tracked by IBD soared more than 900% from March 2009 to July 2015, while ethical drug stocks rallied nearly 750% from March 2009 to August 2015.T. Rowe Price Health Sciences (PRHSX) took second place among biotech funds, with a 10-year return of 16.8%. The fund, which has $11.7 billion in net assets, has been closed to new retail investors since June 2015. As of Feb. 29, the portfolio held 145 stocks. Services accounted for 35% of assets, followed by biotech at 25%, pharmaceuticals at 22%, products and devices at 10%, and life sciences at 6%. Top holdings included Aetna (AET), Alexion Pharmaceuticals, Allergan (AGN), Becton Dickinson (BDX) and Cigna (CI)."Focus on innovative medicines, diagnostics, devices and business models has been the core driver of success," Taymour Tamaddon, who has managed the fund since February 2013, said via e-mail. "Over the past 10 years, strength has been broad-based, with biotech likely having the highest level of performance." The fund's expense ratio is 0.77%.Prudential Jennison Health Sciences (PHLAX), with a 15.8% return over the past 10 years, has been closed to new investors since the end of June 2012. The fund has total net assets of $2.6 billion and an expense ratio of 1.1%. David Chan, Michael Del Balso and Debra Netschert manage the fund.Biotech made up the biggest weighting as of Jan. 31, at 38% of assets. Pharmaceuticals accounted for 30%, health care providers and services were 19%, health care equipment and supplies were 7%, and life sciences tools and services were 3%. The biggest holdings in the 98-stock portfolio included Celgene, BioMarin Pharmaceutical (BMRN), Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY), Shire (SHPG) and Allergan."We remain focused on the longer-term outlook of our fund, which we believe continues to be very positive based on a range of industry trends, from health care reform to the advent of oncology active immune therapy," the managers said in their Jan. 31 fund commentary. "Although the realization of these companies’ values may encounter intermittent setbacks, we believe the market will recognize and reward them over the longer term."Franklin Biotechnology Discovery (FBDIX), with $1.1 billion in total net assets as of Feb. 29, has a 10-year return of 15%. Biotech stocks made up 84% of the portfolio, followed by 13% in pharmaceuticals and nearly 3% in life sciences tools and services."We focus on biotechnology and generally have limited exposure to other areas in health care," Evan McCulloch, senior vice president and lead portfolio manager of the fund, said. "We avoid more traditional large-cap pharmaceuticals companies, which have less favorable growth prospects and do not show the same levels of innovation we see in biotechnology."Celgene, Gilead Sciences, Biogen (BIIB), Amgen (AMGN) and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals were among top positions in the 119-stock fund. The fund, which closed to new investors in July 2014, has an expense ratio of 1%."Overall, we believe there are strong fundamentals underlying the biotechnology sector's recent growth which have also helped our fund," McCulloch said. "Innovation remains very strong, with promising new treatments in areas like immuno-oncology, gene therapy, Alzheimer's disease, GI (gastrointestinal) disorders, central nervous system diseases and others."Rydex Biotechnology (RYOAX) rounds out the top-five sector funds with a 10-year return of 14.7%. The expense ratio is 1.3%. Biotech accounted for 77% of net assets as of Feb. 29, pharmaceuticals 13%, and life sciences tools and services 9%. Top holdings as of March 8 included Gilead, Amgen, Celgene, Biogen and Regeneron.Health care clearly dominated sector funds over the past decade. But which other funds led their respective categories?T. Rowe Price Global Technology (PRGTX), with $2.4 billion in net assets at the end of February, led tech sector funds with a 14.3% 10-year average annual return. Media, semiconductors and software made up the biggest weightings in the 64-stock fund; top holdings included Alphabet (GOOGL), Amazon.com (AMZN) and JD.com (JD). It has a 0.91% expense ratio.Leading the consumer cyclical sector is Fidelity Select Retailing Portfolio (FSRPX), with $1.8 billion in assets as of Feb. 29 and a 10-year average annual return of 14%. The expense ratio is 0.81%. Internet retail, home improvement retail and apparel retail accounted for the top three subindustries at the end of January. Amazon, Home Depot (HD) and Netflix (NFLX) were its top holdings.T. Rowe Price Media & Telecommunications (PRMTX) topped the communications sector with a 13.7% average annual return. The fund had $3.3 billion in net assets as of Feb. 29; its expense ratio is 0.8%. Media, telecom services and software were the three biggest investment areas, with Alphabet, Amazon and American Tower (AMT) among the 79-stock portfolio's recent top holdings.Rydex Consumer Products (RYCIX), with a 10.6% average annual return and a 1.3% expense ratio, led the consumer defensive sector. Food products, beverages and household products accounted for more than half of net assets; Procter & Gamble (PG), Coca-Cola (KO) and Philip Morris International (PM) were recent top holdings.Burnham Financial Services (BURKX), which held $250.1 million in assets, headed the financial sector with a 7.6% average annual return. Yadkin Financial (YDKN), BNC Bancorp (BNCN) and Atlantic Capital Bancshares (ACBI) were among the fund's top holdings as of Jan. 31. The fund's gross expense ratio is 1.64%, and its net expense ratio is 1.8%.

OK - Look - if you put earplugs in your ears and did not read any newspaper and just watched the indexes - you would think that the US economy is firing on all 12 cylinders...I mean you would think that we are pumping out product like crazy, manufacturing was in overdrive, the job mkt was overheating and wages were strong.You would think it was 1989 all over again....Ronald Reagan in the White House, Russia (Formerly the USSR) on the verge of collapse, The Berlin Wall - no longer a wall at all and now a distant memory, GDP was 2.7%, Inflation running at 5%, Unemployment at 5.4%, The FED Prime Rate was 10.5%, The FED Funds Rate was 9.5%, 30 yr fixed rate mortgages were at 10.3% + 2 pts, the S&P was at 341.91 and the Dow was 2,741.22, kids and athletes TIED their own sneakers and rode bikes...... and the country was proud, strong and vibrant.........Now fast forward - take out the earplugs - Ronald Reagan is dead, the USSR is gone per se, but Russia now stands at the precipice of world power, manufacturing is on life support, the Berlin Wall has been sold off in pieces to excited tourists, GDP is 1%, Inflation is 1%, unemployment is 4.9%, The FED Prime Rate is 3.5%, the FED Funds rate is 0.5%, 30 fixed rate mortgages (if you can get one) are 4% , the S&P is now at 2040.59, the Dow is at 17,481 and the country is in despair struggling to breathe and Marty McFly (Back to the Future) is alive and well, bikes have been replaced by hover boards and you don't tie your sneakers any more.....as technology destroys the very core of the American way of life..I mean did you see the NIKE (NKE) news yesterday? "Self Tying Sneakers" or as Mark Parker - CEO explains it - Adaptive Lacing! REALLY? Adaptive Lacing...is powered by an underfoot motor and it"proposes a groundbreaking solution to individual idiosyncrasies in lacing"Did you read that? 'Individual idiosyncrasies in lacing'..... Is it ME??? HELLO????"We've entered a new era of personalized performance....Today, athletes want more than just a dash board, they want a relationship"..... a relationship with what? A SNEAKER?? And the potential market for this product? HUUUUGGGEEEE! I am getting too OLD for this........what happened to the simple life -when kids were kids and they tied their own shoes and played ball in the street and rode their bikes to the playground and stayed there until dusk, went home kissed their mothers, ate dinner, took a bath and did their homework?Stocks rallied, the dollar got crushed, oil exploded up and thru $40/barrel and gold backs off as the message is: "No worries, Be happy"!Yesterday's action erased any memory of the concern, fear and anxiety that has so consumed the global investor/trader since the beginning of the year as the 'central planners' go about doing "God's work" (as Uncle Lloyd so eloquently defined it) to support stocks and commodities going into April 15th........Income tax day....And while the media will credit the rally in crude oil prices as the catalyst for the global stock rally - let's not kid ourselves.....it is the 'dovish' action of the central banks around the world that has ignited the rally and forced this trade......Because WHAT has really changed in terms of the macro data? Nothing at all.....and the fact that all of these 'Harvard educated' central bankers have to keep throwing money at the problem only reveals that the 'black hole' is really just that - A Black Hole - with no bottom in sight......As we have pointed out - the data is pointing lower, corp earnings are due to disappoint, interest rates are flat to negative, the global economy continues to struggle, endless streams of migrants continue to test the human spirit, The euro zone crisis remains deeply unresolved, Britain is facing a key vote as to whether they will remain in the Euro, and Japan is entering its 3rd decade of despair - yet global developed mkts rally like there is NO tomorrow.....It is just another classic central bank "pump (and then dump)" but it is unsustainable given the macro environment......A look back at the charts reveals that nearly every year - the mkt convulses by mid-April, which is when 1Q earnings are released. Forward earnings estimates are going down yet the Dow and S&P are going up in a complete disconnect fashion - can this continue without real growth in our economy?Expect a lot of volatility this year as investors/traders once again re-price the risk from a fundamental perspective but also from an election year perspective. The FED and the Democrats do not want a crash in an election year, especially given that they (we) have spent some $5 tril coupled with the FED’s shift to the left during the Obama years....causing massive distortion of the real economic data. Watch as the FED along with their big bank counterparts remain committed to making sure the mkt stays right in here - at least thru April. But then - when the reality of corp earnings hits - do not be surprised to see another big plunge....because you can only play this game for so long.....without real and definitive growth.US Futures are up another 6 pts at 2036.......Overnight Asian and European mkts are also in the plus column as the rally continues.... ECB member Praet did make more dovish comments overnight saying that the ECB could lower rates further if need be.......so markets will digest yesterday’s rally and prepare for quadruple witching today. Quadruple witching is the simultaneous expiration of 4 sets of options...it usually creates massive volumes on the opening and closings, but does little for the mkts in between. There are not real notable reports this morning but there are 3 Fed speakers: NY's Dudley at 9:00 a.m., Boston's Rosengren at 11:00 a.m. and St Louis's own Bullard at 2:00 p.m. Now all of these will be important if for no other reason than the entertainment factor...but Dudley’s comments will be especially important following Janet's dovish surprise on Wednesday.March Madness continues today with games starting at 12:40pm and going thru 11 pm...in between the open/close - expect much of the chatter to revolve around the brackets...Take good care. Have a great weekend.Take Good Care
