With smoking supposedly on the decline, what is making the tobacco companies still look attractive to investors?The answer is simple, an addictive product gives you the option of stabilizing, or even growing, revenues through price increases. Lower gasoline prices, have also put some more spending money in the pockets of smokers when they stop at the gas station to get their fix. High dividend yields also appeal to the income investor.Reynolds American (RAI) has offered significant capital appreciation in addition to an attractive dividend yield of 3.4%. The stock moved 56.3% in one-year from a breakout at 31.69 in November 2014. The company has a best possible IBD Composite Rating of 99.The three-year annual earnings growth rate for Reynolds, comes in at 9% with an Earnings Stability Factor of 2, where the lower number reflects more stability in the earnings. Three-year annual revenue growth is lower at 6%, but has seen quarterly acceleration in the last four quarters from 5% to 43%.The stock formed a shallow base flat base and attempted a breakout from a 49.66 buy point at the end of January. It immediately faltered over the next couple weeks but closed back above the buy point last week.Altria (MO) also has a high Composite Rating at 95. The numbers are a little weaker for Altria with three-year annual earnings growth of 8% and annual revenue growth of just 1%. Quarterly revenue has been stuck in the single digits for five quarters after coming off of four quarters where quarterly revenue growth was either flat or declining. Altria focuses on the U.S. market for its marketing and distribution of brands such as Marlboro.The stock formed a shallow flat base and stands just below a 61.84 buy point. The dividend yield is 3.7%Philip Morris (PM) takes over where Altria leaves off with the international marketing and distribution of Marlboro and other cigarette brands. Emerging markets are a key area of growth for them where regulations and taxes tend to be less.The stock has the weakest Composite Rating at 84, mostly hindered by an EPS Rating of just 68. However, the stock has the highest dividend yield of the three stocks at 4.4%. The stock is still in the buy range from a recent breakout above a 90.27 buy point.

It's D-Day! Wednesday March 16 – FOMC Rate Decision Day….and the world anxiously awaits word from Janet Yellen over the fate of interest rates in this country…and do not expect it to be a 'barn burner' at all…… – no one expects her to announce a hike in rates…..but as discussed here in prior notes – they will be watching and listening to every word that she utters in the statement/press conference. What will she say? How will she say it? What words did she delete or insert that is different from the last statement? What is her body language telling us? Is April or May a possibility or has she drawn the line in the sand in June? Can she diverge from what other central banks are doing?Remember the twin mandates of the FED –"The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the Federal Open Market Committee shall maintain long run growth of the monetary and credit aggregates commensurate with the economy's long run potential to increase production, so as to promote effectively the goals of maximum employment, stable prices and moderate long-term interest rates." (So it's inflation and employment)So let's talk inflation for a moment – for the past 7 yrs…inflation has been low due to the GFC (Great Financial Crisis) that walloped this country back in 2008…but in December we were told that Core CPI was on the rise which is why the FED raised rates.Now today we will get another read on CPI (Consumer Price Index) and Core CPI (which is EX food and energy) and this has the ability to cause some angst for the FED. If Core CPI is on the move then the hawks will scream that rates need to rise, if it remains under control then the doves will have the upper hand.What will be interesting will be if she ties the recent rise in oil prices to her statement….remember Core CPI is usually defined as EX food and energy – but then again – the definition can change based on who is doing the talking and what they are trying to achieve. So will the nascent rebound in oil prices over the past 3 weeks (up 35%) give Janet a reason to become 'concerned' and suggest that rising oil prices present an issue……..(read inflation) which would then give her a reason to suggest that she needs to 'get out in front' of it by raising rates? Remember - Economists always seem to use the definition that best fits the story.And now employment? They tell us that unemployment (U3) is running at 4.9% the lowest it has been in years and now essentially below their 5% target – so from that measure they have succeeded – but again – that depends on what definition you use – because if you use U6 – then unemployment/underemployment is still at 9.9%....a vastly different number.So yesterday stocks were just a bit weak on the back of the weak eco data (Retail Sales), weaker oil prices (down 2.3%), another 'Super Tuesday' primary voter day in the race for the White House (GOP continues to make a mockery of the process while Bernie professes the benefits of a Socialist State), a deteriorating economy, weaker corp earnings and the general sense of angst over the future of interest rates were all factors that cast a pall over the mkts. The choppiness of the last few days only highlighting the resistance at S&P 2020 that we have discussed.I think what the FED really wanted was for the mkt to pierce the 200 dma to the upside – which would have caused the algo's to run wild and initiate BUY orders which then would have appeared to change the psyche….but that did not happen. The technical downtrend remains firmly in place….and my guess is that no matter what she says today – is not going to be viewed as bullish enough to cause the mkts to rally even more. If anything – her comments may cause the mkts to test lower and see if the bulls are going to defend the position. If they do – then that means that they are ready for a hike – if they don't then it's back to the drawing board. Note that FED FUNDS Futures are still not convinced that we will get 1 never mind 2 hikes this year at all.S&P futures are essentially flat this morning as the mkt waits. I would not expect much in the way of action for the broader mkt until we get closer to 2 pm. I continue to see 2020 as resistance with S&P 2000 as near term support – a break below here will send us to 1975. Remember – in the end it's about the body language……so pay attention to the signals that Janet is giving.Take Good Care
KP

Stocks rose for a 4th week in a row! Another jump in oil prices (due to rapidly declining production & rig count numbers) coupled with a new analysis of the latest ECB stimulus program ignited the latest rally which was led not only by energy stocks, but also by the financials – and that makes some sense – because when the buying starts – expect the underperformers (financials & Energy) to outperform on a strictly ‘trading basis’. Once the fundamentals start to disappoint those underperformers will go back to being ‘those underperformers’.So get this: Joe Davis – Chief Economist at Vanguard had this to say about the rally:“The gains are an acknowledgement that the past recessionary fears were somewhat overstated”So let me ask you something - this guy thinks that Friday’s rally is about past recessionary fears?HELLO???? Hey buddy turn on the TV - The ECB announced another ‘BAZOOKA’ stimulus program and NOT because they are hitting the cover off the ball - but because they are afraid that their recession may turn into another depression.Now just an FYI - the Germans are not happy with Uncle Mario (Draghi) and the latest move by the ECB. Surely the southern nations welcome the move - bank stocks in Italy, Greece and Spain rocketed higher on the news.....But the northern nations (read: GERMANY) are not happy at all.....German finance minister concerned that a 'one size fits all monetary policy ' will do nothing but undermine the German economy, investments, insurance and retirement plans.Oil prices which have rallied some 45% off the lows are only recovering from the slaughtering that they have taken because that slaughtering has resulted in major layoffs and massive cuts in the number of producing oil rigs – Last week the IEA (International Energy Agency) did tell us that the price of oil may have bottomed out due to lower output from the US and other NON-OPEC producers. (So calls for $20/barrel are no longer the rallying cry at GS - in fact - Let's see what they do now......will $50/barrel be the new $20?)So the perception is that rising oil prices must mean that the economy is turning around......think again....oil is moving higher because the massive cuts in production suggest that supply will diminish and if those rigs remain offline then current demand will begin to outstrip supply (basic Econ 101 – the Supply/Demand Equation). Now while the oil surplus may be easing - crude inventories are still at 80 yr highs - so don't expect any supply shortages just yet..... - Iranian production is expected to rise in the coming months and do not discount the cost savings that the major US producers have imposed after the 70% collapse in prices resulted in major cost overhauls.Chevron (CVX) is a perfect example. They have 16 rigs in the Texan Permian Basin that are due to come online by year end and CEO John Watson tells us that"We think that those wells that are being drilled will be economic at the kinds of low prices that we are seeing today"He went to say that some of those wells will make money at prices below $50/barrel and some at even below $30/barrel. Note that Oil closed at $38.50 on Friday.Next: The FED is on hold about what to do with rates – go up or go negative (precisely because of our stagnating economy) joining a large part of the world that now offers ‘negative interest rates’ – recall that the ECB lowered rates to -0.4% last week. Currency wars are breaking out again as individual nations protect themselves......here at home we continue to create minimum wage jobs to replace those higher paying jobs that we are losing on a monthly basis. The underemployment rate (U6) is still closer to 10% and this guy thinks that the rally is an acknowledgement that past recessionary fears were somewhat overstated? (Where do I send my resume?)I would argue that the move on Friday was due to a technical ‘break out’ rather than any change in fundamentals… I mean look – the mkt got off to a bad start this year…..the collapse in oil prices caused many of the sovereign wealth funds to hit the SELL button – unloading massive amounts of equities in order to raise cash with little regard to price - sending the mkts into a tailspin – artificially knocking them out whack – forcing some money managers to choke while others backed up the truck unafraid of the waves of sell orders.This – as we know – caused global mkts to tremor -sending some into BEAR mkt territory while others managed to remain in CORRECTION territory. Global Mkts suffered massive technical damage – and needed time to repair. Now yes – there is still concern about the health of the global economy as there will always be – but the action on Friday and the past couple of weeks has been all about central bank action and rebounding oil prices. I beg to differ with the fine gentleman from Vanguard – this is NOT about the overstated recessionary fears at all. Those fears existed before and continue to exist - the move is about technical's.Recall my comments from Friday morning’s note”"US futures are screaming higher....currently up 18 pts taking us right back to where exactly? S&P 2000 - Which is the 3rd time in 6 days that we have done so.....This could be key..... If futures remain strong then the S&P cash will open in the 2009 range - its 3rd time as well - giving it the momentum it needs to challenge the down trending 200 dma at 2020. I would not be surprised at all to see today be the day that traders take the mkt higher as the bull looks to take control of the situation yet again."And so it was written……The S&P broke out of its most recent resistance level – the 100 dma and went ahead to test the next significant ‘technical resistance level’ – the 200 dma at 2020. Expect mkts to now digest and churn – unable to pierce this down trending resistance line - until we get some catalyst that CHANGES the conversation.......What will that be?Will it be the latest word from the FED on Wednesday at 2 pm? Now while Janet is expected to leave rates unchanged – the devil is in the details – Rates are not going up now, but the sense is that they are going higher in June. How will she say it? What words will she change from the January statement? Will she make note of the 'explosive rise' in the price of oil as a reason to 'get ahead of the inflation monster'? Expect Jon Hilsenrath- Chief Economic Correspondent at the WSJ otherwise known as ‘Deep Throat’ - to give you his blow by blow analysis – you see – he says what she can't say - and this way she gets to test the mkts reaction. Oh the intrigue and drama of it all.....….It’s so Frank Underwood…..After the FED announcement - investors will look for the fundamentals to play the supporting role…This week is full of US macro data points and with only 3 weeks to go before the start of earnings season – investors have to ask: Will earnings surprise or disappoint? (We have already seen an increase in the number of 'downgrades'). Will forward guidance be positive or negative? Is the S&P fairly valued based on these data points? Is the talk of recession no longer the subject of so many cocktail parties?This morning we see global mkts all higher - playing catch up with Friday's action.....US futures are now down 3 pts.....(not surprising). For the immediate future - my sense is that the short trading range is now 1998/2020. No eco data today, but tomorrow we get Retail Sales exp of -0.1%, Ex autos and Gas of +0.2%, PPI of -0.2% but ex food and energy of +0.1%, Empire State Manf of -11.50 (that would UP from -16.64). Later in the week look for Housing Starts, Mort Apps, Building Permits , CPI and CPI ex food and energy, Ind Prod, Cap Utilization and the FOMC RATE DECSION (Wed at 2 pm). You can feel the anticipation building....In the end – the mkt is now down 1% this year and still off some 5% from 2015 highs of 2134. This rally back to flat is probably where we should have been all along before the Sovereigns puked....so let's see what's next..... A decisive break ABOVE 2020 - will unleash the bulls......as there is not real resistance until we get back into the 2075/2100 range.....But any indication that rates are going higher in June will surely cause traders to re-think their strategy while the long term investor continues to look for the value.....

Some investors seek out high-octane growth stocks with the potential for big, fast gains. Others prefer slower, steadier companies that offer dividends and can be held for the longer term.The Income Investor column is almost tailor-made for the slow but steady crowd -- almost, because some fast-growth companies are also featured in the column from time to time.Each day, Income Investor (in today's IBD on page B9) highlights one or more companies that not only pay steady dividends but also meet key fundamental and technical criteria. The accompanying Dividend, Utility and REIT Leaders screens next to the column in IBD offers plenty of ideas, while the six minicharts above the lists provide detail about those stocks.Dividend Leaders, the broadest screen, shows names such as AT&T (T), Merck (MRK) and Philip Morris (PM) making the screen lately, thanks to their steady earnings track record and dependable dividends. Other younger tech stocks recently on the list include Cisco Systems (CSCO) and Microchip Technology (MCHP).Utility Leaders are often considered as defensive plays. When the broader market is ailing and growth stocks are getting hit, utilities tend to hold up well. Income investors can also count on a steady dividend due to utilities' reliable revenue streams. That's why utilities have topped IBD's ranking of 197 industry groups during the recent market volatility.REIT Leaders, the last screen, also offer a relative safe haven in a rocky market. Real estate investment trusts are set up in such a way that they can avoid paying corporate taxes if they pass the majority of their profits on to shareholders. They do so in the form of dividends, which is why many income investors also like REITs.While a slow economy can hurt these businesses as well, REITs also have a fairly steady revenue stream since they collect rent payments and lease proceeds from buildings or other real assets they own and operate. Due to their tax structure, they pay out most of their profits in the form of cash dividends.Keep in mind that even utility and REIT stocks can sink rapidly when the stock market goes into a deep decline. That's exactly what happened during the 2008-2009 bear decline. From July 2008 to March 2009, the Dow utility average fell 45%. So in severe situations, losses in every stock must be cut short and cash must be raised.The three screens provide annualized dividend yields and long-term dividend growth rates for each company, in the last two columns of each list. From there, investors can decide which ones they would like to research further. Most of these stocks won't look like the typical high-growth companies that are setting up for a breakout, but it's usually better to be buying and holding them when the long-term trend is up.AT&T has outperformed the market recently. The telecom giant has rallied 8% this year, after edging 2% higher in 2015. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 were both slightly underwater last year and down 6% this year. AT&T, a S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrat, tops the Dividend Leaders list with a 5.24% yield, well above the S&P 500's average payout of 2.26%.

Reynolds American's (RAI) fourth-quarter sales surged more than expected, aided by its recently acquired Newport brand and higher prices.Revenue jumped 43% in Q4 to $3.05 billion. Wall Street expected $3.04 billion. Earnings per share minus one time items grew 9.1% to 48 cents, 2 cents below consensus.In July 2015, Reynolds agreed to buy Lorillard for $27.4 billion.The tobacco company guided for 2016 EPS to $2.25-$2.35, with the midpoint is below analyst views for $2.34. Reynolds also raised its dividend 16.7% to an annualized rate of $1.68.Nomura analyst Owen Bennett said Reynolds is the best growth story in the tobacco space, and chances are good it will top its own guidance."Given the company is likely to remain cautious early on in the year, then the top end of guidance can be seen as encouraging," Bennett said in a report.Reynolds American shares closed up 2.2%. Reynolds stock has a 99 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed at least 99% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth. It briefly rose above 50 on Feb. 1 to an all-time high before consolidating.Reynolds said Thursday that its U.S. cigarette volume rose 33.6% in Q4, driven in part by the addition of the Newport brand. Industry cigarette volume declined 0.5% during the quarter, and fell 0.1% for the full year, the company said. Reynolds expects the industry to return to its traditional 2% to 3% shrinkage in 2016.Last week, Philip Morris International (PM), which sells Chesterfield, Lark and Marlboro cigarettes outside of the U.S., reported a 21.4% drop in EPS and 11% slide in revenue. The company also forecast a third straight drop in full year 2016 earnings. Shares fell 1% Thursday.Altria (MO) on Jan. 28 reported slightly higher Q4 profit as its flagship Marlboro brand grew retail sales for a fourth year in a row, and announced layoff plans to cut costs. Altria dipped 0.1% Thursday.

Philip Morris International (PM) sees 2016 earnings falling further after declines in 2015 and 2014.The maker of Chesterfield, Lark and global No. 1 seller Marlboro cigarette brands forecasts its full-year earnings per share to be $4.25-$4.35 at current exchange rates, down from $4.42 in 2015 and well below consensus of $4.52.That would follow drops of 12% in 2015 and 7% in 2014.Shares of Philip Morris closed down 0.9% on the stock market today. Among other large tobacco companies, Altria (MO) lost 0.6%, British American Tobacco (BTI) fell 1.75% and Reynolds American (RAI) dipped 1%.In Q4, Philip Morris' adjusted earnings fell 21.4% to 81 cents, in line with analysts' expectations. Unfavorable currency rates had an 18-cent impact in the quarter.Revenue dropped 11% to $6.39 billion, below consensus for $6.49 billion and the the fifth straight quarter of declines, as its cigarette shipment volume fell 2.4%, excluding acquisitions.The decline was largest in Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Africa, where revenue plunged 19% to $1.72 billion. The company doesn't sell in the U.S. since it was spun off from former parent Altria, which operates Philip Morris USA, in 2008.The Philip Morris namesake brand was its top gainer, as volume grew 20.2% to 9.8 billion cigarettes. Despite new packaging and marketing, its Marlboro brand saw a weak 0.7% rise to 71.8 billion units.Chief Executive Andre Calantzopoulos said efforts to develop electronic cigarettes and other cigarette alternatives picked up steam.“We continued to make exciting progress on the development, assessment and commercialization of our Reduced-Risk Products," he said. "We significantly expanded the roll-out of iQOS (smokeless cigarette) in Japan and introduced it into several new markets."

It was a SUPER TUESDAY in America.....March came in like a LION as global investors grabbed for anything that wasn't nailed down and......Some would have you believe it was a MAGA (Make America Great Again) rally.....I say - 'not so fast cowboy.....it ain't over until the fat lady sings......'Voters went to the polls to try and cull the Presidential field......Democrats pulling for Hill as she looks to be the anointed leader of that party (although Sanders has not conceded, but should) .....while the GOP is still struggling trying to find their next leader......The Donald would have you believe it is him as he continues to cause earthquakes every time he opens his mouth and now that it looks like he could really snatch it - the calls from the GOP establishment get louder and louder to STOP him.......as the party spins out of control.............. Kasich and Carson barely registered on the Richter scale while Teddy and Marco cause tremors across the nation .....tremors yes, but a real quake - not so much.......but they are not giving up so easy - vowing to take this fight to the convention in what would is known as a 'contested convention'.....the Democrats would LOVE this to happen.....as it just confirms that the GOP is a mess......[A contested convention (or brokered convention) is a situation where no one single candidate has secured the required number of delegates to be the clear front runner - so the process then goes to 'political horse trading' at the summer convention......At the convention - if there still is no clear candidate then all of the delegates are released from their prior pledges and the slate is wiped clean. And the 'brokering' or 'horse trading' begins anew....after a couple of winks, some promises and a handshake - the party chairman calls for a new vote of the delegates. It is then hoped that this will result in a clear winner as a majority of delegates rally around one candidate....The interesting thing here is that a brokered convention does not necessarily reflect the will of the people and could end up being more divisive rather than inclusive - and then we will be saying congratulations to President Rodham- Clinton (again)]And as far as the mkts go - it was a Super Tuesday for stocks as well....Stocks around the world rallied hard.... In the US - all of the indices broke up and thru resistance....and in a vote of confidence - OIL also made history as investors in that asset class took WTI (West Texas Intermediate) up and thru its resistance as well to end the day at $34.44/barrel.....The excitement started early.....Global mkts were on fire after NY FED's Dudley made very dovish comments overnight (Monday evening in NY, Tuesday morning in Asia) in China - concerning US interest rate policy and the PBoC (Peoples Bank of China) announced more stimulus - after a very disappointing manufacturing PMI report - Couple that with expectations of more ECB action as Europeans continue to struggle with what their future looks like......and we got a massive global rally.......Germany’s DAX shot up 2.3%, France’s CAC-40 added 1.2%, and the broader Eurostoxx Index added 1.7%.....Here at home - stocks came out of the gate strong and finished even stronger......The Dow closed up 2.1%, The S&P tacked on 2.4%, Nasdaq rallied 2%, the Russell 2000 +2% ......and so the story continues.....Central banks are at it again.....jawboning to pump up prices— They have spent a great deal of effort in changing the narrative for oil, for stocks, and for the economy - trying to drive up prices for stocks as we enter the final month of the 1st qtr.Now March came in 'like a lion - but will it go out like a lamb' as the saying goes?Overnight the excitement continues.....Japan rallies 4% as news that the Japanese gov't pension fund - (GPIF) - the largest fund in the world with some $1.2 trillion dollars may put some $47 bil to work in the Japanese mkt after the recent beating it took......Other mkts in the region jumped on board for the ride.....Hong Kong rallies 3%, China +4.1% and Australia + 2%. Now Moody's tried to throw cold water on the party by cutting the Chinese country's credit rating outlook to NEGATIVE from stable...but that was not successful at all.... Investors thumbed their nose at Moody's reminding them that they are always late to the party....and that their track record of protecting investors is suspect - think Great Financial Crisis of 2007-2016.....In Europe - mkts there are in rally mode - but not nearly as excited as the rest of the world at the moment...They seem to be in digesting mode after all of the excitement.....as they continue to speculate on the next move by Uncle Mario and the ECB...FTSE -0.34%, CAC 40 + 0.16%, DAX + 0.4%, EUROSTOXX +0.45%, SPAIN +0.8% and ITALY +0.83%This morning - US futures are taking a breather...currently down 4 pts....which is completely understandable...and I would not be surprised to see us back off and test support at the 50 dma....which is now 1940.....We don' t have too, but it would not be a surprise at all, before the next attempt to pierce S&P 2000. Oil is also backing off a bit and has now once again broken thru support - as it is down 0.68 cts...at $33.72/barrel....in what I think is a test to shake out the weakest links before a move higher once again.San Fran Fed's Williams is due to speak today at 10 am est.Eco data today includes ADP employemnt - exp of +190k.....Mortgage Apps came in at minus 4.8% and that makes sense after the pending home sales number on Monday......Fed's Beige Book due at 2 pm.Now with the official results still being counted - it does look like Hillary and Donald took the majority of the delegates last night so the momentum builds. The mkt will now start to pay more attention to the battle as analysts/strategists position themselves for what both a Rodham-Clinton Presidency and Trump Presidency would look like....Will Janet and the FED will fade to black as the investors ponder the political landscape? After yesterday - talk of the pace and timing of rate hikes once again grew louder....but March for all intents and purposes is off the table - June is the next opportunity for any rate hike and then December if at all...so maybe we get 50 bps in 2016, but for sure we will not get 100 bps and maybe that is part of the reason to celebrate......Take Good Care

When the economy is entering a recession, stocks in consumer staples, health care and telecoms "are the best places to hide," said Barclays' Jonathan Glionna, who names tobacco giants Philip Morris International (PM) and Reynolds American (RAI) and drug giants Merck (MRK) and Pfizer (PFE).Meanwhile, he includes General Electric (GE) among the stocks to buy for a recovery.He doesn't see a recession in the near term, but there are red flags such as the collapse of oil prices, the 10% retreat in the S&P 500 so far this year and slowing growth in global No. 2 economy China.In a report Monday, Glionna joined a growing number of analysts providing lists of recession-resistant stocks. But he took a slightly different tack from others, offering two lists: a Recession Playbook and a Recovery Playbook.Among other top picks on his Recession Playbook are Campbell Soup (CPB), Coca-Cola (KO), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Procter & Gamble (PG) and Hormel Foods (HRL).Philip Morris stock closed up 0.3% Tuesday, and Reynolds American, the maker of Camel cigarettes, added 1.3%. Merck gained 0.7%, and Pfizer rose 1.9%. Campbell Soup climbed 1.7%, while Johnson & Johnson and Procter & Gamble ended flat.Glionna said of his Recovery Playbook: "The best performing sectors in previous periods of economic recovery -- using the exit of a recession as indicative of a recovery -- have been energy, materials, industrials and consumer discretionary."Among stocks on that list: Ford Motor (F), General Electric, General Motors (GM), Harley-Davidson (HOG) and Viacom (VIA).Ford ended down 2%, and GM lost 2.8% Tuesday. GE ticked up 0.4%. Harley-Davidson fell 1.5%, and Viacom plunged more than 21% on worse-than-expected results for the December-ended quarter.Meanwhile, Cowen analysts put out their own list of recession stocks Tuesday, saying, "We believe stocks that appeal to the low-end consumer and have minimal global exposure appear well-suited to weather an economic downturn."Among their top picks: off-price clothing retailer Ross Stores (ROST) and Wal-Mart Stores (WMT).Ross Stores climbed 2.25%, and Wal-Mart fell 1.6%.

U.S. stock indexes stumbled in afternoon trading Thursday, as the major indexes sank further under their 50-day moving averages and approaching their Tuesday intraday lows.X The Dow Jones industrial average led the losers with a 2.5% dent. The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 followed, scrapping off 2.4% and 2.2%, respectively.Volume in the stock market today was running lower on the NYSE but higher on the Nasdaq vs. the same time in the previous session.Most leaders were losing ground, and a few suffered chart damage. Chip equipment maker Ichor Holdings (ICHR) dived more than 14% as it pierced its 200-day moving average line in heavy volume. The small-cap stock had already triggered a sell signal after it fell more than 8% from its 33.09 buy point.After Wednesday's close, Ichor reported a 40% earnings gain in Q4 on a 39% jump in revenue.Among 197 industry groups, the chip equipment group has fallen from No. 25 about two months ago to 93 going into Thursday's session.Chart damage also was apparent for apparel maker Canada Goose (GOOS). The small-cap stock gapped down 16% before finding support at its 50-day line.Canada Goose fell despite reporting a 38% increase in earnings and 27% in revenue in fiscal Q3 ended in December. The Street is expecting fiscal 2018 earnings to drop 34%.In the S&P 500, cigarette maker Philip Morris (PM) led with a 2% gain.In the Dow Jones industrial average, Apple (AAPL) was among the better performers with a fraction loss. Apple is trading near its 200-day line after losing the 50-day line Jan. 25.Meanwhile, the Innovator IBD 50 Fund (FFTY) dropped 3.4% in above-averag volume. The exchange-traded fund tracks the IBD 50. Innovator IBD 50 gained 37% in 2017, but is down 5% so far this year, approaching its 200-day line.RELATED:Stocks Dive, But S&P 500 Earnings Beating Estimates By Most In YearsCanada Goose: Good News, Bad ReactionHow To Use The 50-Day Moving AverageNew Buys By Top Funds

Stocks reversed lower Tuesday, with the Nasdaq composite ending with a 0.2% loss as Nvidia (NVDA) and other chip stocks sharply pared their gains.X The tech-heavy index rallied as much as 0.9% intraday. But PowerShares QQQ Trust (QQQ) held a 0.1% gain to lead major index ETFs, while SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) gave up 0.4% and SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) fell 0.45%.Small caps underperformed with iShares Core S&P Small-Cap (IJR) down nearly 1.1% and iShares Russell 2000 (IWM) losing 1%.Among sector funds in the stock market today, chips and technology bucked the downtrend. VanEck Vectors Semiconductor (SMH) finished flat and iShares PHLX Semiconductor (SOXX) edged 0.1% higher. Component stock Nvidia, up as much as 3% intraday, trimmed its gain to 0.6%. Applied Materials (AMAT) showed similar action; Broadcom (AVGO) reversed to a 0.7% loss.The biggest losers included banks, homebuilders and metals miners. IShares U.S. Home Construction (ITB) and SPDR S&P Homebuilders (XHB) fell nearly 2% each. Toll Bros. (TOL) gapped down and sank 7% after reporting lower-than-expected quarterly results.Bitcoin Investment Trust (GBTC) hit a new high before diving 14%. Bitcoin prices got closer to the $12K level and were recently trading around $11,800. CBOE Global Markets (CBOE) will start trading Bitcoin futures on Dec. 10 and CME Group (CME) on Dec. 18.If you like Coca-Cola (KO), Procter & Gamble (PG), Wal-Mart (WMT) and other blue chips, as well as market-beating dividends, here's a fund for you.With the Dow Jones industrial average trading near record highs, perhaps it's no wonder a consumer staples ETF is getting close to a possible breakout.Consumer Staples Select Sector SPDR (XLP) is shaping the right side of a cup base with a potential buy point at 57.46, or a dime above the left-side high. It's logged six consecutive up days through Monday. Shares climbed 3% after a prior cup-with-handle breakout in April to their June 5 high.The fund, which will mark its 19th anniversary Dec. 16, has amassed $8.4 billion in assets. As its name implies, XLP tracks the Consumer Staples Select Sector Index. Companies in the index include food and drug retailers, food and beverage producers, household and personal products makers and tobacco firms.Consumer defensive stocks accounted for nearly 96% of assets as of Dec. 1, according to Morningstar Direct, while health care names made up the remaining 4%. Three of its top 10 holdings were Dow component stocks: Procter & Gamble, Coca-Cola and Wal-Mart Stores. Wal-Mart, up 40% year to date through Monday, has outpaced the broader market by a wide margin. Coca-Cola has gained 10%; P&G is up 9%. Wal-Mart has been trading near record highs since an 11% gap-up move Nov. 16 on an earnings beat and upbeat holiday-quarter guidance.Among other top names in the fund, Costco Wholesale (COST) has climbed 18% this year. Colgate-Palmolive (CL) and Philip Morris International (PM) are up 14% apiece.IBD'S TAKE: On the lookout for ETF ideas that may be worth a closer examination? Check out IBD's weekly ETF Leaders column for a featured fund and a list of highly rated ETFs.XLP has returned 11.8% year to date as of Dec. 1, trailing the S&P 500's 20.3% advance. Its posted average annual returns of 12.6%,  9.8% and 9.7%, respectively, over the past five, 10 and 15 years vs. the benchmark index's 15.6%, 8.2% and 9.3% gains for those same periods.The ETF offers an annualized dividend yield of 2.6%, above the S&P 500's average 1.8% payout. The expense ratio is 0.14%.RELATED:Disney, Banks Rally, But Nvidia Sinks; Ready For Bitcoin Futures?Stocks Fall On Flynn's Russia Plea Deal, But Bitcoin ReboundsStocks Rally As Apple, Nvidia Bounce Back; What's Bitcoin Up To?

It was bizarre watching KABC TalkRadio in Los Angeles — my hypocritical ex-employer — hold a televised news conference. It turns out that one of the station's news anchors, Leeann Tweeden, claims Sen. Al Franken groped her. In 2006, Tweeden said, before Franken became a senator, he and she participated in a USO tour to entertain the troops in the Middle East.But, claims Tweeden: "(Franken) repeated that actors really need to rehearse everything and that we must practice the kiss. I said 'OK' so he would stop badgering me. We did the line leading up to the kiss and then he came at me, put his hand on the back of my head, mashed his lips against mine and aggressively stuck his tongue in my mouth."I immediately pushed him away with both of my hands against his chest and told him if he ever did that to me again I wouldn't be so nice about it the next time."I walked away. All I could think about was getting to a bathroom as fast as possible to rinse the taste of him out of my mouth."I felt disgusted and violated."Why was the KABC news conference about Franken's misconduct bizarre?Only a few years earlier, the same KABC radio executive who arranged the Tweeden news conference fired me for calling out the blatant left-wing hypocrisy over allegations not just of groping but of rape. I dared insist that the allegations made against President Bill Clinton by Juanita Broaddrick — who claims that she was raped by Bill Clinton and that then, two weeks after the rape, Hillary Clinton verbally intimidated the alleged rape survivor — should have been taken seriously. "No one cares about this issue," said the very same KABC exec now allegedly incensed over the groping allegation against Franken. As for Broaddrick, the executive screamed, she is "old news," as, he insisted, were Bill and Hillary's treatment of multiple accusers. He burst into my radio studio, with the show in progress, and literally yelled at me for pounding an "irrelevant" topic. Shortly before I got fired, the executive sent this letter to my agent:"I point out that from 3:15 pm to almost 4 o'clock, Larry is AGAIN talking about Kathleen Willey, Juanita Broderrick (sic), Monica Lewinsky, Paula Jones and somehow linking Hillary Clinton and James Carville to Bill Clinton being a rapist and sexual harasser. This line of discussion is repeated and repeated, day after day. It is neither timely or relevant to today — though I assume Larry thinks it is in some way. It is my opinion that the sheer volume of instances — sometimes multiple times a day — where he brings this old, arcane topic up is very detrimental to the ratings. While there are literally scores of current, important and compelling stories, Larry is talking, again, about an issue from over 20 years ago. For the better part of an hour. Please let me know if you have some idea of how to get it to cease, short of embargoing mentions of the names above. ... It was my understanding that Larry was going to stop by and see me. He has not."XIt isn't enough to criticize Bill and Hillary Clinton — so-called advocates for women — for their hypocrisy. What about ABC News' "chief anchor," George Stephanopoulos, who helped set up the "war room" to respond to allegations made by women against Clinton? Stephanopoulos, then a top aide to presidential candidate Bill Clinton, even said, "Bill Clinton has no character problem." How does a partisan like Stephanopoulos, who consistently defended Clinton's behavior and blamed the "Republican attack machine," become the "chief news anchor" of anything, let alone of ABC News? If, at last, much of the country is reassessing their opinion of Bill and Hillary Clinton, what about enablers like Stephanopoulos?What about media executives, like the one I once worked for, who downplayed the hypocrisy and, in his case, actively attempted to squash any discussion of it? What about these media enablers? Comedian Chelsea Handler recently tweeted: "Imagine being molested by an older man. Then that man denies ever doing it and then goes on and gets elected to United States Senate. What kind of message does that send to young girls everywhere? And men to all the men who abuse women?"Juanita Broaddrick tweeted back: "I can imagine. I was raped by the Arkansas AG who then becomes Governor & President and NBC held my interview explaining the rape until after his impeachment hearing. But I'm sure you don't want to go there." Handler apologized: "You are right and I apologize to you for not knowing your story. Democrats along with Republicans and the rest of the world's political parties all need to do better and respect the firsthand accounts of victims. I believe you."Why did Handler not know her story? Blame media decision-makers who ignored or downplayed this issue — and even threatened the careers of those who dared call out the hypocrisy.RELATED:Hollywood Moralists Exposed As HypocritesFLASHBACK: Obama Admin Protected Sex Offender, Helping Re-electionHollywood Harassment Scandal Now Envelops Amazon And TwitterClick here for more Commentary and Opinion from Investor's Business Daily.Want to make more money in the stock market? Start with IBD University.

Major stock indexes were slightly lower near midday Wednesday on the eve of the Thanksgiving holiday, but Apple (AAPL) continued to warm investors' hearts as it recouped more of its moderate losses seen over the prior week and a half. Shares rose nearly 1% to 174.36 in active trading.That extends Apple's gain from its latest breakout from a new cup with handle at 160.97 to 8%, so it's out of the proper buy zone for now. The 5% chase zone goes up to 169.02.XMeanwhile, banking shares continued to show good action this quarter, with a new breakout coming from New England-based Meridian Bancorp (EBSB). Shares bolted more than 2% higher to 20.42, rising past a 20.25 buy point in a long cup with handle.Meridian is a thinly traded small cap with an average daily volume of 181,000 shares over the past 50 sessions.At 1 pm ET in New York, the Nasdaq edged less than 1 point lower, keeping virtually all of Tuesday's solid 1.1% advance. At 6864, the tech-rich composite index holds a 5.7% gain since Oct. 1.The S&P 500 eased nearly 0.1%, and the Dow Jones industrial average is off 0.2%. Small caps fell by a similar amount, with the S&P SmallCap 600 down 0.1%.Volume was running sharply lower vs. the same time Tuesday on both main exchanges. The stock market will be closed Thursday and open until 1 p.m. ET on Friday.Apple has done very well for long-view-minded investors over the past year. As repeatedly noted in IBD's Stock Market Today column late last year and early in 2017, the iPhone, iPad and digital services titan broke out of a first-stage cup-with-handle base on Jan. 6-9, rising past a 118.12 buy point.Volume came in a little higher than normal in a few up days over the next three weeks, then gushed higher on Feb. 1 after Apple reported a solid turnaround in quarterly results (fiscal Q4 profit up 2% to $3.36 a share, halting a three-quarter streak of year-over-year losses, and revenue up 3%).The gain from that first-stage bottoming base has now reached 49% to a new all-time high of 176.24.Apple has certainly delivered on the fundamentals over that period. Growth has accelerated. After that 2% rise in earnings, Apple has posted EPS increases of 11%, 18% and 24% on revenue gains of 5%, 7% and 12%. Growth is expected to continue accelerating.While no sell signals have triggered for investors who bought on the January breakout or have even larger capital gains, Apple at one point will be vulnerable to a correction, just like the greater market itself. When this occurs, expect the megacap tech to test support at its long-term 200-day moving average, currently near 152.A big collapse through that 200-day line would likely mean that a significant new base-building period is in the works. See the 200-day moving average painted in black on a MarketSmith daily chart. The 200-day line tracks the average closing price for a stock over the past 200 trading sessions, or roughly equivalent to 10 months. A rising 200-day line means the overall long-term price trend is up.While institutions are clearly bullish about the current fundamentals in Apple, some are expressing concern over the company's ability to keep raising the cash payout.Alex Crooke, head of global equity and income strategies at Janus Henderson, notes that Apple likely has had to raise debt in order to pay the dividend since the company is not making any move to repatriate profits from overseas businesses. Indeed, long-term debt vs. shareholder equity has gone up to a still manageable 73% in FY 2017 (ended in September) vs. 45% in FY 2015."The margins might stay up, but the (dividend and profit) growth rate may moderate," Crooke told IBD, adding that he sees some limitations in the volume sales for the latest iPhone X, which can cost more than $1,000 per handset.The Street sees strong growth in FY 2018 (ending in September), with earnings jumping 24% to $11.44 a share on a 20% leap in sales to $274.3 billion. A 24% EPS pickup would be the strongest increase since a 43% bulge to $9.22 a share in FY 2015.For FY 2019, the estimates are 5% EPS growth and 2% revenue growth, but keep in mind that Wall Street analysts tend to be very conservative with forecasts that far out into the future.Crooke manages the Bankers Investment Trust, a closed-end fund started in 1888 and currently traded on the London Stock Exchange. The fund is on track to achieve 51 years in a row of increasing dividends paid to fund holders. Apple was the second largest holding in the $1.2 billion fund, according to data as of Oct. 31. Total return over the past five years is 123.3%.Apple paid a quarterly cash dividend of 63 cents a share on Nov. 16. The stock has a 1.5% annualized yield, below the 1.9% yield for the S&P 500.On IBD Stock Checkup, the SMR Rating for Apple is currently at a top-notch A on a scale of A to E and signifies leadership in terms of sales, profit margins, and return on equity.Going back to Meridian, the handle in Meridian's base began with a decline on Oct. 27, and the 7.2% correction within the handle portion is normal for a good cup with handle pattern.The operator of savings and loans in three counties of Massachusetts boasts a top-notch 99 Earnings Per Share Rating in IBD Stock Checkup. Earnings per share have risen 64%, 69%, 29%, 100% and 39% vs. year-ago levels in the past five quarters.Other banks acting well lately include Bank of America (BAC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM), both of which recently found buyers during the latest pullback to the 50-day moving average.BofA is in the proper buy zone since clearing a 25.90 buy point in a seven-month-long flat base. That flat base may also be interpreted as a shallow saucer base.The stock is trading flat on Wednesday at 26.67, up nearly 3% from the proper entry.The 5% chase zone for BofA goes up to 27.20.The money center bank is expected to grow fourth-quarter profit by 20% to 48 cents a share. That would mark a second straight quarter of acceleration following EPS gains of 12% and 17% in the prior two quarters.Q4 revenue is seen slipping 3% to $21.96 billion.B of A's Composite Rating on Stock Checkup is a respectable 82 given that the bank is continuing a turnaround in fundamentals.JPMorgan, at 98.82, has climbed modestly since clearing a 95.32 base-on-base buy point in late September.RELATED:Also In Stock Market Today: 5 Reasons To Keep Holding AppleLooking For Top Large-Cap Firms: Inside Big Cap 20Which New Public Companies Will Emerge As The Future Cisco, Google and Microsoft?How To Find The Next Great IPOs: Check This ScreenThe Big Picture: Why The Future Of The Market Rally May Lie HereHow To Search For The Best Growth Stocks: Start Here

Major indexes edged higher at midday Monday, the start of a holiday-shortened week that currently see the market in a confirmed uptrend.Apple (AAPL) backtracked in light volume, and another light-volume drop could put shares back in buy range. Last month, Apple cleared a brand-new cup with handle, moving past a 160.97 entry. The 5% chase zone extends up to 169.02.XOther key megacap and big-cap techs to keep watching with less than two months to go in 2017 include Applied Materials (AMAT), Lam Research (LRCX), Adobe Systems (ADBE), Square (SQ) and Nvidia (NVDA). All five of these names rank in the latest IBD Big Cap 20.All five of these names are currently extended from a proper buy point. However, given their excellent fundamentals, superior position within their respective markets, and outstanding relative price strength, they certainly deserve a spot on a long-term watch list. New follow-on entry points or new bases will eventually emerge.At 1 pm ET, the Nasdaq composite rose less than 0.1%, while the S&P 500 rose close to 0.2%. Most Chinese ADRs flexed strength, following a third straight advance for the Hang Seng equities benchmark in Hong Kong. Volume is running sharply lower vs. the same time on Friday, which saw turnover boosted by expiring monthly and weekly stock and index options.The Dow Jones industrial average rallied nearly 0.4%, buoyed by 1-point gains or more by at least five of the 30 components, including Home Depot (HD), 3M (MMM), Caterpillar (CAT) and IBM (IBM).Investors received additional confirmation that the U.S. economy is rising. The leading indicators index showed a 1.2% gain in October, blasting the Econoday consensus view of up 0.6% and a big improvement from a 0.2% drop in September.Home Depot barreled more than 1.5% higher to 170.49, good for a new all-time high. The stock marked a follow-on entry point as it bounced off the rising 10-week moving average near 165 last week in hefty volume.Those who bought shares when the stock cleared earlier buy points may add a small amount of shares to the winning position. Adding shares to your best stocks is a great way to compound your overall return, but it should only be done when the market is in a solid uptrend, as noted in the Market Pulse table of IBD's The Big Picture.The Street sees the home improvement chain's earnings rising 12% to $1.62 a share in the fiscal fourth quarter ending in January. That would extend Home Depot's streak of double-digit profit growth to 16 quarters in a row.No wonder Home Depot's EPS Rating, as seen in IBD Stock Checkup, is a very respectable 92 on scale of 1 (atrocious earnings) to 99 (exceptional profit growth, both near and long term).Back to Apple, the stock provides multiple reasons why the outlook for a continued fundamentals turnaround remains very strong.Earnings per share jumped 24% to $2.07 in the September-ended fiscal fourth quarter, and Apple crushed the consensus view by nearly 11%. But perhaps more importantly, the iPhone marketer is poised to continue growing profit at double-digit pace into the next fiscal year.The Street sees fiscal Q1 earnings (for the quarter ending in December, a big-time shopping month) rising 12% to $3.77 a share; that would also be a quarterly best.A second reason to have confidence in Apple's turnaround? Revenue growth is accelerating. In the latest quarter, revenue jumped 12% to $52.58 billion, the biggest year-over-year gain in nearly three years. Analysts on consensus see sales picking up 10%, 30%, 25% and 17% vs. year-ago levels in the next four quarters.Three, Apple's ratings in IBD Stock Checkup continue to stay solid and show dramatic improvement vs. the start of the year. While the Composite Rating dipped just a bit to 89, it's still up strong from a lowly 51 on Jan. 1. The RS Rating continues to reflect leadership among big caps at 83.Four, the daily and weekly chart action for Apple has not shed any sell signals, other than to take profits at 20% to 25% for those who wish to raise some cash and look for perhaps a better growth name. Apple has jumped nearly 50% since clearing a first-stage bottoming base pattern at 118.12 on Jan. 6-9. Meanwhile, the B- Accumulation/Distribution Rating, on a scale of A to E, indicates mutual funds, banks, hedge funds and insurers are overall net accumulators of Apple shares.IBD's TAKE: Taking many gains when your stock has risen 20% to 25% past a proper buy point is an excellent way to build a strong overall return. Not only are you locking in gains in a stock on the way up, but you are also freeing up cash to possibly put into another top market leader. OH, oh, oh...."Where do I begin, to tell the story of how great a love can be......" It is the end of the qtr.......lots of window dressing taking place.......

Global markets are SURGING... Asian markets ended the day in positive territory - Japan + 2.7%, Hong Kong + 1.4%, China +0.4%, ASX +2.1%.....As morning turns to afternoon in Europe - we see those markets all moving up....FTSE +2.05%, CAC 40 + 2.60%, DAX +2.45%, EUROSTOXX +2.5%, SPAIN +2.3% and ITALY +2.3%....even Greece is up 2.27%...... As a new day dawns here in America - we see US futures pointing higher (taking its lead from around the world) - currently up 22 pts....hitting her head on resistance at 1900.....oh but the day is young....

September has seen some $11 trillion dollars wiped off the face of the earth and the 3rd qtr of 2015 will go down in history as one of the most volatile qtrs for global financial markets since the depths of despair of the GFC (Great Financial Crisis).

So - is this just a 'one off' on the road to more volatility and weakness ahead? The bears will tell you that nothing has really changed between 4 pm last night and 6 am today....and the Bulls will tell you that there is a sale going on and that the global outlook is not nearly as negative as the bear case......so you decide - which side are you on?

We still have the issues - slowing China, Fed policy, coming earnings, European deflation - yes folks that is correct - I did say DEFLATION....because the Euro area's inflation rate is now negative -as reported today by the European Union Statistics office based in Luxembourg.....the 19 nation block reported that inflation fell 0.1% y/y vs. an estimate of 0% ...unemployment remains stubbornly high at 11% and so this news only adds pressure on the ECB ( European Central Bank) to RAMP UP its stimulus program.
Giada Giani - Economist at Citi in London says that this read was "broadly driven by the energy component, but there are very little inflationary pressures even aside from the oil-price shock..."

So this puts Uncle Mario (Draghi) in a tough position - because the last thing he wants is DEFLATION....and so now - the smart money is betting that he will increase his current $1.2 bil stimulus plan before year end.....

What does this mean for the US? What will Janet do now? Can she raise rates (even insignificantly) now that Europe is in a deflationary mode? We may find out later on today....because - unlike yesterday - we are due to get more FED speak during the day....Janet will be speaking at 3 pm in St Louis, while Bullard (St Louis) and Dudley (New York) and Fed Governor Lael Brainard also take to the airwaves during the course of the day.... Strap in for this.....we are sure to get a range of mixed messages as each one opens their mouth and mixed messages translates into volatility.....who will the market pay attn to? The Hawks or the Doves?

Ok...so yesterday we started to see the discount buyers pick away.....but they did remain a bit apprehensive - taking the market right up to 1900 where it hit resistance, causing the buyers to back off a bit...........Biotech's got a bit of break in the morning, but then took it on the chin again by day's end. Many big cap names also came under pressure as the day wore on - making it seem like investors were raising cash in the names that they could vs. inflicting more damage on some of the mid to small cap names... Demand for treasuries (always a safe bet) rose....

The sense is that the skittishness is alive and well and many do not want to be caught on the wrong side of these daily knee jerk reactions....today brings us the ADP employment report - exp of +190k jobs is right in line with recent reports...so this is NOT a market mover - unless of course it surprises BIG in either direction......Friday brings us the gov't NFP report - and exp for that are +200k so again - this is NOT a barn burner unless of course that number surprises as well. This is the last read on job creation before the FED makes its next decision.....

'Threats' of a 25 bps rise off of a ZIRP (zero interest rate policy) continue to permeate the conversation.....but the global economy continues to be uncooperative....but at some point - we must do what we must do.....It will just be interesting to see how they 'position it' now......considering they found EVERY excuse NOT to raise rates when it made perfect sense to do so.....

If the investors really want the FED to raise rates - because they think it is the right thing to do - then we should expect that the market will surge on that move....but you can also argue that even though they may want rates to normalize - the market is not prepared for that considering the state of the global economy and that will cause the market to weaken...... so in the end - we must play the hand we are dealt.....Preparation is key.....

Tomorrow brings the world a read on China's Sept manf activity.......and this will surely give us more insight into the economic health of that country.....or at least that is what it is supposed to do.....Will that reading be below 50 (which we already know it is via the preliminary read last week) and if so - what's the big deal...the markets have already DISCOUNTED this negative number..... would this be a 'sell the rumor, buy the news' type of event? Or will the bears stand up and scream that China is circling the drain.....(a bit dramatic)

Look - when the markets are in a fragile state, when all we hear is angst, anxiety and negativity - then no matter what - everything appears to be bad news.....and so the markets tend to be erratic.....but if you are an optimist - then here is your opportunity.....Remember the famous WB (Warren Buffett) words:
"Be greedy when others are fearful and be fearful when others are greedy".....it seems that right now - 'others are fearful'......I'm just sayin.....
On a side note (speaking of negative) - this morning's WSJ announces that BofA (Bank of America/Merrill Lynch) has begun the process of LAYOFFS....

"BofA Merrill Confronts Austerity" - and so the annual Wall St dance has begun.....Yes folks - it is that time of year.....every investment bank is trying to manage yr end expectations in terms of compensation and opportunity..... Yesterday - BAC began 'the process' as they are forced to do 'more with less'... a common theme of late..... Expect to see a sea of blood on the street before Thanksgiving.....in fact - we will start to get the news as each one reports earnings in the next couple of weeks.
On the other hand (speaking of positive) - Case Shiller tells us that Home Price Growth remains strong and vibrant...rising 4.7% m/m....although mort apps this morning are down 6.7%......

US Futures are UP 24 pts.... and if they stay strong into the bell then watch the S&P pierce 1900 (psychological resistance) early on.....if it does look for short term resistance at 1905ish...if we pierce that - then it's 1925!

Remember - it IS the end of qtr...so lots of window dressing. Tomorrow wipes the slate clean and asset managers have another 3 months to make it work......Although I still think we end the year higher from here - I no longer believe that we will end the year with a 2100 handle.....But - we shall see.....
Take good care -
Kp

Let's leave the wild gyrations to Nicki Minaj. The stock market's erratic moves this quarter frayed ETF investors' nerves and sent them scurrying to products that promise a smoother ride. Many dividend ETFs are packed with larger, blue-chip companies that are seen as more stable. And low volatility exchange traded funds specifically target the risk-averse investor. But why settle for…

Markets on SALE again this morning as investors react to all the new data.....In Asia - China reported that industrial profits PLUNGED by 8.8% y/y - the largest decrease since 2011. Analysts came out saying this is "No Surprise" - considering the weekly WEAK eco data that China has been reporting for months now..... Yating Xu - Economist at IHS…
GDP revised up

The economy expanded 3.9% in Q2's final estimate. That's up from an earlier estimate of 3.7% and reflects a healthy rebound from Q1's meager 0.6% gain. Exports, nonresidential and residential fixed investment, and state and local gov't spending all increased in the final revision. Imports also increased, subtracting from the GDP calculation but pointing to firmer demand across a strengthening economy.
Consumer confidence rises

The Univ. of Michigan's final Sept. read rose 1.5 point to 87.2, beating expectations of a reading of 87.1. That's still the weakest since last Oct., as consumers remain skittish after stock market gyrations. The outlook for jobs improved 1.2 points but is still the lowest since last Sept.

 First-timer homebuyers dwindled over the summer, according to the Campbell/Inside Mortgage Finance HousingPulse survey. First-time buyers made up 36.4% of purchases in August, down from the 5-year high of 38.3% in May. Other metrics show a firming market, including the average time on market, down to 7.9 weeks in Aug.
 ECRI's weekly leading gauge rose to 132.1 in the most recent reading, up from 131.1. The contraction rate moderated to -1.9% from -2.2%.

 A flash services PMI dipped in Sept. Markit's index showed strong growth at 55.6, but that was still the slowest pace in 3 months. Survey respondents said the domestic outlook was improving, although some clients had concerns about "heightened uncertainty."
Mixed news on Japan inflation

The consumer price index rose 0.2% in Aug., more than the 0.1% decline in July, though the yearly change of 0.2% held steady, well below the central bank's target. Excluding food and energy, the yearly gain accelerated to 0.8% from 0.6% the prior month. But excluding just food, the yearly change went negative for the first time since the Bank of Japan launched its latest round of stimulus, a possible danger sign for expectations and sentiment around PM Shinzo Abe's efforts to end deflation.
Eurozone lending rises

Household lending grew 1% in Aug., up from a 0.9% boost in July, while lending to non-financial corporations was up 0.4%, vs. July's 0.3% uptick. That signals more demand in the economy, but a measure of money in circulation grew by 4.8% in Aug., down from a 5.3% gain in July and below economists' estimates.
COMING UP MONDAY
 Personal income and outlays for Aug., 8:30 a.m. ET.
 Pending home sales for Aug., 10 a.m. ET.

"Weebles wobble but they don't fall down" Do you remember this tag line? It rose in popularity during the launch of this toy in the early '70's, then was reborn in 2000 and once again raised from the dead in the 2010 're-launch' of this timeless child's toy. (Weebles are that line of toys produced by the Playskool division of…

Stocks headed lower yesterday as the markets remain unsettled over coming earnings, FED policy, last night's Chinese PMI report (wasn't good!) , declines in commodities and continued concern over global growth......yesterday's losses took the major indexes into negative territory for the week.......although - in the end - they did manage to close off of their lows for the day.

(The Bloomberg Commodity Index (BCOM on your BB terminal) is a basket of prices for natural resources like copper, oil, gold, soybeans, sugar, wheat, cattle, zinc, hogs, coffee, nickel,.... fell 1.6% yesterday. This gauge is now down 16% ytd looking like it is heading for the lows of 2002! This move continues to spook the FED as the big bad boogeyman known as DEFLATION lurks just below the surface - pushing up the dollar which in turn puts pressure on commodity prices (inverse relationship) - it's a vicious circle - now toss in the China syndrome and investors are not willing to ignore what now appears to stronger negative headwinds)

Are we heading to test the August lows of 1865 on the S&P, 15,381 on the Dow and 4300 on the Nasdaq? Well - maybe and no one should be surprised if we do - why? Way too much uncertainty surrounding the coming earnings season...with all this talk of a weaker China - we can see how analysts are slashing estimates as they try and perfect their calls ahead of the qrtly confessional. Once we really begin to see the impact of what a 'slowing China' is really having on company bottom lines and what that means for forward guidance - investors will err to the side of caution - and rightly so.....Now what can we expect? We can expect the usual song and dance....analysts cut estimates (to the bone) ahead of the reports and then somehow - miraculously - 75%-80% of companies BEAT those lowered estimates and then it's all good!

Now if the market successfully tests and holds the August lows, then I think the market will try and rally as we make our way thru earnings.....But investors/traders should be prepared for some disappointments in earnings as well as very cautious commentary about future guidance...... Now if we test and fail at the August lows, then it means we would establish a lower low on the monthly charts further confirming a 'bearish condition" setting us up for more volatility ahead.

Now last night while were sleeping - China reports that PMI fell to 47 - a 6 yr low.. while a gov't probe of CITIC Securities revealed evidence of 'insider trading' sending this stock to 18 month lows and major markets into a tailspin....or Risk Off mode. Japan -1.98%, Hong Kong -2.26%, China -2.19% and ASX -2%... Comments by President Xi Jinping have done little to help and in fact many think his comments (while vacationing in the states) have hurt any attempt to stabilize. Wang Zheng - CIO at JingXi Investment Company had this to say -

"The market is reacting to the bad economic data, which seem to show no improvement.... Xi's comment indicates that the government's rescue measures will be phased out and the state won't buy as much as it did before to ramp up the market."
(Xi's comments were that the Chinese stock market has 'reached a phase of self-recovery and self-adjustment as he compared China's economy to a giant ship sailing in stormy seas')

On top of that - speculation continues around FED Chair Yellen.......and in a speech she is about to give in Amherst, Ma on "Inflation Dynamics and Monetary Policy" It is here that she will get to do 'clear the air' (laugh track inserted here).

Will she in fact confirm that the FED is on track to raise rates as the 3 stooges told us on Monday and Tuesday? Or will she confirm what so many investors already believe to be true - that rates are not going anywhere until next year? The question is: Was Janet among the 13 of 17 officials that think rates should rise this year or not? If she clarifies her position about the economy and rates - will this serve to stabilize markets or create more chaos? Look - she is all about transparency - no? So if that is the case - she does NOT want to say "SURPRISE!!!". She has to lay out a course of action and then stick to it - maybe she needs a good PR firm to help negotiate the message? And no matter what - the market is now second guessing everything they do....because it has been disappointed over and over again...and then she sends out the troops to deliver different messages as she tries to calm the markets......As Bryan Carter - Former US Treasury Economist and now lead PM at Acadian Asset said -
"They are creating the conditions that are causing the external environment to be weak, and then they say they can't hike because of those same conditions that they have created."

European markets are bucking the trend - as they move higher....seemingly ignoring the Chinese PMI data and the growing VW scandal (which still remains a company-specific problem - not an industry problem) yet this issue has taken 41% out of the value of VW since the news broke.....FTSE + 1.5%, CAC 40 +0.94%, DAX + 0.83%, EUROSTOXX + 1%, SPAIN +0.77% and ITALY +1.4%.

US futures are up 8 handles at 1940 as trader types are following in Europe's footsteps - ignoring the negative news out of Asia.........Now yesterday - we traded right down to support at 1925ish......and bounced.....as the day wore on - we found plenty of bargain hunting going on as they rallied them off the lows towards the end of day....I suspect the market wants to once again try and rally around the 1950 level on the S&P.....but any move much above that will surely be met with resistance as the trader types move in and out taking advantage of the volatility.
Expect volumes to be light today as many participants are away for the Jewish holidays...
Take good care.
Kp

This gauge is now down 16% ytd looking like it is heading for the lows of 2002! This move continues to spook the FED as the big bad boogeyman known as DEFLATION lurks just below the surface - pushing up the dollar which in turn puts pressure on commodity prices (inverse relationship) - it's a vicious circle - now toss in the China syndrome and investors are not willing to ignore what now appears to stronger negative headwinds)Are we heading to test the August lows of 1865 on the S&P, 15,381 on the Dow and 4300 on the Nasdaq? Well - maybe and no one should be surprised if we do - why? Way too much uncertainty surrounding the coming earnings season...with all this talk of a weaker China - we can see how analysts are slashing estimates as they try and perfect their calls ahead of the qrtly confessional. Once we really begin to see the impact of what a 'slowing China' is really having on company bottom lines and what that means for forward guidance - investors will err to the side of caution - and rightly so.....Now what can we expect? Keep Hope Alive! Janet shifts into overdrive and sends out the troops - in this case - the 3 stooges - Moe, Larry & Curly - San Francisco's Fed President Williams (voting member), Richmond Fed President Lacker (voting member) and St. Louis President Bullard (non-voting member) as they try to do 'damage control'......now while Moe (Williams) was a bit cautious in his comments - he was in the end upbeat about jobs, wages, unemployment and the overall economy. Larry and Curly - (Lacker & Bullard) they both came out to say that 'the FED's objectives had been met and that the decision was close - but alas..... no cigar!

This morning we are joined by Shemp, (Dennis Lockhart) who is also now making the case for a rate rise....I guess the question is: Where were these guys last week? If they are so convicted in what policy should be - who exactly overrode their arguments?

This morning US futures are getting slammed - currently down 30 pts decisively piercing the 1950 level and now once again on its way to test support at 1925...... European markets plunge as these markets are all down better than 2.5%....FTSE -1.9%, CAC 40 - 2.78%, DAX - 2.44%, EUROSTOXX -2.57%, SPAIN - 2.61% and ITALY -2.6%, SWITZERLAND - 2.7% - and if you follow Twitter at all - there are so many blaming this selloff on Volkswagen's diesel emissions scandal! Are you kidding me! Who actually thinks this stuff up? An internal scandal (if you can even call it that) at VW is NOT causing global markets to implode.....

Consider - if you will what the clowns at the FED have done.....they tease and tease for months about how strong the economy is, they prepare us for the 'rate increase', they note that we are at FULL employment and wages are on the rise (sure they are...) and then they CHOKE...... and then - once they realize global investors are disgusted she sends out the 3 stooges and then some to try and calm the markets and this morning that is having the opposite effect.....instead of calming the markets - all of the commentary only serves to clarify the belief that the FED is loosing credibility FAST.....

What is interesting is that all of these men continue to strongly suggest that rates will rise sometime over the next 90 days…..90 days, that's all we got until they are jammed into Times Square counting down the seconds to welcome in the new year - 2016.

Now yesterday - these comments helped to stabilize the dollar almost assuring investors that it now comes down to October or December - note that November is not mentioned because there is no formal FOMC meeting during that month - BUT that does not mean that she can't pull a fast one and make a 'surprise' announcement if she decides that it is important enough…..So - let's go with option #1 - if that is the case - I am betting October - because I can't imagine that the FED wants to wait until the 3rd week of December to raise rates - I mean with the holidays upon us and plenty of businesses in the financial services industry operating on skeleton crews at that time - does that make much sense? (That's a rhetorical question - no answer needed). (Now I am only going with the stated objectives - when in reality I think there is a real chance that rates go nowhere until early 2016 no matter what they are saying today.)

Now remember - we are due to get so much more data in the coming weeks......First up would be the all important NFP report due on Friday Oct, 2, 2015 - exp of +200k jobs to be created.......then we get 3rd qtr earnings which will begin on the week of the 12th…now some will say that AA sets off the season and they are due to report on Thursday October 8th at 4:05 pm - because they were always the first to report, they are a global company (metals, miner and refiner of Alumina) that was also a member of the DOW….- but they no longer fill that role since being removed from the DOW last year….JPM has replaced AA and is now the 'Belle of the Ball' and will report the morning of October 13th at 7 am and this will be the 'official kick off of the 2015 3rd qtr earnings.

Earnings will then extend right thru the end of the month - causing daily bouts of angst and anxiety as investors consider the implications of forward guidance and the role that CHINA will play......Next up? The FED meeting on October 27-28th - oh Boy....... and we will have gotten plenty of information between now and then concerning both micro data - individual company reports and guidance and the usual macro data points concerning the health of the US and global economy. So - we will be able to assess the damage and then predict the result……and you can hear the clock go tic/toc/tic/toc……

Now yesterday the Dow and S&P opened strong and marched higher throughout the morning - only to become skittish after Turing Pharmaceuticals announced that they were raising the price of a 60 yr old - tried and true -drug (Daraprim) used in the care of life threatening parasitic infection from $13/pill to $750/pill - that's right a $737 increase from Monday to Tuesday…..So Hillary stepped up to the plate and took advantage of the situation sending out a Tweet threatening to take on the biotech industry's tendency to 'price gouge' (for this she must be applauded) …..this sent biotech's plunging while taking the broader market into negative territory for 5 mins or so at about 1 pm. It then recovered and finished strong as investors seemed to be a bit more settled......

(The Infectious Diseases Society of America along with the HIV Medicine Association recently sent a joint letter to Turing calling the price increase for Daraprim "unjustifiable for the medically vulnerable patient population" and " unsustainable for the health care system." Now it should be noted that this is NOT an isolated event by any means….the biotech industry is known for using this strategy to make money - as they force patients to choose life or death (in some cases)….no wonder health care costs are spiraling out of control….Other biotech's in the news for price gouging include Rodelis Therapeutics, Marathon Pharmaceuticals and Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX).)

So what happened overnight? Why the turn in sentiment - Well - a couple of reasons.....1. European stocks got hit - miners leading the way lower....causing commodities to sell off once again raising concerns about growth and inflation......(blah, blah, blah)......2. Someone is using the debacle at VW to cause autos to sell off......(ridiculous really - VW is a company-specific problem) and 3. Because as the 3 stooges plus 1 continue to go out on the road and tell their story - investors are left to wonder - Why are you telling us? We expected you guys to do the right thing all along and in the end you CHOKED.....so don't make public confessions to clear you conscience - DO WHAT IS RIGHT.....and if you can't, then we as investors will re-price the risk based on what we perceive to be the truth.

Now in the end - do not be surprised to see the market churn and even test the August lows of 1870 on the S&P over the course of the next month as investors/traders get hit with all kinds of data points as the market searches for clarity across a range of issues - including Interest rates, China, Iran, Greece, Europe, and earnings. In the end - I do think we are setting up for a yearend rally- a rally that takes us back to the 2050/2100 range which would be essentially flat on the year - but that is a lot better than down 15%.
Take good care
Kp
