By 1973, as striking coal miners brought the British government of Prime Minister Edward Heath to its knees, Margaret Thatcher was a young Cabinet minister filled with apprehension about her country’s future.The miners’ union, she would note later in her autobiography, seemed more intent on bringing down the government than in securing benefits for their members.And because the miners' work was vital to keeping up the nation’s electricity supply, they had the power to do it. Heath’s Conservative government, unwilling to break the strike and unable to appease the strikers, instituted a national three-day workweek just to avoid electrical blackouts.Similar scenes repeated themselves often enough that Thatcher became convinced Britain’s trade unions threatened British democracy itself.As it turned out, Thatcher (1925-2013) was stronger, rising to become Britain's first female prime minister and igniting her country's economy.The unions had not been the only culprit in weakening Britain, which the Wall Street journal in 1975 called “the sick country of Europe.”Thatcher also faulted her own Conservative Party’s lack of principle in resisting creeping socialism. Heath’s approach was heavy on central economic planning and light on conservative principles. He showed repeatedly that he lacked the nerve to ride out rough patches in public opinion and give his own policies a chance to work.After voters threw out Heath’s government in 1974, Thatcher called for a change of direction. In a daring move that would have ingloriously ended her political career had she failed, she challenged him for party leader in 1975. Despite his formidable institutional support, she upset him by winning a plurality on the first ballot. He dropped out of the race, effectively handing her the victory, but he never forgave her until he died in 2005.In the autumn of 1975, at her first Conservative Party Conference as leader, Thatcher laid out an economic platform that clashed with both parties’ obsession with central planning.“Let me give you my vision,” she said. “A man’s right to work as he will, to spend what he earns, to own property, to have the state as servant and not as master -- these are the British inheritance.”Such talk appealed strongly to the party rank and file and to Britain’s middle class in a time of double-digit inflation and high unemployment.Thatcher dutifully opposed the Labour government in Parliament until its wheels finally came off in December 1978. Again, striking trade unions dealt the fatal blow. Health service workers, government workers (including trash collectors), truckers and even gravediggers went on strike almost simultaneously.Of these unfortunate events, Thatcher wrote that “without their exposure of the true nature of socialism, it would have been far more difficult to achieve what was done in the 1980s.”It prepared the electorate for Thatcherism and steeled her resolve for reform that seemed radical at the time.“The reason she became leader of the Conservative Party in 1975, and the reason she became prime minister, was that everything was going badly,” Charles Moore, a Thatcher biographer, told IBD.Thatcher became prime minister after the election that followed in May 1979, with the Tories winning their largest parliamentary majority in two decades.Americans primarily remember Thatcher for her collaboration with President Reagan in countering the Soviet threat at the end of the Cold War era. Long before Reagan’s election of 1980, she publicly criticized the Western policy of detente with communism, calling the Soviets “hell-bent on world domination” in a famous 1976 speech. The Russian press dubbed her the "Iron Lady" in response, and she lived up to the nickname, occasionally upbraiding Reagan to hang tough in his dealings with the Soviets.As prime minister, Thatcher also had to face down a terror in the homeland. Early in her administration, she refused to give in to demands from imprisoned Irish Republican Army terrorists, 10 of whom starved themselves to death in a 1981 hunger strike. Thatcher, who had seen friends and political allies murdered by the terrorist group, herself became the target of a 1984 IRA assassination attempt, which killed five others at a Conservative Party conference in Brighton.“A lesser figure today would have run away,” said Nile Gardiner, a former Thatcher aide and co-author of "Margaret Thatcher on Leadership." “She remained on site and dedicated her speech to crushing the IRA."The IRA would not lay down its arms until 2005, but Thatcher helped set the stage for successful peace talks and the Good Friday Agreement of 1998 when she moved to include the government of the Republic of Ireland in the process for the first time.Thatcher is most loved and most hated in Britain for her domestic policy, which restored the nation’s economic dynamism. She broke from the orthodoxy of her day by fighting inflation not with socialistic wage or price controls, but with cuts to government spending and higher interest rates. This was not popular at a time when unemployment was still high, but she stuck to her guns. By her fourth full year in office, inflation had fallen below an annual 5%.Thatcher also moved as quickly as she could to prevent unions from bringing down future governments. She repealed civil immunity for union actions and imposed the critical requirement that union members be given a binding vote on strikes. This paid dividends in the next major union confrontation of 1984, a long struggle but one that her government won decisively against the striking National Union of Miners. The defeat of the miners’ union, viewed then as the nation’s most powerful, had a ripple effect. Strikes had cost Britain 29.5 million man-days of work in 1979. In 1990, when Thatcher left office, they cost it only 1.3 million.Thatcher’s swift and successful military response to Argentina’s 1982 invasion of the Falkland Islands helped ensure her 1983 re-election over a fragmented British left. The Tories gained 38 seats to form the largest majority that any party had held at that point since World War II.Thatcher cut income tax rates while raising the U.K.’s value-added tax, reasoning that this removed disincentives for work and shifted them to consumption. She privatized dozens of major industries and companies that had been nationalized by previous socialist governments.The government sold off previously unprofitable state-owned enterprises in oil exploration, utilities, shipbuilding, automotive production (Rolls-Royce and Jaguar), telecommunications and commercial air travel (British Airways). Thatcher called privatization “one of the central means of reversing the corrosive and corrupting effects of socialism.”Thatcher’s tenure as PM came to an end in 1990, not through electoral defeat but through the fraying of alliances within her own party. The issue that occasioned her downfall was European integration. She had been cautious of giving too much power to the Continent and was skeptical of the common currency in the planning stage.“She was fundamentally right about the euro single currency,” said Moore, pointing to current problems in the countries of southern Europe. “She believed the poorer nations couldn’t cope with the rigors of a single currency.”After failing to defeat a challenge to her leadership in the first round by a sufficiently large margin to end the matter, Thatcher went out on a high note. She announced her resignation the next day, Nov. 22, 1990.Margaret Roberts was born to Beatrice and Alfred in the east England town of Grantham, where they were the odd Tory family in a left-wing environment.Thatcher wrote fondly of her pacifist pastor, “the kindest and holiest man,” who would eventually preside at her wedding. From his example, she also concluded that “personal virtue is no substitute for political hard-headedness.” This became especially apparent to the young future prime minister when England’s anti-war politicians, including those in the ruling Conservative Party, desperately tried and failed to appease Adolf Hitler and avoid a major European war.She became involved in Conservative Party politics while studying chemistry at Somerville College, part of Oxford. Debates of the Oxford University Conservative Association became a major source of her extracurricular intellectual stimulation, in part because the Oxford Union (the mainstream debate society) did not allow women as members.After graduating and finding work as a chemist, she was chosen in 1951 by the Conservative Party to be the sacrificial lamb in a hopeless run for Parliament in Dartford. She lost as expected but met Denis Thatcher, “an exceptional man,” who as she put it “knew at least as much about politics as I did and a good deal more about economics.” She and Denis were married in December 1951, and she became mother to twins Mark and Carol.Mrs. Thatcher put her name forward for Parliament again in the more promising constituency of Orpington in 1954, but failed to gain the nomination. In her view, party officials -- even women in the party -- were hesitant to select a female nominee, especially a mother.“Perhaps some of the men at selection committees entertained this prejudice,” she wrote, “but I found then and later that it was the women who came nearest to expressing it openly.”She would not win election to Parliament until 1959. As late as 1973, when she was a Cabinet minister, Thatcher said in a town hall she did not expect to see a woman become prime minister in her lifetime. Later, though, as party leader, she said she had “a woman's ability to stick to a job and get on with it when everyone else walks off and leaves it."Prime minister of Britain from 1979 to 1990.Overcame: Sexism, party establishment groupthink, powerful special interests, foreign aggression.Lesson: A determined woman can overcome any challenge.“State intervention in the economy is not ultimately an answer to over-mighty vested interests, for it soon comes to collude with them.”

Altria (MO) reported slightly higher fourth-quarter profit as its flagship Marlboro brand grew retail sales for the fourth year in a row. The company also said it plans layoffs to lower costs.The No. 2 tobacco company by revenue behind Philip Morris (PM) said earnings per share rose a penny in Q4 to 67 cents, one cent less than the analyst consensus of 68 cents. It was the first time in six quarters that Altria failed to meet or beat profit estimates.Revenue rose 2.5% to $4.729 billion, lighter than the expected $4.745 billion.On its earnings call Thursday, Altria said it plans to eliminate jobs to cut up to $300 million in costs annually, according to the Wall Street Journal. Chairman and Chief Executive Marty Barrington declined to say on the call how many jobs would be cut.The results were in line with Stifel's forecast. Prior to the earnings report, Stifel analyst Christopher Growe said in a Jan. 14 report that he had a buy rating on Altria with a positive bias.Growe said he expected 2016 industry growth to be lower than 2015's, but he generally sees robust conditions, saying the recent period for tobacco makers is a "Golden Age" amid global expansion and the rollout of new products such as electronic cigarettes.During Q4, Altria continued to build its Nu Mark portfolio of e-vapor products to additional retail outlets.Altria forecast full-year 2016 EPS of $3 to $3.05, below the consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $3.05.The tobacco company is a major shareholder of SABMiller and is hoping the proposed merger between Miller and brewing giant AB InBev (BUD) will go through.If it does, "we expect to capture a significant premium on our very large investment in SABMiller and continue our participation in the global beer profit pool on attractive terms," Barrington said in the earnings statement.Altria shares closed up 1.1% in the stock market today. Altria continues to trade near its all-time-high close of 61.53 on Oct. 29, and it sports a 93 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed more than 93% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.Philip Morris added 1.1%. Among other large tobacco companies, Reynolds American (RAI) rose 19%, and British American Tobacco (BTI) climbed 2%.

Tobacco stocks have risen into the upper echelon of IBD's industry rankings as investors seek a safe haven from the market's gyrations.The eight-stock industry group has jumped 25 places over the past six weeks to No. 15 out of 197 as of Tuesday amid remarkably stable earnings growth, slow-but-steady stock price appreciation and healthy dividend increases.Reynolds American (RAI) leads the industry with a best-possible Composite Rating of 99, putting it in the top 1% of all stocks based on five fundamental criteria such as sales and profit growth and relative price strength.The IBD Leaderboard stock has pulled back to just below a 49.66 buy point of a flat base after breaking out Thursday in volume 15% above average. Still, its relative strength line is soaring and its Accumulation/Distribution Rating indicates net positive demand for the shares.Reynolds, which makes cigarettes under brands such as Camel and Pall Mall, boasts a dividend growth rate of 8%. Also, its annualized dividend of $2.26 a share yields 2.9%, which is above the S&P 500 average.Tobacco companies have offset declining cigarette sales by raising prices, cutting costs and developing new products such as electronic cigarettes.Profit at Reynolds rose 17% in the latest quarter, picking up from the prior quarter's 13% gain. Revenue jumped 41%, accelerating for the third straight quarter following the company's acquisition last year of Lorillard, whose popular Newport cigarettes helped boost Reynolds' earnings last quarter.Altria Group (MO), the maker of cigarette brands such as Marlboro,  reported Thursday that Q4 profit edged up 2% to 67 cents a share on a 1% gain in revenue to $6.32 billion. Both figures trailed Wall Street forecasts. The company reportedly said after its earnings release that it would eliminate 490 jobs in the U.S. in order to save $300 million a year by the end of 2017.Yet Altria has risen 12% in the past year even as the S&P 500 has declined. The stock sits just 1% off a record high as it works on a flat base with a 61.84 buy point. Its relative strength line is soaring, which is a bullish sign.Philip Morris International (PM), also boasts a five-year earnings stability factor of 1 on a scale of zero (most stable) to 99 (least stable).Philip Morris is just 1% below an all-time as it hovers under a 90.37 buy point of a flat base. Its long-term dividend growth rate of 11% and annualized dividend yield of just over 4% are highest among the three stocks discussed here.Philip Morris, which was spun off from Altria in 2008, will report Q4 results Feb. 4.Profit for the period is seen falling 21% to 81 cents a share on a 10% decline in revenue to $6.49 billion due in part to the strong dollar. Altria spun off Philip Morris in 2008 to reduce regulatory risk, though the two companies are working together to develop and jointly market e-cigarettes.Image provided by Shutterstock.

From yesterday's note:"Bottom line is that crude oil prices once again survived the $30 support level and now faces another test. That test is a challenge of the 50dma which is at $34.44.....A failure for oil to pierce this resistance level will ensure that oil and stocks will hit another road block. An advance up and thru the 50 dma will ignite another rally in stocks - taking us up and thru the 50 dma at 1946 on the S&P - which will then cause sellers to back off as the bulls will push the mkt back to 2000"Now - oil did not pierce it's 50 dma - YET (but it's coming) - but once again it did unexpectedly strengthen as the day wore on.....and this renewed strength was enough for investors to grab the BULL by his .........HORNS (come on, did you really think I would have said anything different?) and charge resistance at 1946 on the S&P......As the mins ticked by - you could feel the excitement - the BULL (investors) began to 'paw the ground' in the way that he does prior to the charge....(*Pawing the ground is the way that the BULL readies himself for the coming charge warning any potential victim (in this case the BEARS) of what is to come.)At 3:40 pm - he made his move, the BEAR - now known as The Bandillero (or matedor) dressed in his 'traje de luces' (suit of lights) teased the BULL and BANG..... the BULL charged and it was all over.....The BEAR was history......and the geeks who hide behind the algo's and computer screens fell like toy soldiers...... Where did they go? They scattered like rats......as the BULLS screamed - BUY AMERICA!Now - if crude oil joins the party and breaks thru resistance at $33.44 then it is likely that the broader mkt will easily advance to it 100 dma at 2000 - which is only 2.5% from here.....a move that could easily happen in a day....... Now do not be fooled - there will be strong resistance at the S&P 2000.....and even stronger resistance at the S&P 2025 - which is the much longer term 200 dma......But - any sustained move higher, accompanied by volume will clearly be a signal that investors are more focused on fundamentals and technical's - rather than all of the noise out of the Mid-East and DC.Remember - it is month end...and there is some window dressing going on.....so a strong advance is not out of the question at all as we move into qtr end on March 31st and the FED remains on hold.And so - it is just another day in the mkts.......but it is getting a bit more exciting now.....as both oil and stocks attempt to take back the night! Now maybe the fact that stocks moved first is in fact the beginning of the disconnect between oil and stocks that should come with stability....Is this the sign?A look at the chart of the S&P reveals a couple of things....First it has created an intermediate term double bottom in January and February of this year- an event that I made note of last week. Second - if you draw a trend line off of the closing lows of August and September and run it across to today - you can see that the support created at the 1865 & 1870 levels then became resistance levels at 1912/1925.....which we have tested a number of times during February - each time getting stuck or backing off....that was until yesterday.......when the BULLS just couldn't take it any longer......So now the question is - Can we continue? Will it hold? Will the FED do something to screw it up? Will the Saudi's back off and give oil a chance to breathe?Global mkts are screaming higher.... The G20 is meeting in Shanghai and they are trying really hard to put it all in perspective......as they try to calm the fears of a new global recession......The OECD (Org of Economic Co-operation and Development) along with the IMF are urging the members to come up with a policy response to tackle what they describe as 'stuttering growth'. Can we expect BOLD action? Is the mkt assuming some kind of additional stimulus?in Asia - Japan +0.3%, Hong Kong + 2.52%, China +1% and ASX -0.01%.....In Europe the BULL continues to slaughter the naysayers....those mkts are up well over 1% across the board on the back of the explosive rally here yesterday....FTSE + 1%, CAC 40 + 1.41%, DAX + 1.67%, EUROSTOXX +1.5%, SPAIN +0.86% and ITALY +1.04%.US futures are up 10 pts!........pushing thru 1960 on the S&P......as the BULL is not backing down......He has had it with all of the BEAR talk and 'end of the world' predictions from the likes of Nouriel Roubini et al.....Eco data today includes: Revised GDP - exp of 0.4% which is lower (but we knew that), Pers Income of +0.4%, Pers Spend of +0.3% and REAL Pers Spend of +0.3%....I always love that stat....Pers spending and REAL Pers spending.......Spending is spending...no? Can you have FAKE Pers spending?I suspect the mkt will continue to advance to the 1980/2000 range before it finds any resistance at all......I mean the sellers are not going to stand in the way of the buyers at this point.....they would do themselves a favor by backing off to take advantage of the current momentum. I think today is gonna be fun.....Have a great weekend.Take Good Care

Cable TV leader Comcast (CMCSA), coffee king Starbucks (SBUX),  “innovative” drug companies such as Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) and a few biotechs make Morgan Stanley’s list of companies with pricing power.Amid a low-inflation environment and worries over a global recession, stocks with pricing power should get a serious look, says the Morgan Stanley report.Its list also includes American Tower (AMT), Amgen (AMGN), Biogen (BIIB), Celgene (CELG), Constellation Brands (STZ), Equinix (EQIX), L Brands (LB), Mindbody (MB), Phillip Morris (PM), Reynolds American (RAI), Sally Beauty Holdings (SBH), and Sherwin-Williams (SHW).Here’s Morgan Stanley’s take on why some of these companies have pricing power.1) American Tower. “Towers effectively offer local monopolies, and there is little alternative for wireless carriers wishing to add capacity to improve network quality.”2) Amgen. “While drug pricing has been a topic of debate since U.S. presidential candidates raised focus on the topic in the late summer of 2015, we continue to see pricing power among large cap biotech.”3) Biogen. “In 2015, management took around 11% to 12% gross price increases across its portfolio.”4) Celgene. “Management in 2015 took 7-10% gross price increases across its portfolio and we would expect a similar net price trend in 2016.”5) Comcast. “We are positive on CMCSA’s broadband growth story and see improved results in video given X1 (set-top box deployment).”6) Sherwin-Williams. “(Its) pricing power relates to its control of its own distribution, as well as its outsized leverage to professional painting contractors.7) Starbucks. “SBUX remains the category leader in the high-margin, premium coffee segment and benefits from selling an often-craved, habitual product.”

On Monday Oil rallied, on Tuesday oil retreated, on Monday stocks rallied and on Tuesday stocks retreat.....On Monday - the talk was all about growth and the consumer, on Tuesday the talk turned to recession and global growth concerns, on Monday - the FED appeared to be on hold, on Tuesday - well maybe not so much..........Do you see the pattern?There has been so much talk about how the stock mkt is tied to the oil mkt and stock traders will be led around by the nose on the whims of the oil traders.... Let me emphatically clear).....Mkts - whether oil, stocks, real estate, gold, copper, silver, milk, coffee etc are all driven by supply and demand and investor confidence. Confidence in gov't leadership, gov't policies, potential regulations, global outlook, technology improvements, Industry dynamics, company performance, future expectations and mkt action - now while some assets move in concert with each other in the near term, others do not and in the end assets will move to levels where natural supply meets natural demand. In times of uncertainty - those levels are not so clear....thus confusion and volatility result in action that leaves us with a stomach ache.Since January 7th - we have been in the 1850/1950 trading range as the mkt looks for stability after the beating and breakdown that began back in December when we broke thru all of the technical supports (50, 100 & 200 dma's) shaving some 14% off of the US indexes before we came to our senses.We have discussed this - global mkts took a beating on China devaluations, concern over what a slowing China would do to the global economy, what will the breakdown in oil mean for the industry, the Hi-Yield mkt, the banks (via their exposure). And then the whole NEGATIVE rate discussion raised the stakes yet again. Janet, in her testimony to congress, did not emphatically dismiss the idea at all...in fact she said 'everything was on the table' ....so you ask - Why is the mkt stuck?We need a real catalyst and up til now - it has been a re-hash of the same issues - and the re-hash has not produced any new results...it's like insanity.....when you do the same thing over and over and expect a different result... It ain't happening!

As we approached the February highs of 1945 ish....I suggested that we would stall, unable to push up and thru right now because nothing has changed - no new catalyst has emerged..........and as we moved there we see a lightening of volume as the rally meets resistance. So what does it all mean?Well - it means that investors/traders are not yet willing to bet the ranch on this latest move until they get more data and direction (read catalyst). I will say that the fact that volumes are drying up as we approach resistance leaves one to take a position and get off the fence.....It can be seen both as a negative or a positive.....Negative because the buyers are not sure that this latest move is real.....so they are not committing a lot of new dollars - arguing that the sellers will come back with a vengeance sending the mkts lower to test 1850 for a 3rd time.........yet you can argue also that it is positive because the sellers are not putting a ton of pressure either - leaving them to wonder if resistance here at the 50 dma (1949 now) will in fact prove to be significant and if not - then once we pierce it - the algo's will kick in attempting to force the mkt higher to test the next level - which is 2000. (It appears today's action is reflective of the NEGATIVE view as global mkts are under pressure.But – let's not kid ourselves.....much depends on the geopolitical situation and what OPEC and the other nations do about the oversupply of oil, it also depends on how investors read JP Morgan Chase's (JPM) latest statement -"JPM Sounds Fresh Warning on Energy-Loan Losses - the bank plans to build reserves by ANOTHER $500 million tied to oil and gas exposure"Clearly - Jamie is not taking any chances about the potential damage that defaults could wreak on the banking industry......and so - banks got hit again yesterday.....(recall that JPM already has $800 million in oil and gas reserves but as Jamie told us - he views it as 'a drop in the bucket' and re-iterates the silver lining story.....for as much as someone will get hurt, there will be someone who benefits on the other side...so which side will you be on? .)US futures are now down another 16 pts - taking us down and thru 1900 on the S&P as the oil story re-ignites the RISK OFF mentality.......looks like we are going to re-test the 1850 level again.....(3 time's a charm) before this is over......The argument again today is oil (and the pattern continues)....and this morning WTI is down 3.3% - trading at $30.77/barrel....Yesterday - The Saudi oil minister did say that the world 'should not expect production cuts...' and BOOMMMM, the bottom falls out once again......A freeze - maybe, but if the other nations do not fall in line then we can expect the Saudi's to ramp it up until they choke everyone else..... as Guillermo Hernandez Sampere (Head of Trading at MPPM EK) tells us:“The fact that Saudi Arabia would rather give out the oil for free instead of giving market share to Iran will continue to weigh on oil prices and this weighs on markets”And the song plays on.....European mkts are under real pressure on the back of the Saudi comments....In the end - No one is going to play nice in the sandbox.....they don't trust each other nor do they believe that any cuts in production will be forthcoming - not until the Saudi's see blood in the streets.We have the pleasure of 3 FED speakers today.....Jeffrey Lacker (Richmond FED) at 8 am, Richard Kaplan (Dallas FED) at 1:15 and our old favorite - St. Louis's James Bullard at 6:30 pm....(I think they should pair James up with Wendy Williams (talk show host) like they did with Kelly and Michael....Think about that for a minute....)Eco data today includes; Mortgage Apps -4.3%, much weaker than last week's +8.2%, Markit US Services PMI - exp of 53.2, new home sales of 520k or a month over month decrease of 4.4%....but remember - yesterday's existing home sales number was a bit of a surprise - so anything is possible...I mean look at The Donald - he swept Nevada - and is now clearly in the lead and the candidate to beat.....(who would have thought?) Teddy and Marco coming up the rear.....and Kasich - what happened to him? I guess so many Americans are just fed up with the BS in DC......This could almost be a sitcom......Take Good Care

Altria's (MO) profit growth is projected to cool to the low single-digit range when it reports fourth-quarter results early Thursday, though the tobacco industry is considered to be in a "Golden Age."Analyst consensus is for earnings per share to rise 3% to 68 cents, which would be its weakest quarterly growth in more than four years. Revenue is projected to rise 2.7% to $4.74 billion, which would be its smallest growth rate in four quarters."Over the past 18 months, we have regarded the conditions of the U.S. Tobacco industry as very strong leading us to regard this recent era as 'the Golden Age,' " said Stifel analyst Christoper Growe in a Jan. 14 report that it has a buy rating on Altria and maintains a positive bias on it.While he expects 2016 industry growth to be less robust than 2015, the general industry conditions are still robust enough to support his bullish stance.He cited light litigation and regulatory activity, modest tax hikes, commanding market share, strong pricing, and an improving consumer market.Sales volumes slowed in 2014 but rebounded in 2015, led by stronger overall economic conditions like lower gas prices and employment gains, though those tailwinds should be lapped in early 2016.Altria shares crossed above its 50-day average last Friday and pushed higher Monday. It's been above the 200-day line since early October. Its stock  was up about 1% at 58.82 in Monday afternoon trading on the stock market today. It has a strong 92 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 92% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth.Philip Morris International (PMI), was up 0.8%. Reynolds American (RAI), the top-rated company in the eight-company tobacco group with a  best-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating, climbed 1.6%. British American Tobacco (BTI) rose 0.5%.

The major market indexes were strongly higher in early Thursday morning trade ahead of the House's vote on the tax reform bill scheduled for after 1:30 pm ET. Shares are trading at the top of the 5% buy range from a 1083.41 buy point.Among companies reporting earnings, NetApp (NTAP) announced strong quarterly results, sending its shares up over 17%. Production issues with the Model 3 have weighed on the stock, as it sits below its 50- and 200-day moving average lines.Within the IBD 50, PayPal (PYPL) jumped nearly 3% to new highs, and is well-extended from a 55.24 flat-base entry.In the meantime, Paycom Software (PAYC) rose over 3%. Stocks dropped hard at Thursday's open, as undertow from global markets, company news and mixed early earnings reports took a toll.XThe Nasdaq led the drop, down 0.6%, with the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 each falling 0.3%.A sell-off in Hong Kong left the Hang Seng index down 1.9% as a sudden rise in short-term lending costs sent property developers sharply lower. The index has gained more than 30% since the start of the year.Hong Kong's stumble rippled into Europe's markets, which came under additional pressure after Spain's government formally suspended the autonomy of Catalonia. The region's parliament had elected to secede in what the Spanish government considered an illegal vote. The federal government reportedly plans to begin taking over control of the region Saturday.Spain's leading index, the IBEX 35, traded down 0.9%. Frankfurt's DAX and the CAC-40 in Paris fell hardest among Europe's larger benchmarks, down 0.6% apiece in afternoon trade.Verizon (VZ) surged to top top of the Dow, up almost 5% as third-quarter earnings fell less, and revenue rose more, than expected by analysts. Wireless subscriber growth was the big surprise, with 603,00 new subscribers vs. estimates for an increase of 362,000.The move lifted Verizon shares past a 50.41 buy point.Travelers (TRV) dropped 0.4%, despite after reporting third-quarter revenue and earnings well above analysts' targets. Investors had watched the report closely following for the impact of hurricanes in Texas and Florida.Early Thursday, Travelers rose above a 130.47 buy point in a cup base but reversed below the entry.At the bottom of the Dow, Apple (AAPL) dived 1.8% after news reports that the one company providing cellular service to Apple Watch products in China cut its service without explanation. Apple shares have been fighting to hold above support at their 10-week moving average.Nike (NKE) dropped 0.5% after Goldman Sachs downgraded the stock to neutral from buy. Goldman cited high levels of inventory at brick-and-mortar retailers, and pressure from promotional pricing as Nike products move to direct online sales via Amazon.com (AMZN) and others.EBay (EBAY) slumped 4%, after reporting late Wednesday that its third-quarter results met expectations, but its fourth-quarter earnings guidance stopped short of consensus views.Shares have pulled back in a test of support at their 10-week moving average, just above a 37.58 buy point in a cup base.Tobacco brand Philip Morris (PM) dipped 4% in early action. The Marlboro maker missed analysts' third-quarter targets on its earnings and revenue lines, and guided fourth-quarter expectations below consensus views.  Shares have been declining since June.IBD 50 stock Winnebago (WGO) dropped 2%, depite better-than-expected fiscal fourth-quarter results and a new a $70 million share buyback program.  The stock ended Wednesday up 19% from a 37.30 buy point. Investors who bought during that September breakout should consider locking in some profit once gains hit 20%.Adobe Systems (ADBE) opened 9% higher as the stock received an upgrade after the software and cloud leader released positive fourth-quarter guidance late Wednesday. Adobe shares closed Wednesday 3% below a 157.99 buy point in a flat base.Unemployment claims declined for a third straight week, to 222,000 in the week ended Oct. 14, the Labor Department said. That was down from 244,000 claims in the prior week, and well below consensus expectations for a decrease to 240,000.The four-week moving average dropped to 248,500, also a third straight decline and its lowest level of the third quarter.Mid-Atlantic region manufacturing activity powered up in October, sending the Philadelphia Federal Reserve's Manufacturing Business Outlook Survey to 27.9 for the month, up from 23.8 in September and clobbering estimates calling for a decline to 20.2.New orders and shipments decreased for the month, but remained positive, the report said. Employment rose and the length of workweeks increased, delivery times increased and backlogs rose.The Conference Board releases its Leading Indicators index for September at 10 a.m. ET. Release of the September Treasury budget was pushed back for a second day, to 2 p.m. ET.Esther George, president of the Kansas City Federal Reserve, is scheduled to speak on rural and urban growth issues in Altus, Okla., at 9:30 a.m. ET.RELATED:The Big Picture: Market Indicators Don't Signal Another 'Black Monday'MongoDB Prices High After Qudian's Strong Debut: How To Play New IPOsHottest Stocks For Busiest Day Of Earnings: Investing Action PlanNew Option Strategy Limits Risk Around EarningsStocks Near Buy Zone Ahead Of Earnings

Key indexes remained near the breakeven point Thursday afternoon after the first set of top-tier banks Citigroup (C) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) reported decent third-quarter results, officially kicking off Q3 earnings season.XBoth Citi and JPMorgan fell in heavy turnover, but are not triggering any sell signals.Apple (AAPL), meanwhile, quietly retook its former buy point from a flat base at 156.75 while social media phenom Snap (SNAP) jumped sharply for a second straight session.Apple is trying to stretch its win streak to four sessions and got as high as 157.37. Investors with conviction or a big cushion of gains in the stock may purchase shares, but volume is largely absent. Another strategy would be to wait for the iPhone giant to climb back above the 50-day moving average, currently near 158, or wait even longer and see if it can form a new base.At 2:30 pm ET, The Nasdaq composite edged slightly lower after marking a new all-time high of 6613.50. The Nasdaq 100-tracking Powershares QQQ Trust ETF (QQQ), S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average were all virtually flat.Volume was running higher vs. the same time Wednesday on both main exchanges.Apple had rallied a little more than 5% after clearing its 11-week flat base on Aug. 2 following its best EPS growth in nearly a year. The pullback to below the 156.75 entry and drop below the 50-day moving average reflected a sobering of investors' minds after the company unveiled its iPhone 8 and X models.However, such drops back to a proper buy point are not unusual, even among big market winners. IBD has noted in the past that as many as four out of 10 true leaders will backtrack to or near the buy point in a proper base, shaking out weak holders, before resuming its rally.Plus, Apple did not trigger the golden rule of selling.Apple has gained more than 39% since its Jan. 6-9 breakout from a first-stage cup with handle. Investors who bought at that prime entry would be justified in taking gains, but those who wish to see if there is room to run may hold until the stock shows a devastating break of the 10-week moving average (as seen on an IBD weekly chart; the 10-week line is painted in red) in massive volume.That has yet to occur.As noted in an earlier Stock Market Today column on Wednesday, the iPhone, Apple Watch and iMac marketer is in the middle of a slow yet steady turnaround in its fundmentals. IBD research has pointed out that nearly one out of four of the best stock market winners in history were corporate turnaround situations.In such cases, the stock's recent price-and-volume action, RS Rating, relative strength line and changes in current quarterly numbers matter far more than conventional IBD measures of growth that look at longer time periods. For instance, IBD's EPS Rating looks at both annual profit performance over the past three to five years as well as those in the past few quarters.For this reason, IPOs tend to have weaker EPS Ratings, because they have a younger record of profits.Snap, however, did trigger the golden rule of investing after it tried to rally back following a fireworks-like debut on the NYSE and a spectacular 34% free-fall in two weeks' time in March. Those who tried to buy later that month broke a key IBD rule, which is to never buy a stock before its base fully forms.While the rebound from an 18.90 low on March 17 to as high as 24.40 six sessions later was impressive, Snap was still in basing mode. Those who bought on the way up were forced to cut their losses at 8% or less.Now, shares in the money-losing social media network are trying to fashion an authentic first-stage base following a 62% slide from its all-time high of 29.44.Snap has lost money every year since 2015 despite showing excellent top-line growth. Shares are rising amid bullish comments made by Credit Suisse. Morgan Stanley is Snap's chief investment banker.In the second quarter, Venice, Calif.-based Snap lost 16 cents a share even though revenue soared 153% to $181.7 million, a quarterly record. Snap showed gross margin of $29.5 million, or 16.2% of total revenue. However, Snap also marked an operating loss of $449 million as R&D costs rose 608%, sales and marketing expense jumped 270%, and general and administrative costs ran up 308%.Defense firms continue to rally amid an ongoing threat of military conflict between North Korea and the U.S. Lockheed Martin (LMT) rose 0.7% to 320.95 to mark its 10th straight gain. The F-35 fighter jet maker is up nearly 19% after rising past a 269.84 flat-base entry in mid-March.Lockheed's earnings per share have climbed 49%, 24%, 8% and 12% vs. year-ago levels over the past four quarters amid revenue increases of 15%, 19%, 7% and 10%.Are there other relatively young IPOs (going public in the past five years or later) that are making money and doing well in the market today? Sure.Square (SQ), Five Below (FIVE), Ollie's Bargain Outlet (OLLI), eBay spin-off PayPal (PYPL), YY (YY), Jupai (JP) and others are just some examples. Most of these inhabit the IBD 50. Watch for follow-on entry points or new bases to develop.On Thursday's economic news, weekly U.S. jobless claims fell to 243,000, below the Econoday forecast of 252,000 and 17,000 claims less than the prior week.Crude oil dropped hard after U.S. inventories slumped by 2.7 million barrels, a smaller drawdown than the 6 million barrel decline in the prior week. WTI futures on the NYMEX fell 1.4% to $50.56 a barrel. Gold jumped more than 0.6% and futures hit a session high of $1,299.80 a troy ounce.IBD'S TAKE: Did you know that the flat base, which reflects an unwillingness among large fund managers to dump their shares, often serves as a launchpad for big breakouts and tremendous price gains for many growth stocks? Learn the elements of this bullish pattern via this Investor's Corner column and add it to your knowledge of charts so you can have an edge on Wall Street.RELATED:Will The Stock Market Top Soon? Major indexes still held near the break-even line in late-afternoon trading Thursday, a day after details on President Trump's tax cut plan failed to gather praise from congressional Democrats. Bipartisan support is likely necessary for Trump to follow through on his pledges to reinvigorate the economy.XMeanwhile, Q2 U.S. GDP growth was revised slightly up to an annualized rate of 3.1%, up from 3%. August durable goods orders jumped 1.7% on a month-to-month basis, shocking the Street. Ex-transportation equipment, orders still rose a respectable 0.2% while core capital goods orders rose 0.9%."Healthy readings for these indicators suggest continued upbeat momentum in the industrial sector despite downside risk from the recent hurricanes," Lewis Alexander, North American economist at Nomura, wrote in a recent note.The Building-Residential/Commercial industry group ranks 13th out of 197 IBD industry groups for six-month relative price performance. Energy-Solar, Machine-Material Handling/Automation and Aerospace/Defense industry groups are also in the top 20.At 3:30 pm ET, the Nasdaq composite edged 0.1% lower, taking a 0.6% drop in dull trading by Apple (AAPL) shares in stride. Apple had rebounded as much as 3.4% in the past two sessions after hitting a short-term low of 149.16.At 153.10, the iPhone giant remains modestly below the 156.75 buy point in a second-stage flat base, a key chart pattern seen in many top growth stocks.The Nasdaq 100-tracking PowerShares QQQ Trust (QQQ) ETF was off 0.2% and is finding support at its 50-day moving average. But the Dow Jones industrial average edged up less than 0.2% and the S&P 500 less than 2 points, or less than 0.1%.Volume is running lower on both main exchanges vs. the same time on Wednesday.Returning to Apple, the megacap tech is still up more than 29% since clearing a first-stage bottoming base pattern on Jan. 6-9, when it broke out of a three-month cup with handle at 118.12. In a bottoming base, a stock typically declines 50% or more from its all-time high, but then bottoms out and forms a new base that can set up a potential breakout to 52-week highs.Selling a stock once it's risen 20% to 25% past a proper buy point in a cup base, double bottom or other pattern is one of the most important offense-type sell signals for individual investors.Those who have more conviction can decide to hold longer but then must be on the lookout for signs that the tide is turning from that of heavy demand to heavy supply. That's where sell signals, such as a sharp break through the 50-day moving average and failure to rebound quickly, the biggest single-session point loss in heavy turnover, or a failed breakout from a late-stage base, come in.Among top-ranked industry groups, biotech, chip equipment and plastics firms led the upside with gains of 0.8% or more. However, former big winner Gilead Sciences (GILD) fell nearly 5% in fast turnover to 79.82, giving back a lot of the gains made over the past month.The pioneer in HIV treatments cleared a first-stage bottoming base pattern with a 76.59 buy point four weeks ago.Watch to see if the stock can stay above its rising 10-week moving average, which is drawn in red on an IBD weekly chart.The Dow Jones transports rallied 0.4%. At 9880, the index has now risen 9.7% from its Aug. 24 low.Autohome (ATHM) helped spark a sell-off in some names in the Chinese internet space. The online provider of car information and ads at one point slid more than 9% to an intraday low of 57.70 before rebounding. Volume continued to run more than triple usual pace. At one point, the stock got as low as 57.70, below its rising 50-day moving average.When a stock posts its biggest single-day point drop in heavy volume since a proper breakout, it usually means it's a great time to take at least some gains and lighten up on the position.In the case of Autohome, it is also the first time for the stock to pierce its 50-day moving average since an early-May breakout past a 36.11 entry in an eight-week cup. Autohome rose as much as 87% before its current correction. A further drop below the 50-day line, especially in heavy turnover, would warrant selling shares and locking in profits.Autohome fell on news of an abrupt resignation of both President Yan Kang and CFO Julian Wang. The company also named Jun Zou, former chief financial officer at iDreamSky, to replace Wang.The company announced that the resignations "were not due to any disagreement with the Company regarding its business, finance, accounting and/or any other affairs."A more serious concern for shareholders may lay in whether Autohome will be able to maintain high growth in its fundamentals.Earnings grew 39% to 71 cents a share in the second quarter, matching the highest increase over the past six quarters. The increase also was an acceleration from a 15% rise in Q1. However, Q2 sales grew 11% to $230.4 million, slowly sharply from gains of 56%, 74% and 16% in the prior three periods.In the year-ago quarter, revenue jumped 49%.Analysts see revenue growth to slow further, to 3% in Q3 to $227 million, then fall 11% to $257.6 million in Q4 vs. a year ago.Despite the slower growth in the top line the past two quarters, Autohome was able to grow earnings by 39% in Q2 to 71 cents a share on the back of improving margins. In Q2, gross margin rose to 81.4% vs. 65.9% in the year-ago quarter.Net margin rose by a surprising 750 basis points to 36.2%, the highest in eight quarters, according to research by William O'Neil + Co.Autohome went public in December 2013.IBD's TAKE: Do you want to quickly check the quality of a new stock prospect in terms of its fundamentals, technical action and level of institutional sponsorship? The Stock Checkup is your answer. Notice how the doctor's facial expression changes based on the quality of its rank across five major categories, such as relative strength, earnings per share growth, and SMR (Sales Growth + Margins + ROE). However, the chart is still the best way to determine when a stock should be sold and gains should be locked in, not IBD's proprietary ratings such as the Composite Rating. Read about how Stock Checkup can help you improve your results in this Investor's Corner.Online retailer JD.com (JD), meanwhile, slumped for a sixth straight session, falling more than 3% to 38.40 in double usual volume. The stock is now forming a new base since peaking at 48.99 and remains comfortably above its rising 200-day line.(Follow Chung on Twitter at @IBD_DChung for intraday comments on the stock market and leading stocks.)RELATED:How To Win With Stocks: Start With A Simple RoutineIs It Time To Buy Stocks Now? They call it stormy December, but January was  -- worse.On the heels of December's 1.58% decline in the S&P 500 and 2.80% tumble for U.S. diversified stock mutual funds, in January the broad market lost 4.96% and U.S. diversified stock funds dove 6.25%, according to Lipper Inc.It was the sixth worst January for the big-cap bogey in the past 47 years. And in that span it was the third worst opening month to a year for U.S. diversified stock funds as a group.Click Here To See List Of Top Performing Mutual Funds Past 6 MonthsThere was no mystery about the main culprits. Investors worried about stock market news that harped on China's economic slowdown and speculated about how badly it would affect the global economy -- including that of the U.S.And investors fretted about oil's declining price. Light sweet crude, for example, fell from $37.04 a barrel to $33.62 by January's end. It closed below $30 on five trading days."China and oil are two of the reasons for the weak market in January," said Phil Orlando, chief equity strategist at Federated Investors. "I would also throw into the mix the strong dollar, high inventories, weak manufacturing sector and the political cycle."Still, the market trended higher in its final eight sessions. Why? Credit the Federal Reserve, Orlando says. On Jan. 27, the Fed signaled that its decisions regarding future rate hikes "would be dovish, data dependent and cautious," Orlando said.That was in stark contrast to the Fed's quarter-percentage-point rate hike in December.Also, Japan's central bank went to negative interest rates on certain bank reserves -- a move that bolsters stocks by making them more attractive than cash.The Federal Reserve action preceded by two days the Bureau of Economic Analysis' release of its advance estimate of GDP growth in the fourth quarter: annualized 0.7% growth, lower than Q3's 2% gain and slightly below market expectations of 0.8% for Q4.So investors, who were already spooked by the five indicators that Orlando cites, were relieved by the BEA's move, which virtually wiped out the prospect of three or four rates hikes in 2016. "And when the Fed does make its next rate hike, investors know that that will be a sign of the Fed's faith that the economy is strong enough to handle it," Orlando said.Orlando believes that the Fed won't lift its rate again until the U.S. sees a quarter with 2% annualized GDP growth. "July is the earliest we might see sufficiently strong data," he said. "Then September is the next time that they'd be likely to raise the rate."A 9.03% gain made dedicated short-bias funds the best-performing mutual funds among all U.S. diversified stock funds in January.Click Here To See The Top-Performing Stock And Bond Mutual Fund CategoriesAmong just market capitalization and style categories within U.S. diversifieds, large-cap core funds did best by losing the least, 5.35% in the month. Equity-income funds gave up even less: -3.92%.Top large-cap growth managers included Frank Caruso, whose AB Large Cap Growth Fund (APGAX) fell 6.08% last month.Reflecting the flight to safe havens, commodities precious metals funds paced all sectors, gaining 2.53%.Also reflecting the flight to safety, U.S. Treasury bond funds leapt 3.45% as taxable-bond funds overall lost 0.34% in the month.Latin American funds led foreign-region stock funds by losing the least, -4.30%.Orlando expects the market blahs to continue until about midyear."I don't think China is going into recession," he said. "Consumers are doing well there, but it will take a couple of quarters for investors to figure that out. Consumers in China will offset weakness in manufacturing by midyear."By midyear, investors should also see that the U.S. dollar has stopped strengthening altogether, or at least as fast as it has, he adds. "That dollar stabilization will make it easier for U.S. megacaps to export, which will boost corporate earnings," he said.Corporate inventories are already falling, he says. "So we might see a restocking-cycle kick off in the second half of the year, which would boost manufacturing," he said.The Chicago Purchasing Managers Index jumped to 55.6 in January from 42.9 in December, the highest pace of growth in a year. When that barometer tops 50, it's a sign of growth in the manufacturing sector. "It was in contraction mode the last six months," Orlando said.As for politics, only once in the past 75 years has the party in power extended control of the White House to a third straight term. Concern about weak growth in jobs and wages should help swing control of the presidency to Republicans, Orlando says. And that should be good for business interests.With his eyes glued to midyear, Orlando expects that the technology, consumer-discretionary and industrial sectors to lead the breakout. That should benefit tech-hardware makers, chipmakers, automakers, homebuilders and airlines, he says."Once the Fed starts to tighten again, then financials ought to work better," he said.In the meantime, his focus is on lower-beta, higher-dividend stocks. Names that he likes include Exxon Mobile (XOM) and Royal Dutch (RDSA)."In the first half of the year, we have overweights in Europe and Japan vs. the U.S.," he said. "We're overweight in developed foreign markets but underweight in emerging markets."Jeff Rottinghaus, manager of $1.6 billion T. Rowe Price Growth & Income (PRGIX) and of $203 million Large Cap (TRULX), also expects "a pretty tough year." To cope with slower earnings growth, he has beefed up what he calls quality and higher-yield stocks. He's also been looking for early cyclical stocks with sound fundamentals, whose prices have been beaten up.In railroads, he began to buy Kansas City Southern (KSU) late last year. "In a recovery, it should do well," he said. The stock is 32% off its 52-week high. Earnings fell 6% last year and are expected to increase 1% this year and 13% next year.In financials, he likes Intercontinental Exchange (ICE). "They take advantage of volatility," he said. Intercontinental provides a market for derivatives, which many investors use to hedge volatility.He also likes American Tower (AMT) and Crown Castle (CCI), two REITs that own wireless towers. Their long-term contracts with telecom carriers give them "fantastic recurring revenue businesses that should do well in a more stressed economic environment," he said.And in consumer staples he owns CVS (CVS), PepsiCo (PEP) and Philip Morris International (PM).In fixed income, he expects bonds generally to look more appealing if the Fed is forced to pause its rate hikes. In that scenario, bond prices should stabilize rather than decline.Rottinghaus would like to find commodities stocks that have been dragged down by their sector or industry group -- more than their own fundamentals call for. "Those companies could do well over the next couple of years," he said. "But they're still not there yet."Image provided by Shutterstock.

As far as most income investors are concerned, the steadier the payout the better. An added bonus: a high dividend growth rate. Here are five Dividend Leaders that offer both, as well as a yield that's well above the S&P 500's average 2.08% payout.All five score a Dividend Stability Factor of 1 on a scale from 0 (most stable) to 99 (most volatile) on a three- to five-year basis.

Philip Morris International (PM), which pays a 4.6% annual dividend, tops the list based on that measure. Its long-term dividend growth rate is 11%. The Marlboro maker on Dec. 9 boosted its quarterly payout by 20% to $1.02 a share, or $4.08 for the year.Analysts expect the tobacco firm's earnings to decline for a second straight year in 2015, before rising 5% next year. The stock is below a 90.18 flat-base buy point. It's up about 7% year to date, vs. the S&P 500's 2% loss.Pfizer (PFE), which also made the Friday column featuring high-yield drug stocks, is second, with an annualized payout of 3.7%. Like Philip Morris, its dividend growth rate is 11%. The stock is still below its 10-week and 40-week lines as it consolidates.General Mills (GIS) also has a long-term dividend growth rate of 11%. The cereal maker on Thursday announced a 33% increase in its quarterly payout to 44 cents a share. That works out to $1.76 on a full-year basis, for a 3.1% yield.The company also reported quarterly results that day that missed views on both the top and bottom lines. Shares fell 3% Thursday but found support at the 200-day moving average. The stock, up about 8% year to date, has been consolidating since early August.Coca-Cola (KO), which also pays a 3.1% annual dividend, has a long-term dividend growth rate of 9%. The beverage giant is an S&P 500 Dividend Aristocrat — companies that have increased their dividends each year for the past 25 years — and a top Warren Buffett holding. Shares are slightly positive this year.

***Breaking News — Alcoa earnings reported after the close…..***Alcoa (AA) comes out of the gate running then walking then tripping — in regular way trading yesterday the stock closed down 8 cts on the day at $8/sh,  then at 4:02 pm they announced earnings and - it is very confusing for most of us to grasp....... You see they 'swung to a loss due to restructuring charges'.....(Those losses totaled $500 mil or -0.39 cts/sh), Top line revenues fell 18%  - but once you ignore all of that and add back those nasty 'one time charges' - then they reported 'adjusted earnings' of +0.04 cts/sh......beating the analysts estimates of +0.02 cts/sh - Never mind that those numbers were off by 90% y/y - that is not important......what is important is that they 'beat the analysts predictions'.......  This initially sent the algo's into a frenzy and the stock rallied, fell, rallied and then fell again.....ending that session 0.06 cts lower....So AA is the first one to set the tone....they beat the estimate and they talked up their book - discussing the coming split and the positive guidance and outlook for the new companies........CEO KIaus Kleinfeld - takes to CNBC with Kelly Evans and lays it out -  "We basically have done everything in our own control, reshaped the business and look where we are, we're still standing and still making a profit," — stressing that they have “changed the architecture”….In addition he has a very specific view on China and is sure that the slowdown in demand in commodities from China would not be a negative for Alcoa….saying —

"We are not dependent on China. China has opportunities rather than threats for us".And THAT is the kind of statement that investors want and need to hear — “We are not dependent on China…”  Will this be the new rallying cry for earnings announcements?   How many more companies will make the same claim?  Think of the ‘rip your face off rally’ that would consume the mkts if more CEO's put it in perspective...... This morning AA is trading up 20 cts  or +2.5% - in pre-mkt trading......

And that 'rip you face off rally'...well - US futures are now up 15 pts as a new day dawns here in the US......this is NOT unexpected as we are well into oversold territory...........Expect more chatter out of street strategists and Fed officials about the state of the US economy - especially after Klaus made it clear that he does NOT see China as the problem that so many have made it out to be....... We bounced off of S&P 1900 again yesterday to end the day at 1923......we could easily rally to 1950 with no problem and if the algo's really go wild - then a move towards S&P 2000 will be the next stop.....remember - sellers are exhausted - so expect a 'vacuum' if the mood turns.....why would anyone stand in its way?Overnight - Asian mkts continued to struggle - most closing lower - Japan -2.7%, Hong Kong - 0.89%, ASX -0.14%, Kospi - 0.21%...the only surprise?  China - they closed +0.20% - as they defended the Yuan - buying the currency to help support it - sending it up 0.7% vs. the dollar.........Oil and commodity demand though,  (or lack of) still casting a pall over that region of the world.....Oil falling once again edging ever closer to $30/barrel in overnight trading.European mkts this morning are disconnecting from Asia - as the rout in oil and other commodities (copper, silver, gold etc) began to pare the losses seen in Asia - giving investors/traders there a reason to breathe and jump on what is looking to be that snap back rally that we have all been expecting.  FTSE +1.63%,  CAC 40 +2.34%,  DAX+ 2.55%, EUROSTOXX +2.19%, SPAIN +1.66% , and ITALY +1.55%

Now yesterday — the mkt did try to stabilize — struggled all day — both the Dow and S&P swinging on both sides of the unchanged line only to rally into the close ending the day in the green.  Russell small cap lost another 12 pts sending that index into the abyss - at one point confirming a 'bear mkt' for US small caps......taking it down 20% from the midsummer 2014 highs....……. The S&P and Dow have just entered 'correction territory (-10% +) off their 2014 highs...which is actually surprising considering all of the issues it has been dealing with.....In fact -  the fact that 'the mkt' has not imploded and gone into bear mkt territory (decline of 20% or more)  is a testament to the broader strength of the US equity mkts.... -  in light of weaker oil, stronger dollar, slowing export growth, weaker commodities, more signs of a manufacturing recession — never mind a psychotic China, the coming currency wars,  slowing Europe and slowing emerging mkt countries coupled with major global geo-political issues - including hydrogen bombs being set off by an imbecile dictator -  does suggest that maybe just maybe - investors continue to believe that we are the prettiest girl on the street.....and that the US economy is able to better weather this storm.   Now that being said — there are individual names and sectors that have gotten slaughtered for sure, but on the whole — the mkt could be in a very different place considering the daily beating that it has taken for months now

Now Oil broke (again) and is now testing 12 yrs lows....breaching the all important $32.40 support level early on…..…this alone  should have been more than enough to cause the mkts to go into SELL mode — but they did not…surprising so many…… Having crude oil take out the 2008 lows is not surprising given all of the talk but there is some support at the $30 level (look back to 2002). However, be forewarned - mkts tend to over react once the herd piles on - So, it could get even rougher before this is over.The VIX — otherwise known as the fear index — tells us another story......and while it has not SPIKED higher — it has traded higher -  further suggesting an orderly re-allocation vs. a throw  "the kitchen sink out panic"…… Yesterday's high of $27.66 feels more like a top and if so - then we may see that reversal soon....

As bearish as it feels now we need to understand that this market is now incredibly oversold  on a short-term basis. We are due for a short covering - 'rip your face off rally' at any moment....Could today be it?.Eco data today is relatively insignificant....and the only FED mouthpiece is Richmond Fed Pres - Jeffrey Lacker who speaks at 3:15 pm .Take good care.KpFollow Kenny Polcari on Twitter and KennyPolcari.comKenny Polcari is Vice President and director of NYSE Floor Operations on behalf of O’Neil Securities, Inc., a sister company of Investor's Business Daily. Stocks surged yesterday - The Dow ended 390 points higher, The S&P ended up 48 pts or 2.5% higher after the mess on Friday that had investors worried that China - which had been closed for two days (Thurs/Fri) last week, was going to IMPLODE on Monday……..Rumors and chatter that the 'end was near' caused a massive Risk Off mood going into the weekend……but alas - that was not the story that was written.

As we now know - On Monday - China did end the day a bit lower - 1.5% - but did not IMPLODE, then on Tuesday - a late day surge pushed the Shanghai composite up 2.9% subtly suggesting a bit of 'state intervention' no matter what they say…

(Now remember - China is 12 hours ahead of NY - so Sunday night in NY at 9 pm is Monday morning in China at 9 am - Since US markets were closed on Monday - China had two days to trade (Sunday night and Monday night) BEFORE US investors/traders were back at their desks)

During Monday night trading (Tuesday morning in China) we saw that late day surge causing global markets to breathe a sigh of relief - the negative news about a fall in both imports and exports did little to damp investor demand….….European markets moved higher and US futures - which had been up all night - continued the push…..On Tuesday - the US market opened up 300 + pts - in one move - and then churned there for most of the day before the late day surge that closed the markets on its highs.

Now this is important to understand - trading today is highly automated, investors get to react to global news instantaneously, computers have replaced the human element - so unlike human-based open outcry trading - that would have seen markets open up 10 or 12 pts on the S&P and then move higher during the day, creating the excitement and energy - today when the futures signal a strong (or weak) opening - all the action happens in the early minutes of trade - stocks open up 30 pts and then don't do very much - the move that used to take the whole day - now happens in seconds and then it's over….

OK - so now you ask me - then how come two weeks ago when the market opened DOWN 1000 pts we saw that immediate push higher and the increased volatility that whole day and for the days since? Fair question -

That move was way overdone (markets were down 6% in the mins after the opening bell rang) - caused by the automation, fragmentation of the markets, volatile ETF products that in a panicked market could not be correctly priced (WARNING- RED FLAG) all resulting in massive dislocation of prices and 'broken technical support' levels that once pierced - caused much more action by traders and long term investors who now took advantage of the stupidity. Those broken technical levels -caused big internal damage to the market. This then raised the level of volatile as long term investors and traders re-evaluated risk, as they searched for opportunities in the wake of the bloodbath. Ask yourself - Who was in control that day? The Buyers or the Sellers? Clearly the buyers - as the sell algos were in panic mode.

Now yesterday's surge was not anything to write home about - the market opened up 0.75% (less than 1%) - so that dislocation was not the same. (0.75% vs. 6%). Stocks which now seem to be in the 1920/1970 range were trading smack in the middle at short term resistance of 1950 and did NOT really pierce this short term resistance until very late in the day - which is when you saw the action build.

Once the buyers realized that the sellers were being a bit pricier - they started to come after them - challenging the next technical resistance level at 1970. So ask yourself - Who was in control yesterday? The buyers or the sellers? Clearly the Sellers - as the buy algos became a bit anxious to 'scoop up' the bargains created by the panicked sellers from Friday. (It's like a circle really).

And this morning - global markets are on a tear yet again……this morning US futures are up 20 pts - currently trading at 1983 - piercing last Thursday's highs of 1975 and now looking to test S&P 2000. All this is all about psychology 101. Remember - the market has suffered some internal damage and needs to back and fill and find support before really moving substantially higher. Today we get the JOLTS job report (Job Openings/Labor Turnover) for any additional hints on the health of the labor market. Expect to continue to hear more about next week's Fed meeting and 'The Policy Decision 2015!' (I mean it's almost like the Presidential race coverage - "Race for the White House -Election 2016")
Look for the market to run into resistance at the 1990 level but find short term support at 1970 and larger support at 1950.

In Asian trading - investors/traders went wild for stocks. Japan awakens and surges 7.7% or 1300 pts as investors went on a shopping spree. Remember - trading on Tuesday saw that market fall 2.4% erasing all gains for the year causing investors to wonder - what's next? In early trading - PM Abe announced that he would seek to lower the corporate tax rate by 3.3% and the rest is history - as they say. Analysts/investors and traders around the globe applauded the PM's attempts at employing FISCAL policy to complement MONETARY policy. Financials and export-oriented stocks led the way - The question now is - Is this move a head fake or does it have legs?

China rallied another 2.3% as speculation continues about more gov't support in the form of - guess what? FISCAL policy. Hong Kong and Australia followed in kind and ended the day up 4% and 2% respectively.

In Europe - the opening bell saw those markets all surge in the early mins of trade. Positive economic news out of Germany - both imports and exports suggest that the German economy is healthy and global demand for German goods is strong coupled that with the FISCAL policy initiatives out of Asia and you see investors cheering. The sense is that the broader macroeconomic environment in Europe is on solid ground and that Mario Draghi and the ECB are in control. FTSE +1.8%, CAC 40 +2.4%, DAX +1.7%, EUROSTOXX+2.3%, SPAIN +2.4% and ITALY +1.8%.
Take good care -
Kp

Rome wasn't built in one day, and wealth takes time to accumulate. In the stock market are some top-rated names that investors may want to hold for the long term. For ideas on great stocks to put in your portfolio for the long haul, take at look at the Income Investor column (today on B9).
IBD isn't just about covering the fastest-growing, highly volatile stocks. There is money to make from stocks in the Income Investor , published every day.

First, check stocks on the Dividend Leaders screen, a table that runs to the left of the column. Many of them are old, established companies that have seen their best days of growth behind them. They are still making money, but growth has slowed to a trickle.
Firms such as AT&T (T), Philip Morris (PM) and General Electric (GE) have made the screen recently.

Sometimes, faster-growing companies make the screen. U.S. Silica (SLCA) did it back in late November of 2013. The maker. If you already have a large gain, don't give everything back and exit with an 8% loss.

Instead, watch out for sell signs such as breaking above a channel line and climax tops. Also consider selling if a stock breaks a major uptrend line or slices its 50-day or 10-week moving average in big turnover.

The Nov. 5, 2012, edition of the Income Investor featured Starbucks (SBUX). The coffee giant raised its quarterly payout. The column also highlighted its strong earnings and other business fundamentals.
Starbucks was building the right side of a new base. It would go on to form a cup-with-handle base with a 56.10 buy point (1).
The stock cleared that entry in the week ended Jan. 25, 2013, but didn't get far before forming what turned out to be a new flat base with a 57.37 buy point.

Starbucks broke out again in the week ended March 8. Volume bulged above average (2). Although it pulled back soon after, it eventually perked up and rallied 29% by early August (3). Shares doubled by July 2015.Rome wasn't built in one day, and wealth takes time to accumulate. In the stock market are some top-rated names that investors may want to hold for the long term. Best ETFs 2015 August Performance

Dividend ETFs are charging ahead in the performance stakes, and little wonder. Amid China-induced choppiness, these funds brought a measure of reassurance to frayed nerves. They're packed with well-established companies, often with a value tilt.

PowerShares S&P 500 High Dividend  (SPHD) — a top-performing ETF in the past month with a 2.6% gain — holds IBD Dividend Leaders AT&T (T), Philip Morris (PM) and Altria Group (MO) in its 50-stock portfolio.

Investors sought out value stocks amid concerns about global growth, both at home and abroad. First Trust Dorsey Wright Focus 5 (FV) shrank 2% in the past month, as decidedly mixed earnings weighed on investors. Year to date, growth-focused exchange traded funds are still the clear winners. FV, a $4.34 billion ETF with a midcap growth skew, is up 13% year to date.
SDPR S&P 500 (SPY), holding a blend of growth and value stocks, gave up 0.9% in the past month and has climbed 3.4% year to date.
What are money managers' ETF picks for successful investing in the year ahead? Here's the scoop:
 Luke Nagell, associate portfolio manager at Denver-based Weatherstone Capital Management; $750 million in assets under management:
Our outlook for the second half of 2015 remains cautious due to a slowing in global economic growth and subdued commodity prices coupled with rising bond yields.

Vanguard Health Care (VHT). The ETF provides a good broad-based exposure to the health care industry ranging from health care equipment to pharmaceuticals. The health care sector continues to exhibit strong earnings and revenue growth, and we expect this trend to continue for the rest of the year. Additionally, the pickup in M&A activity among health care companies is a positive sign, particularly within the pharmaceutical sector. VHT provides good exposure to this sector.

Market Vectors Pharmaceutical (PPH). To access the pharmaceutical sector directly, we recommend this ETF. In addition to pharmaceutical companies leading the way in M&A activity, the sector has exhibited positive signals on a longer-term momentum basis.

PowerShares Preferred (PGX). This ETF provides a good source of income during this period of volatility within the fixed-income space. It is made up of preferred securities, primarily within the financial sector. For investors searching for income and who would like to stay more defensive, this is a good way to generate a reasonable rate of return without taking on the additional risk inherent within the common stock market. The 6% yield is attractive on an absolute basis and financial firms' strong balance sheets should continue to make this a stable source of income.
 Masood Vojdani, founder and CEO of MV Financial in Bethesda, Md.:
We favor U.S. exposure as the current risk environment is tilted towards non-U.S. threats, particularly in developed Europe and China.

IShares Core S&P 500 (IVV). An S&P 500 exposure would be a good portfolio anchor in this environment. IVV is one of the most liquid ETFs currently traded and is allocated across all 10 GICS sectors. IVV has a 0.07% expense ratio.

IShares Core S&P SmallCap (IJR). There continues to be growth opportunities in the U.S. that small companies will partake in. A broad small-cap exposure without a particular style tilt can further diversify core U.S. equity holdings as we move through the second half of the year. IJR has a net expense ratio of 0.12%.
Health Care Select Sector SPDR (XLV) and Financials Select Sector SPDR (XLF). We believe the health care sector will benefit from robust earnings growth and M&A activity among providers.
The sector also continues to benefit from the Affordable Care Act, which helped contribute to it being the second best sector last year with a return of 25.34%.
The financial sector is well positioned with the Federal Reserve's rate hike looming. This will work to the advantage of banks and insurance companies, which tend to benefit from rising rates.

Both ETFs have net expense ratios of 0.15%.Best ETFs 2015 August PerformanceDividend ETFs are charging ahead in the performance stakes, and little wonder.
