History has a way of repeating itself....How many times do we need to hear this phrase? The phrase refers to the fact that we are creatures of habit and in short - events that have happened in past are bound to repeat themselves - because in the end - do we ever really learn? Think 1929, 1987, 1999, 2007-20012, and now 2015.....What do these years have in common? Stock mkt CRASHES - and if you look at each one - the common theme that runs through all of them is eerily similar.

No matter what - the stock mkt crashes were (are) the result of a variety of economic factors (domestic & international)/structural (monetary and fiscal policy) and technological imbalances coupled with raging speculation, and new and exciting "derivative products" that promised to save everyone....How's that working for you?

Recall the "roaring Twenties" (that is the 1920's) it was a time of wealth and excess.....Easy credit, high levels of debt, slowing economy and other signs of economic fissures, speculation and high margin debt all contributing factors to the crash of '29.

In 1987 - after the roaring bull mkt that began in the summer of '82 - the mkt crashed - falling 22.5% in 6 hrs.....losing over $500 bil in one day..... The move higher was fueled by falling interest rates, hostile takeovers, leveraged buyouts and a surge in junk bonds. (Junk bonds, now known as 'High Yield' are bonds that pay high interest rates due to their HIGH RISK - you see - it is the risk/reward argument)....

Portfolio Insurance (that first iteration of the coming derivative boom) that only accelerated the decline.....You see - in addition to the economic issues and structural imbalances created as a result - Portfolio Insurance was the new 'savior'. Global asset managers all bought into it - using this 'new brain child' as a way to protect against losses....(Portfolio insurance is a hedging strategy that uses stock index futures to cushion equity portfolios against broad stock market declines). As interest rates rose, many institutional money managers tried using this insurance to hedge their portfolios at the same time. As we moved through the week of Oct 14th, 1987 - the mkt got weaker and came under pressure closing on the lows on Friday Oct 16th in what was an unusually heavy volume day. On October 19th 1987, this portfolio insurance product issued a sell signal and any institution that had bought it was told to sell X% of their portfolio in order to protect it.....

The signal was issued on Sunday night - just as Asian mkts were opening...and the bloodbath began....selling beget more selling and the bottom fell out of global mkts....stock index futures mkts was flooded with billions of dollars worth of sell orders and within minutes, both the futures and stock markets began to crash and as the sun set on Asia it rose in Europe and the process continued, the bloodletting unstoppable.....and then the sun rose over the Atlantic to warm the shores of the US and the perfect storm blew the windows out......by 4 pm global mkts had suffered inconceivable losses.....as analysts/strategists and everyone else tried to put it in perspective.....The FED came to the rescue and intervened trying to prevent a repeat performance. Remarkably - the mkt recovered fairly quickly and moved higher until the fall of 1999 and the Dot Com Crash.

E-commerce and Dot Com - that was the new gold rush...any company that had either in its name helped to created another historic bubble...the Internet - was going to be the game changer. You see - the period from like 1993 - 2000 was marked by the explosion of the Internet and the founding and spectacular failures of these new companies - Investment banks hungry for product brought these companies public - selling the story of how the world was different now. Companies with zero history, revenues or any chance of ever making any revenues were brought to the mkt - investors could not get enough - IPO's and pricing boggled the mind - opening trades left you speechless and technology allowed anyone with a computer to play. Speculation and the herd mentality once again took hold. People margined their houses and their first-borns....a new type of investing was born - what came to be known as 'prefix investing' - And then it happened.....the Nasdaq peaked at 5132 on March 10, 200 only to find its low months later after losing better than 50%.

Then came the housing boom - fueled in part by failed fiscal policies initiated under Pres Clinton and Fed Chairman Greenspan.....No income verifications loans, teaser rates, interest only loans anything to get 'every American' into a home of their own....investment banks packaged these 'loans' and securitized them and sold them to global investors as the new product! Ratings agencies marked them all AAA+++ rated....never really knowing what was in them. The gov't encouraged Wall St to play nice and help make these products successful. The global economy was humming along, global investors pumping all kinds of money into these products.....then new derivative products came to the mkts.....CDS's ABS' etc....it all worked until it didn't. The problem was that no one on Wall St - ran a model that provided for a global slowdown - no one knew what would happen if the music stopped...and the music stopped in March of 2008....and the world collapsed - everyone pointed the finger at someone else - proclaiming that it was 'not our fault'...it was lack of regulation or lack of insight, or just plain greed.

The FED and every other central bank came to the rescue - artificially stimulating mkts.....many screamed about this intervention - but at the time it was the right thing to do, but then, as usual, it went on to long. Along the way - the mkts recovered, people started to feel good again....new products were designed - ETF's (exchange traded funds) gave the investor the sense that we somehow found the holy grail. You could now invest in one product and get instant access to a range of investment options....Sectors, developed countries, emerging countries, frontier countries, bonds, high yield, low yield, average yield...... different strategies, (long, short, super long and super short - leveraged products) built using 'synthetic equity'...... (a financial instrument that is artificially created) promising to offer all of the benefits of stocks (or bonds) while not being stocks (or bonds). Trade them easily...get in and get out with one product.....sounds too good to be true - right?

Well it is....because when the global economy begins to convulse you can't really trade this crap as easily as you were told. And when panic ensues - and those mkts freeze - what happens - asset managers end up selling what they can vs. what they should....and this causes stocks to crash...because - the US capital mkts are the most liquid and deepest and when push comes to shove - you can always raise money in the developed global mkts.

And today - what do we have - completely manipulated mkts - fueled by central banks around the world as elected officials shirked their responsibilities and failed to enact fiscal policy stimulus....policies that would have gone much farther in helping to solve so many issues. But that was not to happen....and today we find ourselves in another mess.....Global mkts coming unglued, monetary policies failing to make a difference after trillions of dollars and years of artificial stimulation. In fact - this global meltdown is NOT about the FED and a 25 bps hike in US rates at all. It is a realization that there has been a massive failure of leadership, a massive failure of real fiscal policy initiatives.... Couple that with unreal expectations of major global trading partners and you have a real mess.

Overnight - Asian mkts led the crash - as they did in 1987....China losing 8.5% other Asian mkts following in kind Hong Kong -5.1%, ASX -4%, Japan -4.6%.... The reason...... a complete lack of any commentary or real economic data supporting any kind of growth from Chinese authorities, which is only re-enforcing the idea they ARE NOT in control. .As the Sun rises over Europe those mkts getting drawn in - (recall 1987)....FTSE -3%, DAX -3.29%, CAC 40 - 3.4%, SPAIN -3.25%, EUROSTOXX - 3.2%.....as the blood bath continues.....

And now the sun is again washing the shores of America....US futures are showing down 47 pts...or 2.3%....as the day begins.....there is no rhyme or reason - no explanation for what will happen today....You can feel the 'panic mentality" in the air....This just has to play out for now.....no commentary from Janet or anyone else will stop this train today.....the mood is set and the action will happen as investors try to make sense out of this mess. We have broken so many tech levels....there has been a lot of damage done to global mkts.....many will speculate on levels that should hold and support - but like a massive hurricane - we won't know the extent of the damage until global mkts can calm down. For now - strap in.
Take good care
Kp

The phrase refers to the fact that we are creatures of habit and in short - events that have happened in past are bound to repeat themselves - because in the end - do we ever really learn? Think 1929, 1987, 1999, 2007-20012, and now 2015.....What do these years have in common? Stock mkt CRASHES - and if you look at each one - the common theme that runs through all of them is eerily similar.No matter what - the stock mkt crashes were (are) the result of a variety of economic factors (domestic & international)/structural (monetary and fiscal policy) and technological imbalances coupled with raging speculation, and new and exciting "derivative products" that promised to save everyone....How's that working for you?Recall the "roaring Twenties" (that is the 1920's) it was a time of wealth and excess.....Easy credit, high levels of debt, slowing economy and other signs of economic fissures, speculation and high margin debt all contributing factors to the crash of '29.In 1987 - after the roaring bull mkt that began in the summer of '82 - the mkt crashed - falling 22.5% in 6 hrs.....losing over $500 bil in one day..... The move higher was fueled by falling interest rates, hostile takeovers, leveraged buyouts and a surge in junk bonds. (Junk bonds, now known as 'High Yield' are bonds that pay high interest rates due to their HIGH RISK - you see - it is the risk/reward argument)....Portfolio Insurance (that first iteration of the coming derivative boom) that only accelerated the decline.....You see - in addition to the economic issues and structural imbalances created as a result - Portfolio Insurance was the new 'savior'. Global asset managers all bought into it - using this 'new brain child' as a way to protect against losses....(Portfolio insurance is a hedging strategy that uses stock index futures to cushion equity portfolios against broad stock market declines). As interest rates rose, many institutional money managers tried using this insurance to hedge their portfolios at the same time. As we moved through the week of Oct 14th, 1987 - the mkt got weaker and came under pressure closing on the lows on Friday Oct 16th in what was an unusually heavy volume day. On October 19th 1987, this portfolio insurance product issued a sell signal and any institution that had bought it was told to sell X% of their portfolio in order to protect it.....The signal was issued on Sunday night - just as Asian mkts were opening...and the bloodbath began....selling beget more selling and the bottom fell out of global mkts....stock index futures mkts was flooded with billions of dollars worth of sell orders and within minutes, both the futures and stock markets began to crash and as the sun set on Asia it rose in Europe and the process continued, the bloodletting unstoppable.....and then the sun rose over the Atlantic to warm the shores of the US and the perfect storm blew the windows out......by 4 pm global mkts had suffered inconceivable losses.....as analysts/strategists and everyone else tried to put it in perspective.....The FED came to the rescue and intervened trying to prevent a repeat performance. Remarkably - the mkt recovered fairly quickly and moved higher until the fall of 1999 and the Dot Com Crash.E-commerce and Dot Com - that was the new gold rush...any company that had either in its name helped to created another historic bubble...the Internet - was going to be the game changer. You see - the period from like 1993 - 2000 was marked by the explosion of the Internet and the founding and spectacular failures of these new companies - Investment banks hungry for product brought these companies public - selling the story of how the world was different now. Companies with zero history, revenues or any chance of ever making any revenues were brought to the mkt - investors could not get enough - IPO's and pricing boggled the mind - opening trades left you speechless and technology allowed anyone with a computer to play. Speculation and the herd mentality once again took hold. People margined their houses and their first-borns....a new type of investing was born - what came to be known as 'prefix investing' - And then it happened.....the Nasdaq peaked at 5132 on March 10, 200 only to find its low months later after losing better than 50%.Then came the housing boom - fueled in part by failed fiscal policies initiated under Pres Clinton and Fed Chairman Greenspan.....No income verifications loans, teaser rates, interest only loans anything to get 'every American' into a home of their own....investment banks packaged these 'loans' and securitized them and sold them to global investors as the new product! Ratings agencies marked them all AAA+++ rated....never really knowing what was in them. The gov't encouraged Wall St to play nice and help make these products successful. The global economy was humming along, global investors pumping all kinds of money into these products.....then new derivative products came to the mkts.....CDS's ABS' etc....it all worked until it didn't. The problem was that no one on Wall St - ran a model that provided for a global slowdown - no one knew what would happen if the music stopped...and the music stopped in March of 2008....and the world collapsed - everyone pointed the finger at someone else - proclaiming that it was 'not our fault'...it was lack of regulation or lack of insight, or just plain greed.The FED and every other central bank came to the rescue - artificially stimulating mkts.....many screamed about this intervention - but at the time it was the right thing to do, but then, as usual, it went on to long. Along the way - the mkts recovered, people started to feel good again....new products were designed - ETF's (exchange traded funds) gave the investor the sense that we somehow found the holy grail. You could now invest in one product and get instant access to a range of investment options....Sectors, developed countries, emerging countries, frontier countries, bonds, high yield, low yield, average yield...... different strategies, (long, short, super long and super short - leveraged products) built using 'synthetic equity'...... (a financial instrument that is artificially created) promising to offer all of the benefits of stocks (or bonds) while not being stocks (or bonds). Trade them easily...get in and get out with one product.....sounds too good to be true - right?Well it is....because when the global economy begins to convulse you can't really trade this crap as easily as you were told. And when panic ensues - and those mkts freeze - what happens - asset managers end up selling what they can vs. what they should....and this causes stocks to crash...because - the US capital mkts are the most liquid and deepest and when push comes to shove - you can always raise money in the developed global mkts.And today - what do we have - completely manipulated mkts - fueled by central banks around the world as elected officials shirked their responsibilities and failed to enact fiscal policy stimulus....policies that would have gone much farther in helping to solve so many issues. But that was not to happen....and today we find ourselves in another mess.....Global mkts coming unglued, monetary policies failing to make a difference after trillions of dollars and years of artificial stimulation. In fact - this global meltdown is NOT about the FED and a 25 bps hike in US rates at all. It is a realization that there has been a massive failure of leadership, a massive failure of real fiscal policy initiatives.... Couple that with unreal expectations of major global trading partners and you have a real mess.Overnight - Asian mkts led the crash - as they did in 1987....China losing 8.5% other Asian mkts following in kind Hong Kong -5.1%, ASX -4%, Japan -4.6%.... The reason...... a complete lack of any commentary or real economic data supporting any kind of growth from Chinese authorities, which is only re-enforcing the idea they ARE NOT in control. .As the Sun rises over Europe those mkts getting drawn in - (recall 1987)....FTSE -3%, DAX -3.29%, CAC 40 - 3.4%, SPAIN -3.25%, EUROSTOXX - 3.2%.....as the blood bath continues.....And now the sun is again washing the shores of America....US futures are showing down 47 pts...or 2.3%....as the day begins.....there is no rhyme or reason - no explanation for what will happen today....You can feel the 'panic mentality" in the air....This just has to play out for now.....no commentary from Janet or anyone else will stop this train today.....the mood is set and the action will happen as investors try to make sense out of this mess. We have broken so many tech levels....there has been a lot of damage done to global mkts.....many will speculate on levels that should hold and support - but like a massive hurricane - we won't know the extent of the damage until global mkts can calm down. For now - strap in.Take good careKpKenny Polcari is Vice President and director of NYSE Floor Operations on behalf of O'Neil Securities, Inc., a sister company of Investor's Business Daily. Does it hurt to accuse someone of being a Nazi or a racist who is neither of those?  How about calling someone those vile terms when he has spent his life supporting Jewish and black causes?Over the weekend, the Democratic Party's Deputy Chair, Keith Ellison, put out an email claiming: "even with Steve Bannon gone, Donald Trump's inner circle still includes prominent white nationalists and enablers of white supremacy."  Ellison labeled one senior advisor as "a member of a Hungarian Nazi organization."On Saturday, Howard Dean, the former chair of the Democratic Party, said: "If you want to vote for a racist in the White House, then you better vote for Republicans."  Other Democrats keep echoing those charges.The venerable Foreign Policy magazine ran an article the end of last week asserting: "For the first time in our history, a Nazi sympathizer occupies the Oval Office."  Foreign newspapers like The Independent or The Guardian have headlines: "Donald Trump's Defense of neo-Nazi" and "The president of the United States is now a neo-Nazi sympathizer."Sunday morning's national television talk shows, such as "Meet the Press," only could find Republicans who were critical of Trump.If you believe what the media are telling you, we now supposedly have the first Nazi sympathizer as president, but who is also the first president to have an orthodox Jewish daughter and grandkids.  A president who pledges unwavering support for Israel and who has been a friend of the current Israeli PM for decades. Nazis are socialists, yet Trump supports less regulation and lower taxes.Before running for the president as a Republican, Democrats had wonderful things to say about Donald Trump regarding race.  In the late 1990s and early 2000s, Jesse Jackson frequently praised Trump for his "lifetime" of helping the black community.Days before Democratic Party's Deputy Chair Keith Ellison sent out his weekend email, the experts interviewed by the liberal PolitiFact had already shot down those claims. "Are any of these four officials white nationalists? When we asked this question of several independent experts, they all agreed that none of the four were white nationalists themselves."So why do people believe that Trump is a Nazi or white supremacist sympathizer? ABC News' coverage was all too typical: "Trump quickly blamed both sides for the conflict, adding that there were 'very fine people' among both the protesters — which included white supremacists and white nationalists — and the counter protesters."But Trump never came close to saying that any white supremacists or neo-Nazis were "very fine people."  At his press conference last Tuesday, Trump clearly made this point several times.  For example, "And you had people, and I'm not talking about the neo-Nazis and the white nationalists, because they should be condemned totally. But you had many people in that group other than neo-Nazis and white nationalists."When pressed by a reporter if Trump was saying that the press was threatening white nationalists unfairly Trump emphatically said: "No, no." And Trump again referred to the "bad people — neo-Nazis, white nationalists."People were also angry at Trump's initial statement on Saturday immediately after the news broke. But compare that to the praise for a joint statement that former presidents George W. Bush and George H.W. Bush put out last Wednesday. The Bushes wrote: "America must always reject racial bigotry, anti-Semitism, and hatred in all forms."But how is that different from Trump's universally denounced statement four days earlier: "We condemn in the strongest possible terms this egregious display of hatred, bigotry and violence on many sides, on many sides. ... It has no place in America."Is the only difference that the Bushes condemned bigotry "in all forms," whereas Trump condemned it "on many sides"?In fact, Trump was right.  The people on the left, such as Antifa and Black Lives Matter, where not only as racist and hateful, but even the liberal and left-wing media from The Nation to BuzzFeed News to the Los Angeles Times have documented that they also instigated violence in Charlottesville.As one University of Virginia student told the New York Times before the car attack: "I was on Market Street around 11:30 a.m. when a counter-protester ripped a newspaper stand off the sidewalk and threw it at alt-right protesters. I saw another man from the white supremacist crowd being chased and beaten. People were hitting him with their signs. A much older man, also with the alt-right group, got pushed to the ground in the commotion. Someone raised a stick over his head and beat the man . . . ."The media's false statements are out of control, distorting what President Trump said, and the Democratic Party leaders have pushed these claims even further.Racism is vile and must be condemned.  But lying is also wrong, especially about such serious charges.

Tobacco companies Altria Group (MO), British American Tobacco (BTI) and Philip Morris International (PMI) retreated Monday amid a bearish analyst note, extending Friday's sector losses on the back of news that federal regulators intend to clamp down on nicotine levels in cigarettes. XAnalysts at RBC Capital Markets cautioned against "buying the dip" in tobacco stocks in a note on…

Some growth stocks with top-notch IBD ratings bucked the mild decline by major indexes Wednesday and summoned enough power to stage new breakouts.XThe Nasdaq composite, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrials all showed losses from 0.2% to 0.4% in afternoon trading. Volume is running lower on the Nasdaq vs. the same time on Tuesday.As noted in an earlier Stock Market Today column, airline stocks tanked amid concern over a potential rise in seat capacity in the U.S. market. The Dow Jones transports fell nearly 1.3%.Apple (AAPL) is trying to buck the market on a down day as shares briefly edged up around 0.4% to 160.38, extending its gain from a 156.75 entry in a solid 2-1/2-month flat base. Around 1:15 pm ET, however, shares receded to a nearly break-even level.Apple's Relative Price Strength Rating now reflects superior performance at a 91 out of a maximum 99. A 91 means that Apple has outrun 91% of all stocks in IBD's database over the past 12 months.Also seen in IBD Stock Checkup, Apple scores a much improved 94 Composite Rating, which takes into account a company's earnings, sales, profit margins, return on equity, level of institutional buying, and recent stock price action. When Apple continued its major turnaround with a breakout on Jan. 6-9, the Composite score was a paltry 51, and Apple's Telecom sector ranked a middling 14th out of 33 sectors ranked daily by IBD within its stock research tables.In the latest IBD Weekly print edition, Telecom ranked 13th and shows a year-to-date gain of 12.8%, better than the S&P 500's 9.3% advance.Some small- and midcap growth plays are thriving. MiMedx (MDXG) slipped as much as 4.5% in morning trading, but that actually offered a chance for new buyers to scoop shares closer to a 16.30 buy point. Shares then rebounded off the day's low of 16.55 to cut the loss to less than 2% at 17.04.As noted in IBD Leaderboard, the small-cap play ($1.9 billion market value) in skin grafts broke out of a seven-week base at 16.30 on Aug. 15. Notice on a daily chart how volume was powerful that session as nearly 4.5 million shares exchanged hands that day, 271% more than its 50-day average.The 5% proper buy zone from 16.30 goes up to 17.12.Earnings have shown an accelerating trend at MiMedx; in Q3 of 2016, profit came in flat at 6 cents a share, but have climbed 17%, 75% and 40% in the prior three quarters. Keep in mind that the EPS figures alone are still in the single-digit range, which mathematically makes it easier for any company to post big earnings increases. However, the Marietta, Ga., firm also shows beefy top-line growth. Sales rose 31%, 35%, 36% and 33% vs. year-ago levels in the past four quarters.MiMedx develops and markets regenerative biomaterial products and bioimplants that are processed from human amniotic membrane and other birth tissues, and from human skin and bone.Paycom Software (PAYC) rose for a third straight session, edging slightly up to 73.87 in heavy volume, climbing past a 73.71 flat-base buy point. The HR functions support expert rallied 44% from a prior Feb. 9 breakout at 51.07.Paycom shows an excellent 95 RS Rating, and its relative strength line is moving into new high ground, meaning the stock is outperforming the S&P 500.IBD's TAKE: See the RS line, painted in blue, in every IBD daily and weekly chart, accessible via the Research section on the home page of Investors.com. The best growth stocks tend to show an RS line jumping into new high ground as they break out of well-formed bases including the cup with handle, flat base, and double bottom.Essent Group (ESNT), a major player in the private mortgage insurance market, flew 3% higher to 39.65 despite a sour U.S. new-home sales report for July. The Bermuda-based firm and former Sector Leader member has had a rocky few weeks since surpassing a 39.60 buy point in a flat base.The flat base, which requires a decline be no more than 15% from the highest intraday price to the lowest intraday price within the base, began in April and wrapped up at the start of July.Three weeks ago, Essent posted strong Q2 results (EPS up 35% to 77 cents, revenue up 27% to a record $137.6 million). But watch for the potential for a cooling trend. Q3 profit is seen rising 22% to 79 cents a share; the average EPS gain over the past eight quarters is 42%.New-home sales came in at an annualized rate of 571,000, well below the Econoday consensus view of 610,000.RELATED:3 Reasons Why Apple Could Rally Another 20%When Did Apple Stage A Follow-On Buy Point Below 156.75?Investor's Corner: Do You Know What The C In "CAN SLIM" Stands For?

Tobacco companies such as Altria Group (MO) and British American Tobacco (BTI) plunged Friday after the Food and Drug Adminstration outlined a comprehensive regulatory plan that includes lowering nicotine in cigarettes to non-addictive levels.XThat could pose a fundamental challenge to the cigarette industry, which has survived massive settlements and steadily declining volume sales.Shares of Altria, maker of Marlboro, Virginia Slims and Parliament brands, crashed 9.5% to 66.94 after falling as low as 60.01, a 15-month low. British American Tobacco, which recently bought out the rest of Reynolds American, dived 7% to 64.93, falling intraday to 60.15, its lowest level since January.However, one cigarette maker fared reasonably well. Peer Philip Morris International (PM), which sells Marlboro and other brands outside the U.S., rose 0.3% to 118.51 on the stock market today, rebounding from session lows for 109.31. Philip Morris presumably would not be directly affected by FDA rulings on cigarette sales in the U.S.Vector Group (VGR) lost 4.7% and Universal Corp. (UVV) dipped 0.85%."The overwhelming amount of death and disease attributable to tobacco is caused by addiction to cigarettes -- the only legal consumer product that, when used as intended, will kill half of all long-term users," FDA Commissioner Scott Gottlieb said in a statement from the agency."The FDA plans to begin a public dialogue about lowering nicotine levels in combustible cigarettes to non-addictive levels through achievable product standards," the agency said.The FDA gained regulatory powers over the tobacco industry in 2009.Altria, Philip Morris and British American Tobacco are big dividend payers, so their stocks have been favorites for income investors for decades. Phillip Morris International has a 3.5% dividend yield, with Altria at 3.3%. British American has a 3.2% dividend yield.Cigarette makers are already dealing with steadily declining volumes in the U.S., offsetting that with higher prices. But non-addictive cigarettes would be a huge blow to the industry.RELATED:Phillip Morris Misses On Earnings, Slashes GuidanceThe Income Investor

Major indexes held modest gains in afternoon trading Friday, following reports that the ultra-right-leaning White House advisor Steve Bannon will step down. Meanwhile, some leading growth stocks regained a bit of their luster, including Apple (AAPL), Applied Materials (AMAT) and Broadcom (AVGO), all of which rose 1% to 2% or more and are outperforming the key benchmarks.X The key averages all look poised to stage minor weekly losses. Going forward, watch to see if the Nasdaq composite, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrials find buying support near their respective 50-day moving averages.The Dow industrials' bounce off its 50-day line earlier on Friday was a bullish move. However, as noted in the latest Big Picture column, institutions have shown more willingness to sell stocks and take profits amid Year 10 of the secular bull market that began with a solid follow-through on March 2009.The S&P 500 bottomed out near 667 back then and has since rallied nearly 265% to 2432, excluding dividends.From the October 2002 bottom near 768 at the end of the dot-com crash to its October 2007 peak at 1576, the S&P 500 rallied 105% over a five-year span.Some market observers openly wondered whether President Trump's controversial reaction following the death of an anti-Neo Nazi and anti-KKK protester and injuries among others in Charlottesville, Va., last weekend would make it even harder for the White House to pass meaningful legislation that could help further boost the U.S economy.Apple, as noted in an earlier Stock Market Today column, is showing at least three factors that point to the possibility for more gains. It rose to an intraday high of 159.50, up less than 2% from a new flat-base breakout point of 156.75. Shares are up 37% since Jan. 1, and the overall action remains solid ever since the iPhone and iMac giant burst out of a first-stage cup with handle on Jan. 6-9 at 118.12.The Nasdaq composite led the rebound, up nearly 0.4% before the gains faded some as of 2:15 pm ET. The S&P 500 gained a little more than 0.1% while the Dow Jones industrials fought to stay above break-even.Volume was running sharply higher than at the same time on Thursday, due in part to the expiration of equity and index options.Apple continues to harbor improving SmartSelect ratings, as seen in its Stock Checkup.  The Composite Rating, which offers an at-a-glance view of a stock's IBD ratings plus an assessment of recent stock price action, is now a buoyant 95 out of a maximum 99. When Apple broke out in January, the Composite was well below 90. An improving Composite Rating is highly favorable.Notice, too, in the Stock Checkup that Apple has now posted four quarters in a row of accelerating earnings per share growth. Fund managers' antennae go way up when a company is seeing faster rises in earnings per share than in prior quarters or years. Apple's profit has grown 2%, 11% and 18% vs. year-ago levels in the past three quarters as revenue improved. Plus, with the likelihood that many iPhone users will likely consider upgrading to a new phone when the 10th anniversary iPhone comes out later this year, the prospects of continued double-digit EPS growth appear to be gaining traction.For FY 2018, which ends in September of 2018, Apple is expected to grow earnings by 20% to $10.78 a share. Apple hasn't seen double-digit annual earnings gains since FY 2015 ($9.22, up 43%).Applied Materials, which posted fine quarterly results late Thursday (EPS up 72%, revenue up 33%), is up more than 3% to 44.49 and is trying to reclaim its 50-day moving average. Volume is running stronger than normal, a sign that mutual funds, hedge funds, insurers, banks and the like are eager to accumulate shares.A further advance would be bullish in the fact that the semiconductor equipment titan is forming a new base that features upside resistance near 47-48.Applied's semiconductor equipment industry group has fallen a bit in recent months yet remains in the top 40 among the 197 industries tracked each day by IBD, at No. 37 through Friday afternoon. (Go to Stock Lists on the home page of Investors.com and click on Data Tables to see the entire rankings.)The Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless group is ranked 67th, down from 45th six weeks ago.Solid and increasing institutional sponsorship is a hallmark of a stock that shows a big long-term rise, and Applied is showing the right stuff. For instance, highly regarded fund Fidelity Contrafund (FCNTX) has been a shareholder for each of the past five quarters. A total 1,085 mutual and hedge funds owned shares in Applied as of the end of the second quarter, up from 913 funds at the end of Q3 2016.Broadcom, a big play in chips for cell phones, cars, the data center and other internet-enabled gear, has been trading in a relatively tight range between 227 and 256 for several months.Earnings in the global chip designer and manufacturer are seen rising 39% to $4.03 a share in the July-ended fiscal third quarter.In other financial markets, WTI crude oil futures ramped up more than 2.8% to $48.42 a barrel. Gold futures on the Comex backed off from session highs of $1,306 a troy ounce and were nearly flat at $1,291. Gold reached the highest level since early November, as investors sought to move some cash into safe havens amid another series of ISIS-sponsored terrorism and turmoil in the White House.The U.S. dollar gained against both the euro and the yen. The yield on the benchmark U.S. 10-year Treasury bond edged back up a bit to 2.20%, still well below this year's high of 2.62%.RELATED:When Will The Stock Market Really Top? Here Is The Easy Way To Spot ItThe Case For A New Long-Term Bull Run In GoldThe Cup With Handle, And How It Makes Money For InvestorsWhich Companies Currently Remain In IBD Leaderboard?

Phillip Morris International (PM) reported weaker-than-expected second-quarter earnings as cigarette volumes continue to tumble. The overseas tobacco giant also cut full-year EPS guidance. Shares tumbled early, but the big dividend payer pared losses by midday.XPhillip Morris earned $1.14 a share excluding various items, down from $1.15 a year earlier and below estimates for $1.23 according to Zacks Investment Research. Net revenue rose 1.5% to $19.3 billion, below various estimates. Net revenue excluding excise taxes rose 4% to $6.9 billion, below Zacks estimates for $7.054 billion. Cigarette shipments fell 7.5% vs. a year earlier.Phillip Morris, which sells Marlboro cigarettes and other brands outside the U.S., cut its full-year EPS outlook to $4.78-$4.93 from $4.84-$4.99.Shares fell as low as 117.55, briefly undercutting their 50-day line. But shares rebounded to a loss of just 1.4% at 119.95 on the stock market today. Phillip Morris hit a record high of 123.55 on June 20.Shares of Altria (MO), which sells Marlboro and other such cigarettes in the U.S., rose 0.1%. Altria fell below its 50-day line last month. British American Tobacco (BAT) climbed 1.15%. Reynolds American (RAI), which is being bought out by British American Tobacco, gained 0.85%. Reynolds American shareholders OK'd BAT's takeover on Wednesday.Phillip Morris International has a 3.4% dividend yield, with Altria at 3.3%. British American Tobacco and Reynolds American have 3.1% dividend yields.

Stocks took a beating for the first week in 2016…. — and it does not look like it is abating anytime soon… and on Friday — despite stronger futures, a 'decent - albeit surprising' monthly jobs report and relative calm in Asia, both the European mkts and the US mkt failed to sustain any positive momentum.  Investors were unimpressed by the shenanigans in China — as Chinese authorities tried to support the mkt.   Going into the close, the mkts came under renewed selling pressure ahead of the weekend and ending just off the worst levels of the day. The Dow gave back 168 points (-1.0%), Nasdaq slid 46 points (-1%) and the S&P tumbled 21 points (-1.1%) and the small cap Russell 2000 ended the day down 1.72%.   So for the week — the Dow lost 6.2%, the S&P lost 6% and Nasdaq gave back 7.3%....

Oil — under more pressure ended the week lower (- 15%) taking the energy sector down 7% and as we speak — oil is trading at $32.56 - down another 1.8% ……only cts away from the key level at $32.40 - but that is deceiving - because overnight OIL broke down and thru the all important $32.40 support - putting in a new 8 yr low at $32.24/barrel..... That being said - you can see it struggling to hold in right here......another test at support and we could see it break, falling into the high $20's.   Gold on the other hand is benefitting from all of this turmoil….…..it saw its price rise by 3.5% for the week  and this morning it is up once again at $1103 on its way to challenging resistance at $1110/oz.  Now back to China......If you listen closely - you can hear Asian investors singing the Englebert Humperdink  1967 classic - "Please Release Me"....“Please release me, let me go, For I don’t love you anymore.  To live a lie, would be a sin, release me and let me love again……I have found a new love, dear.  And I will always want her near.  Her lips are warm where yours are cold, release me darling, let me go…..”  As the Asian mkts opened last night - investors began to "let go" again.......…Asian mkts continued to crash all opening lower….— Japan -0.69%, Australia -2%, Kospi (Korea) -1% , Hong Kong — 2%, China, -2.14%,  as the concern over China and lower commodity prices continue to permeate the psyche.  At the end of the day - the picture was not any brighter.....Japan - 0.39%, Hong Kong - 2.7%, China -5.5%, Kospi -1.19% and ASX -1.17%.

Taimur Baig — Chief Asian Economist for Deutsche Bank Research made this observation: "The key risk is China, where fears of continued economic slide are causing capital outflows, exchange rate depreciation, asset market selloff, and policy dilemmas."And continued difficulty in the region will ultimately hurt sentiment across the Asian region — resulting in possible deflation, a credit crunch and monetary policy dilemmas.  And if that is not enough — the threat of more China Yuan devaluations is raising the pressure on the ‘Asian Tigers’ (South Korea, Taiwan, and Singapore) to follow suit….. And if this come to pass — then strap in — because it will clearly dampen global economic growth causing investors to re-price risk again (can you say lower prices?) …..and recall that global growth that has ALREADY been revised lower by both the IMF (International Monetary Fund) and the World Bank.  Bottom line is that there is now a realization that global equity mkts may be a bit overpriced — after years of all that Kool Aid…..And like many have argued — the effectiveness of all of this massive liquidity has just about reached its limit and with the FED now beginning to tighten -  investors can no longer base their investment assumptions on continued liquidity- but must now base it on fundamentals….but don’t worry — the Great  Wizard of Oz tells us…… “Pay no attention to that man behind the curtain…”  It’s all good.  And if oil does not find support right here then look for a swift move into the high $20’s.  — which will surely put more pressure on stocks.  Never mind that earnings are once again at hand and that is also causing some angst resulting in a ‘shoot first, ask questions later’ mentality.   Last week also saw the all important NFP (Non Farm Payroll) report....and to everyone's' surprise - the gov't reported a surge in job creation - wink, wink... The Labor Dept said non-farm payroll employment climbed by 292,000 jobs in December compared to economist estimates for an increase of about 200,000 jobs while the unemployment rate held steady  at 5%.    But is this read on unemployment really just a false indicator?   There are a record number of individuals (100 mil)  who remain permanently unemployed, having given up trying to find a job after so many months of failure.  So - fortunately, for the gov't - these unemployed people are no longer counted in the “official” unemployment rate.  And the broader U6 - Underemployment/Unemployment rate remains stubbornly high at 9.9% - which is a better indicator of reality.   One more thing - what this monthly report does not highlight are the number of job losses that occurred during the month......the monthly job loss rate for 2015 averaged about 43k losses according to Challenger, Gray and Christmas - but why emphasize any of the negatives - it just un-American.....So if you net out the avg monthly gains of +225k and the avg monthly loss of 43k - we have an avg monthly gain of +183k....well below what we really need to achieve 'escape velocity'.   I'm just sayin......

Eco data this week is light.....until we get to Friday.....Retails sales are expected to show a decline of 0.1%, ex autos and gas then a gain of 0.3%.....Empire State Manf of -4, Industrial Production of -0.2% and Capacity Util of 76.8%.  (Capacity Util is a measure of the rate of potential output expressed as a percentage)   - so at this rate we are running at 3/4 of full capacity - which leaves plenty of room to grow before we really start seeing pressure on prices.....You need to start to worry when Capacity Util approaches the high 80's....so we've got time......

Earning begin this week...and as usual - Alcoa (AA) kicks it off tonight after the bell....but all eyes are focused on Thursday - when JP Morgan  (JPM) - the first DOW stock reports.......European mkts - were all higher in early morning trade, but have since given up some of those gains as they struggle to stay green.  As noted - oil under pressure as it tries to hold onto the all important $32.40 level.  And while many think that the mkts reaction to events in China are overblown - it is what it is and until investors feel comfortable - expect the volatility to continue.  FTSE flat,  CAC 40 +0.39%,  DAX+ 0.52%, EUROSTOXX + 0.55%, SPAIN +0.25% , and ITALY +0.10%

US futures have had a wild ride overnight......at 9 pm est......futures were down 20 pts testing 1895......only to swing back 33 pts to challenge 1928 on the S&P at 4 am est.  Currently they are +9 at 1921.....suggesting that the mkt and investors are trying to put it all in perspective.  Remember - China's stock mkt is not a good indicator of the overall health of their economy...it is an emerging mkt and mostly retail - it does NOT have the depth or inner strength of European & US mkts.  So a collapse in prices in China is more a reflection of  a suspect evolving mkt place that is struggling to define what it wants to be....  I continue to look for the mkt to test the August lows during this earnings season before it finds its footing.   Unless earnings completely disappoint (unlikely) I think the mkt can hold it together....
Two Fed speakers today.....Lockhart (Fed Reserve Bank of Atlanta)  at 12:40 and Kaplan (Fed Reserve Bank of Dallas)  at 5:50 pm.
Take good care.
Kp

Stocks took a beating for the first week in 2016…. — and it does not look like it is abating anytime soon… and on Friday — despite stronger futures, a 'decent - albeit surprising' monthly jobs report and relative calm in Asia, both the European mkts and the US mkt failed to sustain any positive momentum.  Investors were unimpressed by the shenanigans in China — as Chinese authorities tried to support the mkt.   Going into the close, the mkts came under renewed selling pressure ahead of the weekend and ending just off the worst levels of the day. The Dow gave back 168 points (-1.0%), Nasdaq slid 46 points (-1%) and the S&P tumbled 21 points (-1.1%) and the small cap Russell 2000 ended the day down 1.72%.   So for the week — the Dow lost 6.2%, the S&P lost 6% and Nasdaq gave back 7.3%....Oil — under more pressure ended the week lower (- 15%) taking the energy sector down 7% and as we speak — oil is trading at $32.56 - down another 1.8% ……only cts away from the key level at $32.40 - but that is deceiving - because overnight OIL broke down and thru the all important $32.40 support - putting in a new 8 yr low at $32.24/barrel..... That being said - you can see it struggling to hold in right here......another test at support and we could see it break, falling into the high $20's.   Gold on the other hand is benefitting from all of this turmoil….…..it saw its price rise by 3.5% for the week  and this morning it is up once again at $1103 on its way to challenging resistance at $1110/oz.  Now back to China......If you listen closely - you can hear Asian investors singing the Englebert Humperdink  1967 classic - "Please Release Me"....“Please release me, let me go, For I don’t love you anymore.  To live a lie, would be a sin, release me and let me love again……I have found a new love, dear.  And I will always want her near.  Her lips are warm where yours are cold, release me darling, let me go…..”  As the Asian mkts opened last night - investors began to "let go" again.......…Asian mkts continued to crash all opening lower….— Japan -0.69%, Australia -2%, Kospi (Korea) -1% , Hong Kong — 2%, China, -2.14%,  as the concern over China and lower commodity prices continue to permeate the psyche.  At the end of the day - the picture was not any brighter.....Japan - 0.39%, Hong Kong - 2.7%, China -5.5%, Kospi -1.19% and ASX -1.17%.Taimur Baig — Chief Asian Economist for Deutsche Bank Research made this observation: "The key risk is China, where fears of continued economic slide are causing capital outflows, exchange rate depreciation, asset market selloff, and policy dilemmas."And continued difficulty in the region will ultimately hurt sentiment across the Asian region — resulting in possible deflation, a credit crunch and monetary policy dilemmas.  And if that is not enough — the threat of more China Yuan devaluations is raising the pressure on the ‘Asian Tigers’ (South Korea, Taiwan, and Singapore) to follow suit….. Torture — the action of inflicting severe pain on someone as punishment: or to force them say or do something: or for the sole pleasure of the person inflicting the pain.  — that is what they do in war…..

Chinese Water Torture — a process whereby water is slowly dripped onto a restrained person’s forehead, finally driving that person insane.  That is what they do to the stock mkt……slowly drive the investor insane…..

By now - we are all well aware of the disaster that had taken place in global mkts since the beginning of the new year - that is unless you have been living under a rock - but either way - we have seen some $2.4 tril wiped out the value of global mkts....some of the blame can be placed squarely on broad macro themes, a breakdown in Apple (AAPL) shares, renewed nervousness concerning Mid East and North Korean geo-political issues, the coming earnings season, health of the consumer, etc.........but for the most part the most recent cause of mkt nervousness  has been front and center - China...  Right or wrong - they have become the scapegoat.....

Now - look - there is a lot of 'stuff' going on there.....slowing Chinese economy, currency devaluation,  plunging commodity prices....blah, blah, blah......but can we really pin total mkt action on this one 'developing, emerging mkt country'?  Hardly....but it is fun, isn't' it?   I mean you always look to deflect responsibility - or better yet - look to place blame....and for now - the Chinese economy seems to suit everyone just fine.....I mean we have to blame someone and we were tired of blaming the usual suspects...... Corp earnings, The FED,  Lack of inflation,   Housing slowdown,  Oil and other commodities,  - well you get the picture......

Yesterday  - as the world waited all day for Thursday night/Friday morning trading to begin once again in Asia the US mkt continued to come under pressure.   But again — no one threw the kitchen sink out the window or jumped off any roof.  Was it ugly, yes, was it frustrating, yes.  The Dow at one point was off more than 450 pts while the S&P was off over 46 pts……Nasdaq got slammed as well taking that index down more than 3% in early trade.…  It was the classic 'herd mentality' taking hold.....fear builds and people lose their sense of the bigger picture.....and the mkt swings and usually overshoots the reality......

After the absolute crushing that China took on Thursday - global mkts were naturally on edge.......Europe sold off and here in the US - the train kept coming......Mid morning yesterday — word spread that the Chinese gov’t was abandoning their circuit breakers - circuit breakers that were supposed to ease the chaos, but which in fact had only exaggerated it....and so — they did away with it…..which left European and American investors time to think about what that could mean.  Was it a good thing?  Would we witness the first major financial crisis of 2016?  Would the Chinese stock mkt implode on Friday?  And if so — what would be the knock on effect for Europe and the US…….

Well let’s get one thing straight….You don’t really think that the Chinese would abandon the curbs without making sure that the mkt would go UP  do you?How ridiculous would that be?  How would they be able to prove to the world that they were actually in control if they allowed their mkt to go over the edge?   I mean — You can just hear it, no?  Remember - China is a COMMUNIST country that is trying to be a CAPITALIST country with all of the state controls......so the gov't  made it very clear to investors —‘No selling allowed — otherwise we kill you….. Death by Firing Squad…’ and as so many of us sat glued to our computers last night at 9 pm……we waited and waited…..Japan, Australia opened lower — setting the tone…..US futures remained cautious….ticking slightly higher….as the seconds turned to mins and the Chinese mkt opened…..BOOM!!!!

Just like that it rocketed higher by 3% -  then sold off to -2.2%  (causing the first round of ‘deaths’)  which then served as a warning to anyone else who even considered hitting the SELL button…… Netflix should make a docu-series - "China ! - How the State Manipulates Global Mkts"  I mean think about it…... UP, Really?  Well, yes in the short term...look that mkt is OFF 17% since Christmas.....so maybe it was a bit oversold.....

The papers detail it precisely -  "The Shanghei Composite Index closed 2 percent higher, after falling as much as 2.2 percent earlier. Regulators removed the circuit breakers after plunges this week closed trading early on Monday and Thursday. The central bank set the currency’s reference rate little changed Friday after an eight-day stretch of weaker fixings that roiled global markets. State-controlled funds purchased Chinese stocks on Friday, focusing on financial shares and others with large weightings in benchmark indexes.    The scrapping of the circuit breaker system will help to stabilize the market, but a sense of panic will remain, particularly among retail investors, The ‘national team*’ will probably continue to buy stocks significantly to stabilize the market."(*National Team = Gov't)

Ok..so guess what?  Yup....global mkts breathe a sigh of relief and the 'snap back relief rally' began.....European mkts WERE higher in initial trade but have since all turned lower - German industrial Production sorely disappointed - missing estimates at -0.3% vs. the +0.5% exp.... US futures are up nicely +15 pts  but off the highs of the early morning trade when we were up 25 pts.... Expect more volatility today.....as the focus now turns to our 'big event' - the NFP (Non Farm Payrolls) report...at 8:30  exp are for +200k jobs but after Wednesday's strong ADP employment report - the pressure is on for a 'better than expected' number...and my sense is that we will get it - especially after the recent drubbing global mkts took - this will allow today's FED speakers to tell us how great it all is.......(smoke and mirrors...)

The mkt is on track for its worst start to a year since recorded history!!!  (According to FactSet stats that go back to 1897).   If the first five days are any indication of what is to come.....the get ready - because here it comes... If there were any doubts about the crash in the Hi Yield bond market last year warning us about what was coming for the stock market this year, we can put that to bed....

Technically, the Russell 2000 index is leading all indexes to the downside, breaking through last year’s lows of last September on its way to challenge the October 2014 lows at 1,040.  Typical of the Russell leads both in bull markets and bear markets and this latest move does not signal a building BULL mkt just yet.....in fact it looks ugly...... The Dow Trannies also took out their 2015 lows of 7682 and are down 16% from the November  highs and down 23% from their highs of February 2015.  Looks like a big fat brown BEAR to me......

We are clearly short term oversold  - as the Dow gives back 1,100 points in five days and the S&P gives back 111 pts during the same time frame.  Expect a snap back rally but also expect that sophisticated asset managers will 'sell any rally' until there is a real shift or catalyst in thinking..... Remember - the mkt can stay IRRATIONAL longer than you can stay LIQUID.  Side Note — Friends — As so many of you know — The Headstrong Project (getheadstrong.org) is an organization that is very close to my heart.  It is a Veteran’s charitable organization that provides POST 911 combat veterans dealing with PTSD and thoughts of suicide with world class mental health care through its treatment program at Weill Cornell Medical Center.   (The Dept of Defense reports 22 suicides a day  and over 350k confirmed cases of veterans dealing with PTSD.) Take a moment to look at the latest qtrly newsletter to learn more about this amazing organization — of which I serve on the Board of Directors — and choose to support those men and women who chose to serve and protect you.  Thank you all for you past support and my hope is that you will continue to support The Headstrong Project team help heal ‘The Hidden Wounds of War’. With gratitude —Take good care    Kp

NYC - 8 pm (est) Tuesday, January 5th / Los Angeles, CA - 5 pm (pst),  Tuesday, January 5th/ London, England - 1 am (gmt) Wednesday, January 6th/ Pyongyang, North Korea - 10 am (kst — Korean Standard Time)  Wednesday, January 6th —

The US geological Service reports a 5.1 magnitude earthquake 30.4 miles outside of Kiju, North Korea….Reports of the event start to circulate around the world — Questions arose — Suspicions confirmed — North Korea's state owned TV confirming that the country had successfully conducted a 'hydrogen nuclear bomb test' saying that the country will not give up any nuclear capability until the US drops its hostile foreign policy towards that country.  Surrounding countries go into overdrive immediately condemning this action…… South Korea President Park Geun-Hye - quickly criticizing Kim Jung-Un calling this test a "grave provocation to this country's security' and ensuring that North Korea will 'pay the price for conducting a nuclear weapons test"  Japanese PM Shinzo Abe calls the test a 'grave threat to our nation and one we cannot accept"
The White House - though aware said nothing but the US National Security Council did say:

"While we cannot confirm these claims at this time, we condemn any violation of U.N. Security Council resolutions and again call on North Korea to abide by its international obligations and commitments,  We have consistently made clear that we will not accept it as a nuclear state. We will continue to protect and defend our allies in the region, including the Republic of Korea, and will respond appropriately to any and all North Korean provocations."
Remind me again - Who is that guy that lives in the WH?

Mkts in Asia - which had just opened for trading and were weak to begin with -  turned lower still....……News of the test sent Japanese, South Korean, Australian and a host of other Asian nations  lower…..China - which once again is attempting to weaken its currency only added selling pressure to mkts around the world.

Emerging mkts falling to 6 yr lows as renewed concern over a weaker Yuan remind global investors of the beating that stocks took back in August when the Chinese devalued their currency.......for the most part though, Asian mkts took it in stride — they did NOT implode….and history suggests that the mkts will not become obsessed with it......But while a slowdown in China, weakening global macro data reports, coming downgrades to US corp profits, concern over FED policy, and the crisis in the mid-east continue to give investors/traders reason for caution - this new geo-political development raises the bar and adds fuel to the already burning fire….

All of this news sent investors into typical 'safe haven assets'….the Japanese Yen surged higher vs. the dollar,  Yields on 10 yr treasuries down by 2.22 bps to 1.27% (prices up/yields down) — and Gold currently UP $7.60  considered by so many to be the 'safest haven asset' moved higher — piercing the down trending 50 dma — (see yesterday's comments) and now trading at $1086/oz….looking to move and test $1112/oz.

Defense stocks in Asia all moved higher, but did close off of their intraday highs — resource stocks in Australia ended the day lower on the back of the China currency moves— dragging that index down by 1.6% as broad based indiscriminate selling engulfed that mkt…..

This morning European mkts are all a bit lower as the world begins to assess the damage caused by both of these latest international events.  (North Korea and China's currency weakening) .  Oil coming under renewed selling pressure as concerns about growing supply rise - closed under $36/barrel yesterday and today has fallen another 90 cts to $35.07/barrel -  taking us back to the lows of early 2009 during the height of the GFC (Great Financial Crisis) and this is really setting the tone for both Europe and the US.

European mkts are getting clobbered...as the morning becomes afternoon....and the selling intensifies....FTSE -1.5%, CAC 40 - 1.69%, DAX - 1.85%, EUROSTOXX - 1.6%, SPAIN -1.8% and ITALY - 1.8%......   US futures - took a nosedive lower on the Pyongyang news overnight and continue to succumb to weakness as the sun rises over the Atlantic......S&P futures are currently down 35 pts or 1.7% - as they sliced right thru S&P 2000 "like a hot knife thru butta"  (as Barbara Streisand would say in her signature style Brooklyn, NY accent).  Once again the tone has been set - it is Risk Off (for today)....

The choppy trading on Wall St over the last two months makes it very clear.......traders/investors are voting with their feet..... expressing  uncertainty about the future outlook:  corp profits, FED policy, presidential politics, strangling regulation, higher taxes, exploding social welfare programs and huge international geo-political risks ......

After Monday's plunge  the  "buy the dip"  crowd is not so sure that this time it makes sense to buy the dip......maybe - we should just sit back and see how this unfolds......Look - a lot of downside gaps were created on Monday's action - never mind the overall negative tone permeating the psyche  and as noted - the mkt has suffered a fair amount of technical damage........ and while the FED (like every other central bank) may be trying to stabilize the mkt to keep it from falling off of a cliff - at some point it makes no sense to 'stand in front of an oncoming train' .  The mkts will go to the level of equilibrium sooner or later - NO MATTER who tries to stand in its way.

We are now significantly below S&P 2000 - we tested 1976 in early pre-mkt a level where I have been saying the mkt needed to go to.....but there may be a bit more to go....in fact I still think a test lower (1950) is not out of the question.  ECO data today includes Mortgage Apps  DOWN by 11.6%  and the ADP Employment Change - expected to show +195k jobs.  In addition to the other eco data points due out - the FED is due to release their DEC mins at 2 pm....I do not suspect we will learn anything new at all....it's just the usual confessional  to make them all feel better.....  Expect mkts to break lower at the opening - but do not necessarily get sucked in just yet.....a break below 1950 will surely cause the mkts to test the August lows of 1870......
Take good care.
Kp

Good morning and Happy New Year.  Stocks did very little on Friday ending the day and the year just a touch lower….I have to say that I was a bit disappointed that they couldn’t nudge it just to the unchanged mark vs. what they did by allowing the S&P to close off fractionally for the year.   In the end — I think it was complete exhaustion — considering what the last quarter has been like.But strap yourself in this morning......so much going on......First up - as usual - Asia kicks off trading in the new year and overnight it was NOT pretty at all.....China back in the spotlight!  Chinese macro economic data kicks the year off with a bang..... Weak manufacturing and PMI (Purchasing Managers Index) reports set the tone - both suggesting a continued slowdown (now this is not really new news...but after a couple of months of near quiet - this report ignited the pent up concerns) .....add in the fact that the gov't imposed restrictions on 'selling stock' by institutions that were put in place during the summer meltdown are about to end and the sense is that there is a tidal wave of sellers just lining up.........All of this triggered a massive sell off in Chinese equities - (Shanghei lost 7%).....causing the first ' trudging halt' (otherwise known as circuit breakers)  to kick in when the mkt had fallen 5%.  Now circuit breakers are new to the Chinese mkts...so the halt in trading only caused more fear and panic among investors as no one - it seemed wanted to be the last guy turning in the room........so after a 15 min halt - the selling resumed and the index fell another 2% within mins....causing a complete trading halt at 1:34 pm.....Now since investors could not sell stocks in China any longer - then what happened - they sold what they could vs. what they should!     Yup - the selling spilled over into the other mkts - causing Japan to fall 3+%, Hong Kong fell 2.6% and ASX lost -0.48%.   Emerging mkts like Taiwan, Korea, India, Indonesia, all suffered losses of better than 2.5%..... And as the sun set on Asia - it rose in Europe and as you would expect - the panic  and indiscriminate selling followed.....Mkts in across the continent all under siege as a 'shoot first, ask questions later' mentality takes hold.....At 6 am (est) - European mkts are gasping for breath....FTSE - 1.9%, CAC 40 - 2.25%, DAX - 3.5%, EUROSTOXX -2.6%, SPAIN -2.25% and ITALY - 2.4%...... Now what is interesting is to see how the 'herd mentality' takes over.....because the latest reads on European macro eco data point to better days ahead.....PMI's across the Euro zone all show expansion:  Italy 55.6, Ireland 54.2, Germany 53.2, Spain 53, Austria 50.6, France 51.4 and even the Greeks are joining in the party at 50.2....remember - a reading ABOVE 50 suggests expansion...so Europe is looking pretty good..... Yet when the mood is decidedly negative - the herd all runs in the same direction.....which is exactly what creates the opportunity for those of us who have an iron stomach!US Futures are now pointing lower (no surprise) currently down 35 pts or 1.8%.....sitting right on S&P 2000  - levels last seen in mid December just ahead of the FED interest rate announcement.......Now what is important here is that we have broken all technical supports - the 50, 100 and 200 dma's......so the mkt could go into an August 24th style free fall with the next stop at or near 1950......Concern is building....   Will the algo's unleash the power of milli, micro second executions at the expense of real analysis?   Like I said on Thursday - do we really know or understand the  'exposure' created by all of the fancy, sophisticated derivative products that we call the ETF mkt?   Let me remind you - the exposure is unknown - no matter what they say......an air pocket in the mkts will cause them to go into free fall - then the additional pressure created by all of the varied ' leveraged synthetic products' - will only exacerbate the move...- so sit back, strap in and watch the show begin...Do not expect the buyers to be anywhere in line and do not expect this morning's moves to be logical at all.......Fear is a funny thing and it causes all kinds of unexplainable actions and reactions.....Now to add to the story we have new geo-political unrest in the Mid East......Over the weekend — the Saudi’s decided that it was time apparently to execute a dissident Shiite cleric and 46 other Sunni extremists in a show of force and a show of ‘not in our backyard’…….In 2011 this cleric was accused of being the leading voice in the then Arab spring that swept across a range of nations….this movement rocked the Arab world (think Egypt, Libya, Yemen) and threatened to cause unrest in the Saudi kingdom.   These men were all arrested then and sentenced to death -  the  execution is supposed to show the world that the Saudi’s DO NOT tolerate disobedience.  As you can imagine — this event did not go unnoticed in the Shiite world (think Iran)…..The Iranian Supreme leader — Ayatollah Khamenei -  calling for Saudi Arabia to face divine retribution for the killings…… Demonstrations in Tehran and other Mid East cities over the weekend calling for the end of the Saudi Kingdom……On Sunday — the Saudi’s cut diplomatic ties with Iran and have ordered the Iranian diplomats out of the country by Tuesday January 5th…..  Welcome 2016!Legend has it that as we move into the new year traders and investors should be aware of the January effect.  This argues that the first five days of the month and then the total months performance tends to predict what to expect for the entire year.  In other words, if  the first 5 days are good and that momentum carries thru to the end of the month then history tells us that the probabilities are high that the bull market will continue.  Conversely - a poor start and finish for the month is a bad omen for the year.    Recall the beginning of 2015 - January began the month at 2058 and ended the month at 1994 - or a loss of 3%.......and what did the mkt do last year?  The Dow lost 2.2%, the S&P lost 1% while Nasdaq rallied 5.7%......  I'm just sayin...'Eco data today includes:  US Markit Manf PMI - exp of 51.1, Const Spending of +0.7% and ISM Manufacturing - exp of 49...so it is a mixed bag of data...but no worries the tone has already been set...no matter what our data says...So - ladies and gents - get ready for a difficult day....I would look for cooler heads to prevail at some point.....I think the mkt will clearly test S&P 2000  to see where the buyers live....any sense that they are not home - will cause the sellers to test lower again......and the buyers know this - so let the game begin......Take good care —
Kenneth Polcari
Vice President, Director NY Floor Operations
