X Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) was upgraded Thursday, while PayPal (PYPL) and Etsy (ETSY) were downgraded, and Piper Jaffray initiated coverage on Altria (MO), Reynolds American (RAI) and Philip Morris International (PM).Chipotle was upgraded to buy with a 550 price target at Argus, which cited new marketing efforts, a differentiated menu, expansion plans, and a strong balance sheet. Argus raised its full-year EPS forecast to $9.00 from $8.50 and its 2018 EPS view to $12.50 from $12.00.Shares climbed 0.5% to 481.39 on the stock market today.Piper Jaffray started coverage on Altria (MO) with an overweight rating and 76 price target and initiated coverage on Reynolds American (RAI) with a neutral rating and 67 price target. Philip Morris International (PM) was started with an overweight rating and 131 price target.Altria shares rose 1.8% to 74.14. Philip Morris advanced 1.75% to 119.48, hitting a record high. Reynolds American climbed 0.5% to 66.76.PayPal was downgraded to hold from buy with a 51 price target at Stifel, which noted the stock's high valuation but said the payment company is still positioned for long-term growth.Shares fell o.2% to 50.93.Etsy, an online Market Place for handmade goods, was downgraded to neutral by Citigroup.Earlier this week Amazon (AMZN) announced it was getting into the wedding business with its Wedding Shop from Handmade at Amazon, which could be major competition for Etsy.Etsy shares slid 1.6% to 13.18. Amazon shares climbed 1.3% to 993.38, hitting an all-time high of 999.RELATED: Apple's Price Target Raised; Qualcomm, Ciena, Finish Line UpgradedU.S. Steel, Nucor Upgraded; Shake Shack Started At Buy; Ciena Downgraded

The Relative Strength (RS) Rating for Philip Morris International (PM) entered a new percentile Thursday, with an increase from 77 to 81.IBD's unique RS Rating tracks technical performance by using a 1 (worst) to 99 (best) score that identifies how a stock's price action over the trailing 52 weeks matches up against other stocks.Over 100 years of market history reveals that the best stocks typically have an RS Rating north of 80 in the early stages of their moves.Philip Morris International is now considered extended and out of buy range after clearing a 104.30 buy point in a first-stage consolidation. See if the stock forms a new pattern or follow-on buying opportunity like a three-weeks tight or pullback to the 50-day or 10-week line.The company posted 4% growth in the latest quarterly report, while sales growth came in at -1%.The company holds the No. 6 rank among its peers in the Tobacco industry group. Reynolds American (RAI), Turning Point Brands (TPB) and British American Tobacco (BTI) are among the top 5 highly rated stocks within the group.RELATED:IBD Stock Rating Upgrades: Rising Relative StrengthWhy Should You Use IBD's Relative Strength Rating?How Relative Strength Line Can Help You Judge A Stock

Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq 100 rose modestly early Friday as investors remained resilient event after after the surprising U.K. election news that the Conservatives have lost their majority in Parliament.The Conservatives remain the largest party and likely will retain control in some fashion, but PM Theresa May's fate is unclear while Brexit negotiations, set to start later this month, could face delay or more. The pound was sharply lower.XKeep an eye on financial stocks. Citigroup (C) broke out Thursday as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Bank of America (BAC) test key levels. Meanwhile, Amazon (AMZN)-Dish Network (DISH) rumors swirled again.Stock futures initially fell Thursday evening after initial exit polls predicted that Conservatives would fall short. But futures gradually firmed somewhat.Futures for the Dow industrials rose 0.2% vs. fair value. S&P 500 futures climbed nearly 0.2% while Nasdaq 100 futures were up 0.1% above fair value.Conservatives ended up with roughly 318 seats, down modestly from 330 before the election and less than the 326 seats needed for an outright majority. Labour should get 261 seats, a big rise, as most third parties lost ground.That would create a hung Parliament. However, Northern Ireland unionists, with 10 seats under the DUP, are set to provide enough support to give Conservatives control via a minority government.When May called the early election this spring, the Conservatives started with a huge lead, with most analysts betting that the ruling party would amass a sweeping majority and a freer hand in Brexit negotiations with the European Union.Now political uncertainty is heightened just before Brexit negotiations are supposed to get underway. Even though Conservatives likely will retain control of Parliament, May not be able to hang on as PM for long. But she apparently will fight to stay on for now.It's also unclear what direction Brexit will take if a handful of anti-EU hardliners or those who favor a "soft"  Brexit hold the process hostage.The DUP itself supports a "comprehensive free trade and customs agreement" with the EU, suggesting it wants a deal that retains as much access to the single market as possible. Northern Ireland does not want a hard border with Ireland.The U.K.'s FTSE 100 rose 0.65% in Friday intraday trading. The internationally focused FTSE 100 benefits from a weaker pound. Germany's Dax advanced 0.5% and France's CAC-40 climbed 0.5%.On Thursday, the Nasdaq composite climbed 0.4%, hitting a record high, while the Dow and S&P 500 eked out tiny gains.Citigroup and Bank of America rose fractionally in premarket action on the stock market today. JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs were not yet active. If global financial markets swing, Wall Street banks could be bellwethers.Citigroup, perhaps the most internationally exposed of the big U.S. banks, rose 2.15% to 63.21 in Thursday's regular session, hitting an 8-year high and clearing a 62.63 buy point. Bank of America, Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase rose more than 1%, all finding resistance at their 50-day moving averages. (Goldman and JPMorgan are Dow industrial components.Treasury yields, which were little changed early Friday, have risen modestly off recent lows in the past few sessions. Ex-FBI Director James Comey's testimony Thursday, though it didn't paint President Trump in a good light, didn't offer new bombshells. Also, the House OK'd legislation to roll back much of the Dodd-Frank financial regulations, though the real hurdle is the Senate.Meanwhile, Dish Network rose 3% late on a Benzinga report that it's in talks with Amazon for an expanded alliance, possibly even a takeover. The Hawks (Dudley, Mester, Lockhart, Kaplan, Bullard....) are circling.....and like vultures - they can circle for hours (or in this case years) riding the 'thermals'.  (A thermal is an upward current of warm air that birds use to gain height and yes thermals can also be underwear - but that is not what we are talking about here.)   In this case though, the thermal is the improving US economy - and so......

The FED opens the door just a bit more - to let more of that 'thermal' escape allowing the Hawks to circle faster, driving the Doves (Brainard, Tarullo & Evans)  to the sidelines.....while making sure that if  the US economy cools down they can quickly shut the door....... During the past year - the FED has been sending out repeated signals of the coming increase and yesterday they seemed to make it clearer while also making it very clear that any FUTURE increases will be 'slow and steady'..........The 2 pm release of the FED mins now suggests that the launch date to be T minus 28 days.......

They left themselves plenty of  ‘wiggle room’….or ‘the capacity to negotiate; flexibility to interpret,  in order to modify a previous statement or decision’  and it sounded like this: “It may well be appropriate to raise the benchmark lending rate in December, members emphasizing that this change was intended to convey the sense that, while NO decision has been made, it may well be appropriate to initiate the normalization process at the next meeting… as they assess both realized and expected progress toward its objective of maximum employment and 2% inflation”  Notice what was said — maybe yes or maybe no……It might be appropriate BUT hold on….NO decision has been made………And so we wait until the 16th of December….but the mkt decided to surge ahead….sending the message that it can no longer wait for the FED to make a decision — investors in the end will decide if the economy is ready or strong enough to withstand the ‘normalization process’ and by the looks of what happened yesterday - the answer is yes…..or maybe the answer was - we are just tired of the lack of clarity and the black cloud that hangs over us…..so let’s just get on with it — the uncertainty will only continue to kill the mood..... And in the end — does 25 bps off of ZERO really matter?   Haven’t we been discussing rising rates for months now? (if not years?) Was there anything in the mins to suggest that anything has really changed?  Not so much…I mean look — the mins continue to show that the committee is divided (we knew that), they also showed that the members continue to ‘actively debate the perception of moving too fast or too slow (we knew that too.)  The mins then reiterated the concern over sending the wrong message (we knew that as well) and finally — what to do if conditions improve faster than expected as well as what to do if conditions deteriorated from here — and guess what — We knew that too.  ‘Deep Throat’ — otherwise known as Jon Hilsenrath — tries to tell us in today’s WSJ that ‘officials changed the wording of their policy statement…..to ensure their options were open’……Not sure where he has been — but they have been doing that for months now…..every meeting the expectation has been for normalization to begin — going back to the early spring,  they have been threatening for months now - yet they always found a reason to stay the course — causing confusion and frustration for global investors and global mkts…. So I ask - Is changing one sentence really the key?  Does that now make it official?   In fact - word has it that some members of the committee (read Doves)  were concerned that this change in wording would send the wrong message - creating the expectation that rates WILL be increased in December - leaving no room to 'wiggle'. OK...but look — the FED has been telegraphing its intentions for weeks now....and yesterday alone we got more hawkish commentary from 4 of the regional presidents….telling us that the US economy is on solid footing and that they intended to raise rates ‘soon’…...see that’s part of the ‘wiggle room’….soon can mean so many things….it can mean soon like the next couple of weeks or it can mean soon like the next couple of months….take your pick.  The funny thing is that the economy was so much better in the spring, the data was so much more positive, which only adds to the confusion — are they really data dependent or have they just painted themselves into a corner?  Either way — strap in — the ride is about begin and it should - because at this point - another delay has the ability to create real turmoil in the mkts.....so pick your poison.  OK...so by now you know that stocks rallied hard yesterday.....picking up momentum after the announcement.....surging up and thru resistance at 2065 - rocketing towards the magic 2100 number.....closing at 2083 up 1.6% on the day.  The Dow rallied 1.4% while Nasdaq surged 1.8% - thanks to a new BUY recommendation on Apple (AAPL) by our friends at Goldman Sachs  (GS)......Funny how that works - GS puts Apple on their 'conviction BUY list' on the same day as the FED hints at a policy move.....helping to create a warm fuzzy feeling among traders and investors.  Throw in the fact that the gov't is now urging  Apple, Google  (GOOGL), Facebook (FB), Yahoo (YHOO), Amazon  (AMZN)), Twitter  (TWTR)  to help 'crack the code' of ISIS encrypted phones....and you get the perfect patriotic rally.....

Now   Technically,  the mkt had become a bit oversold so it makes sense that it is attempting to recover - yesterday's action took us thru resistance and now sets us up for a run at 2100...before we hit anymore  resistance.  Now next week is Thanksgiving - and barring any more terrorist events I would expect the mkt to try and hold it together going into the holiday and the Black Friday shopping extravaganza......Let's hope that Wal-Mart  (WMT) is right and that the consumer has been saving up for this one day to 'spend their money'  because if Black Friday is not the winner that they all suggest - the mkt will find reason to back off once again..........

This morning global mkts are all higher building off yesterday's US rally.......Economically - the BoJ held steady and UK retail sales were in line..... Japan +1.07%, Hong Kong +1.4%,  China +1.36%  and ASX + 2.13%.  In Europe this morning — mkts are enjoying the rally - celebrating the moves made against ISIS and the global resolve to address this issue.   7:30 brings us a statement from the ECB - no change in policy expected...... FTSE +1.216%, CAC 40 +0.70%, DAX +1.53%, Eurostoxx +0.93%, Spain +1.02% and Italy +0.59%. US Futures continue the ride....currently up by 7 pts....which would put the S&P within striking range of 2100...... on the eco front we will get Init Jobless Claims of 270k, Cont Claims of 2.16 mil, Philly Fed - exp of -0.5 would be an improvement over last month's -4.5......

FED speak:  Loretta Mester (Hawk) on CNBC this morning,  Dennis Lockhart to speak  at 12:30 and Stanley Fischer at 4:45 pm.... Of the 3 today....I suppose Fischer (Vice Chair) is the most important.....but at this point - when anyone of them opens their mouths - the algo's listen.....Take good care - Kp

Philip Morris International (PM) raised its full-year earnings outlook after reporting third-quarter results that topped Wall Street estimates early Thursday.The maker of Marlboro-brand cigarettes said that its Q3 diluted earnings fell 9.4% to $1.25 per share. Adjusted earnings fell 10.8% to $21.24 per share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting $1.11 per share. Revenue dipped 11.8% to $6.93 billion, above views for $6.76 billion, on strong sales in Latin America, Eastern Europe, the Middle East and Canada, which offset weaker sales in the European Union and Asia.Philip Morris shares closed up 1.9% at 86.07 on the stock market today.Despite weaker-than-expected sales in the EU, Philip Morris expects an improved economic environment to help boost sales in the region."Organic volume, market share and pricing trends remain very robust against the backdrop of an improved macroeconomic environment, particularly in our EU and EEMA (Eastern Europe, Middle East and Africa) Regions," CEO Andre Calantzopoulos said in the earnings release.As smoking rates decline in developed nations, cigarette makers are raising prices to help boost profits.Looking ahead, Philip Morris raised its full-year earnings outlook."Although currency headwinds have again stiffened slightly, our business momentum is such that we are today revising and narrowing our full-year guidance and increasing the projection of our constant-currency adjusted diluted EPS growth rate range to 11% to 12%," Calantzopoulos said.Earlier, the company forecast a 9% to 11% earnings growth rate.Reynolds American (RAI) will announce quarterly results Oct. 27. Reynolds shares finished 1.4% higher at 46.68.Follow Gillian Rich on Twitter @IBD_GRich.

Japan's economy contracted for a second straight quarter, putting more pressure on the Bank of Japan, which meets this week. GDP shrank at a 0.8% annual rate in the third quarter after falling 0.7% in Q2. Analysts had expected a 0.2% decline. Nonresidential fixed investment fell more than expected as Japanese companies remain wary of investing at home. But consumer…

After the Monday spike rally - stocks end little changed yesterday as the focus once again turned to monetary policy uncertainty.......Stocks closed mixed as utilities and energy led the way lower and retailers moved into the plus column......the star performer ?  Wal-Mart! -  rallying 3.5% as their earnings weren't as bad as they had predicted...

Now funny thing - on the way home last night - the business reporter on Bloomberg was commenting on Wal-Mart  (WMT) - telling the audience that - Wal-Mart is gearing up for Black Friday...expecting 'massive crowds'....why?  Because - in their analysis (Wal-Mart - not Bloomberg)  - last week's - WEAK retail sales report is due to the fact that consumers have been holding back - not spending money ahead of the big annual holiday shopping season, that we are getting ready to 'unleash' on all of the Black Friday sure to be 'Specials'.....They are predicting a massive crowds beginning on Thanksgiving and going thru Black Friday......and they are stocking up and getting ready......

And if they are wrong - then you can expect to see those 'Black Friday Specials' become  'Black December Inventory BLOWOUTS'........Let the countdown begin....we only have 37 shopping days until Christmas.....(that's 888 hours - just fyi)..........Should we organize a 'Black Friday' strike - Everyone stay home and watch 'em sweat?    Maybe the Wal-Mart planning committee hasn't noticed all the 'sales' that are taking place now....as retailers are clearly nervous that they are the ones that are gonna get 'stuck holding the bag'.......Anyone care to wager a bet on how many of those 'One Day SALES' Macy's (M) is gonna throw?    "Hello???  Can you hear me now?"  Ok...back to the mkts.....stocks did try to rally some more only to run into resistance at 2065- as noted in yesterday's piece....in fact - we did manage to pierce 2065 - just a bit before the sellers woke up and applied the pressure.....Commodities continue to get hammered as the dollar creeps higher.

Yesterday we got the CPI (Consumer Price Index) and it came it smack on expectations of +0.2% - Remember - the CPI is a measure of what we pay for goods and services - and it is a closely watched report by the FED......OK.....I get it... So now this report suggests more support for the FED to raise rates next month......But we must ask - what is driving this 'inflationary' report?  Hello????  RISING HEALTHCARE COSTS......and for all of us - January is coming and the reality of what healthcare costs is now beginning to hit home..... Rising monthly costs, rising deductibles and rising co-pays all picking the pockets of everyday Americans.  Obamacare - really???  2 pm today - will bring us the FED mins from last month.....will we really learn anything new?  We already know that they want to raise rates next month - barring a new meltdown somewhere.......Will their intentions be any clearer - not likely.....Do you expect to see anything definitive?  Don't hold your breath.....What you can expect is that they will just re-iterate what they already said in October - which left the mkts confused.....because they played both sides of the fence....The only thing they could add is any new analysis that shows how the situation is different today than it was in September or October.....They will also confirm that the pathway forward will be slow and thoughtful - no reason for anyone to suggest that future moves will be bigger or faster......Whatever!  Today also brings more FED speakers.....CNBC Squawk Box will host Richmond's Jeff Lacker at 8 am,  while - NY's Dudley, Cleveland's Mester and Atlanta's Lockhart will all be together on a panel discussion at the Clearing House Annual Conference in NY......  At noon - we get the soulful sounds of Dallas's Fed President -  Rob Kaplan - speaking about the economy and FED policy, while Uncle Benny (Bernanke) lunches with the Economic Club of NY.... It's only 7 am and I already have an Excedrin Headache just thinking about this! Watch oil today as well....10:30 brings the official gov't inventory data - many are expecting continued build in reserves - a definite factor holding oil in check.  Overnight in Asia - mkts flat to lower......commodities weaker, gold falling to a 6 yr low at $1070......Oil though managing to move marginally higher - but nothing to write home about......China home prices on the rise (this month) but that did nothing to help the broader mkt-  Chinese Pres Xi Jinping acknowledging some downside risks to Chinese growth as he suggests that maybe - a slower and steadier GDP will be the new norm......Add in the concern over FED policy and the developing drama between the world and ISIS and you have a perfect reason for  investors to stay on the sidelines..Japan +0.06%, Hong Kong -0.34%, China  -1% and ASX  +0.29%. In Europe - a pre-dawn raid in a Paris suburb yields 7 arrests and 2 deaths....- Chock one up for the 'Good Guys'..... Tensions remain high after more terror threats yesterday and overnight - a situation that is not going away anytime soon..... Investors trying to focus on the macro and the coming FED mins... FTSE -0.02%, CAC 40 -0.65%, DAX  -0.36%, Eurostoxx  -0.64%, Spain  -0.9% and Italy -0.23%.   US futures are up 3 pts.....Mortgage Applications rose an unexpected 6.2% ....Housing starts to be released at 8:30 - exp of -3.8% m/m while building permits are expected to rise by 3.8% m/m.......The mkt will remain in the 2035/2065 range until 2 pm......depending on what the news is -  A signal that we are on track for a rise will keep the pressure on.....any indication that rates 'could' stay the same will cause us to challenge resistance...... ...And the plot thickens.....
Take good care. Kp

Stocks pulled a fast one.......they rallied on Monday despite the negative tone set from last week....the broken technicals, the fear over FED policy, the weaker macro data and yes - the attacks on Paris - that shook all of humanity.

You see - recall the chatter last week - BEFORE the Paris attacks.........the data is getting weaker yet the clock is ticking....the FED has painted themselves into a corner so now they are trying to prepare investors/traders for 'The Move', a drama coming to a theater near you in December......

The talk of rate increases sending mkts into a tailspin - why?  Because it is confusing to think that 'now' is the right time to launch...I mean the data is NOT cooperating and the global economy is once again struggling (vs. where it was in the spring) US macro data is weaker, confidence is waning, leadership is lacking yet....we get all of the FED mouthpieces now telling us that  WE are all wrong, that WE can't see the truth, that WE must be confused - things have never been better...I mean look - we can point to ONE macro data report that surprised even the most seasoned economists - which must mean that it's all good....OK......no problem....if that is what YOU want us to believe - we can play along......all that means is that assets will get re-priced....no worries....

All this talk has caused investors/traders to re-price a range of assets to reflect the 'new risk'...the risk of what higher rates in a weaker environment will mean to the broader picture.....No worries - the mkt will dictate what those assets are worth....... This is all very normal.....if monetary policy is going to change, then analysts/strategists have to re-calculate the impact and that is what has been happening....If monetary policy remains confused then the mkt will remain confused.....and so we have seen the rotation.......Financials, Industrials, Energy, Retailers, Housing and Utilities all under the gun.....Tech, Healthcare, Consumer Staples attempting to carry the load....and all this makes sense in a struggling economy with the threat of rising rates.....

Then we had Paris......the images over the weekend causing fear and concern....speculation that Monday would be another 'blood bath' as investors fled the mkts based on technical weakness and FEAR.........But that was not the case.....in fact - I would argue that because  France took the bull by the horns and declared WAR on ISIS - they helped to create the environment for global mkts to rally.....It felt globally patriotic........and now that France is considering exercising “Article 5 of NATO”,  it creates a whole new conversation.

Article 5 states that "an armed attack against European and North American members, as well as Turkey, shall be considered an attack against them all.’’ As a result, NATO members would be obligated to impose military force on a NATO adversary.  (There are 28 member nations in NATO (North American Treaty Organization) - they include: Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, Iceland, Italy, Luxembourg, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, UK, US, Greece, Turkey, Germany, Spain, Czech, Hungary, Poland, Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia, Albania, and Croatia)

Recall that after 911 - NATO triggered Article 5 to announce military support for the US in the event the US chose to wage war against the terrorists.  However, Syria is a complicated mess - you have Shiite Syrians backed by Hezbollah, Iran and Russia fighting Sunni Syrians.  You have ISIS pushing for a caliphate - You have Al-Qaeda and the Kurds -  You've got conflicted foreign policies from a range of nations.....and now you have the biggest exodus of refugees that most of us alive today have ever seen.  in the end you have mess.... Yet, the cycle of war alwys seems to rear its ugly head when the world economy lags......History in fact DOES repeat itself.

Technically the mkt has completed a short cycle sell off with last week’s hard correction and yesterday's action tested support - sending the mkts to once again test resistance at 2065. As expected - Oil rallied (global unrest), causing the energy sector to rally 3.6%, Defense stocks also enjoyed an up day - the  iShares U.S. Aerospace & Defense ETF  (ITA) and Spdr S&P Aerospace & Dfn  (XAR) both rallied 2+%....... The broader mkt went along for the ride - piercing resistance at 2035 ending the day at 2053......

US futures are pointing higher this morning - currently up 7 pts.....as we await today's eco data.....CPI is expected to be +0.2%, but remember - PPI was -0.4%, so it is almost impossible for CPI to surprise at all...remember - CPI is Consumer Price Index (inflation) and that is derived from the PPI which is Producer Price Index - if producer prices are falling - how can consumer prices be rising?  Capisce?   Industrial Prod at 0.1% and Cap Util at 77.5% are the other two important reads today.    Also expect traders to be focused on the release of the FED mins tomorrow at 2 pm.....

Fed speakers will be at the top of the leader board as investors/traders listen intently to their chatter.  Fed Governor Jerome Powell to speak at 12:30, Daniel Tarullo at 3:30 pm and former Chairman Bernanke at 4:10 pm.....Overnight -  global mkts all surging higher on a positive US session.   Japan +1.22%,  Hong Kong + 0.93% and ASX +2.29%, China flat.  In Europe - mkts there are all higher..... German ZEW Survey beat estimates and the “expectations” component, a leading indicator in the report, rose for the first time in 8 months. Hollande calling for a united response against ISIS is helping mkts to surge....As expected defense stocks are in focus..... FTSE +1.77%, CAC 40 +2.3%, DAX +1.9%, EUROSTOXX + 2.15%, SPAIN +2%  and ITALY +1.65%. Take good care    Kp

New York-area factories contracted for a fifth straight month, signaling manufacturing continues to struggle. Meanwhile, Japan's economy has fallen back into a recession.
N.Y.-area factories shrink again

The New York Federal Reserve's Empire State Manufacturing Index was -10.74 in November, not much different from October's -11.36 and the 3 months before that. Economists had expected a bigger improvement to -5. New orders and shipments were less negative, but still fell for the 6th straight and 4th straight month, respectively. Unfilled orders were the weakest of the year, while the workweek and employment gauges showed the weakest runs in years. The Empire State index is the first of several factory gauges for the month of November.
Japan falls back into recession

The economy contracted at a 0.8% annual rate in the third quarter after falling 0.7% in Q2. Analysts had expected a 0.2% decline. Business spending fell at a 1.3% rate, worse than forecasts and also the 2nd straight retreat as Japanese companies remain wary of investing at home. But private spending rose 0.5%. The data are a blow to PM Shinzo Abe and his Abenomics program. It will put more pressure on the Bank of Japan to step up monetary easing, but BoJ officials have been reluctant to do so. The BoJ holds a two-day meeting on Wednesday and Thursday.
Eurozone prices pick up some

October consumer prices rose 0.1% vs. September and vs. a year earlier, with cheap energy depressing already-low underlying inflation. But that's up from flat prices year over year in September. Core CPI grew 0.2% in October after a 0.5% gain in September. Core inflation was 1.1% vs. September's 1%. Economists still expect the European Central Bank to step up easing efforts in December.
 The U.K.'s Rightmove House Price Index fell 1.3% in November, more than reversing October's 0.6% gain. Year over year, home prices rose 6.2% vs. October's 5.6%.
The U.K.'s Rightmove House Price Index fell 1.3% m/m in November, missing expectations and reversing a gain of 0.6% in October.
COMING UP TUESDAY
 Consumer price index for October, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: CPI up 0.2%, core CPI up 0.2%).
 Industrial production for October, 9:15 a.m. ET (forecast: output up 0.1%, manufacturing production up 0.3%, capacity utilization 77.5%).
 NAHB Housing Market Index for November, 10 a.m. ET (forecast: 65).
 E-commerce sales for Q3, 10 a.m. ET.

Massacre in Paris France Pounds ISIS with AirstrikesFrance Widens Crackdown at Home as Bombs Rain on Islamic StateFrance Strikes Back as Hunt Widens

These are just some of the headlines that hit the papers over the weekend and this morning- constant media coverage keeping the pressure on as President Hollande and the civilized world vows revenge....Asian mkts - the first to react - came under pressure as investors/traders initial reaction was to hit the SELL button.....but as the night progressed and word got out that France took control and started to drop bombs on the ISIS stronghold mkts reversed course....more to follow.   As a survivor of 911 - My  thoughts go out to all of those who suffered and those families who mourn the death of fathers, brothers, sisters and mothers.....#PrayforPeace......________________________________________________________________

Stocks closed lower on Friday finishing the week on a sour note — the selling violated the second level of support leaving the mkt in limbo with only the final support level needing to be tested at S&P 2005.  The Dow lost 202 pts while the S&P lost over 1%, closing lower by 23 pts….led by a continued free fall in commodities and the glaringly weak reports on retail sales and PPI (producer price index)…For the week — the S&P lost over 3.5%, the energy sector lost 6%, retailers lost 9%, Tech lost 4.7% , Consumer Discretionary lost 5.1%. Well you get the picture.  The PPI at -0.4% was so bad it is now indicating DEFLATION….but no worries — Janet and her band of merry men and women are singing about the benefits of that still strong NFP report from two weeks ago — in fact on Friday — Cleveland Fed Pres Loretta Mester said that the time to hike rates was ‘quickly approaching’….suggesting that the time is now for rates to rise…and so what we are seeing is a re-pricing of risk assets across the spectrum — why?  Because they (the FED)  clearly missed that opportunity 2 or 3 times already and the mkt is telling us that NOW is not the time to move on rates - especially in light of the weekend's events…..what’s the rush?  I mean the DATA is really not cooperating...but she is trapped - trapped like a rat..... (Remember December is a ‘self imposed’ deadline.)

And it was a very disappointing day for retailers on Friday — in fact the retailers rolled over and played dead…..October retail sales rose by 0.1% vs. the 0.3% expectation and if you look at retail sales EX autos, gas, building materials and food services rose by 0.2% vs. the 0.4% expectation.  Add in some weaker than expected earnings and the retailers got slaughtered…..JW Nordstrom (JWN) gave up 15% on horrific earnings, terrible revenues and a cut in full year sales and profit forecasts…. JC Penney  (JCP) also closed down 15% on terrible earnings, but the silver lining for them was that comparable store sales rose by 6.4%......The Gap, Inc. (GPS) -3%,  Kohl's (KSS) -3.2%, Macy's (M) gave up another 2% on top of the 24% in the last week alone.....Target (TGT) lost 2.5%......not a pretty picture by any stretch.....

Now Friday afternoon also brought word of a terrorist attack in Paris….and the chaos and confusion that that event created only served to put more pressure on an already weak mkt as investors/traders tried to understand the extent and impact of this horrific event.  As the day drew to a close — more information became available — and the selling pressure picked up into the bell.  Over the weekend — we learned of the very horrific events that engulfed the ‘City of Lights’ — the world mourned — allies stood together, world leaders who had gathered in Turkey for the G20 meeting denounced the actions of those pathetic souls that call themselves ‘jihadists’ — calling this an ‘attack on the civilized world’……. and then President Hollande of France declared ‘war’ on Isis…..Sunday night unleashing a barrage of French bombs — (neatly packed in French air force Rafale Fighter Jets…)  upon the nerve center in Raqqa, Syria — wiping out a command center, a weapons facility, and a training ground… and this is only the beginning…..there is now a global commitment to intensify and eradicate this terrorist organization…… and so it begins - the instability, the fear, the bombs and the continued threats of chaos will now become some of the directional drivers in the global mktplace. Asia was the first mkt center to open — and stocks moved lower as mkts react to the worst terror incident in over a decade…..investors kneejerk reaction is to hit the SELL button (fear) as they assess the impact that this event will have on the European economy and the global economy…. Weaker macro data in Japan also did not help the tone — GDP for the 3rd qtr fell by 0.8% on top of the -0.7% in the 2nd qtr.  Sending that country into RECESSION — this is the second recession since PM Shinzo Abe took office in December 2012.  This news put renewed pressure on Abe and the BoJ Governor Kuroda to do MORE! Over the weekend - the Chinese gov't raised margin requirements (bearish) but at the same time indicated possibly more accommodation as the gov't pursues pro-mkt reforms (bullish)......Japan - 1%, Hong Kong -0.89%, China + 0.48% and ASX -0.9%. In Europe this morning — mkts are mixed but marginally higher after initial selling pressure subsided.....Investors/traders now digesting news of French attacks on ISIS is sending mkts into positive territory.....As you would expect - travel, hotel, airlines and leisure stocks will take it on the chin a bit, but expect that defense stocks will benefit as the civilized world gears up to destroy those cowards.    Macro data in the Eurozone showed inflation data in October to be 0.1% up from 0%.   FTSE +0.44%, CAC 40+0.03%, DAX +0.34%, Eurostoxx +0.20%, Spain +0.01% and Italy flat.   Now US futures had a wild ride overnight......opening down 11 pts at 2007 - only to test 2000 then rally as the bombs dropped.  Currently - US futures are higher by 5 pts indicating that investors/traders will not allow ISIS to dictate capital flow and investor reaction.  CNBC puts  Billionaire Wilbur Ross on the television to tell us that these latest attempts on humanity will be 'unlikely to cause a mkt correction' and I agree...what will cause a mkt correction is the inability of the global economy to fire on all cylinders and a pre-mature move by the FED to raise rates at a time when the data is not confirming 'escape velocity'.  Now last week we broke S&P intermediate support at 2034....closing lower at 2023.....Overnight we tested support at 2000 and held.....I suspect that we are now stuck in the 2000/2034 trading range as the week begins.   The talk  will be about  broken technical's, attacks on ISIS, and more eco data this week.....

Today  we WON'T get any FED speak but we will get the Empire Manf Survey - exp of -6.3 - which would be an improvement over last month's -11......Mortgage foreclosures and delinquencies round out today....later in the week Traders/Investors will keep an eye on CPI exp of +0.2%, Industrial production of +0.1%, Cap Util of 77.5%, housing starts of 1.1 mil which would be a decline of 4%..... On Wednesday we get the FED mins and although I do not think we will learn anything new - it will be a key to the action amid concerns over what the FED will decide to do in 4 weeks.  On the earnings front, retail giants Wal-Mart  (WMT), Home Depot  (HD), Target (TGT), Staples (SPLS), and Best Buy  (BBY) are among the companies due to report their quarterly results this week.
Take good care. Kp

A European Parliament tax committee is set next Monday to ask representatives of nearly a dozen multinationals — including Facebook (FB) and Amazon (AMZN) — about their tax practices on the Continent. The hearing comes after a failed attempt earlier this year to put company officials on the hot seat. It also follows the European Union's decision last month to…

The biggest trade agreement since NAFTA has run into the most populist presidential campaign in memory. It's a sure bet that sparks will fly. What's not clear is when the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership linking 40% of global GDP and 800 million consumers will come to a vote in Congress — it might have to wait until after the election — much less whether it will pass.
After five years of negotiations, trade officials sealed the deal in Atlanta on Monday, but the reception wasn't exactly celebratory.
Populism Rises On Left, Right

Socialist Bernie Sanders, who has rallied the far left behind his Democratic presidential bid, bashed the deal, but he wasn't alone. Ford Motor (F) criticized the deal for failing to protect U.S. producers from foreign currency manipulation — the same issue that's been seized on by Hillary Clinton and, even more aggressively, by Donald Trump.
Even GOP supporters in Congress were dismayed.

"I am afraid this deal appears to fall woefully short," said Sen. Orrin Hatch, one of the deal's biggest boosters on Capitol Hill. "The Trans-Pacific Partnership is a once in a lifetime opportunity and the United States should not settle for a mediocre deal."
The letdown isn't exactly a surprise. Trade talks generally leave the toughest issues until the end, and the U.S. had to make several big concessions.
Instead of 12 years of intellectual property protections for biotech drugs, the U.S. settled for 5 to 8 years.

While NAFTA requires 62.5% of an automobile to be sourced from within the trade bloc, TPP would cut that to 42.5%. That opens the possibility for Japanese cars to include more parts made in a non-TPP country such as Thailand.
Instead of opening up Canada's dairy market, the U.S. and other TPP members got just a toehold: imports capped at 3.25% of the market.

TPP rules for settling investor-state disputes have come under fire, but the new complaint is that tobacco companies were denied the same rights as other multinationals. That would disallow suits such as Philip Morris International's (PM) challenge to Australia's plain packaging for cigarettes.

"The problem is the reaction from Republicans," said Dan Ikenson, director of trade policy studies at the Cato Institute, since President Obama can't afford to lose more GOP support in the House. Most Democrats are expected to vote no.
While some trade-offs, such as the U.S. taking 30 years to phase out a 25% tariff on trucks, aren't ideal, Ikenson expects that the deal will be a positive step in liberalizing trade.

The Peterson Institute for International Economics estimates the deal would raise U.S. incomes, on net, by $77 billion a year, growing relatively high-paying export-related jobs by 650,000, though at the cost of some manufacturing jobs.
TTP Vote After Election?

A thoughtful debate over the deal seems unlikely during primary season. A vote in Congress could come in three months, but Ikenson expects Obama to slow the process. Tweaks are still possible, if unlikely, he says.
If Vice President Joe Biden enters the race, Clinton might be tempted to amp up her disapproval of the deal. But Trump, who says Washington is run by bad deal makers, might hit a higher decibel.

Obama could seek a vote after the primaries, but that could risk depressing Democratic voters. That's why he may leave it for a lame-duck Congress to decide.The biggest trade agreement since NAFTA has run into the most populist presidential campaign in memory. It's a sure bet that sparks will fly. What's not clear is when the 12-nation Trans-Pacific Partnership linking 40% of global GDP and 800 million consumers will come to a vote in Congress — it might have to wait until after the election — much less whether it will pass.After five years of negotiations, trade officials sealed the deal in Atlanta on Monday, but the reception wasn't exactly celebratory.Populism Rises On Left, RightSocialist Bernie Sanders, who has rallied the far left behind his Democratic presidential bid, bashed the deal, but he wasn't alone. Ford Motor (F) criticized the deal for failing to protect U.S. producers from foreign currency manipulation — the same issue that's been seized on by Hillary Clinton and, even more aggressively, by Donald Trump.Even GOP supporters in Congress were dismayed."I am afraid this deal appears to fall woefully short," said Sen. Orrin Hatch, one of the deal's biggest boosters on Capitol Hill. "The Trans-Pacific Partnership is a once in a lifetime opportunity and the United States should not settle for a mediocre deal."The letdown isn't exactly a surprise. Trade talks generally leave the toughest issues until the end, and the U.S. had to make several big concessions.Instead of 12 years of intellectual property protections for biotech drugs, the U.S. settled for 5 to 8 years.While NAFTA requires 62.5% of an automobile to be sourced from within the trade bloc, TPP would cut that to 42.5%. That opens the possibility for Japanese cars to include more parts made in a non-TPP country such as Thailand.Instead of opening up Canada's dairy market, the U.S. and other TPP members got just a toehold: imports capped at 3.25% of the market.TPP rules for settling investor-state disputes have come under fire, but the new complaint is that tobacco companies were denied the same rights as other multinationals. That would disallow suits such as Philip Morris International's (PM) challenge to Australia's plain packaging for cigarettes."The problem is the reaction from Republicans," said Dan Ikenson, director of trade policy studies at the Cato Institute, since President Obama can't afford to lose more GOP support in the House. Most Democrats are expected to vote no.While some trade-offs, such as the U.S. taking 30 years to phase out a 25% tariff on trucks, aren't ideal, Ikenson expects that the deal will be a positive step in liberalizing trade.The Peterson Institute for International Economics estimates the deal would raise U.S. incomes, on net, by $77 billion a year, growing relatively high-paying export-related jobs by 650,000, though at the cost of some manufacturing jobs.TTP Vote After Election?A thoughtful debate over the deal seems unlikely during primary season. A vote in Congress could come in three months, but Ikenson expects Obama to slow the process. Tweaks are still possible, if unlikely, he says.If Vice President Joe Biden enters the race, Clinton might be tempted to amp up her disapproval of the deal. But Trump, who says Washington is run by bad deal makers, might hit a higher decibel.Obama could seek a vote after the primaries, but that could risk depressing Democratic voters. That's why he may leave it for a lame-duck Congress to decide.
And this headline says it all - "Brisk Job Gains Ease Fed's Path" - Solid wage growth and robust hiring raise chances of rate hike at December meeting" - wsj 11-7-15

Stocks should have celebrated that 'great news'.....yet - they showed a lack of direction for much of Friday as traders/investors digested the 'blow the roof off the house' monthly jobs report. The major averages spent the day bouncing back and forth across the unchanged line before closing mixed.

U.S. employers supposedly added jobs in October at a pace unimagined while boosting wages at the fastest rate since 2009, giving the FED the all clear signal  that the economy is back and is strong enough to withstand an interest-rate increase next month.

Nonfarm payrolls rose a seasonally adjusted 271,000 last month - beating the expectation by more than 100k jobs - causing the unemployment rate to fall  to 5%, a level Fed officials expected it to reach before the end of the yr.  [ Note that September was revised down to 135,000 and remember that last month August had been revised dramatically down as well.]  I would expect that October's numbers will also be 'revised' next month — or maybe in January, after the Fed has used these 'dramatically improved' numbers to justify  a rate hike in December.  I mean these numbers are just too good to be believed.

Economists and strategists are now convinced that  the likelihood of the first rate increase is now on the table - remember - 'Fed officials have said for months they would start lifting their benchmark rate, which has been near zero since late 2008, after they saw more improvement in the labor market and felt "reasonably confident" annual inflation would rise toward their 2% target'...Stephen Stanley - Chief Economist at Amhearst Pierpoint Securities had this to say:  "This is the kind of employment report that even the most diehard doves on the Fed cannot ignore,"  I would say - "That is if you believe it".

What they buried deep in the report is that there are still some 8 mil people who want a job and can't find one..... and what they didn't tell you is that there are  2.2 mil LESS people in the work force vs. last year....so the drop in the unemployment rate is NOT because of some dramatic real increase in jobs as much as it is a function of less people in the workforce.  What they failed to explain is - How could the actual report be so different from Wednesday's ADP report and all the analysis by some of the street's smartest economists?   I mean not even GS had the number - I guess they didn't get the 'wink'

Look the majority of the jobs created - as the story points out -  were in the "domestically oriented service sectors that are largely immune to overseas turbulence, including retail, food services, health care and construction"   Retail jobs - (think - part time Holiday jobs) rose by 44k...those jobs disappear in late January after the rush of returns subsides.... and then they chimed in and told us that the retail sector wage growth rose to $14.90/hr..... that equates to $30k/ yr  - IF you work 40 hrs a week and have that job for the whole year.   (Which ain't happening...) - so why even use that stat?

One thing is for sure - the FED needed a strong number and miraculously - they got it......and the overriding take away is that the hike is on!   And this is curious why?  Because all of the reasons for delay back in September including  - overseas economic weakness, a China implosion, weaker oil, stronger dollar - still exist....nothing has really changed other than this ONE report...... In fact - Oil has only gotten weaker the dollar has gotten stronger......

In international news - Overnight - the OECD (Organization of Economic Cooperation & Development) cut global growth forecast to 2.9%  from 3% in Sept.....and down from 3.1% in June......and this morning a Bloomberg article points out that Maersk - the largest shipping company in the world suggests that   "Global GDP is worse now than what the official forecasts show".

In his article - the CEO of  points out that the IMF is overly optimistic....saying that: "We believe that global growth is slowing down, Trade is currently significantly weaker than it normally would be under the growth forecasts we see.  We conduct a string of our own macro-economic forecasts and we see less growth -- particularly in developing nations, but perhaps also in Europe -- than other people expect in 2015."

On Friday Maersk reported that 3Q profit fell by 61%...and trade from Asia to Europe is suffering the most.....blaming the weaker euro for exporters like China to remain competitive......So we must ask - How long before we see another China devaluation?

Overnight - Asian mkts were mixed....hopes for more Chinese stimulus helped China surge by 1.6%.  Look the Chinese macro data was mixed at best...Currency reserves rose for the first time in 5 months - that's good, but October exports fell by 6.9% vs. the exp of -3.2% and imports fell by 18.8% vs. exp of  -15.2%.  The data doesn’t really  change the conversation very much.....but it  does reinforce there’s still no real growth.  Japan +1.9%,  Hong Kong -0.6% and ASX -1.8%

In Europe - mkts there are all lower.....German export data did beat the expectation - but that did nothing to ignite investor confidence today as the focus was on weaker China data and the stronger US jobs number - suggesting a rate hike. FTSE -0.1%, CAC 40 - 0.53%, DAX - 0.39%, EUROSTOXX - 0.43%, SPAIN -0.23%  and ITALY - 0.49%.

And this morning US futures are down by 7 pts......after investors and traders got a chance to digest Friday's NFP report and the likely implications of the first rate hike....because now the conversation turns to the 'pace and timing of the NEXT rate hike (assuming that Dec is now a fait accompli').   The implication is that the FED is now behind the curve  (think strong jobs number) - so many are now suggesting that the FED will need to be more aggressive in 2016 to combat the rising threat of inflation..... If that is the case - then strap in - because the mkts will swiftly re-price asset values across the spectrum.  Why?  Because Janet has made it very clear that the pace and timing of any future rates increases will be measured and thoughtful......not swift and erratic....so stocks will get hit, housing prices will fall, emerging mkts will get clobbered - but hey - it has to happen at some point....and it should have happened months ago......

I would expect that we could see the mkt test 2063 over the next couple of days...as the mkt listens to the coming FED speeches this week.  Boston's Rosengren is the first one up at bat today at 12 pm - expect to hear him fawn over the strength of the US economy as he floats the first 'higher rate balloon' since the NFP report.  Take good care    Kp

Kenny Polcari is Vice President and director of NYSE Floor Operations on behalf of O’Neil Securities, Inc., a sister company of Investor's Business Daily. Tobacco makers continue to pay smoking-hot dividends even as they keep transitioning toward smoke-free products. Philip Morris International (PM) has increased its annual dividend every year since it went public in 2008. The New York-based tobacco company currently pays $1.04 a share on a quarterly basis, or $4.16 for the full year, which works out to a 3.7% annualized yield.…

Major market indexes continued to flex strength in afternoon trading Thursday as earnings reports across a wide swath of industries seemed to reinforce investor confidence in the ongoing recovery of the U.S. economy.Steel companies rebounded sharply, as did American Express (AXP), which helped boost the all-important financial sector. The stock gapped up 5% and regained its 50-day moving average line.As of 2:30 pm ET, the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite all rallied 0.8% to 1% in the stock market today, topped only a little bit by the small-cap Russell 2000, up more than 1.1%. Volume is mixed, up sharply on the NYSE vs. the same time Wednesday and virtually even on the Nasdaq.At its intraday high of 2361, the S&P 500 retook the key 50-day moving average. In recent sessions, though, the Nasdaq composite showed superior strength on the back of a strong bounce off its 50-day line, bolstered by continued institutional demand in medical, software, chip, internet and select consumer-oriented stocks. For more color on the general market action, please read IBD's The Big Picture column on a daily basis. Steel Dynamics (STLD) rose 4.8% to 34.28, still shy of reclaiming its 50-day line. On the bright side, a recent two-week pullback stopped short of becoming a test of support at the long-term 200-day moving average.The highly efficient maker of steel, based in Ft. Wayne, Ind., reported a 215% leap in first-quarter profit to 82 cents a share as revenue jumped 36%, accelerating from gains of 1%, 8% and 20% in the prior three quarters.Steel Dynamics' RS Rating is 74 on a scale of 1 to 99, so it could use some improvement. And it's down from a much better rank of 90 seen eight weeks ago. Generally, the best growth stocks already show a Relative Price Strength Rating of 80 or higher before the complete a base and potentially break out.The stock, whose $8.4 billion market cap makes it a mid-cap play, has a superior RS Rating than American compatriot Nucor (NUE) at 52. U.S. Steel (X) has an 84 RS, fourth best in the steel producers industry group, as seen in IBD Stock Checkup.In the IBD 50, a number of small-cap firms have posted rousing returns in recent months. Holders with a large profit cushion should remain in the stock until a clear sell signal arises. Among the leaders, keep an eye on these five: Essent Group (ESNT) (in Leaderboard), a mortgage insurance leader; Nutrisystem (NTRI), which recently regained its short-term 10-day moving average; Masimo (MASI), an expert in medical diagnostic gear for hospitals; and Veeva Systems (VEEV), which is excelling in business software for Big Pharma and biotechs; and Advanced Energy Industries (AEIS).Essent, which marked new all-time highs on Wednesday, is still in buy range from a recent flat-base breakout at 38.20. The 5% chase zone goes up to 40.11. Leaderboard added the Bermuda-based seller of private mortgage insurance on April 5. As noted on an annotated Leaderboard daily chart, Essent also triggered an aggressive buy point at 36.91.The stock initially broke out of a first-stage bottoming base pattern with a 24.53 entry on Aug. 4, 2016. The rally has since expanded as much as 61%.Essent's earnings per share have increased 111%, 78%, 52%, 45%, 37%, 39%, 48% and 42% vs. year-ago levels in the past eight quarters. The Street sees Q1 profit rising 33% to 69 cents a share.Revenue jumped 28% to 67% over the same time frame. The IBD 50, as featured in full in each issue of IBD Weekly, shows the most promising small-, mid- and large-cap stocks in terms of earnings and sales excellence, stock strength, and increasing mutual fund and hedge fund sponsorship.RELATED:Stock Market Today: When Will Snapchat Operator Snap Break Out?How To Invest: Lessons On Risk Control From A World Class Air Racer IBD's Take On The Latest Earnings News: Go Here

Prime Minister Theresa May set the U.K. on course for leaving the European Union in two years time, a divorce that will redefine the country's relationship with its largest trading partner and end decades of deepening political integration on the continent."After nine months the UK has delivered," EU President Donald Tusk, said in a Twitter post after receiving a signed letter by May, which invoked Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty.The ties that have bound the U.K. to the EU since 1973 started to unravel at around 1:20 p.m. in Brussels when Britain's ambassador gave Tusk the letter."I want us to be a truly global Britain," May told lawmakers in London.Nine months since Britons unexpectedly voted to leave, the phony war of what Brexit might look like will turn into a real battle over the complex terms of a settlement with 27 other governments. Enough lines over money, trade and immigration have been drawn to suggest a tough process with costs to both sides."We're moving from a U.K. monologue to a hard negotiation," said Gregor Irwin, chief economist at Global Counsel, a consultancy, and a former official in the U.K. Foreign Office. "There are going to be many upsets along the way."The pound on Wednesday initially weakened against all of its Group-of-10 peers and fell to a one-week low against the dollar, but quickly hit a daily high after the long-expected move finally took place. Pound sterling has dropped 17% since the referendum although it stabilized recently as investors awaited signs of how the talks would progress.May is aiming by March 29, 2019, to have won back control of labor flows and lawmaking, while also landing a new free trade pact with the bloc. The EU is demanding the U.K. first pay a 50 billion-pound ($62 billion) fee and there is the threat of sweeping tariffs being imposed if a deal isn't struck in time."It is my fierce determination to get the right deal for every single person in this country," May will tell parliament, according to her office. "We all want to live in a truly global Britain that gets out and builds relationships with old friends and new allies around the world."In the background is London's future as an international financial hub and threats by banks to up sticks. There's also Britain's commercial relations with the rest of the world and even the potential breakup of the U.K. as Scottish nationalists use Brexit in their push for autonomy. The legislature in Edinburgh voted on Tuesday to pursue another independence referendum."Today the PM will take the U.K. over a cliff with no idea of the landing place," Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon wrote on Twitter. "Scotland didn't vote for it and our voice has been ignored."The talks will test the negotiating mettle of a premier in power for just eight months and her ability to play to a domestic audience, especially the anti-EU wing of her Conservative Party that remembers she voted to stay in the bloc. Britain is divided over a "hard Brexit," where May could walk away with no deal, and "soft Brexit" with continued tariff-free trade, which Scotland and other pro-EU factions want.May interpreted June's referendum result as a protest against some of the key tenets of globalization, a trend that also swept Donald Trump to power in the U.S. and put National Front leader Marine Le Pen ahead in some polls before French presidential elections next month.For Europe, it's a question of cohesion. Any deal struck between the U.K. and the EU potentially could decide whether Britain proves to be a trailblazer for other countries to leave, or remain the skeptical outlier it has always been. To ward against encouraging others to eye the exit door, EU officials say Britain will not be allowed to enjoy better terms outside the bloc than inside it.Both sides talk publicly of the need to avoid hostilities, with May speaking of a "new deep and special partnership" on the eve of the trigger. She also telephoned Tusk, German Chancellor Angela Merkel and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, agreeing with all of them that "a strong EU was in everyone's interests and that the U.K. would remain a close and committed ally," according to her office.Chancellor of the Exchequer Philip Hammond told the BBC on Wednesday that the British still want security, defense and science relationships with the EU.Still, Juncker has in the past predicted negotiations will be "very, very, very difficult." David Davis, the Brexit czar, is preparing for what "may be the most complicated negotiation of all time."European officials will bide their time to make a considered response, knowing the British have ceded control of the clock to them. Tusk will speak to reporters on Wednesday afternoon and publish draft guidelines for EU negotiator Michel Barnier by the end of the week, but leaders won't sign off on them until an April 29 summit."In the end, the words of the letter won't matter much," said Guntram Wolff, director at the Brussels-based Bruegel think tank. "In such negotiations, it is actions that matter."In an early blow to May, three people familiar with the matter said Tusk will limit Barnier's remit to the terms of divorce rather than widen it to include a future trade relationship. Merkel also plans to push May to cover the U.K.'s financial commitments, people familiar with her strategy said.May and Barnier agree the terms of the breakup need to be settled in about 18 months to give the British and European Parliaments time to rubber stamp them.May wants to leave the EU's single market to reduce the number of people allowed into Britain to work. She also wants to escape the oversight of the European Court of Justice and cease sending what she calls "vast" sums of money to Brussels.As for trade, she is requesting the "best possible deal," while at the same time winning the freedom to line up trade accords with countries such as the U.S. and China.European governments have shown rare unanimity in declining to enter even informal talks before May gave official notice to leave.An early flash point will be money. Barnier says the U.K. must agree to settle financial commitments. Davis questions whether the U.K. is under any legal obligation to pay anything. An impasse might leave the EU refusing to engage on trade and potentially forcing the issue in front of the courts."We simply do not recognize some of the very large numbers that have been bandied about in Brussels," Hammond said.That's why May's team wants to discuss the split and new commercial ties in tandem. The British hope the amount of goods and services the EU sends to the U.K. will allow for a compromise.In a bid to maintain bargaining power, May warns that "no deal is better than a bad deal." That would lead to the imposition of World Trade Organization tariffs on products from cars to strawberries.Other issues to be discussed early on include the border between the two Irelands, the rights of EU citizens residing in the U.K. as well as Britons living in the bloc and regulatory agencies such as the European Banking Authority. The two sides may also have to line up a transitional phase between leaving the bloc and any new trade rules with banks threatening to shift staff from London if they don't get time to adjust.The task at hand is daunting. Philip Wood, special global counsel at law firm Allen & Overy's intelligence unit, estimated there are at least 339 negotiating points for Brexit, embracing security, intelligence and even science."The most unsatisfactory result would be for the parties not to agree so that the U.K. just exits unilaterally," said Wood. "We believe that this might leave the U.K. and the other nations of Europe embittered and resentful for a generation."

Stocks kept a bullish tone in afternoon trading Wednesday as the indexes easily recouped last week's mild declines and more.Meanwhile, Apple (AAPL) continued to stage positive action following its breakout past a 118.12 cup-with-handle buy point. The megacap consumer tech play rose more than 1.5% to 121.90, stretching its gains past the proper entry point to nearly 3%.Volume was running 13% above average at around 1:30 pm New York time, another sign that the iPhone giant is still enjoying robust institutional sponsorship; watch to see how it finishes. Apple's 50-day average turnover is 29.8 million shares. The 5% buy zone extends up to 124.02.Apple is not the only company to reassert itself after a long, deep decline. Other stocks that have rebounded nicely following the formation of a bottoming basing process include Eagle Materials (EXP), GrubHub (GRUB) and Seagate Technology (STX).At 2:30pm ET, the Nasdaq composite rallied more than 0.8%, as did the small-cap Russell 2000. The Dow industrials and the S&P 500 were both up nearly 0.7%. Volume is running moderately higher on both exchanges.As noted in Tuesday's IBD Big Picture column, the above-average turnover on the NYSE as the major indexes gained sharply on Tuesday added further evidence that mutual funds, hedge funds, large investment advisors, banks, pensions and college endowments are busily accumulating shares. None of the down sessions on the S&P 500 this year have featured above-average turnover on the Big Board so far.Returning to Apple, keep a close eye on the stock action as investors wait for fiscal Q1 results, covering the October to December time frame, to be released after the market close on Jan. 31.As noted often in past Stock Market Today columns, Apple is trying to halt a three-quarter slump in earnings. The current estimate has been revised slightly up as the Street now sees earnings down just 2% to $3.22 a share. The strength of service-related revenue and the issue of whether Apple can get iPhone unit sales to grow again are major points of concern.Apple initially cleared its long bottoming base by rising past a 110.33 entry in a choppy cup with handle on Sept. 14. Shares rallied nearly 8%, then pulled back to test institutional support at the 200-day moving average.Apple's revenue is on consensus seen rising 2% to $77.4 billion. That would bust the company's unenviable three-quarter streak of falling revenue (-13%, -15% and -9% in the prior three quarters).However, Q2 sales may continue an accelerating trend as the Thomson Reuters forecast expects 6.9% growth to $54 billion. For all of FY 2017, which ends in September, the Street expects sales up 6.9%.IBD reported in its Click Tech Blog today that the upcoming iPhone 8 may get special 3D sensing features to allow users to have an augmented reality experience with their smartphones.Seagate Technology, gapping up more than 15% to 43.30, rushed past a 41.55 buy point within a deep cup with handle that is part of a long bottoming process. The 5% chase zone extends up to 43.63.Seagate reported a 68% jump in fourth-quarter earnings to $1.38 a share, crushing Wall Street's view by nearly 28%, as sales fell 3%, the smallest decline in seven quarters. Q1 profit is currently seen soaring 291% to 86 cents a share.GrubHub, No. 10 in the IBD 50, has been forming a new cup base that is nestled within a much longer, deeper cup structure that spans all the way back to its 47.95 high seen in early April of 2015.In that deep cup, GrubHub plunged 63% to as low as 17.77.GrubHub rallied 3% to 41.79, getting closer to a potential buy point at 44.68, 10 cents above the current base's left-side high.Eagle Materials, moving nicely after reporting a fourth straight quarter of double-digit profit growth, has broken out past a base-on-base pattern at 103.26. The 5% buy zone extends up to 108.42.Shares are up more than 3% to 108.04 in volume running 2-1/2 times normal levels.Eagle — which also posted accelerating revenue growth as sales rose 9% to $302 million, up from a 1% jump in Q3 — built its own bottoming base pattern when it slumped from 105.69 in 2014 to a multiyear low of 45.03 a year ago.RELATED:Seagate Flies On Strong Earnings Report; Western Digital Up NextThe Bottoming Base, Part I: How It Helps Investors Make MoneyThe Bottoming Base, Part II: Why Apple Formed One In 2009How To Invest: Master The Elements Of An Excellent Cup With HandleWhere To Find The Latest Earnings News In Tech

After years of delays and a sharp drop in oil prices, President Obama announced Friday that he had rejected TransCanada's Keystone XL oil pipeline, saying that it wouldn't serve the nation's economy or interests.

Obama also said that Keystone had taken on an "overinflated role in our political discourse," adding that it wouldn't have been a "silver bullet for our economy" or "the express lane to environmental disaster."
Since 2011, the House of Representatives approved the pipeline 10 times, and the Senate approved it once.

TransCanada (TRP) shares tumbled 5.2% to 32.56. U.S. crude fell 2% to $44.29 per barrel, and Brent crude dipped 1.2% to $47.42, despite another decline in drilling activity. The number of active U.S. oil rigs fell by six to 572 in the latest week, according to Baker Hughes.

The pipeline would've run 1,200 miles, from Alberta to Nebraska. Canada's previous prime minister, Stephen Harper, had been an outspoken supporter. But the Liberal Party and new PM Justin Trudeau, who is seen as more environmentally friendly, swept Harper and his Conservative Party out of power last month.

The plunge in oil prices since the summer of 2014 also weighed on the Keystone pipeline, which would've transported tar sands that are costlier to extract and require higher oil prices to be produced profitably.
Obama's decision came ahead of a United Nations climate change summit in Paris next month.

The U.S. Chamber of Commerce said, "President Obama has put politics before the best interests of the country. Rejecting Keystone breaks two promises the president made — to put jobs and growth first and to seek bipartisan solutions."

Environmentalists were more sanguine. "The power of the American people decisively beat out the fossil fuel special interests," NextGen Climate President Tom Steyer said.After years of delays and a sharp drop in oil prices, President Obama announced Friday that he had rejected TransCanada's Keystone XL oil pipeline, saying that it wouldn't serve the nation's economy or interests.Obama also said that Keystone had taken on an "overinflated role in our political discourse," adding that it wouldn't have been a "silver bullet for our economy" or "the express lane to environmental disaster."Since 2011, the House of Representatives approved the pipeline 10 times, and the Senate approved it once.TransCanada (TRP) shares tumbled 5.2% to 32.56. U.S. crude fell 2% to $44.29 per barrel, and Brent crude dipped 1.2% to $47.42, despite another decline in drilling activity. The number of active U.S. oil rigs fell by six to 572 in the latest week, according to Baker Hughes.The pipeline would've run 1,200 miles, from Alberta to Nebraska. Rejecting Keystone breaks two promises the president made — to put jobs and growth first and to seek bipartisan solutions."Environmentalists were more sanguine. "Fed Keeps December Rate Hike In Play - Officials remove explicit mention of concern at overseas tumult, delivering warning to markets" - WSJ 10-29-15
The operative word in that headline is 'Play'....in this case Play is defined as 'engaging in activity for enjoyment or fun - to amuse oneself'
"Federal Reserve officials explicitly said they might raise short term interest rates in December pushing back against investors who have bet that the central bank wouldn’t move this year."

They continue to try and convince us that they are going to move in 2015....and December is their last opportunity.......but can they really?  US macro data continues to weaken,  The U6 Underemployment rates is still above 10%, inflation remains frustratingly low,  congress just approved a disastrous 'spending plan' kicking their responsibility into the NEXT CENTURY,  The ECB announces a new bigger & better QE type program to further stimulate that sagging economy, and China?  Well they cut short term lending rates last week in a last ditch effort to 'boost growth' while they continue to threaten another currency devaluation.....and Hilsenrath thinks that these moves signal 'STRENGTH'.........and pave the way for the FED to raise rates?   Now in a move to show us how serious they really are - the FED " struck from their policy statement a sentence introduced in September that pointed to market turbulence and global developments as potential restraints on U.S. economic activity. As those concerns recede, the Fed has fewer impediments standing in the way of a rate increase."

Now the funny thing is that the FED is clearly split....some say go, while other say no.......and yesterday's statement was supposed to remove any doubt at all about the coming increase.   Remember - the FED remains 'data dependent' so we will get two more months of 'data' before the FED meets again on Dec 16th/17th.....but remember - they may have wanted to send 'that wakeup call' but in the end - yesterday's statement DID NOT commit to a December move.....(they left the door slightly ajar so that they have an exit plan....)

And amuse themselves is exactly what they did.....Stocks rallied early on prior to 'the announcement'  - the DOW was up 131 pts at 2 pm.....then the news hits...the mkts stumbles as it dissects the headline...then the algo's hit......sending stocks into a minor tailspin sending the DOW  - down 287 pts - from hi to lo.....in a matter of 13 mins.....only to reverse and surge higher into the close as the 'smart algos' realized that the statement didn't really say anything new...there was NO definitive decision....there was nothing in there that sets the path for a move in December at all.....Yeah - there was a vague reference to a move - but does anyone really believe it to be true?  Not yesterday anyway...as they closed the mkt on its highs  at 2090 on the S&P and 17,779 on the DOW..... You gotta love when the FED speaks out of both ends, no?

It is interesting to think that all of a sudden the FED thinks that economy is ready to launch..... Remember!  The Fed hasn’t raised interest rates since 2006 - (they have only lowered them)  and here 9 yrs later  when we have zero interest rates (while some countries have negative rates)  - we also have manufacturing crashing, durable goods and retail sales plunging our national debt approaching $19 trillion, housing still struggling, healthcare costs soaring, wages stagnating,  entitlement programs exploding, Underemployment still in the double digits, weak commodity prices, struggling global economies, half the world in recession and the other half gasping for air and NOW she thinks it's the right time to launch?   Is it me?  Now all this says is that monetary policy alone cannot solve the world's problems....so I once again point the finger at leadership.....or lack of...but hey...that's a conversation for another time I guess.....
In the end - The FED made it clear that they won't raise rates until they are 'reasonably confident' that the data supports the move.....and that ain't happening in 60 days.....

Technically  - the mkt has enjoyed a surge off the August lows...making everyone 'feel better' but is it really better?   Have we moved too fast and now need to play catch up?  I think that answer is yes....and as the mkt gets used to the latest FED speak and analysts/strategists recalculate the possibilities - I suspect that we see the mkt back and fill..... Last night we ended at S&P 2090.....a good 30 pts above support.....earnings are coming to an end and so the focus will return to more broader global macro issues once again....For now - I think we are in the 2060/2100 range...and if the 'data' continues to disappoint then expect the mkt to find its legs and push higher (indicating NO rate increase) ....but if as Janet indicates - the 'data' becomes stronger -then yes....look for the mkt to back off as the reality of an 'increase' hits home....and the mkt re-prices.  Either way - I do not think we get a move in 2015...so I suspect that the mkt churns and attempts to return closer to the yearly highs (2150)  as we approach year end.

Now this morning - US futures are off 8 pts  as we await the first release of 3rd QTR GDP...and it does not have a 3 handle on it, and it does not have a 2 handle on it......we will be lucky if it has a 1 handle on it...as the Atlanta FED suggests it will be 0.9% (vs. the robust 3.9% in the 2nd qtr) and some of the biggest investment banks in the country are looking for 1.2% - 1.4% .  The 'official' (govt) expectation is for a reading of +1.6%.... and if it comes in stronger then I think someone will have 'a lot of 'splainin to do' ......
Look for earnings today from MasterCard (MA),Western Union  (WU), CME Group  (CME),Air Products  (APD), Good Year Tires  (GT), Coca Cola  (KO), Pitney Bowes  (PBI),  and Marathon Oil  (MRO).....

European mkts are in negative territory.....not big, but a bit softer....earnings are the focus.......DBK reports a loss of $6.5 bil  and said that they will CUT their workforce by some 26k jobs over the next 2 yrs - sending that stock lower.........Barclays also missed on their earnings....sending that stock down 4.5%... Frances Total Oil reports a 69% drop in revenue....(no surprise)  and they take the stock UP......Take good care. Kp
