So Twitter (TWTR) both beats and misses at the same time.......posting softer user growth - 320 mil avg monthly users vs. the expectation of 324 mil users - while also offering guidance that was less than upbeat.....BUT - they did beat on the top line - Revenues were $569 mil vs. exp of $559.6 mil.... the stock traded off 13% in after hours trading...but look....they had taken the stock up 30% off the lows of Oct 2 (the same day that they announced the appointment of Jack Dorsey as CEO) at $24.34.....so now they gave back 10% on this 'miss'.......so net net...the stock is still up 18% from those lows....was this is a classic 'buy the rumor/sell the fact' reaction? I mean it seems that Twitter always misses on user growth, so what's the big deal?

Now Apple  (AAPL) on the other hand - BEAT, BEAT, and slightly missed.... Beat on earnings, beat on revenue, but missed on IPhones sales targets - ..expectation was that they would sell 48.5 million units and they ONLY sold 48.05 mil units - Can you believe that? They ONLY sold 48.05 mil units! But even that still represents a 22% y/y increase in growth!.... So? What's the fuss? Now analysts pay very close attn to the 'units sold' to see if Apple can continue to grow this number - but the concern is - Will Apple become a victim of its own success?

The stock traded up $3 in afterhours trading or 2%. and is currently trading at $116.56 in the early morning session..... Now look - They have taken the stock up 12% from the Oct lows of $107.31.....Last week when the chatter started about a possible miss - they gave back 3.5% and churned there until today.....So - net net - the stock is still up 8% for the month....Now that is all well and good if you bought the stock on Oct 2.. but if you bought it on the 23rd...then yeah....You are NOT really happy.....But hey - trading is not for the faint of heart....

Yesterday - for the most part traders continued to avoid making any big commitments ahead of today's FOMC (Federal Open Market Committee) monetary policy announcement.....Yesterday's action was a 'repeat' of the muted action on Monday as traders and investors really just sat on the sidelines...waiting and waiting..

Now the broader mkt essentially traded flat, but the transportation index (otherwise known as the 'Trannies') got hammered. (The Dow Transport Index is an index of 20 US transportation stocks....Airlines, truckers, rails etc... all stocks that are directly connected to the transportation of goods) Now why would this be so? A couple of reasons that all suggest a building global slowdown......

1. Yesterday's eco data - Durable Goods report - was not encouraging at all - it showed a continuing decline in durable goods orders for another month. Durable goods orders slid by 1.2% in September following a revised 3.0% decline in August. If we take out transportation equipment - durable goods orders still fell by 0.4% in September after declining by 0.9% in August. (Durable Goods are those goods that are not quickly consumed or replaced often - so think of appliances, cars, computers, home or office furnishings etc...)

2. Consumer confidence showed a sharp retreat in September 3. Continued oil weakness So taken together - these data points indicate that a slowdown and loss of confidence and means less goods will be shipped. And if companies are shipping less goods then it makes sense that the trannies get hammered. And they did...the index was off 2.6% or 218 pts. Small caps also took it on the chin...and why? Because if investors believe that a recession or slowdown is on the horizon - they would rather put their money in 'Value Stocks - defined as 'large, safer, dividend paying American Blue Chips vs. the risk of small cap 'growth stocks'. So today is FED day...as if you didn't know that.....and stocks will remain in this holding pattern until precisely 2 pm.....(or maybe 1:59:30 if you 'BUY' access to the headlines before they actually hit the tape....but that is another story for another day...).

The FED is not expected to change a thing.....rates will remain at zero....but do expect strategists and analysts to pull apart the statement 'word by word' looking for any clue as to FUTURE policy actions.....Really? Look - global stocks have been propelled higher because the ECB (European Central Bank) and the PBoC (Peoples Bank of China) launched additional stimulus - so now the only question is - Will Janet join in the party and serve up more Kool Aid? And if so - the stocks look relatively cheap in zero interest rate environment.....and cheap means a bargain and a bargain means that buyers will come in - at least for today.... Rue the day that all this free money just stops..... But let's not go there right now....

Overnight in Asia - mkts were mostly lower.....volumes were light as investors await the FED action.......continued weakness in commodities - oil, copper etc keeping the lid on...... Japan was the standout - rising by 0.68% as many await the BoJ (Bank of Japan) policy announcement next week. The expectation is that they will announce MORE KOOL AID for everyone! In Europe - mkts are all a bit higher....because they believe that the FED will do nothing and if so - then stocks will rally..... couple that with some good earnings and it's off to the races! FTSE +0.39%, CAC 40 +0.34%, DAX +0.64%, EUROSTOXX + 0.61%, SPAIN +0.32% and ITALY +0.88%. US futures are up 4 pts in early trading.... finding support yesterday at 2060 which is also the , now flattening out, 200 dma.......If we hold here then a surge up to 2100 is not out of the question at all.....if the mkt becomes disappointed with what they hear out of the FED then the a move back to the 2035 level would not be a surprise at all.....

The focus is not about today...but about the future moves that the FED will make and that will depend upon how they position today's policy statement.... In the end though, I do not expect rates to rise in 2015 at all. They have successfully kicked that can into the 1Q of 2016..... Earnings today include: Hershey (HSY), General Dynamics (GD), International Paper (IP), Occidental Petroleum (OXY), Valero Energy (VLO) , and the owner of the NYSE - Intercontinental Exchange (ICE). Take Good Care KP

So there were a number of surprises last week......First the ECB leaves rates alone but hints at more stimulus coming in December. Then overnight on Thurs/Friday - China announces further loosening in monetary policy in another bid to boost a slowing economy. And then after the bell on Thursday the 3 big tech stalwarts surprised the markets with much better…

Sophia Loren, Michelangelo, Benvenuto Cellini, Leonardo da Vinci, Guglielmo Marconi, Fibonacci (Leonardo Bonacci), Federico Fellini, Luciano Pavarotti - There is just a handful of famous Italians that have contributed immensely to Italian and world history ......and today - one of the most famous (and sexually charged) Italians comes to the NYSE......Today - we welcome Ferrari - ticker symbol RACE to the NYSE family of companies.

Ferrari - is an Italian luxury sports car manufacturer - founded by Enzo Ferrari in 1929....originally to build race cars...in 1947 - Ferrari moved into the production of 'street legal' luxury cars. In 1969 FIAT acquired 50% of the company and in 1988 took control of 40% more taking their total stake to 90%.
In 2014 Fiat Chrysler announced that it would sell 10% of the company to the public and today is the day.....expect the 'street' to be awash in testosterone as the excitement builds....

Broad Street - now known as 'experience square' has a dozen Ferrari's on display - 'only to look at - no touching allowed' ...which will only serve to drive the men into a frenzy..... The IPO was priced last night at $52/share - at the high end of the range - and was 'way oversubscribed' .....so instead of raising the IPO price to cool demand - they decided to remain within the range to create the 'desire' in the aftermarket......You can feel the excitement building, the tingle in your spine, the rapid breathing, the toe curling excitement and the rush of blood as the heart beats faster and faster exploding with fury as the opening bell rings.....( What a great way to start the day - I 'm exhausted already...)

Stocks chopped yesterday - as healthcare stocks got whacked over more political wrangling and investors/traders grew concerned about IBM (IBM) earnings and mounting concerns over Marissa Meyers options at Yahoo (YHOO) .......... The choppy trading on Wall Street suggests that traders are uncertain about the near-term direction of equities following the recent volatility and continuing disappointments in earnings reports and forward guidance.
IBM shares dropped 5.75% (or $8.50) after the company reported lower quarterly revenue for the 14th straight quarter - they also lowered guidance for the fiscal year.

So - investors and traders reacted to how far off the mark IBM's stock price was from fundamentals. The stronger dollar in this case - did hurt. The stock has been in a downtrend since July as investors began to re-price the company based on $ concerns..........breaking every support level it had only to find support at the $140 level in late August....churning and building a new base...............It was only in the last month that investors/traders thought that maybe the market had adjusted for it and punished it enough causing some to go on a bargain hunting spree. Well - that didn't work out too well...yesterday's news sent the stock right back down to those lows.....the question now is: Will it find support in here at $140/share?

YHOO - also disappointed - and warned about what the future holds - putting Mayer's turnaround plan in jeopardy.....causing her to announce a new plan - a resetting of sorts after two top executive 'flew the coop'.....saying that the changes are 'the result of careful planning' - one should ask - who's planning was it?

More broadly - 70% of companies so far have beat on the bottom line while only 40% of companies have beat on the top revenue line...this is becoming more of a problem, causing a disconnect between fundamentals and stock prices.....despite all of the rhetoric from Washington that the economy is doing just fine......

When the recession of 2008 hit and continued to hammer earnings, stock prices eventually fell hard. Are we gearing up for another fall? Technically, we are still struggling, bulls and bears are locked in a battle.....All of the major indexes are still in a downtrend....their 50 dma's are trending below their 200 dma's and all have found resistance as they have recently approached this longer-term technical indicator. So we remain locked in a tight range.

Next up - Oil and energy stocks.....what will they say about the current state of the economy? My sense is that stocks will stay in a sideways channel (1985/2050) as long as oil prices remain in the $43 to $50 range. If oil breaks $43 then look for stocks to come under renewed pressure breaking below 1985...and if for some reason - oil pierces $50 (unlikely in the short term) then we will see renewed excitement for stocks....taking us to the longer-term resistance at 2060. Now overnight oil fell 2% and is now trading at $45.75/barrel.....which will only cause some to remain laser-focused on today's EIA report. (Energy Information Admin).

Look for reports from BA, KO, ABT, BHI, BIOGEN, NT, GM, EMC, STJ and ITW today - as well as one FED Governor - Jerome Powell who will be speaking at 1:30 pm. - Will he give us a clue about what rates will do in October? My money says - no rate hike..... .
Take good care.
Kp

42-year low for jobless claims There were 255,000 initial jobless claims in the July 18 week, the lowest since Nov. '73, and the 4-week moving average fell by 4,000 to 278,500. Continuing claims edged down by 9,000 to 2.207 mil. Some analysts believe automaker factory retooling may cause fluctuations in the claims data around this time of year.  The…

Builders get brighter The Nat'l Assn. of Home Builders' July index rose 1 point to 60, rather than staying flat as expected. That's the highest reading since Nov '05. The current conditions gauge rose 1 point to 66, but the expectations component jumped 2 to a strong 71. The traffic index dropped 1 point, though. Philly Fed factory index falls…

"The mountain is high, the valley is low, and you're confused on which way to go, So I've come here to give you a hand, and lead you into the promised land....So come on and take a free ride, come on and sit by my side...." - Free ride - Edgar Winter Band - 1972

This should have been the opening remark from Janet Yellen yesterday during her Congressional Humphrey Hawkins testimony....The song is right - it has been a bit confusing of late - BUT Yellen - as you might expect remains upbeat about the U.S. economy, citing an increase in consumer spending (forget the fact that retail sales declined by 0.3% in Tuesday's report) along with the improving employment picture (where exactly that is - is another question) as she prepares investors for the coming increase in rates.......

What I thought was interesting is the fact that she thinks that the chaos in Europe and China 'isn't threatening the U.S. economy enough' to cause her to veer off course. As expected - she did not get pinned down - she did though try to make clear that her preference is to move rates up sooner and slower rather than later and faster....I think most investors/analysts and strategists would agree with that strategy...and so the market did not panic.....Look - the Fed and every other central bank around the world will continue to do their part to stimulate and support global markets...(since elected officials are clearly impotent and are unable to perform as expected) .......so sit back and relax....no worries....the song says - ' I've come to give you a hand and lead you to the promised land' doesn't it?

Across the pond - a couple of things happened - just in case you missed it.....Greeks voted to accept the latest (and worst) bailout plan - but not without any drama.....late yesterday - images appeared of Athens under fire....Molotov cocktails being tossed about, police using tear gas to disperse the crowds, inside the parliament building - the room erupted into chaos - Greek ministers up in arms with Alexis - as the sense is he sold his country out....yet in the end - the measures did pass (was there really a choice?). If nothing else - the deal does provide some respite and will allow that country to return to some sense of normalcy. For the markets - yesterday's vote did represent a major hurdle and now that it is over investors can move forward and look ahead - this morning it is clear that the 'Risk On' mentality is alive and well as Global markets are all in relief rally mode.

Now do not discount the good earnings that we have seen so far......the Banks here in the U.S. have not disappointed (good) add in Netflix (NFLX), Intel (INTC) and UnitedHealth (UNH) and the tone of earnings feels decidedly positive.....Yes - I understand that we are only 4 days into it - but considering what analysts had prepared the street for - it is a welcomed relief that initial reports are 'better than expected'.

Economic data at home today includes Initial Jobless claims of 285k, Continuing Claims of 2.3 mil - both would be an improvement over last week, Philly Fed Survey - expectation is 12.0. In Europe - we are awaiting the ECB rate decision - expectation is for NO change - rates to remain low.....but the real focus will be if the ECB ups the ante for Greek assistance.

Since Yellen's second day of testimony is to yield no surprises - the only thing we will be waiting for is the Q&A from the Senators - let's hope that we do not see the stupidity displayed by congressman Sean Duffy (R-Wis.) yesterday - as he attacked Ms. Yellen during her testimony over documents related to a possible Fed leak in October of 2012 - when Uncle Benny was in charge...

European markets are all up - FTSE +0.43% , CAC 40 + 1.39%, DAX + 1.50%, EUROSTOXX +1.38%, SPAIN +1.32% and ITALY +1.28%.... and here, too, the focus will now turn to earnings - which are also coming in better than expected - Banks and retailers showing early strength.......Greece will now be returned to the back burner until the next crisis......

Technically - we are above all of the moving averages....and they all now represent support...... U.S. futures are up 8 points in early trade looking to test the recent highs at 2125ish.....earnings today include Charles Schwab (SCHW), Ebay (EBAY), PPG (beat), Philip Morris (PM) (beat) , Goldman Sachs (GS), and Citigroup (C) to name just a few.....The tone is decidedly bullish - a complete change from last week as investors celebrate the good news.
Take good care -
Kp

Industrial production rises Production increased by 0.3% in June, beating expectations of a 0.2% gain and rebounding from a 0.2% decline in May. Capacity utilization, which measures the amount of slack in firms' use of capital, rose 2 ticks to 78.4%. Manufacturing was flat on the month, just missing forecasts for a 0.1% gain, but a 0.2% decline in May…

"Mama said there'll be days like this - there'll be days like this my mama said…. I went walking the other day and everything was fine then I met a boy named Billy Joe and then I almost lost my mind - oh Mama said there'll be days like this, there'll be days like this my mama said..." - the…
Retail sales slump

Sales declined 0.3% in June, badly missing expectations for a gain of that amount. A 1.2% increase in May was revised down to 1%. Excluding autos, June sales fell 0.1%; excluding autos and gas, the decline was 0.2%. Experts have long expected to see consumers upping spending as the job market firms and gas prices stay low, but sales have been tepid at best.

 Small business sentiment cratered in June, the Nat'l Federation of Independent Business said. Its monthly survey fell 4.2 points to 94.1, the lowest in over a year. Owners are less inclined to hire, invest in capex or expand, they told NFIB.
Import, export prices slide

Import prices were down 0.1% in June vs. expectations for a 0.1% gain. Export prices declined 0.2% vs. forecasts for a gain of 0.1%. June's dips followed a May in which prices surged 0.6% for exports and 1.2% for imports. For the year, export prices stand 5.7% lower while those for imports are 10% lower.
 There were 41,000 completed foreclosures in May, CoreLogic said, up 4.1% for the month but 19.2% lower than year-ago levels.
 Business inventories rose 0.3% in May, a tick less than in April but more than the 0.2% gain expected. The inventory-sales ratio was unchanged at 1.36.
After Greek deal euphoria, a letdown

A confidential IMF study says Greece will need debt write-downs well beyond what eurozone officials have agreed to consider, Reuters reported. European leaders received the report just hours after hashing out a deal with Greek PM Alexis Tsipras. As eurozone — and Greek — legislatures prepared to pass the deal, German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble said members of his gov't would have preferred the temporary Grexit scenario he proposed.

 Canadian home price gains leapt to a record high in June, according to the Teranet-National Bank Composite index. Prices were up 1.4% for the month and 5.1% for the year, faster than the yearly gain in May. Vancouver homes surged 8.5% and Toronto prices were up 7.8%. The head of Canada's largest real estate services firm warned the central bank against a further rate cut, saying no more monetary stimulus was needed.
Eurozone industrial production teeters

Output was down 0.4% in May, below analysts' expectations of a 0.2% gain. A 0.1% uptick in April was revised down to unchanged. The yearly gain, 1.6%, also missed forecasts. Most of the weakness was centered in energy, which slid 3.2%.
 German consumer prices dipped 0.1% in June, as expected and the same as in May. For the year, prices were up 0.3%, also as expected and matching May.
German investor sentiment jumps

ZEW's July survey rose 1 point to 63.9, the first monthly increase since April. That beat expectations for a decline to 59.4. The expectations gauge fell to 29.7 from 31.5, but that was stronger than forecast. ZEW says investors are relatively upbeat about the economy.
 U.K. consumer prices were unchanged in June and vs. a year ago.
 More eurozone banks — a net 13% — saw demand for corporate loans rise in Q2, up from 1% in Q1. A net 49% saw increased demand for mortgages, up from 30% in Q1.
COMING UP WEDNESDAY
 Producer price index for June, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: 0.3%, ex food and energy 0.1%).
 Industrial production for June, 9:15 a.m. ET (forecast: 0.2%, manufacturing 0.1%).

CFOs downbeat Deloitte's Q2 CFO Signal survey found earnings expectations down to 6.5% from 10.6% in Q1, with revenue growth expectations at 3.1%, the lowest in the survey's 5-year history. Net optimism fell to the lowest in nearly 2 years, although CFOs expect strong growth in the economy in North America. Equipment investment seen growing Investing in equipment and software…

Tehran and the West could reach a historic agreement soon over Iran's nuclear program, opening the country up to U.S. companies for the first time in decades, but renewed commercial ties could be a mixed blessing for some American firms. U.S. businesses have been unable to do business with Iran since the Islamic Revolution in 1979, except for medical and…
Like they say at the Opera - "It ain't over till the fat lady sings" Well - can you hear her singing? Greece and the EU strike an 11th hour deal! The Opera is over….or is it?
(Who is kidding who? It's never over.)
This morning global investors are waking up to the headlines:
"Tsipras Capitulates to Creditor's Demands to Keep Greece in the Euro"
"Greece and Eurozone Thrash out Rescue Deal"
"Agreekment! Overnight Talks Result in Aid-for-Reform Deal"

This is like a sequel to the 1994 comedy - "Dumb and Dumber" Only this one stars Alexis Tsipras and the whole Greek Parliament...I mean have you ever seen anything so breathtakingly stupid? Alexis Tsipras was elected on the platform of "Screw the European Union" - Remember - he was the one that claimed that he would not accept one more ounce of austerity, or cuts, or tax increases (not that anyone in Greece pays taxes - so what difference does that make?)

Following months of ranting and raving against Germany and the Troika (IMF, ECB and EU) - He rejected plan after plan then forced a referendum vote in his country, campaigned for his citizens to vote 'NO' - and when they 'overwhelmingly agreed' that last week's deal was a bad one - he then sold them down the river! He made such a dramatic reversal that it's almost laughable.....and to make it more ridiculous - the latest 'final offer' is far worse than ones he had turned down! We now have a new word that is sure to light up the Twitter sphere - "Gridiot".
Paul Krugman - an American Economist and Professor of Economic and Int'l Affairs at Princeton University - summed it up this way:

"This goes beyond harsh into pure vindictiveness, complete destruction of national sovereignty, and no hope of relief. It is, presumably, meant to be an offer Greece can't accept; but even so, it's a grotesque betrayal of everything the European project was supposed to stand for."

Global markets, now all relieved (at least for today), have moved into positive territory. Beginning in Asia - markets there sensing relief on the Greek front caused investors and traders to review recent market action. Add in some positive economic data across the region and it was Risk On. China - which has been the focus of late - reported trade figures showing that exports rose 2.8%, substantially beating the expectation of +0.2%.....on a side note - Gov't officials tried to temper the mood saying that 'exports are likely to face relatively big pressure in the coming months'. (Because - How long can they keep up this façade?)

China ended the day up 2.4% extending Friday's gain of better than 6%. Clearly the market has been boosted by the recent 'reforms' instituted by Beijing….Brokerages were told in 'no uncertain terms' on Sunday to use real names and national identification numbers on all trades - Imagine that - no more imaginary brokerage accounts! Who would have thought of using real names? Over the weekend - Xinhua - the state owned news outlet - reported that some brokerage houses were 'suspected of manipulating futures prices and other malicious practices. Like I said last week - China is not a free market and while the measures recently imposed have caused the markets to rally - what happens once they are removed? Are foreign investors really feeling any better? Not so much….

In Japan - money poured into the Yen - as the safe haven trade. Equities also moved higher as investors got the 'all clear' sign on a Greek deal while the GPIF (Gov't Pension Investment Fund) released performance figures showing a 12% return in the 12 months ended March 31st. Shoji Hirakawa, Chief equity strategist at Oksan Securities, did say that the fund looks like they still have another 4 or 5 trillion Yen left to put to work in the Japanese stock market - Ah…Hello??? 5 Trillion more Yen going into stocks....Anyone want to stand in front of that train?

In Europe this morning - as you can imagine - markets there are on a tear….FTSE + 0.61%, CAC 40 + 1.78%, DAX +1.32%, EUROSTOXX +1.64%, SPAIN +1.25% and ITALY +1.26%. Good for today - but if Tsipras can't deliver - then expect it to all fall apart mid-week. Even if he does deliver - and that is a big "IF" - will he be able to hold onto his position as PM? Relief- sure.....Greece now has 72 hours to vote in the reforms. There is already trouble brewing in Parliament - you can imagine the rage among those that supported Tsipras in his efforts and now feel like he turned his back on them.

German Chancellor Merkel had this to say: "Trust has to be rebuilt, the Greek authorities have to take on responsibility for what they agreed to, It now hinges on step-by-step implementation of what we agreed."
And that agreement is for more spending cuts, pension cuts, and tax increases - everything that the country voted against.....Are you beginning to see the Dumb and Dumber reference?

U.S. futures are soaring - currently up 14 points - at this rate we will be banging our heads on S&P 500 2100 before lunch. There are no economic reports for today but later in the week we get a slew of data points - Retail Sales, PPI, Empire State Manufacturing, Industrial Prod, and Capacity Utilization......

We are now well into earnings season...Tomorrow starts the beauty pageant....JPMorgan (JPM), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Wells Fargo (WFC) - later in the week - we get US Bancorp (USB), Bank of America (BAC), CSX (CSX), Yum Brands (YUM) to name just a few.....The focus now will turn to the earnings and future guidance.....The Greek-think is a bit exhausting....but will remain simmering on the back burner.

Look for the S&P 500 to test both the 100 and 50 DMA's (2095 & 2099). Those will be tough resistance points for the market to breach....that is where the economic data and earnings will play their part....Investors want to know if we are finally really making headway - Any perceived failure will cause markets to find support once again at 2056....

This week also features an annual event - Semicon West (July 14-15th) - a 'must see' event - a two-day innovation conference at the Moscone Center in San Francisco - featuring startups/investor and research forums.... Look for presentations from some of the big boys - IntelINTC, OracleORCL, IBMIBM, Texas InstrumentsTXN, San DiskSNDK along with some new and exciting startups - The market is sure to be getting all kinds of positive data and presentations coming out of this conference so expect positive market action in the publicly-traded names.
Take Good Care
KP

Japan and the Asian Development Bank plan to boost funding for what they term high-quality infrastructure projects in Asia to about $110 billion over the next five years.

Prime Minister Shinzo Abe outlined some of Japan's latest funding plans during a speech in Tokyo on Thursday night, while in Singapore representatives of 57 nations met to thrash out details of how the new China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank will operate.

Japan and the U.S. haven't said they will join the new $100-billion lender being established by China, which will boost Beijing's presence in the region's infrastructure business. Japan has expressed concern about governance standards at the AIIB and says the funding described by Abe will be for durable, environmentally friendly projects.

"Japan will, in collaboration with the ADB, provide Asia with innovative infrastructure financing," Abe said. "We should call for even more diverse capital to enter Asia from around the world, changing this place of Asia into land where dynamic innovation comes into full bloom."

About half of the funding in the five-year plan described by Abe will come from the Japan International Cooperation Agency and the Japan Bank for International Cooperation, and the remainder from the Japan-led Asian Development Bank, according to the finance ministry.

The ADB earlier this month said it would boost its total annual lending and grant approvals by 50% to as much as $20 billion. While China is a member of the ADB, Japan and the U.S. are the biggest shareholders and the institution's chief is Japanese.
AIIB Influence

"Japan must have been provoked by the establishment of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank by China," said Naoto Saito, an economist at Daiwa Institute of Research. "Japan's investment will help promote infrastructure projects in Asia, expanding business opportunities for Japanese companies."

Japan will have JBIC provide more funds to infrastructure projects in Asia via public-private partnerships in a bid to introduce more efficient management methods, according to the finance ministry. Japan will also promote private sector investment in infrastructure projects through yen-dominated loans to governments that plan public-private partnerships.

Annual funding by Japan and the ADB for high-quality infrastructure projects currently totals about $17 billion, according to the finance ministry. The increase over the next five years will be by about 25%.Japan and the Asian Development Bank plan to boost funding for what they term high-quality infrastructure projects in Asia to about $110 billion over the next five years.Prime Minister Shinzo Abe outlined some of Japan's latest funding plans during a speech in Tokyo on Thursday night, while in Singapore representatives of 57 nations met to thrash out details of how the new China-led Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank will operate.Japan and the U.S. haven't said they will join the new $100-billion lender being established by China, which will boost Beijing's presence in the region's infrastructure business. Not so much....The right decision - 1000%. U.S. markets today are…

That was up from a slightly downwardly revised 5.33 mil in April that had held the record. It's also 16% higher than a year ago. Hires eased slightly, to 5 mil from 5.03 mil, as…

"What have I got to do to make you love me, What have I got to do to make you care, What do I do when lightning strikes me, And I wake to find that you're not there? What have I got to do to make you want me, What have I got to do to be heard, What do I say when it's all over? And sorry seems to be the hardest word. It's sad (so sad), It's a sad, sad situation, And it's getting more and more absurd……. Why can't we talk it over? Sorry seems to be the hardest word….. " Elton John - 1976 - "Sorry Seems to be the Hardest Word"

SORRY was the word or choice yesterday...as the Greeks voted NO to the creditor demands...so - Sorry ECB, IMF and EU! 'We've had enough and we are not going to take it anymore" as the Greeks went to the polls to vote on the referendum….when the dust settled 61% of the voters spoke their mind- handing Tsipras a resounding NO vote causing massive celebrations around Athens and other Greek cities......celebrations that are sure to end in one hell of a hangover......

As you know by now - the NO vote means that they support Tsipras' stand - NO MORE AUSTERITY, NO MORE SUFFERING, NO MORE BEING LED AROUND BY THE NOSE FROM THE European Union….or at least that is what the Greeks think it means… We are about to find out what the rest of the European Union thinks it means.....

Tsipras is now convinced that the NO vote has given him new power, new strength in negotiating terms of a new deal with the creditors…… A deal that he and Yanis (Varoufakis - the now FORMER Greek Finance Minister) think will come together in 24 hours……Really? - Well - we are already 12 hours into the NO vote and does anyone see anything even close to a deal? They couldn't agree on whether or not the sky was blue for the past 6 months - and now they will have a deal in 24 hours? Seems very unlikely….

This morning we find out that Alexis Tsipras asked for and got a formal resignation from his 'game theory*' finance minister - Yanis Varoufakis....Confrontational right to the end - Varoufakis said that the PM 'had judged it helpful if he was absent from future talks with international creditors' causing Yanis to say that he would 'wear their loathing with pride'

(*Game Theory is the study of 'strategic decision making' - it essentially studies the mathematical odds of conflict or cooperation between - and this is the key - Intelligent rational decision makers. Game theory is used across a range of disciplines including economics, politics, computer programming & science. To be fully defined, a game must specify the following elements: the players of the game, the information and actions available to each player at each decision point, and the payoffs, for each outcome. A game theorist typically uses these elements, along with a solution concept of their choosing, to deduce a set of equilibrium strategies for each player such that, when these strategies are employed, no player can profit by unilaterally deviating from their strategy. These equilibrium strategies determine an equilibrium to the game-a stable state in which either one outcome occurs or a set of outcomes occur with known probability - Wikipedia.)

The ball is now in Angela's court - she is on her way to Paris to meet with President Francois Hollande at 6:30 pm local time (12:30 pm ET) to discuss the next steps - both have agreed to respect the will of the people - that being said - it does NOT mean that Germany and France will just roll over and play dead......What would 'game theory' tell her to do? Word has it that they are waiting on Greece's next move....The European leaders as a group are not expected to meet until Tuesday - clearly that takes us beyond the 24 hour period that Tsipras and Varoufakis suggested it would take to come to a deal......as they wait for Tsipras to offer up a proposal that will suddenly change everyone's mind - allowing Greece to stay within the euro currency bloc.....

As the situation remains very fluid - the markets await word of a conference call between European Commission Pres - Jean-Claude Junker, European Central Bank President Draghi and Eurogroup Area Finance Chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem as they mull over what to do about the Greek banks that are dependent on the emergency lifeline extended by the ECB.....As of now - Greek banks and the Greek stock market - remain closed.....unlikely to open anytime in the foreseeable future....ATMs now only giving out 20 Euros at a time as the Greek Central bank tries to stop the bleed.

Last night - Global markets came under pressure…..Asia the first to react - saw markets there down 1% - 1.5% in early morning trading only to weaken as the day moved on. But many analysts/strategists think it is an early overreaction and will be short lived. China - having problems of its own managed to buck the trend and close a bit higher......Now look - China has sold off 26% from this year's highs - but PUT IT IN PERSPECTIVE....the Chinese market was up 60% year to date and was up 150% in the last 12 months.....Does anyone think just maybe that market center got a bit ahead of itself? A 26% pullback was probably way overdue.....remember - with risk comes reward - but with risk also come RISK.......and a developing market like China that rallies 60% in 6 months should have caused some concern for investors - what goes up (in a straight line) must eventually re-group - China is re-grouping. Japan -2.08%, Hong Kong -3.1%, China +2.4% and ASX -1.14%.

European futures initially pointed down 4+% for nations across the continent.....that proved to be a bit drastic... Germany (DAX) - the country with the most to lose - opened down 2% and has since stabilized and is trading down 1.3% at 7 am......France (CAC 40) -1.5%, EUROSTOXX -1.7%, SPAIN -1.8% and ITALY is down 2.65% - now this makes some sense - considering the chatter is that the Italians are watching very closely to see how this situation unfolds....a sweetheart deal for Greece could ignite a revolt across the Italian countryside - something I do NOT subscribe to at all. In the UK - the FTSE is off 0.59% as that country takes it all in stride and is under pressure only because the tone is negative. Overall - the reaction feels a bit muted considering what the expectation was....but remember - this drama IS still developing.....it could all turn on a 'drachma'......

Now S&P 500 futures opened down 40 handles (last night at 6 pm) and then traded a bit lower - touching 2038 in the moments right after - I would credit this to less liquidity in the overnight session and an algorithmic 'over reaction' to the news.....Look - they pushed them lower trying to force the weak links out of the branches.....they lit the Twittersphere up with talk of Armageddon etc.....that has NOT happened and U.S. futures have recovered - currently down 12 points - and are now hovering right at the 200 day moving average (2055 representing long term support). Central bankers from around the world pledging to keep the calm, no reason for panic…….but expect - at least for today - that global investors will pay for the Greek decision as the markets re-price risk......My sense is that we hold here and await more news.....a significant breach will cause the sell algos to kick into high gear - if that happens - expect the buyers to retreat and bid lower as they test the anxiety level of the sellers.... I do not see any reason (yet) for any buyer to be aggressive - so I do not expect any significant rally at all. We remain in the 2050/2090 range. Much closer to our ytd highs than not....capisce?

Last week - I pointed out that back in October when we breached that key support (200 dma) the market fell 4.5% very quickly taking us to 1820 on the S&P (which was also a 10% move off the highs)......If we follow that same pattern a real breach of the 200 dma could take us to 1975 ish....equal to the lows of December.... Right now that does not feel like it is the case - but the day is young.....This too shall pass......
Take good care.
Kp

Much closer to our ytd highs than not....capisce?Last week - I pointed out that back in October when we breached that key support (200 dma) the market fell 4.5% very quickly taking us to 1820 on the S&P (which was also a 10% move off the highs)......If we follow that same pattern a real breach of the 200 dma could take us to 1975 ish....equal to the lows of December.... Right now that does not feel like it is the case - but the day is young.....This too shall pass......Take good care.KpKenny Polcari is Vice President and director of NYSE Floor Operations on behalf of O'Neil Securities, Inc., a sister company of Investor's Business Daily. Manufacturing strengthensISM's closely watched factory PMI was stronger than expected in June, at 53.5. That was up 0.7 point from May and the strongest since Jan. Employment surged to 55.5, up nearly 4 points, and new orders were a robust 56.0. But export orders dipped below the neutral 50 line as the dollar continues to weigh.Private payrolls jumpPrivate employers added 237,000 jobs in June, processor ADP said, up sharply from its 203,000 reading in May and also beating estimates. ADP has a mixed record of predicting the government's employment report that follows: Labor said employers added 280,000 jobs in May. Markit's manufacturing PMI dipped to 53.6 in June from 54.0 in May, the lowest since Oct. '13. The dollar continued to weigh as new export orders dropped for the third straight month, the longest such stretch since '12. Construction spending rose 0.8% in May, stronger than the 0.5% expected, though down from a 2.1% monthly gain in April.Planned job cuts surgeEmployers announced 44,842 cuts in June, said Challenger, Gray and Christmas, up 9.3% vs. May and capping the highest midyear total in 5 years. The 287,762 cuts in '15 are up 17% from '14. But many of the cuts were due to weakness in the oil patch, which is likely in the rearview mirror. Mortgage applications fell 4.7% in the Mortgage Bankers Assn.'s June 26 index. Purchases were down 4% and refinancings sank 5% as the average interest rate rose 5 bps. A jobs index from Gallup rose in June to the highest since '12. The Payroll to Population survey touched 45.5, up a full point, the strongest monthly gain in a year.Did Greece blink?PM Alexis Tsipras sent a letter to international creditors agreeing to accept most of the demands in the last offer they had drafted. But his counterproposal differed enough that creditors — and markets — remained skeptical. All eyes are on the ECB, which must decide whether to keep extending emergency liquidity to Greek banks, which are closed all week, following a skipped payment to the IMF Tues. The June eurozone factory PMI was unchanged at 52.5 in June, 0.3 point above May, Markit said. France's PMI was upped to 50.7 in the final read from 50.5, while Germany's reading was unchanged at 51.9, nearly a point above May.Japan spending, confidence roar backThe Q2 Tankan survey found big companies plan to up capex by 9.3% in fiscal '16, the strongest pace in a decade. The sentiment index swelled to 15 from 12, which had been the consensus forecast. That was the first increase in nearly a year. Markit's manufacturing PMI for Japan sank to just above the neutral 50 line in June. At 50.1, it was down nearly a point vs. May. New orders contracted, but new export orders picked up.
Pending home sales at 9-year high

Contract signings rose 0.9% in May, the Nat'l Assn. of Realtors said, taking its index to 112.6, the highest since April '06. The index is 10.4% above year-ago levels and has notched yearly rises for 9 straight months. Still, NAR is worried that tight inventory is pressuring prices too high.
Texas manufacturing slide eases

The Dallas Fed's manufacturing index moderated in June, rising to -6.5 from -13.5 in May. New orders were also better, at -10.3 vs. -14.1., as were shipments. The employment index moderated to -1.2 from -8.2, and the wages and benefits index rose to 16.4 from 14.7. Future business condition expectations improved.
From greferendum to bank runs

Greek PM Alexis Tsipras shocked creditors, financial markets and some members of his own government late Fri. when he announced a referendum would be held to vote on a final offer from creditors that was to have been discussed Sat. But the vote, which might as well be called greferendum, would take place July 5, several days after the current bailout program expires, making a default to the IMF likely. What's more, creditors say that offer might not stand in a week. Athens closed banks and the stock market, and imposed controls on ATM withdrawals.

 Voting no in the referendum will mean voting to secede from Europe, European Commission head Jean-Claude Juncker told the Greek people. "You should say yes regardless of what the question is," he added.

 The Swiss National Bank sold Swiss francs as the Greek crisis sparked demand for the franc, considered a safe haven. It was the first time since Jan., when the central bank abandoned a cap linked to the euro, that a policymaker had admitted to intervening.
 Eurozone economic sentiment dipped in May, the European Commission's survey found. It fell 0.3 point to 103.5, while the European Union saw a decline of 0.9 point to 105.5.
German CPI weakens

Consumer prices dipped 0.1% in May vs. a 0.1% gain in April, which economists had expected to be repeated. The yearly rise eased to 0.3% from 0.7%, the first time it's moved backward since Jan. The eurozone as a whole releases inflation data Tues.
PBOC cuts rates

China's central bank slashed interest rates 25 bps over the weekend in response to a plunge in the equity market. It was the fourth rate cut since Nov. Two rates were effected, the first time China has taken such a step since the financial crisis in '08.
COMING UP TUESDAY
 S&P/Case-Shiller home price index for April, 9 a.m. ET (forecast: monthly 0.8%, yearly 5.4%).
 Conference Board consumer confidence for June, 10 a.m. ET (forecast: 97.4).

Consumer confidence at 5-month high The Univ. of Michigan's June read popped to 96.1 from its midmonth 94.6 read, which analysts had expected for the final reading. That's up 6% from May and 16.5% from a year ago. The gauge of current conditions rose 8.0% in June, while the expectations index was up 4.3%. Greece creditors sweeten pot Creditors offered…
Incomes, spending power up

Personal incomes advanced 0.5% in May, the same as an upwardly revised gain in April, and beating expectations of a 0.4% rise. Consumer spending leapt 0.9%, the biggest gain in more than 5 years and also better than expected. The core measure of inflation favored by the Fed was up 1.2% vs. a year ago. Consumer spending was led by auto sales — fueled by low gas prices vs. a year earlier — and gasoline, reflecting higher gas prices vs. April.
Jobless claims stay low
Initial claims edged up by 3,000 to 271,000 in the June 20 week, while the 4-week moving average ticked down 3,250 to 273,750. Continuing claims rose to 2.24 mil from 2.22 mil.
Service sector stumbles

Markit's flash service PMI dipped to 54.8 in June, from 56.2. That was the lowest since January and new business expanded at the weakest pace in 5 months, Markit said. The employment index fell 1.2 points.
 Consumer comfort rose last week by the most since April, according to Bloomberg's weekly gauge, which touched 42.6. The index had hit an 8-year high in April, then retreated.
Down to the wire on Greece

While Greece and its creditors kept talking Thursday, stark differences remained and there was confusion over which versions of proposals were being discussed. With almost no time left before a June 30 IMF payment is due, creditors reportedly presented PM Alexis Tsipras with an ultimatum.

 The German central bank's president criticized Greek banks' reliance on emergency funding from the ECB, saying "this casts doubt on their financial solidity." The flight of capital from the country was due to policy decisions by the Greek gov't, he added.
Canadian wages decelerate

Average weekly earnings rose 2.5% vs. a year ago in April, down from a 2.7% yearly gain in March. But employment surged by 16,400, up from a gain of 3,700 in March. The average workweek was 33.1 hours, up from 32.9 hours a year ago.

 U.K. retail sales growth edged down in June, the Confederation of British Industry said. Its sales index fell to 29 from a 5-month high of 51 in May, and remained elevated above normal levels for this time of year.

 Univ. of Michigan consumer sentiment for June, 10 a.m. ET (forecast: 94.6).

GDP revision shows slight dip The U.S. economy contracted at a 0.2% annual rate in Q1, according to the final revision on GDP. That was what analysts had forecast and shaved the steeper 0.7% decline from the 2nd estimate. Personal consumption was revised to show a 2.1% gain, vs. 1.8%, and fixed investment came in at -0.3%, vs. 1.3%. Exports…

First-time homebuyer traffic up First-time buyers made up 38.8% of purchases in May on a 3-month moving average, according to the Campbell/Inside Mortgage Finance HousingPulse survey. That's the highest in nearly 5 years. First-timers made up 35.9% of sales in May '14. Lower costs for FHA mortgages are helping boost sales, while many investors are ready to sell out. …

Jobless claims sink Claims declined 12,000 to a low 267,000 in the June 13 week, while the 4-week average fell 2,000 to 276,750. Continuing claims dipped by 50,000 to 2.22 mil. Consumer prices dip The CPI rose 0.4% in May, lower than the 0.5% gain expected, and was flat for the year. Excluding food and energy, the index rose 0.1%,…

So....what happened? Markets waited all day for the word from the Fed....at 2 pm - we found out what we already knew......rates to remain unchanged -( but would move higher at some point).........Yellen reiterates caution remains the word of the day....... "Economic conditions are currently anticipated to evolve in a manner that will warrant only gradual increases in the target…

Mixed news on housing constructionStarts sank 11.1% in May to an annualized rate of 1.036 mil, missing forecasts of a 1.09 mil rate but remaining 5.1% above the year-ago level. A pullback from a 22.1% leap in April had been expected. Permits rose 12%, though, signaling better start activity down the road, and prior months' start data were revised upward.…

Just when we thought it was 'safe to go in the water' - maybe you want to think again. Arrogance is rearing its ugly head as talks between Greece and her creditors fall apart…..Tsipras pushing the envelope right to the edge, seemingly unable to hear the demands of the very nations that are trying to help him...there is not more…
Retail sales jump

Sales rose 1.2% in May, a tick shy of expectations, though a flat read in April was revised up to show a 0.2% gain. Excluding autos, the increase was 1%; excluding autos and gas, 0.7%. Both ticks were stronger than expected. There was broad strength across categories, especially building materials and garden supply stores.
 Jobless claims ticked up in the latest week but held near lows. Initial claims rose by 2,000 to 279,000, and continuing claims rose 61,000 to 2.265 mil.
Import, export price declines ease

Export prices were up 0.6% in May, but 5.9% lower vs. a year ago. Analysts had expected a 0.1% monthly gain. Import prices, which rose 1.3%, were also stronger than consensus and declined 9.6% for the year. Both yearly changes were less severe than those in April.

 Consumer sentiment fell for a 9th straight week in Bloomberg's comfort index, a record. Respondents' views of the buying climate hit a low not seen since Nov. Even though the economy, job market and wage gains are picking up, so are gas prices.
This kiwi won't be flying soon

The Bank of New Zealand cut its key interest rate 25 bps unexpectedly for the first time in 4 years, to 3.25%, citing increasing risk of deflation and a strong currency. With hints that further easing may follow, that sent the kiwi lower.

 Greek PM Alexis Tsipras met with European Commission Pres. Jean-Claude Juncker, a man previously seen as his best ally, but whom Tsipras recently alienated. Other creditor representatives stepped up pressure on Greece to reach a deal as time grows short before it must repay the IMF.
China retail sales up

Sales rose 10.1% in May vs. a year ago, 1 tick below expectations, but 2 stronger than in April. The monthly gain was 0.81%, more than the 0.74% from March-April. That's below the '14 average of 12%, though.
China investment growth tanks

Growth in fixed-asset investment sank to a 15-year low of 11.4% for the first five months of '15 in May. As the housing market cools and a glut in manufacturing weighs on the economy, many analysts believe the gov't will have a hard time hitting its 7% GDP growth target.
 South Korea cut interest rates to a record low of 1.5% as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome spread to 122 people and is expected to take a toll on the economy.
COMING UP FRIDAY
 Producer price index for May, 8:30 a.m. ET (forecast: 0.4%, ex food and energy 0.1%).
 Univ. of Michigan consumer sentiment initial read for June, 10 a.m. ET (forecast: 91.2).

Stock futures pointed to a strong open Tuesday amid strength in most overseas markets. Nasdaq 100 futures rallied 17 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures climbed 6 points. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 64 points.
Stocks reversed higher Monday to solid gains, but volume was lower.
Equity markets overseas were mostly higher, with European bourses leading the charge. France's CAC-40 bolted 2.3% and Germany's DAX rallied 1.9%. Meanwhile, London's FTSE 100 gained 1.7%.
In Asia, Hong Kong's Hang Seng climbed about 1.2% and Japan's Nikkei gained 1.2%. But the Shanghai composite was fractionally lower.
After gaining 2.5% Monday on rising tensions from Friday's terrorist attacks in Paris, crude oil pulled back. December crude lost 60 cents to $41.14 a barrel.
On the economic front, consumer prices rose 0.2% in October. That was the the first gain in three months and matched views.
Data on industrial production and the NAHB housing market index will be out at 9:15 a.m. ET and 10 a.m. ET, respectively. Fed Governors Jerome Powell and Daniel Tarullo will be speaking later today.

In stocks, Home Depot (HD) rallied 3% in premarket trading in the stock market today after beating views. The home improvement retailer posted Q3 earnings of $1.35 a share on sales of $21.8 billion. Views were for EPS of $1.32 on revenue of $21.76 billion. It also pegged full-year earnings at $5.36 a share or a nickel above views.
Rival Lowe's (LOW) was also up 3% in premarket trading. It reports quarterly results Wednesday.

Wal-Mart (WMT) rose 2% in the premarket despite posting mixed quarterly results. The world's biggest retailer reported fiscal Q3 earnings of $1.03 a share. But excluding a gain from leases, earnings were 99 cents a share. Sales came in at $117.4 billion. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected EPS of 98 cents on revenue of $117.79 billion.

Fitbit (FIT) gained more than 2% in premarket activity after being upgraded to buy from neutral at Bank Of America/Merrill Lynch. Shares of the maker of fitness trackers bounced back Monday after hitting a record low Friday.

Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) plunged 15% in premarket trade following disappointing earnings for Q3 and a weak outlook. The retailer posted adjusted earnings of 45 cents a share on revenue of $1.64 billion. Views were for EPS of 47 cents on sales of $1.64 billion. The retailer guided Q4 earnings at $1.10 to $1.25 a share vs. views for $1.43. On Monday, shares fell to their lowest levels since January 2012.

Greek bailout talks remained at an impasse Tuesday as Athens gave a cursory set of proposals that creditors dismissed as a "rehash."

Frustration is running high among creditors who have bargained with PM Alexis Tsipras and his left-wing political party Syriza to little effect. Their recent offer to extend the current bailout program to March has gotten little traction.
Meanwhile, many analysts say the Tsipras government may soon fall, creating further political and economic turmoil.
Greek debt yields continued to climb. Stocks in Athens rose 0.6%, but pared earlier gains and are down 40% over the past year.

Even if Greece accepts a deal with a bailout extension, the past months can't be undone, said Jacob Kirkegaard of the Peterson Institute for International Economics: "Because Syriza is so incompetent, they have dragged out this agreement for so long that by now the economic damage to Greece is much larger than it needed to have been, and this is a deal that Tsipras probably could have gotten all the way back in February."
Self-Inflicted Wound

Greece tumbled back into a recession in Q1, as economic activity contracted and capital fled the country. It's likely the country now has a primary deficit, Kirkegaard said. That means even if Syriza achieves one of its key objectives, a lower deficit target that would ease measures it deems austere, it will be harder to meet. "He's politically painted himself completely into a corner," he said.
It's not even clear that the extension idea will be accepted.

After creditors met without Greek representatives last week, Tsipras addressed a restive parliament, denouncing what he called "illogical" proposals from creditors. His speech was angrily dismissed by European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, who until then had been seen as Greece's staunchest ally among the creditor group.
"There remains no sign that the Greeks are prepared to soften the tone from that taken by PM Tsipras in Friday's Greek parliamentary debate," Daiwa Europe strategists wrote in a research note.

The ball is in Tsipras' court, they noted, and some willingness to compromise could unlock fresh options for the county: "But what all these have in common is their reliance on a credible commitment from Greece to comply with, and complete, its program."
'Completely Isolated'
For Kirkegaard, the weekend's events marked a Rubicon for the search for common cause, a notion that was reinforced by comments from international leaders at the G-7 meetings.
"Greece is completely isolated internationally," he said. "It was very clear that Tsipras managed to infuriate his only remaining ally. The trust is gone."
Greece is running out of cash and its current bailout program ends this month.

Even if Tsipras could find a way to agree with creditors on either a bailout extension or another deal to unlock aid, getting Syriza to go along may be an uphill battle. On Tuesday he urged his divided party to rally behind his government.
Most analysts believe Greece faces a national referendum on the terms or even another election.
Both scenarios would be "tricky," Kirkegaard said, because while a referendum would likely pass, it could split Syriza and "lead to a collapse of the government."
It's also not clear who could challenge Syriza, he added.

In either scenario, there could be several chaotic weeks in which the government would have to implement capital controls. Whatever the eventual political solution, the blow to Greece's economy could equal as much as a 5% contraction, Kirkegaard asserted: "It's a very bad scenario. I think this weekend was really a very significant turn for the worse. It's an absolutely terrible tale of political incompetence."Greek bailout talks remained at an impasse Tuesday as Athens gave a cursory set of proposals that creditors dismissed as a "rehash."Frustration is running high among creditors who have bargained with PM Alexis Tsipras and his left-wing political party Syriza to little effect. Their recent offer to extend the current bailout program to March has gotten little traction.Meanwhile, many analysts say the Tsipras government may soon fall, creating further political and economic turmoil.Greek debt yields continued to climb. Stocks in Athens rose 0.6%, but pared earlier gains and are down 40% over the past year.Even if Greece accepts a deal with a bailout extension, the past months can't be undone, said Jacob Kirkegaard of the Peterson Institute for International Economics: "Because Syriza is so incompetent, they have dragged out this agreement for so long that by now the economic damage to Greece is much larger than it needed to have been, and this is a deal that Tsipras probably could have gotten all the way back in February."Self-Inflicted WoundGreece tumbled back into a recession in Q1, as economic activity contracted and capital fled the country. It's likely the country now has a primary deficit, Kirkegaard said. That means even if Syriza achieves one of its key objectives, a lower deficit target that would ease measures it deems austere, it will be harder to meet. "He's politically painted himself completely into a corner," he said.It's not even clear that the extension idea will be accepted.After creditors met without Greek representatives last week, Tsipras addressed a restive parliament, denouncing what he called "illogical" proposals from creditors. His speech was angrily dismissed by European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, who until then had been seen as Greece's staunchest ally among the creditor group."There remains no sign that the Greeks are prepared to soften the tone from that taken by PM Tsipras in Friday's Greek parliamentary debate," Daiwa Europe strategists wrote in a research note.The ball is in Tsipras' court, they noted, and some willingness to compromise could unlock fresh options for the county: "But what all these have in common is their reliance on a credible commitment from Greece to comply with, and complete, its program."'Completely Isolated'For Kirkegaard, the weekend's events marked a Rubicon for the search for common cause, a notion that was reinforced by comments from international leaders at the G-7 meetings."Greece is completely isolated internationally," he said. "It was very clear that Tsipras managed to infuriate his only remaining ally. The trust is gone."Greece is running out of cash and its current bailout program ends this month.Even if Tsipras could find a way to agree with creditors on either a bailout extension or another deal to unlock aid, getting Syriza to go along may be an uphill battle. On Tuesday he urged his divided party to rally behind his government.Most analysts believe Greece faces a national referendum on the terms or even another election.Both scenarios would be "tricky," Kirkegaard said, because while a referendum would likely pass, it could split Syriza and "lead to a collapse of the government."It's also not clear who could challenge Syriza, he added.In either scenario, there could be several chaotic weeks in which the government would have to implement capital controls. Whatever the eventual political solution, the blow to Greece's economy could equal as much as a 5% contraction, Kirkegaard asserted: "It's a very bad scenario. I think this weekend was really a very significant turn for the worse. It's an absolutely terrible tale of political incompetence."

Refinancing applications also jumped, by 7%, even as average rates rose 15 bps to 4.17%, the highest since Nov. Oil-related cuts totaled only about 1,000, Challenger said. Productivity sinks as…

What has really changed other than the month on the calendar? Stocks eked out a small gain after having tested both the support line at S&P 2100 and the resistance…
Reynolds American (RAI) reported view-topping first-quarter results Friday, but its stock action was muted as the tobacco company reaffirmed its full-year guidance.

Reynolds American's earnings increased 19.4% to 86 cents a share in Q1, beating a Thomson Reuters analyst poll by 6 cents. Revenue rose 6.3% to $2.057 billion, surpassing forecasts for $1.983 billion.

Up-and-down shares were up 0.2% at 74.35 by early afternoon, not a bad feat in light of investors pressuring down the major indexes by more than 1% in the stock market today. Reynolds American stock is working on a cup-shaped base with a 76.33 buy point.
The maker of Camel cigarettes reaffirmed its 2015 adjusted EPS guidance range of $3.65 to $3.80, up 6.7% to 11.1% from 2014. Analysts are expecting $3.77.

Reynolds American's $25 billion merger withLorillard (LO), announced last July, is still pending Federal Trade Commission action over antitrust concerns. But executives of both companies met with federal regulators earlier this month in an attempt to address those issues.

Reynolds American has an IBD Composite Rating of 86 out of 99, meaning its shares outperform 86% of all stocks in the market as measured by fundamental and technical factors. Some of those factors are earnings and sales growth, profit margins, return on equity and relative price performance.
Lorillard has a 59 Composite Rating. Its shares were up 0.6% at 70.59 early Friday afternoon and are trading near highs after clearing a 69.71 flat-base buy point on April 2.
On Thursday, rival Philip Morris International (PM) raised its full-year EPS guidance to the range of $4.32 to $4.42 from $4.27 to $4.37. Wall Street has projected $4.26.
The Marlboro cigarette brand maker reported first-quarter earnings that fell 2.5% to $1.16 a share but topped views by 15 cents. Sales dipped 4.4% to $6.61 billion but also surpassed estimates.
Philip Morris shares were off 0.2% to 84.76 early Friday afternoon. Shares jumped 8.7% on Thursday in reaction to the company's quarterly results, retaking their 50-day and 200-day moving averages.

Shares jumped 8.7% on Thursday in reaction to the company's quarterly results, retaking their 50-day and 200-day moving averages.Follow Alissa Williams on Twitter: @IBD_AWilliams.
Core inflation pops in April

The consumer price index rose 0.1% in April, as expected. But core prices, which exclude food and energy, climbed 0.3%, the biggest gain since Jan. 2013. Core inflation was 1.8%, the same as in March and below the Fed's 2% target.

 Mortgage delinquencies ticked up 1% in April, Black Knight said. But they were down 15% compared with a year ago. The number of loans in the foreclosure process dipped to 1.51% in April, the lowest since '08.

 The hotel industry saw record-high occupancy of 66.8% in April, STR said. Room demand, at 99.4 mil rooms, was also the highest on record. Revenue per available room rose 6.4% vs. a year ago in the month.
BoJ optimistic

Bank of Japan Gov. Haruhiko Kuroda told reporters that "a positive cycle is kicking in" to the economy and he sees no need for additional monetary easing now. GDP rose 2.4% in Q1, more than expected, but in part thanks to a boost in inventory that some analysts believe signals lower consumption.
Draghi urges fiscal changes

Easy monetary policy should not be seen as a reason for governments to postpone legislation, ECB Chief Mario Draghi said. While the economy seems firmer now than in "seven long years," he said, outsized debt burdens and stubborn joblessness still require a response.
 Fed chief Janet Yellen will speak later today, capping a long day of top central bankers. Investors and analysts will pay close attention to any hints about when the U.S. might start raising rates.

 The idea of a parallel Greek currency has been raised by German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble, Bloomberg News reported. He has been skeptical that Greece and its creditors can reach a deal. But Greek officials believe a deal is imminent after PM Alexis Tsipras met with other eurozone leaders.
 Canadian CPI ticked down 0.1% in April, when a 0.1% gain had been expected. For the year, it stood 0.8% higher. The Bank of Canada core measure was up 0.1% for the month and 2.3% for the year.
 German capital spending rose 1.5% in Q1, even as overall economic activity flagged, with GDP expanding only 0.3%. But the Bundesbank is optimistic that activity will rebound.
German business sector still chipper

Ifo's business climate survey was little changed in May, with the overall index of sentiment down 1 tick to 108.5. Current conditions rose 0.4 point to 114.3, while the expectations gauge gave up 0.5 point to settle at 103.0. Manufacturing sentiment was weaker, but construction strengthened.

And the headlines said it all.......Many Fed Officials Saw June Rate Rise as Unlikely, Minutes Show - Bloomberg
Fed Looks Past June for First Rate Hike - WSJ
Oh....boy... By now - you are well aware, or you have read, or have heard about what has been on the minds of Federal Reserve officials.....As reported by 'deep throat' (Jon Hilsenrath) -
"'Federal Reserve officials at their April policy meeting said in the MOST explicit terms yet that they are unlikely to start raising short term interest rates in June...."

Now what's funny is - THAT message seems very clear..... in April - Snow White and her 7 dwarfs were well aware that there would be no rate hike in June.....in fact 'in the most explicit terms yet - they were unlikely to raise rates....' but that was not the message being delivered to the marketplace in April at all.....the message was that the Fed is on track to begin the process of normalization.....which is not 'untrue' it was just cloudy - right? The fact is that the Fed was well aware that June was off the table but kept that conversation under wraps causing the markets to go into stall mode - unable to decipher what the future looked like and thus unable to find direction. That was until yesterday.......

We have been stuck in a +/- 3.5% range since late February....as traders and investors try to read the tea leaves about what lies ahead. The market was assuming no change, yet different Fed officials gave conflicting interviews leaving the market and investors confused over policy direction...... When they floated the idea that rates would begin to rise the market came under pressure - so then they changed the tone of the conversation to assure everybody that maybe rates would not rise.....and the churn was born........

The continued churn seen for much of the session yesterday came as we waited for the 2 pm release of the Fed minutes for April..... Now what was not a surprise to the markets is that rates aren't going anywhere - but what was a bit of a surprise is the fact that there seemed to be a very real consensus among the group in April - This fact caused futures to spike strongly - for about 30 minutes. Then reality sets in........traders and investors begin to consider the implications of continued weakness in the economy causing buyers to retreat and sellers to raise the temperature pushing prices back into negative territory.....Many are now wondering if in fact our friends at Goldman Sachs are right (this time)............Has the market topped out here? Is it 'overvalued' as they say? Look - no rate hikes should cause the algos to celebrate....unless of course no rate hikes means that there are darker days ahead still..... that all of the efforts to 'prop up the economy' have fallen on deaf ears...... The bottom line is that they left if deliberately unclear so that you could make the argument either way......so much for transparency......In the end, the market will re-price risk now that we have clarity......at least for now.....

Next up was the piece done by CNBC's Steve Liesman.......on how the San Francisco Federal Reserve wants their own day in the sun - trying to steal the thunder from the Atlanta Fed......You see the Atlanta Fed has the very prescient forecasting economic model - called GDPNow....and it has been eerily accurate on GDP forecasts......Well folks in San Fran say - 'not so quick buddy'.......They figured out that if you just 'double the seasonal adjustments upwards' then you can 'fix' that weak GDP problem.....
You see - they said:
"applying a second round of seasonal adjustment corrects the residual seasonality and after this correction then aggregate output grew much faster than reported'......

Residual Seasonality? Who makes this stuff up? I mean - if the data doesn't fit the story - then just create a new data point (residual seasonality), re-calculate and BOOM! All of a sudden we go from -0.2% to +1.8%.......Are you kidding???? It's almost laughable.....what world are these people living in......just walk outside and ask the 'man on the street' what he thinks about the current state of the economy.....Ask him if he can just 'double his take home pay'...because that would solve a bunch of problems as well........

So - what's on the calendar today? We have a full economic plate.....Chicago Fed, Initial jobless claims of 270k, Continued Claims of 2.23 million, Markit US Manufacturing PMI of 54.5, Philly Fed expectations of 8, Kansas City Fed at -4 and Existing Home Sales of 5.23 mil.

US futures are down 4 points in pre-market trading.......today's macro data will give traders something to focus on - now that the FOMC minutes are out of the way......Expect trading to really slow as we move into the second half of the day as so many are checking out for the Memorial Day long weekend. Unless the data are so strong - I do not expect to see the market move significantly in either direction. 2125-ish to remain resistance and 2100 as psychological support.

Overnight - China reported a weaker PMI number yet that market surged 1.87% - taking it right back to the highs of late April - right before they talked it down off the edge.....expectations of more central bank support has caused investors/traders to take this market right back to the highs......
European markets are slightly lower on the back of some weak macro reports suggesting that the Eurozone recovery is slowing...... Chris Williamson - Chief Economist at Markit had this to say:
"The Eurozone's recovery has lost some of its vigor...at the moment the extent of the slowing is not a major concern, but will no doubt be causing some nail-biting at the ECB..."
And the world turns..... Happy Memorial Day Weekend. I am out tomorrow - but back on Tuesday. Be well.
Take good care
Kp

Industrial production sags

Production was down 0.3% in April vs. expectations for a flat reading and marking the fifth straight monthly decline. Capacity utilization ticked down to 78.2%. March's read was revised up from 78.4% to 78.6%. Manufacturing was unchanged in April following a 0.3% gain in March and against forecasts of a 0.2% increase.
Consumer sentiment tanks

The Univ. of Michigan's initial May read slid hard. Its 88.6 reading was down more than 7 points from April vs. forecasts of a 0.1-point dip, the biggest fall since '12. Survey directors said the plunge signals "a reluctant acceptance ... that economic growth will remain ... lackluster." Economic growth has been lackluster in part because consumers are wary of spending.
New York manufacturing perks up

The New York Fed's Empire State survey rose to 3.1 in May from -1.19, though that slightly missed forecasts of 5.00. New orders rose to 3.9 and shipments were a strong 14. Employment levels improved slightly, but were offset by a small decline in the workweek.
Russian economy contracts
GDP contracted 1.9% in Q1 vs. a year ago vs. a 0.4% gain in Q4. That was less steep a decline than the 2.6% the Economy Ministry had forecast. The gov't expects a downturn that lasts 3 quarters.
Canada factory sales jump

Sales rose 2.9% in March, much stronger than the 1% gain expected. Shipments surged 2.9%, also better than expected. Both measures saw declines in Feb., and better data in March suggest the oil price shock is wearing off.

 India's trade deficit eased to $10.99 bil in April from $11.79 bil in March. Exports declined for the fifth straight month. The trade gap was a topic of discussion when PM Narendra Modi met the Chinese premier this week.
China changes course on local debt

China backtracked on an effort to rein in skyrocketing municipal debt, bowing to the need to continue juicing the economy over implementing financial changes. Local governments will now be able to borrow from government-sponsored finance vehicles.
 South Korea's central bank left interest rates unchanged at a record-low 1.75%, as expected. The bank cut its growth forecast for '15 to 3.1% from 3.4% earlier this year.
COMING UP MONDAY
 Housing Market Index for May, 10 a.m. ET.

 Housing starts for April, 8:30 a.m. ET.
